column2: LEAD: A picture on Jan. 14 showing a model of a condominium, hotel and shopping complex planned for First Avenue and 60th Street was provided in error by the developers' press office. It showed the original proposal for the project. As approved by the City Planning Commission, the building was changed significantly, and its height was reduced by 189 feet.

LEAD: A 13-hour documentary is public television's equivalent of a nuclear explosion. Although no program can live up to the blast of a title like ''War and Peace in the Nuclear Age,'' the series that begins tonight at 10 P.M. on Channels 13 and 21 and at 9 P.M. on Channel 49 makes a considerable impact.

LEAD: Versatility is often applauded in the arts, and many theatrical troupes are celebrated for their eclectic repertories. Yet a strange thing has happened in ballet. Versatility is now slightly suspect in some quarters.

LEAD: PREPARING for bargaining with the telephone companies this spring, the Communications Workers of America recently drew up a statement outlining six broad objectives. Among them, wage increases received one paragraph. Health care was given more than two pages.

LEAD: Crude oil prices plunged yesterday on both sides of the Atlantic. The heavy selling was even more pronounced in the gasoline and heating oil markets after crude oil dropped more than $1 a barrel.

LEAD: MUCH of the excitement in the personal computer industry revolves around the introduction of new or upgraded major software and hardware: a new word-processing or database program, a faster computer or modem, a bigger hard disk. LEAD: Gustavo Espinoza Montesinos, 47, has been a member of the Central Committee of the Peruvian Communist Party since 1966. A former teacher, he is part of the United Left bloc in Peru's congress, the second-largest bloc after that of the Government party. He has not been arrested since 1979, but has often been beaten in protests.

LEAD: Reality advertising lives. In recent months American advertisers have been turning away from grainy black-and-white film and shaky hand-held cameras popularized in 1986-87 by the director Leslie Dektor, but the Martin Agency in Richmond continues to use both in its new campaign for the Signet Banking Corporation, which will be broadcast in Maryland, Virginia and Washington.
LEAD: SINCE women were first admitted to the bar in New York State 102 years ago, discrimination against them has weakened. But for many women lawyers it remains.

LEAD: The regulatory system that has been widely blamed for allowing the savings and loan industry to collapse is today in much sounder shape, according to analysts, industry executives and regulatory officials.
LEAD: The East German leader, Erich Honecker, announced today that his country would reduce its armed forces by 10,000 and also cut military spending by 10 percent.
LEAD: On the XXIIId try, the National Football League finally got a game that lived up to the title Super Bowl. Perhaps after 23 more the league will figure out what to do about its halftime problem.

LEAD: ''My Past Is My Own,'' being presented as a ''Schoolbreak Special'' on CBS at 4 P.M. today, is one powerful scene surrounded by not very convincing contrivances.

LEAD: When Stanislavsky first read Chekhov's ''Three Sisters,'' written especially for the Moscow Art Theater, he was disappointed. There were no real characters, the director complained, only hints of them. Yet nearly a century later the characters who inhabit Chekhov's drawing rooms and gardens in provinical Russia speak more clearly to the eternal yearnings and frustrations of the human condition than those in a hundred contemporary plays.

LEAD: The bel canto revival - the restoration of operas by Rossini, Donizetti, Bellini and the young Verdi - has been one of the three or four most influential postwar operatic movements. The Lyric Opera's current production of Rossini's ''Tancredi'' is arguably a state-of-the-art specimen - critical edition, uncut score, first-choice cast -and so Saturday evening's performance prompted as many thoughts about the bel canto scene in general as about the particular merits of ''Tancredi.

LEAD: Lord Basnett, a former union leader often blamed by his fellow members of the Labor Party for helping to put Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher in power, died today. He was 64 years old.
LEAD: A substantial number of working mothers are finding that they must juggle another responsibility: providing unpaid personal care in the homes of elderly relatives and friends.

LEAD: HDM, a joint venture of Young & Rubicam, Dentsu and Eurocom, has acquired Stone & Adler, a direct-response firm, for an undisclosed amount from Young & Rubicam. A new entity called HDM Direct Marketing Group will be looking after Stone & Adler and HDM Worldwide Direct, which will have combined billings of $50 million, The client list of HDM Worldwide Direct, which was formed 18 months ago, includes Nintendo, Suzuki and Hertz.

LEAD: An article yesterday about the reaction in Richmond to the Supreme Court decision striking down that city's program to aid minority contractors misstated the race of the Mayor, Geline B. Williams, in some editions. She is white. In some copies a picture caption with the article misidentified Henry L.

LEAD: Mayor Edward I. Koch's plan for a new police academy and a major middle-income housing complex in the South Bronx would be a boon for that beleaguered neighborhood and its Hispanic political constituency, whose support the Mayor wants to retain.

LEAD: What would Henry James have had to write about this winter? What would John Singer Sargent have had to paint? The artists who captured this city's temperament using scenes of the snow-touched Boston Common might have been frustrated this January, the first in recent memory with no real snowfall.

LEAD: The president of a Connecticut surgical-supplies manufacturer, who was the target of a bombing attempt by an animal-rights advocate last November, said yesterday that his company has used paid informers to infiltrate animal-rights organizations since the early 1980's.

LEAD: Seymour Lipkin played his way into the forefront of America's young pianists more than 40 years ago when he won the Rachmaninoff Competition, but he subsequently dropped out of the keyboard spotlight to pursue a conducting career and teach. That he has not lost his interest in the piano or his command of the instrument was clear on Tuesday evening at the Juilliard Theater, where he performed in the school's Faculty Recital Series.

LEAD: President Bush today expressed strong support for Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, his nominee for Secretary of Health and Human Services. Then he dispatched Dr. Sullivan to Capitol Hill to soothe the fears of conservative Republican Senators who have voiced concern over Dr. Sullivan's position on abortion.

LEAD: JUDGING by two current movies the power accessory women prefer is multiportraits in the style of Andy Warhol. In ''Beaches,'' Bette Midler's hang in a Mae West-style apartment; Sigourney Weaver's, in ''Working Girl,'' hang amid rare woods and flouncy chintz a la Mario Buatta. Forget gilded mirrors.

LEAD: The Zeromoving Dance Company has come a long way. Although, to speak literally, it has come from Philadelphia - which may not seem far at all - the company has covered great distance artistically. Sporadic previous visits to New York have always given dancegoers much to think about. But, on Tuesday night when Zeromoving opened a week's engagement at the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, the troupe revealed that it has gained an authoritative stage presence, making

LEAD: Bob Probert, the Detroit Red Wings' forward, was suspended for the second time this season when he arrived 25 minutes late for the team's game last night against the Buffalo Sabres. ''He showed up at 6:10 P.M. and he was supposed to be here at 5:45 P.M.,'' said Bill Jamieson, director of public relations for the Red Wings.

LEAD: Bernard Rochand, 50 years old, previously chief executive at Eurocom, has been chosen president of DDB Needham International, a Paris-based operation of the DDB Needham Worldwide network. He will replace John Bradstock, 55, who will become corporate executive vice president in charge of global accounts.

LEAD: Following are excerpts from an interview with President Bush by Gerald M. Boyd of The New York Times and Katherine Lewis of The Houston Post, as transcribed by the White House. Marlin Fitzwater, the White House press secretary, was present.

LEAD: Lawyers for Oliver L. North have subpoenaed two Democratic members of the House of Representatives, Dave McCurdy of Oklahoma and Lee H. Hamilton of Indiana, to testify in Mr. North's defense in his criminal trial, officials in the House said today.

LEAD: The Student Loan Marketing Association, also known as Sallie Mae, is offering $250 million worth of fixed-rate notes due in 1994 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

LEAD: ACOUSTICAL tiles, which are made of porous wood or mineral fibers, are commonly used to cover new and replacement ceilings. Although they are excellent for absorbing sound, they are also soft, easily broken and often hard to clean. Damaged or stained tiles generally must be replaced.

LEAD: A leading official economic adviser said tonight that the real Soviet budget deficit is the equivalent of $165 billion, nearly three times the official estimate, and called the colossal deficit the most important economic problem facing the country.

LEAD: The Palestine Liberation Organization has resumed its divisive debate over the declaration of a provisional government in the Israeli-occupied territories, according to senior P.L.O. officials here.

LEAD: The Favorite Stocks chart in some copies of Business Day yesterday, with the article about the stock market, carried outdated prices. Rather than Monday's closing prices, it should have used Tuesday's, which appeared in the stock market tables.
LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission accused two brokers for Moore & Schley, Cameron & Company yesterday of trying to corner the stock of Chase Medical Group Inc.

LEAD: Hitachi Ltd. filed a Federal lawsuit accusing Motorola Inc. of patent infringment on a microprocessor. The lawsuit follows a similar suit filed last week by Motorola against Hitachi. The dispute centers on Motorola's 68HC11 and Hitachi's H-8 microprocessors, digital electronic devices that perform the control and arithmetic functions of televisions, watches, videorecorders and other products.

LEAD: In January, Christmas trees are a sad sight, naked and brittle, piled up on curbs, waiting to be hauled away. But for the Green Guerillas, a nonprofit horticultural group, these holiday leftovers can help spruce up New York's asphalt jungle.
LEAD: * A series of radio spots featuring the entertainer Steve Allen urging people to be tested regularly for colon cancer has been developed for the Advertising Council by Calet, Hirsch & Spector.

LEAD: George J. Mitchell, the Senate majority leader, today set bipartisanship in foreign policy and the establishment of a ''new social contract'' between the Government and its citizens as the major objectives of Senate Democrats in the 101st Congress.

LEAD: Kirby Puckett avoided salary arbitration by signing a one-year deal with the Minnesota Twins yesterday. Puckett, the All-Star center fielder, had asked for $2.15 million, while the Twins had offered $1.9 million. General Manager Andy MacPhail and Puckett's agent, Ron Shapiro, said the two sides met in the middle.

LEAD: Sam Wyche said yesterday that he has agreed to remain as coach of the Cincinnati Bengals under terms of a new five-year contract. Wyche's team had one of the most dramatic turnarounds in N.F.L. history this past season. After going 4-11 in 1987, the Bengals won the 1988 American Conference championship before losing to the San Francisco 49ers in the Super Bowl.
LEAD: Yves Saint Laurent says that his message for spring is ''easy dressing'' and that it is best expressed in his suits.
LEAD: Sales of existing single-family homes shot up 11.4 percent in December, as sales for all of 1988 reached the highest level in nine years, a real estate trade group reported today.

LEAD: An article in Business Day yesterday about telephone companies' earnings, and a listing in the Company Earnings table, misstated the earnings per share for the BellSouth Corporation. The company earned $3.51 a share in 1988 and $3.45 a share in 1987.

LEAD: A child starts learning about sexuality from the first day of life, and parents are the primary source of this education. Each touch, caress, hug, smile and coo tells the infant that he or she is lovable and attractive, knowledge that is the precursor to a healthy ego and normal sexual functioning.
LEAD: The Past Unearthed, South Street Seaport Museum Gallery, 213 Water Street, off Beekman Street; 212-669-9430.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: VISTA magazine, an English-language Sunday newspaper supplement whose material is intended for Hispanic audiences, is expected to turn its first profit this year, a success it owes to the increasing use of English marketing by advertisers trying to reach Hispanic consumers.

LEAD: Wearing some contact lenses that change the color of the iris may cause some haziness of peripheral vision, researchers at the Louisiana State University Eye Center in New Orleans have concluded.
LEAD: Rival Shiite Muslim militias announced a cease-fire today in their monthlong gun battles here and in southern Lebanon but failed to resolve political differences that provoked the violence.

LEAD: In a speech that seemed to herald his campaign for another term, Mayor Edward I. Koch unveiled ambitious responses yesterday to drug addiction, homelessness and other urban ills, although he left doubt about how and when some of them would be put into effect.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The American Express Company said yesterday that it earned $231 million, or 54 cents a share, in the fourth quarter, in contrast to a loss of $104 million, or 24 cents a share, in the corresponding period in 1987.

LEAD: John G. Tower, President Bush's choice to be Secretary of Defense, sought today to dispel concern about his consulting work for military contractors and past support for huge military budget increases.

LEAD: In an emotionally charged hearing in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, a 16-year-old boy pleaded guilty yesterday to the burning and desecration of a synagogue in which five Torah scrolls were destroyed. The judge said he would sentence the youth to weekends in jail, community service and probation.
LEAD: * Susan M. Machtiger has been named senior vice president at Young & Rubicam New York.

LEAD: President Jose Napoleon Duarte tonight dismissed a proposal by the Salvadoran guerrillas laying out conditions for their participation in presidential elections, saying it amounted to a ''proposal of war.''
LEAD: Special Relationships A Foreign Correspondent's Memoirs From Roosevelt to Reagan By Henry Brandon Illustrated. 436 pages. Atheneum. $24.95.
LEAD: The Dana Corporation, a giant auto parts company, agreed to buy the 82-year-old Champion Spark Plug Company for about $600 million in cash and stock, the companies said today.

LEAD: A superannuated Ivy Leaguer complains that New York City developers keep slamming doors on his past. First it was the lobby under the clock at the old Biltmore Hotel, once a watering hole for generations of students returning to school in the Northeast. Now Donald Trump is closing Trader Vic's, which for 25 years has occupied the basement of his latest acquisition, the
LEAD: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange said today that it had appointed a special panel to recommend some of the most extensive changes in its 115 years of trading.

LEAD: Clarence Norris, the last survivor of the ''Scottsboro Boys'' rape case, which became a symbol of racial injustice in the Deep South in the 1930's, died Monday at Bronx Community Hospital after a long illness. He was 76 years old.

LEAD: Warren H. Reed, a specialist in management training and a retired vice president of Paine Webber, died of AIDS on Sunday at University Hospital in Stony Brook, L.I. He was 62 years old and lived in Cherry Grove, L.I.

LEAD: Madonna, the rock star, has signed a one-year contract with the Pepsi-Cola Company, joining Michael Jackson, Tina Turner, David Bowie, Lionel Richie and the Miami Sound Machine as spokesmen for the soft drink.

LEAD: When Saifuo Khodzhaya was found on Monday, after an earthquake shook this tiny village and a landslide buried it in mud and clay, he was dead, crushed when the roof of his house fell. His arms were stretched through a window, and in them lay his 6-day-old daughter, alive and crying.

LEAD: A democratic nation, like a person with free will, has some control over its destiny. If it denies wrongdoing and flees from moral responsibility, that nation surrenders to Fate's retribution; but if its people are moved to root out corruption, that nation can overcome its past and shape its future.

LEAD: In a major change over the past 10 years, emergency rooms in many American hospitals have begun to rely on a corps of doctors trained in an entirely new medical speciality: emergency room medicine.

LEAD: After examining climate data extending back nearly 100 years, a team of Government scientists has concluded that there has been no significant change in average temperatures or rainfall in the United States over that entire period.

LEAD: The General Accounting Office will soon release a study showing that some of the nation's largest accounting firms failed to detect and report problems at ailing Texas savings and loan associations just before they failed, Government officials said tonight.
LEAD: Gilbert L. Voss, professor emeritus of biological oceanography at the University of Miami, died of liver cancer Monday at his home in Miami. He was 70 years old.

LEAD: As a young pitcher, Carl Erskine was called little Carl by his Brooklyn Dodger teammates because Carl Furillo was already established in right field. Now little Carl, white-haired and wearing a black tie, stood up by the sprays of flowers near the open casket to give the eulogy at Carl Furillo's funeral service.

LEAD: The Philip Morris Companies said yesterday that its net income in the fourth quarter fell 28.5 percent, to $342 million, or $1.48 a share, from $478 million in 1987, or $2.02 a share, as a result of a $348 million pretax charge to cover a restructuring of its General Foods subsidiary.

LEAD: Procedures intended to protect the 15,000 workers who deal with radioactive material at the Savannah River nuclear weapons plant in South Carolina are deficient in dozens of areas, the Energy Department said today. The department said weak management and complacent attitudes at Savannah River, which is operated for the agency by E.

LEAD: Early in the second half tonight, P. J. Carlesimo shed his suit jacket and knelt in front of Seton Hall's bench with a worried look on his face. The Pirates' coach sensed his team was in trouble.

LEAD: Since 1976, the Eastern chapter of the Paralyzed Veterans Association, an advocacy and support group for veterans with spinal cord injuries or diseases, has prepared blueprints for improved wheelchair accessibility in the homes of paralyzed veterans. The organization has just made available a booklet of the blueprints titled 'Wheelchair House Designs.

LEAD: RANDOLPH McAUSLAND, the president of Design Publications Inc., which publishes Industrial Design magazine in New York, has been named director of the design arts program of the National Endowment for the Arts. He succeeds Adele Chatfield-Taylor, who recently became president of the American Academy in

LEAD: AS the days lengthen and thinking about spring becomes less and less a silly notion, I would like to put in a word for the high virtue of inconvenience in a gardener's life. Or maybe say a few grouchy things about convenience.
LEAD: Simon & Schuster announced yesterday that it would publish Ronald Reagan's memoirs and a collection of speeches selected by the former President.

LEAD: Derrick Coleman, a junior basketball player who was named to several preseason all-America teams, was one of five students at Syracuse University who have been sanctioned by a university judicial board in connection with a fight and series of apartment break-ins last month. Coleman, who still faces charges of fourth-degree criminal mischief (a misdemeanor) and harassment (a violation) stemming from the incident on Dec.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: In Washington some titles have a way of sticking, as Charles S. Robb, the former Democratic Governor of Virginia and newly elected Senator, has discovered. ''When I telephone my office, they answer: 'Senator Robb's office,' but the moment they realize who is calling, they say, 'Oh, Hi Governor, what can we do for you?

LEAD: Can performances by the Miles Davis Quintet, the Art Ensemble of Chicago or Bon Jovi be considered chamber music? That was one of the questions raised this week during a panel discussion called ''Chamber Music in the 20th Century,'' part of Chamber Music America's 11th national conference. And it was a notion that did not seem to raise any hackles among the conference's participants, representatives of a field normally regarded as conservative.

LEAD: An MX missile came loose from its support and fell as much as a foot inside its underground silo last year, causing the Air Force to remove that missile's 10-warhead payload and those of four other MX's found to be defective, according to an article published today.

LEAD: A surge of leftist guerrilla activity is bringing new difficulties to a United States-backed campaign to eradicate coca production and break up drug trafficking gangs in Peru's main coca-growing region.

LEAD: SINCE the summer of 1976, when I was convalescing from an illness, my younger daughter and I have watched a soap opera. I had never seen one before that July: turning on ''Days of Our Lives'' was a way to break an otherwise shapeless day into segments. The other ways were a) to talk on the phone in the morning, b) nap from 2 to 3, c) wobble outside to view the filming of ''Kojak'' episodes on my street.

LEAD: SCENIC postcards have been an evocative record of the changing American landscape. The Curt Teich Postcard Collection at the Lake County Museum in Wauconda, Ill., is one of the best. LEAD: As dawn filtered into the forest around this jungle village, policemen once again fanned out along rutted roads and trails, trying to solve a murder that has mesmerized Brazil.
LEAD: * Campeau Corp., Toronto, a Canadian retailer, said its 1988 sales were better than the flat results projected last April.

LEAD: The ballerina Natalia Makarova, who is making her first visit to the Soviet Union since her defection in 1970, is to perform with her old company, the Kirov Ballet, in Leningrad on Wednesday. The ballerina's first performance with the company since she defected was last Aug. 6 in London. In Leningrad, Miss Makarova is to dance two pas de deux from John Cranko's ''Onegin'' at the Kirov Theater and is expected to dance them again next

LEAD: Sam Halper, a journalist who was with Time magazine for many years, died of Alzheimer's disease Tuesday at the Wilton Meadows Health Care Facility in Wilton, Conn. He was 72 years old and lived in Wilton.

LEAD: On the synthesizer keyboard, Denny McLain played the Motown tune ''Stop! In the Name of Love,'' which was made popular by the Supremes more than two decades ago, when McLain was one of baseball's best pitchers.

LEAD: El Salvador's Marxist guerrillas welcomed Ronald Reagan's Administration with an unsuccessful but bloody ''final offensive.'' LEAD: Q.Our dry walls were originally covered with a rough-texture paint. Over the years there has been scraping, patching and repainting so that some of the roughness has been smoothed out in places, but the walls still do not have the uniformly flat look we prefer. Can you suggest how to achieve that look, short of replacing the walls?

LEAD: Joseph B. Ridder, the retired publisher and president of The San Jose Mercury News, died of complications from emphysema Monday at Queens Hospital in Honolulu, where he lived. He was 68 years old and also had a home in Saratoga, Calif.

LEAD: Yields for certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds rose for the week that ended yesterday, but the increases were smaller than those of the previous week.

LEAD: A retired Chilean diplomat has asserted that high-level Chilean officials, in conversations in 1978, acknowledged the responsibility of the head of the intelligence police for two killings in Washington in 1976.

LEAD: A clip of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North testifying at the 1987 Iran-contra hearings sets the cautionary theme of ''Secret Intelligence,'' a four-hour history of the development of American espionage that begins tonight at 9 on Channel 13 and continues in three weekly chapters. At issue is the secrecy treasured by spies versus the openness required by democracy.

LEAD: Texaco Inc. said yesterday that it had posted a fourth-quarter profit of $296 million, or $1.21 a share, in contrast to a year ago, when the company lost more than $4.6 billion because of the settlement of its lawsuit with the Pennzoil Company and write-offs from a restructuring.
LEAD: Legislation to set a uniform nationwide time for closing the polls in Presidential elections was introduced today by Senator Brock Adams, a Washington Democrat.

LEAD: In a country abounding with complaints about shoddy manufactured goods, corrupt public services and adulterated food and drink, a small band of public and private citizens is taking on the monumental task of making consumer protection a national issue.
LEAD: Markets

LEAD: One day after the Ransburg Corporation signed an agreement to be acquired by Illinois Tool Works Inc. for $20 a share, or about $163 million, the LFC Financial Corporation said it would consider submitting a higher bid for Ransburg. Frank P. Slattery Jr., president of LFC, described the bidding process for the Indianapolis-based Ransburg as a ''skewed auction'' in a letter to the Ransburg board today.

LEAD: IN the age of the digital watch, the public timepiece has become a lost communal art. The famous Biltmore Hotel clock in New York is now tucked away in the atrium of a bank building, only five of New York City's historic clocks have landmark status and few new public spaces post the time.
LEAD: Stock prices rose moderately yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average once again reached a post-crash high.

LEAD: Students at the Wharton School, the University of Pennsylvania's graduate school of business, have assembled the alumni magazines of seven top business schools into a unified advertising network called the Management Network.

LEAD: There was a meeting on the Clean Air Act of the House-Senate Environmental and Energy Study Conference yesterday morning in an unventilated room of the Capitol building called E.F. 100. According to a participant, the room was packed and the air became increasingly fetid. Two people fainted.

LEAD: A YEAR ago Pam Faulds, whose mother had died of breast cancer when Ms. Faulds was 6 years old, told her own three children that she had developed the disease. Since that time, her children have tried to make sense of their mother's cancer and to manage the stress of living with a seriously ill parent.

LEAD: Nathan L. Jacobs, a retired associate justice of the New Jersey Supreme Court and an influential figure in court reform in the state, died yesterday at his home in Livingston, N.J. He was 83 years old.
LEAD: Magic Johnson calls it ''winning time.''

LEAD: A smoky three-alarm fire that began in a storage area behind a restaurant forced the evacuation of one wing of the International Arrivals Building at Kennedy International Airport last night, officials said. Eighteen firefighters and seven Port Authority police officers were treated for smoke inhalation.
LEAD: The dollar fell yesterday after the Federal Reserve once again entered the market to sell dollars, traders said.
LEAD: The Rev. Barbara C. Harris sought yesterday to soften her image as a political and theological radical as she prepared to become the first female bishop of the Episcopal Church.

LEAD: Settling a longstanding debate with the Independent Steelworkers Union, the management of the Weirton Steel Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell 15 percent of its shares to the public as part of a $600 million modernization plan.

LEAD: King Glorious, the undefeated California colt who had been rated the early second choice for the Kentucky Derby May 6, is no longer being pointed for the race because of a minor knee injury, his trainer said today.

LEAD: Two Texas investors said they would seek clearance from Federal antitrust regulators to increase their stake in the Foremost Corporation of America to 24.9 percent from 14.9 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, David Bonderman and W. Robert Cotham, associates of the Bass family of Fort Worth, said they would file their request with the Federal Trade

LEAD: The first exhibit - as Susan Sontag might begin if she were writing an essay about herself - is a thin volume entitled ''AIDS and Its Metaphors,'' which adds itself to a growing collection of volumes sharing a widely recognized characteristic. They all strive to be on the cusp of cultural discovery.
LEAD: Kevin Madden and J. R. Reid sparked North Carolina in the opening nine minutes as the seventh-ranked Tar Heels rolled past Wake Forest, 88-74, tonight in an Atlantic Coast Conference game.

LEAD: A veteran Cuban diplomat secretly defected to the United States three months ago after becoming disillusioned with widespread official corruption and with Cuban support for Marxist rebels in at least three Latin American countries.

LEAD: Avoiding an increasingly volatile question once again, a divided State Public Service Commission voted today to postpone action on a $98 million rate increase request by the Long Island Lighting Company.

LEAD: The San Francisco Giants and the Baltimore Orioles traded starting catchers on Tuesday with the Giants acquiring 32-year-old Terry Kennedy, a left-handed batter with a $850,000 salary in exchange for Bob Melvin, 27, a right-handed batter whose salary last season was $145,000. Yesterday, the Orioles signed Melvin for one year at a salary of about $215,000.

LEAD: Marking the end of six flush years for New Jersey government, Gov. Thomas H. Kean today released a proposed $12.09 billion budget for the next fiscal year that he described as ''tight,'' ''frugal'' and ''bordering on the austere.''

LEAD: YOU'VE tried everything: squeezing it into the elevator, coaxing it up the back stairs. You've even considered hoisting it through a window. But no matter what you try, you can't get your new sofa into your apartment. It's a city dweller's nightmare. Luckily, there are skilled people who can cut and reassemble furniture in your apartment.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Two women were killed and two male companions sailed to safety today when their 38-foot sailboat exploded off Adams Key in Biscayne National Park, the authorities said.
LEAD: Expressing his ''thanks to your great city for the many pleasures it's provided me this year,'' Jonathan Ballard of New Haven sent $2,500 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

LEAD: The Morgan Stanley Group said Tuesday that Robert F. Greenhill had been named to the newly created position of vice chairman. Mr. Greenhill, who joined Morgan in 1962, will remain director of the firm's investment banking division. The announcement was made by S. Parker Gilbert, chairman, and Richard B.

LEAD: Schools Chancellor Richard R. Green proposed a $6.4 billion budget yesterday for New York City's schools, the first move in what is expected to be months of negotiations with the state and city governments.

LEAD: N.H.L. Whalers 3, Blues 3: Paul MacDermid of Hartford scored with 11 minutes 9 seconds left as the Whalers battled the St. Louis Blues to a tie in Hartford last night. MacDermid broke in free from the blue line off a pass from Dean Evason and converted a backhander to give the Whalers the tying goal with his 10th of the season.

LEAD: Genentech Inc. today reported a net loss of $15.4 million for the fourth quarter of 1988, after a special charge relating to an excess inventory of its leading drug, tissue plasminogen activator.

LEAD: American Standard Inc., known for its plumbing fixtures and which has gone private through a leveraged buyout, said yesterday that William B. Boyd was retiring as chairman, president and chief executive.
LEAD: President Bush said today that the all-out war on drugs he promised in his Inaugural Address would be mainly an educational effort rather than a law-enforcement crackdown.
LEAD: The president and chief operating officer of the SmithKline Beckman Corporation abruptly resigned yesterday because of policy differences with the company's chief executive, both men said.

LEAD: An airline pilot misunderstood an air traffic controller who told him ''you've lost the engine,'' not realizing it had actually fallen off the plane until he landed safely, a transcript of cockpit conversations shows.

LEAD: THE Brooklyn Museum is known for its period rooms from the 17th to the 20th centuries. But tucked away in storage is a pair of rooms from recent post-modern history: the library, right, and child's bedroom Michael Graves designed for Susan and John Reinhold's apartment on Central Park West.

LEAD: When you're looking for a job in the Bush Administration or if you're a Republican thinking of running for mayor or governor, it couldn't hurt to have contributed $100,000 or more to the Bush campaign for President.

LEAD: Steffi Graf, the defending champion, turned on her awesome power after a shaky start today and overwhelmed Gabriela Sabatini, 6-3, 6-0, in the Australian Open to reach her eighth straight Grand Slam final.
LEAD: Michael Lland, a dancer and ballet master at the American Ballet Theater, died last Friday at Tuomey Hospital in Sumter, S.C. He was 64 years old.
LEAD: The manager of a Manhattan fishing-tackle store is looking forward to a winner of a season, with the new President providing free publicity and public opinion already on his side.

LEAD: Ron Guidry, spurned by the Yankees when they refused to offer him a contract for the coming season, is close to reaching a deal with one of three teams, according to his agent, Reggie Ringuet. The Los Angeles Dodgers, the Toronto Blue Jays and the Minnesota Twins all have contacted Ringuet about a one-year contract for the 38-year-old Guidry.
LEAD: A man wanted in the shooting last week of two New York City police officers was found dead early yesterday in a stolen car after shooting himself, the police said.

LEAD: Mayor Edward Koch of New York proved again yesterday that no matter how beleaguered he may be, he has not lost his political touch. His State of the City address was a masterful election year performance and an example of politics at its best. Mr. Koch responded to the growing number of New Yorkers worried about quality of life in their city, while keeping the opposition off balance; in the process he offered rational, humanitarian priorities and programs that merit support.

LEAD: Dr. Carlos Alfredo Yorio, a professor of linguistics at Lehman College and at the City University Graduate Center, died Monday at New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 48 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

LEAD: The Unisys Corporation, the nation's third-largest computer maker, said yesterday that its earnings for the fourth quarter were essentially flat in the face of a year the company called unexpectedly difficult.
LEAD: Gary E. Nei's job is to restore a once high-flying pharmaceutical company that has been battered by a traumatic year in which everything that could go wrong seems to have done so.

LEAD: * Contel Corp., Atlanta, a telephone holding company, named Alan B. Salisbury president of the Contel Technology Center. It is part of Contel Federal Systems, Fairfax, Va., a provider of telecommunications and information to government agencies.

LEAD: New details about Moscow's plan to withdraw some military forces from Eastern Europe suggest that the withdrawal will substantially blunt Moscow's ability to mount an attack on short notice against Western Europe, according to American experts inside and outside the Government.

LEAD: The nation's largest savings and loan trade association proposed a plan on Tuesday that would call on taxpayers to rescue hundreds of insolvent savings institutions. The plan would reduce the long-term cost of the rescue to the healthy segment of the industry.
LEAD: Once in a while something comes along that makes one feel lucky to be alive at the end of the 20th century.

LEAD: Transition is the key word these days in Washington - and, according to many observers, in international affairs as well. There is a widespread sense that 1988 was a watershed year in international affairs - a year that marked the beginning of a ''new era,'' requiring a radically new approach to relationships with our allies as well as our adversaries.

LEAD: The recent wave of leveraged buyouts and other forms of corporate restructuring has probably crested, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, said today. He urged Congress to shun legislation to restrict such transactions.

LEAD: New Jersey may be America's most densely populated state, but it has an abundance of tranquil small towns and countryside with a more than ample stock of country inns. The historic seaside resort of Cape May is a trove of Victorian inns, the scenic Delaware River region in the northwestern region has many intimate and charming accommodations and small inns can be found throughout the state.

LEAD: Christoph von Dohnanyi is to lead the Cleveland Orchestra in Mozart's Symphony No. 39 (K. 543) and the Busoni Piano Concerto (Op. 39) at 8 tonight at Carnegie Hall. The orchestra is to play another program at 8 P.M. tomorrow at Carnegie Hall, with the soprano Kathleen Battle as the soloist in Villa-Lobos's '' Bachiana Brasileira'' No.

LEAD: The Department of Energy is considering reducing its safety requirements so it can speed the reopening of the troubled reactors at its Savannah River Plant, the chairman of a safety advisory panel said today.

LEAD: An article on Wednesday about the proposed Congressional pay raise misstated the position of Common Cause on the proposal. The group favors the proposal and accompanying legislation to ban honorariums and related payments by private groups.

LEAD: Just a few hours from the nerve-jangling heart of New York City, there exists an almost unrecognizably idyllic world where secluded country inns offer an escape into another, more peaceful time and place.

LEAD: Elizabeth Knowlton, a mountain climber who in 1932 became the first woman to climb as high as 20,000 feet in the Himalayas, died of heart disease Sunday at the Ocean Manor Nursing Home in Scituate, Mass., where she lived for the last four years. She was 93 years old and a longtime resident of Cambridge,

LEAD: Michael Dokes, former World Boxing Association heavyweight champion, had to fight back tears yesterday as he looked back on a career that was nearly destroyed by a cocaine habit. LEAD: There wasn't much the Rangers could do all night, and so there wasn't much they could find to say about the game after it was over. Quiet resignation to the obvious had characterized their play against the Flames, and thus it dominated their muted conversation afterward.

But when Clarence Rollocks Jr. is asked what he thinks of his new apartment, he lights up in a smile and his answer is brief. ''Heaven,'' he says.

LEAD: New orders for durable goods rose by 6.4 percent in December, a much stronger gain than had been expected. Analysts said yesterday that the report was a sign that the economy was entering 1989 with plenty of momentum for continued growth.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A temporary shift in the payment of Social Security benefits held last month's budget deficit to less than half the level of a year earlier, but economists still expect the shortfall for the 1989 fiscal year to exceed last year's level.

LEAD: Ever since the first gusts of Operation Ill Wind, the Department of Justice's investigation into possible fraud in the Pentagon's procurement of arms and equipment, the Army's officers and civilian officials have been watching warily.
LEAD: THE agency that added meat to The New York Post's sizzling image has been banished from the kitchen.

LEAD: CBS won two of broadcast journalism's highest awards yesterday when ''60 Minutes'' received the Alfred I. du Pont-Columbia University Gold Baton and the ''CBS Evening News'' received a Silver Baton for its coverage of the Persian Gulf in the final weeks of the Iran-Iraq War.

LEAD: There was a bit of esthetic tension onstage at the Blue Note on Monday night. The saxophonist Kenny Garrett and the pianist Geri Allen, who have known each other since they were children in Detroit, play with different musical voices. Mr. Garrett is an old-fashioned blistering soloist whose playing is infused with soul and blues ideas that often reach exultant climaxes, fervent as a gospel performance.

LEAD: Farley Inc. said it was extending for the ninth time its $1.4 billion hostile takeover bid for West Point-Pepperell Inc. The new deadline is next Wednesday, a week later than the previous deadline. About 15.7 million shares of West Point-Pepperell common stock had been tendered by shareholders, which gives Farley about 62 percent of Pepperell common stock.

LEAD: In Czechoslovakia, rock music can be played for high stakes: cracked heads, jail sentences, exile. All have been a part of life for the Plastic People of the Universe, which got started in 1968 as a progressive-rock band and became, in the 1970's, the target of Government prosecution and a rallying point for Czechoslovak artists, intellectuals and human-rights activists.

LEAD: If a drug addict says, 'Yes, I'll take residential treatment,'' counselors want to grab him and throw him in a program, pronto. ''The addict will say yes today - he'll say no tomorrow,'' said Kevin Frawley, who knows.
LEAD: Bud Carson, the Jets' defensive coordinator, met again last night with Art Modell, the Cleveland Browns' owner, who wants to name his new head coach today.

LEAD: A team of Government scientists report no sign of a warming trend in the average temperatures in the United States over the last century. Does that mean the greenhouse effect, the feared heating of the earth's atmosphere by burning coal and oil, is just another false alarm? The answer, unfortunately, is an emphatic no.

LEAD: The Johann Strauss family and its immediate predecessors wrote music the Viennese public vastly preferred to Beethoven, Schubert, Brahms, Bruckner and Mahler. We should not forget that a repertory so delicious to us was, in its way, painful to them.

LEAD: The agent for Stanley Wilson of the Cincinnati Bengals, the running back suspended before the Super Bowl last Sunday because of drug use, said yesterday that the Bengals might have contributed to Wilson's relapse into cocaine use by not closely monitoring his nonfootball activities in Miami. LEAD: GOLF Germain Leads: Dot Germain, who last won a tournament in 1980, birdied the last two holes yesterday to finish with a 4-under-par 68 and a one-shot lead after the opening round of the LPGA Oldsmobile Classic in Boca Raton, Fla. Germain sank a 15-foot putt on her 17th hole to pull even with Jody Rosenthal, Dottie Mochrie and Beth Daniel and made a 10-footer on the final hole to take the lead.(AP)

LEAD: The collapse of last year's agreement on the Museum of the American Indian means that instead of a New York museum with a Washington satellite, it will become a Washington museum with a New York satellite. That's a blow to New York pride. But the collection finally will have a decent home and the proposed satellite will give New Yorkers access to twice as much of the museum's huge collection as they have now.

LEAD: The police today arrested a teen-age suspect in the shooting of four students outside a high school here Thursday. The suspect, Rodney Reardon, 18 years old, of Washington, was charged with assault with attempt to murder. It was initially believed that the shooting, in which the victims were only slightly wounded, had been the work of one young gunman, accompanied by another youth.

LEAD: Although John G. Tower sailed through the start of his confirmation hearing this week, several Senators expressed concern that his work as a military consultant could appear to be a conflict of interest, and the Secretary of Defense-designate is likely to face more questions on that score next week.

LEAD: N.B.A. Bulls 117, Bullets 106: Michael Jordan, held to 5 points in the first quarter, scored 16 of his 33 points during a six-minute second-period burst last night, leading Chicago over Washington in Chicago. The victory, which ended the Bullets' three-game winning streak, was the eighth in 10 games for the Bulls.(AP)

LEAD: Americans agree on two goals in Cambodia: First, Vietnam should end its occupation and let Cambodians choose their own government. LEAD: The WCI Holdings Corporation, formerly the Wickes Companies, has sold four apparel businesses to Taren Holdings, a corporation formed by Odyssey Partners and James I. Spiegel. LEAD: It will not cost ''millions'' of dollars to clean up Long Island Sound, as Elex Ingersoll says in an appeal for public support for the task [ Opinion, ''Resolutions: For 1989, Clean Up Long Island Sound,'' Jan. 15 ] . According to Congressman George J. Hochbrueckner, the total cost, including upgrading old sewage plants and building new ones on both sides of the Sound, will be 10 to 15 billion dollars.

LEAD: An age-restricted garden apartment-town house complex is rising in Westchester's Bedford Hills as a result of a cooperative effort between officials of the Town of Bedford and a private developer. LEAD: Eleanor Bergholz's grim story of psychological despair while ''under the shadow of cancer'' describes in detail her unusual, one-year siege of toxicity from the relatively mild CMF regimen for breast cancer. Less than 20 percent of patients receiving CMF suffer the intense toxicity she describes. Her negative attitude is evident in the use of the term ''poisons'' for chemicals that are, indeed, lifesaving.

LEAD: ANGEL-FACED MADELINE KAHN frowns. ''Laughter is a strange response,'' she says. ''I mean, what is it? It's a spasm of some kind! Is that always joy? It's very often discomfort. It's some sort of explosive reaction.'' She flashes a devilish smile and then adds musically: ''It's very complex.'' And you laugh.

LEAD: When my closest friend from college got married, the basement of her parents' home looked like Tiffany's storeroom the day after Christmas. Long folding tables were piled with open pastel boxes of china, crystal and silver carefully nestled in wrinkled tissue paper and bubble wrap. A neat row of file boxes sat at the head of the first table, containing a master guest list with notations and gift cards stapled next to each name.

LEAD: Companies are sparing no expense to dress up their offices. LEAD: THE late President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt was fond of saying that the United States didn't hold just 90 percent of the cards in international affairs, it held 99 percent. Mr. Sadat's statement was an exaggeration, but it reflects a perception still widely shared around the globe. So James A. Baker 3d began his first week as Secretary of State looking out on a world that is scrutinizing his every wink and nod for signs of how he intends to play his opening hand.

After reading this article, I was better able to understand what my wife was going through.

LEAD: THE TAKEOVER BOOM IS A treatment for a disease that is destroying American productivity: gross and widespread incompetent management. Takeovers are part of a free-market response, working to unseat corporate bureaucracies, control runaway costs and make America competitive again.

LEAD: Despite worldwide eagerness to provide medical aid to victims of natural catastrophes, assistance flown in from far away has generally proved of little value, according to reports presented this week to a workshop at the United Nations.

LEAD: ''GET the Brookses!'' people used to say, when it was music recital time in Port Chester. Norman Brooks and his little sister, Lorraine - known then and now as ''Rainie'' - could always be counted on to perform for their school or community: he to play the piano, she to play the piano or sing.

LEAD: The New York City Ballet presented an evening of mostly happy, giddy fare on Tuesday at the New York State Theater. There was Balanchine's delectably mad ''Donizetti Variations'' to begin and ''The Concert,'' Jerome Robbins's comic view of a concert audience's fantasies and manners, to bring the program to a spirited close.

LEAD: Last year, when the Quaker Oats Company moved its headquarters of 30 years from Chicago's Merchandise Mart to a new steel and glass building, it was determined to distribute natural light more equitably to its 2,000 employees.

LEAD: A picture caption on Jan. 1 with an article about Egypt identified a tomb incompletely and misstated its location. It is that of Sennedjem, a necropolis worker, and is near the Valley of the Kings. A map of Cairo with the article omitted the site of the newly opened opera house. It is on the island of Gezira.
LEAD: OTHER PEOPLES' MYTHS The Cave of Echoes. By Wendy Doniger O'Flaherty. 225 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $19.95
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: SOME casinos here may band together soon in a program that would make millionaires of some slot-machine players.

LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: FIVE SEASONS By A. B. Yehoshua. Translated by Hillel Halkin. 359 pp. New York: Doubleday. $19.95.

LEAD: When an 11-year-old boy was charged with killing his baby sitter by setting his house ablaze here in early January, some Maine residents decided it was time to stop studying the problems of seriously troubled children and start helping them.

LEAD: A VOLT-OHM meter is a battery-powered measuring device that is used to diagnose a wide range of household electrical problems. With one, you can test batteries and switches, pinpoint causes of trouble in appliances and measure voltages at outlets.
LEAD: When night falls over this capital, Afghan soldiers, shabbily dressed, but armed with Russian-made Kalashnikov rifles, stop automobiles at every city block.
LEAD: WHICH counts for more, the player or the opening?

LEAD: An article on page 29 of the Arts and Leisure section today about the Los Angeles TV station KCET gives an outdated identification for Bruce L. Christensen; he is president of the Public Broadcasting Service. The article and a caption give an incorrect day for the American Playhouse presentation of ''A Raisin in the Sun''; it will be shown at 9 P.M.

LEAD: The Metropolitan Opera has packed up the immense pillars and omnipresent steps of its ''Trovatore,'' and sent it safely into storage. At the final performance of the season, on Tuesday evening, there were three newcomers to the cast.

LEAD: Q. At the end of last summer, I moved a small chest away from the wall and discovered a lot of mildew on the wall. This is not an outside wall (the living room of another apartment is on the other side) and there are no water pipes inside the wall. I no longer keep the chest flush against the wall and the mildew has not reappeared, although this part of the wall does look darker in some spots.
LEAD: WORK WITHOUT END Abandoning Shorter Hours for the Right to Work. By Benjamin Kline Hunnicutt. Illustrated. 404 pp. Philadelphia: Temple University Press.
LEAD: Regarding Nora Polinsky's letter ''Tap-Dancing Teachers: This Is Education?'' (Jan. 8).

LEAD: WIDOWS, by Ariel Dorfman. Translated by Stephen Kessler. (Penguin, $7.95.) In a land resembling both contemporary Chile and ancient Greece, the unrecognizable bodies of the ''disappeared'' begin washing ashore, tormenting the living with memories of the terror of the secret police. ''The plot resounds with the moral thunder of classic drama, specifically that of 'Antigone' and 'The Trojan Women,' '' Alan Cheuse said here in 1983.

LEAD: When the capital development of a country becomes a byproduct of the activities of a casino, the job is likely to be ill-done. The measure of success attained by Wall Street . . . cannot be claimed as one of the outstanding triumphs of laissez-faire capitalism. - John Maynard Keynes, ''The General Theory of Employment, Interest and

LEAD: MY grandfather died several weeks ago in Mississippi. When he was laid to rest, there were no heads of states or 21-gun salutes, for he was not a great man in the ubiquitous sense in which we judge greatness.

LEAD: THE concept of selling is so pervasive today - from toothpaste to political candidates - that it seems natural that the idea would be among the first things the leaders of two new alcohol- and drug-abuse prevention groups in Pleasantville would think of when considering programs to help them reach their objectives.

LEAD: Sherman Douglas tied a National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I record with 22 assists and Stephen Thompson scored a career-high 29 points tonight as 14th-ranked Syracuse rallied to beat No. 20 Providence, 100-96, in a Big East Conference game.
LEAD: PREVENTING WORLD WAR III A Realistic Grand Strategy. By David M. Abshire. 331 pp. New York: A Cornelia & Michael Bessie Book/ Harper & Row. $19.95.

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: President Bush is publicly and quite consciously distancing his week-old Administration from that of his predecessor, senior politicians of both parties have concluded, even though Ronald Reagan left town with his remarkable popularity intact after eight years in office.

LEAD: A university investigation has confirmed that Jackie Sherrill, who resigned as the Texas A&M football coach last month, gave $1,500 to a former player, but the investigators said they found no evidence that the payments had been hush money.

LEAD: BRICK LANE, IN LONDON'S EAST END, IS A neighborhood peopled by those whom the city never expected to accommodate. It is a neighborhood of Asians - as they are called by the English, who are comfortable still with the old colonial term that did not distinguish among the many peoples east of Europe.
LEAD: There is a large bulletin board in the rear of the Nets' locker room. The coaching staff uses it to keep track of the National Basketball Association standing.

LEAD: Before Louisiana State's game with Georgetown today, there were suspicions that Chris Jackson, the Tigers' outstanding freshman guard, was a regional phenomenon at best, more hype than substance.

LEAD: A 38-year-old woman escaped yesterday morning from the grasp of a man who had grabbed her and exposed himself on a lonely subway platform in lower Manhattan. She hit the man with a tote bag and was able to break free, the police said.
LEAD: Sling-back pumps by Valentino establish the delicate, sexy look of his spring-summer couture collection, shown in Paris this week.

LEAD: In a cathedral with shrines to such eclectic groups as New York City firefighters and AIDS victims, a memorial exhibit has been opened to honor a homegrown artisan whose fluid stone carvings of demons, lion heads and African masks adorn the building's unfinished bell tower.

LEAD: To the Editor: In Joe Mysak's story on the Richmond building that served as the Confederate States' executive mansion (''Where Davis Led the Confederacy,'' Travel, Dec. 4) a guide explained that one of two Confederate banners decorating a mantel included so much white that it was redesigned so as not to be taken as a flag of surrender.

LEAD: To the Editor: Carol Cott Gross must have been in shock when she saw the response (Letters on Travel, Nov. 20) to her light article on condo living in Florida (Travel, Oct. 16). She should be reassured that there are lots of Florida folks who do have a sense of humor. I immediately clipped the piece to show to my dad.

LEAD: A MEANDERING river, lined with old houses; a tall, four-towered cathedral on the hill, and next to it a great Baroque palace: today Bamberg still looks like a late 18th-century engraving of one of those little German towns that time had apparently forgotten. The texture of life - except for the inconveniently numerous cars - still belongs to an easier, sleepier time; from the dark, wood-paneled taverns serving the local white wine, beer and sausages to the impressive antique shops, all here speaks of the past.

LEAD: Accountants faced lawsuits and heavy criticism as the savings and loan industry's dire condition received considerable attention in Washington. M. Danny Wall, head of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, said his agency was suing three accounting firms and expected to eventually sue most of the profession's Big Eight firms.

LEAD: ''WHENEVER someone asks me about success in real estate, I tell them to plan to live a long time,'' said Ian Woodner, a builder of office and residential projects in New York and Washington. ''If you live long enough, everything you own will end up being worth something to you.''

LEAD: The White House chief of staff, John H. Sununu, and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said today that imposing a fee on savings accounts is still an option to help resolve a crisis in the nation's savings and loan institutions.
LEAD: CANDLELIGHT CONCERT

LEAD: If the political extremist Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. mounts a fourth campaign for the Presidency in 1992, it will probably involve very little travel. Mr. LaRouche was sentenced last week to 15 years in prison for his conviction last month on charges of scheming to defraud the Internal Revenue Service and deliberately defaulting on more than $30 million in loans from his supporters.

LEAD: A man who fought in court successfully to let his comatose wife die proposed legislation today to create a state medical ethics commission to make such judgments. In November, the man, H. Glenn Gray, obtained a Federal court order to remove the feeding tube of his wife, Marcia V. Gray, 49 years old, who went into a coma in January 1986 after a blood vessel burst in her brain.

LEAD: WHEN the State Department of Consumer Protection tells Connecticut restaurants ''no substitutions, please,'' it means no fake crabmeat, no jumbo shrimp that is not really jumbo shrimp, and no other half-truths on the menu.

LEAD: Re: Anne Semmes's harsh review of the Newarker, at the Vista Hotel near Newark Airport (Dec. 18): My wife and I recently dined at the Newarker on three consecutive Wednesday evenings and found total satisfaction each time; excellent menu and preparation, superb service, an ambiance of subdued elegance.

LEAD: Nick Price, who said he was ''confused'' over his failure to win in recent years, celebrated his 32d birthday today by charging from six shots behind to tie Mark O'Meara for the lead going into the final round of the A.T.&.T. Pebble Beach National Pro-Am.

LEAD: Compositions seem to crumble under Andrew Hill's hands. His piano style is a patchwork of approaches -ringing chords and quick jabs and stride piano oom-pahs, skittering runs and skewed be-bop lines, melodies fractured by pauses and asides - cobbled together in asymmetrical fits and starts. His own themes are just as eccentric, barely announcing themselves as ballads or hard-bop before veering away.

LEAD: After a month of refurbishing, the Mayflower II is back in its berth at Plimoth Plantation. ''It came back yesterday, and it looks absolutely gorgeous,'' Troy Creane, a spokeswoman for the plantation, said Wednesday. The replica of the Pilgrims' ship, visited by about 300,000 people a year, undergoes major repairs about every two years.

LEAD: THE ball sailed slowly through the air on a high arc as it passed over 150 yards of water on its way to the green. When I first hit the ball I simply wished it success in traversing the hazard. However, as the shot unfolded my expectations soared as I realized that this single effort had the possibility of immortal greatness.

LEAD: As every biographer of Freud must ruefully acknowledge, that great unriddler of mysteries left behind some tantalizing private mysteries of his own. Probably the most titillating of these, which has been generating gossip for perhaps 75 years, is his relationship with his sister-in-law, Minna Bernays.
LEAD: Columbia University has named 66 newspaper editors, executives and others for the jury to nominate entries for the 1989 Pulitzer Prizes in journalism.

He put the bag on his desk and extracted an acetate-covered parchment from within. ''I've been looking at these things since I was a kid,'' the 60-year-old historian said, ''but I never actually held one in my hands before.

LEAD: JUST 30 FEET AWAY, IN THE SUN-FLECKED shadows of the Cambodian jungle, was the sight that locals and visitors most dread: crouched, aiming his rifle, a teen-ager in dirty black pajamas and a red-checked scarf; nearby were four other Khmer Rouge guerrillas, in black with checked scarves, darting and dodging behind trees, guns pointed.

LEAD: THE TRIAL OF BERNHARD GOETZ Starring Peter Crombie (in photo), Larry B. Scott, Richard Libertini, Andrew Robinson. Directed by Harry Moses. 1988. Today Home Entertainment. 135 minutes. $59.95. Not rated.

LEAD: BLUE HEAVEN. By Joe Keenan. (Penguin, Paper, $7.95.) Gilbert Selwyn is a broke, gay author with a heart of gold who is too lazy even to have writer's block. Moira Finch is a broke, straight social climber with a heart of unalloyed steel who has a penchant for disastrous investments. ''Blue Heaven'' is their nuptial adventure story, following them as they embark on a marriage designed to swindle their rich but parsimonious families out of a fortune in wedding gifts.

LEAD: Mark Franko has often choreographed in Renaissance and Baroque styles. But on Thursday night at the Washington Square Methodist Church, his company, Novantiqua, performed works by him to recorded music by Webern and Messiaen as well as Bach and Vivaldi and the program was essentially a modern-dance concert.

LEAD: WHEN Mexico City had money, about a century ago under the brief rule of Maximilian and later under President Porfirio Diaz, it was spent on luxurious parks, vast esplanades and a grand avenue designed to rival the Champs-Elysees. Today these remnants of elegance remain in the city's center, and it is here that three museums of exceptional quality - the Templo Mayor (Great Temple) Museum, the Franz Mayer Museum and the Centro Cultural - have recently opened.

Bayer of Huntington, L.I. The Rev. Mark Glasko, a Roman

LEAD: A map on Jan. 1 with an article about the paradors of Spain mislocated one establishment. The Reyes Catolicos parador mentioned is in Santiago de Compostela, in northwest Spain, not the one on the Mediterranean coast.

LEAD: ''Don Carlo,'' in many ways the most dramatically challenging of Verdi's operas, can also be the most rewarding when everything meshes. The work, a dark study in insoluble conflicts - church versus state, friendship versus duty, love versus jealousy - returned to the Metropolitan Opera repertory on Friday evening in John

LEAD: I MISSED the sexual revolution. I missed the feminist movement. I was too busy diapering babies. I missed the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s sit-ins. I never got to march for anything. I was too busy keeping the pace with carriages.

LEAD: To the Editor: While I couldn't find my way around upstate New York from the position of the sun, as James Howard Kunstler claims he can (''Finding Your Routes,'' Travel, Jan. 8), I can find my way around a stage. Stage right and left are not, as he maintains, referred to from the audience's point of view but from the actor's.
LEAD: The Personal Finance column on Jan. 8 described decreasing term life insurance incorrectly. Benefits payable under this type of policy shrink each year; premiums remain the same.

LEAD: The president of the National Audubon Society, Peter A. A. Berle, will head a new state commission to plan the future of the Adirondack Park, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo announced today.

LEAD: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 11 THE SANDS OF TIME, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $19.95.) Four nuns become pawns in a struggle between the Spanish Army and Basque separatists. 2 2 26 THE CARDINAL OF THE KREMLIN, by Tom Clancy.

LEAD: The college game has come to pro basketball. It arrived in New York by way of Providence College when Rick Pitino became the Knicks' coach July 13, 1987. And it came with all the trimmings: the 3-point basket, an uptempo offense, the full-court trap, and pressure defenses that slice seconds off a team's ability to run their offense.
LEAD: For the Huskies of Connecticut, the frustration of eight years of losses to St. John's was reduced to a footnote today.

LEAD: The engagement of Julia Barrington Forbes and Matthew Scott Burnett has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mrs. Eric K. Lindquist of Sarasota, Fla., and John B. Forbes of New York. Mr. Burnett is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Bradley Burnett, also of Sarasota. An April wedding is planned.
LEAD: Kenny Battle scored 22 points and led a second-half rally tonight as top-ranked Illinois beat No. 16 Indiana, 75-65, in a Big Ten Conference game.

LEAD: John G. Tower, the Secretary of Defense-designate, got a taste today of what his new job entails as defense experts and officials from across NATO wrangled at a seminar here over the future of an alliance increasingly at odds over the peace signals from the Eastern bloc.
LEAD: BOGEYS,'' CRIED A United States fighter pilot facing fast-closing Libyan jets, ''have jinked back at me again for the fifth time. . . . Fox One!''

LEAD: The French have launched a yearlong celebration of their Revolution's bicentennial. It comes when the worth of revolution was never more in question. In 1789 and after, they gave at least as many examples of the lasting damage and distress it causes as of the flowering of ideals it can release.

LEAD: ''This isn't the first thing I've done that was previously for whites only.'' - Ronald H. Brown, on his prospects to become chairman of the Democratic Party. [ 24:1. ]

LEAD: HOW I GOT HIM BACK Or, Under the Cold Moon's Shine. By Valerie Sayers. 300 pp. New York: Doubleday. $17.95.

LEAD: Nearly 30 years ago, in ''The End of Ideology,'' Daniel Bell wrote that the universalist political ideas of the 19th century were exhausted. Marxism in particular. Its premises about the crisis of capitalism and the superiority of socialist organization had simply not squared with reality.
LEAD: ATER being vacant for four years, one of Wilmington's premier pieces of commercial real estate is about to be developed with a $70 million high-rise thrift headquarters.

LEAD: IT may not be the noblest form of democracy, but government by commission does offer certain advantages. In the last month, independent commissions, set up by Congress or at its direction, have taken care of several thorny tasks that seemed impervious to conventional politics.

LEAD: Five ranch workers have been indicted by a Federal grand jury here on charges of killing more than 40 wild horses and burros. The indictments, handed up Tuesday, resulted from an investigation by the Bureau of Land Management into the killing of more than 500 mustangs since last August, most of them in Landeer and Pershing Counties.

LEAD: ONE shouldn't really blame Comrade Tito too much. Brioni, the cluster of small and verdant islands off the coast of Istria at the head of the Adriatic, is irresistibly beautiful. And he was deserving of the Yugoslav nation's gratitude for having led its gallant struggle to throw off German occupation and Soviet dominance.

LEAD: GERTRUDE BELLE Elion was the only female recipient on the stage at last month's Nobel Prize ceremonies in Stockholm. Dressed in royal blue chiffon, she was a flash of brilliance among the starched white evening shirts and formal black suits of the others. George Herbert Hitchings, too, stood apart, at 83 the oldest new recipient by a good many years.

LEAD: AT FIRST IT SOUNDS slightly peculiar to hear Barbara Nissman proselytize for Prokofiev's piano music as if the Russian composer were a new discovery. Prokofiev is hardly unknown - ''Peter and Wolf,'' the ''Classical'' Symphony and ''Lieutenant Kije'' Suite are among the most often played of all 20th-century classics.

LEAD: Members of the staff of the United States Embassy in Beirut locked Ambassador John McCarthy in his office for three hours today to press their demands for higher salaries. A State Department spokeswoman, Nancy Beck, said Lebanese guards had carried out a ''work action,'' but declined to give details.

LEAD: Pakistan has acquired from a West German company a plant for purifying a gas than can be used in nuclear weapons, a German prosecutor says.

LEAD: A nine-inch statuette of the Virgin Mary that a police official put on his desk led to a dispute that has spiraled into a debate on the division between church and state. The debate is being waged in an arbitration case.

LEAD: An argument could be made that the Big East is not only the best conference teamwise, but also coachwise. Every season, Jim Boeheim, John Thompson, Rollie Massimino, and Lou Carnesecca field teams that have the potential to do anything. With the emergence of Seton Hall, it seems that P. J. Carlesimo will soon join the elite.
LEAD: A powerful earthquake, measured at 6.3 on the Richter scale, shook the remote Komandorsky Islands west of Alaska on Friday, the National Earthquake Information Center here reported.

LEAD: When a chef asks his sous chef for her hand in marriage, wedding plans become menus and grocery lists and recipes. That's what happened when Ali Barker, then chef at the Union Square Cafe in New York, became engaged to Marcie Smith, his sous chef. Of course, they would make all the food for the reception, not to mention the rehearsal dinner.

LEAD: The halls at Kidder, Peabody & Company, one of Wall Street's oldest and most prestigious firms, are quiet. Rows of darkened offices overlook New York Harbor and cardboard boxes are stacked on desks where secretaries once worked. Where there was once the chaotic bustle of young men and women rushing around with papers in hand, there is now eerie stillness.

LEAD: To the Editor: I had an interesting experience discovering the Temple of Ptah at Karnak, mentioned by Paula Weideger (''Coping With Egypt on Your Own,'' Travel, Jan. 1). After exploring Karnak for hours, long after the early morning throngs of guided tours had departed the heat of an October day, I was sitting in the cool shadows of the gigantic columns.

LEAD: According to a recent poll by The Associated Press, the Big East had four teams in the Top 20. Only the Big Ten had more. The four ranked teams from the Big East were Georgetown, Syracuse, Seton Hall and Providence. Together, those teams lost only eight games, all to other Big East teams. Outside the Big East, the combined record of these teams was 46-0.
LEAD: Cancer treatment is not in what Eleanor Bergholz calls ''a sorry state.'' It saves the lives of about 40 percent of those who have the disease.

LEAD: CRIME is on the rise at shopping malls throughout the state, law-enforcement officials say. But they say that coping with the increase can be better accomplished by improved training of security guards, not by arming them.

LEAD: ON SEPT. 20, 1985, AGENTS FROM the United States Customs Service and the Secret Service seized more than 25,000 imported, counterfeit watches from illicit distributors in South Florida. Twenty-six people were subsequently arrested and convicted of trafficking in counterfeit merchandise. However, it was more than three years before the case, known as Operation Stopwatch, wound down.

LEAD: The ugly duckling of Lexington Avenue, the 36-story office tower with the esthetics that everyone on the East Side loves to hate, is going to be given an $18 million facelift. The building, at 575 Lexington at 51st Street, was erected in 1958 by Sam Minskoff & Sons and faced with gold-colored aluminum to commemorate the company's 50th anniversary in the building business.
