LEAD: Gil Hodges was the first to go. Then Jackie Robinson. Next after our brief remission from death, Billy Cox. And suddenly there stood a journalist asking Pee Wee Reese, ''How does it feel to be the last person alive from the great Brooklyn Dodger infield?''

LEAD: The jury in the murder trial of Joel B. Steinberg asked the presiding judge yesterday to define the elements of first-degree manslaughter, one of the lesser charges Mr. Steinberg faces in the death of Lisa Steinberg.

LEAD: ALL OUR GAMES. By Erika Mitterer. (Camden House, $24.95.) In the Austria of the Anschluss, 16-year-old Helga Wegscheider zealously embraces Hitler's message, convinced of the justice of his design for Europe. Like her fiance, an SS soldier, she devotes herself passionately to the Nazi cause. But at home something else is taking shape, outside the scope of Helga's bedazzled vision: her brothers hold secretive Bible-group meetings, her parents' conversation is sprinkled with cryptic remarks.

LEAD: A state trooper will face a Saratoga County grand jury Tuesday after he was arrested on seven counts stemming from the rape and sodomy of a 29-year-old woman last fall, the police said today. Robert O. Bennett Jr., 35 years old, of Clifton Park, was arrested Friday, a state police spokesman said. Mr.

LEAD: Valeriya Ionava struggles privately in her Moscow apartment to live on a monthly pension of less than $60. Yelena Smolnikova has to skip meals so that her meager income can be stretched to buy warm clothes for her children.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: WHILE affirmative action programs in education and employment have been subject to frequent, sometimes heated debate in recent years, another kind of race-based remedy for discrimination - public spending set-asides - have operated with relatively little dispute over the last 20 years.
LEAD: Anti-Semitic incidents in the United States rose to a five-year high in 1988, the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith reports.
LEAD: A bill introduced in the State Senate on Thursday would bring back public whipping as punishment for people convicted of dealing in hard drugs.
LEAD: Additional titles of interest:
LEAD: James Gleick's article ''Why Can't a Robot Be More Like a Man?'' (Dec.11), exhibited a fine touch of realism, technological insight and humor.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Patricia Pettigrew Wroe of Weston, Conn., of the engagement of her daughter, Polly Egan Wroe, to John H. Knowles Jr., the son of Edith LaCroix Dabney of Chestnut Hill, Mass., and the late Dr. Knowles. The couple plan to marry June 3.

LEAD: THE Governor's choice to be the state's new Economic Development Commissioner is Stephen Heintz. The Commissioner is responsible for attracting and retaining business in the state, and he and and a staff of 100 employees also coordinate business education and development programs. The department has a budget of $8.5 million.

LEAD: I HAD heard all the stories: A friend whose purse was grabbed in Paris, a man who lost his wallet in London, another who had paid an exorbitant fare for a dizzying ride around the Etoile. Thus alerted, I determined that none of the above would happen to me on my first trip abroad.

LEAD: THE question of whether the public weal outweighs the rights of public workers has been aboil for some years, drawing fresh fuel from the Reagan Administration's recurrent proposals to require polygraphs and random drug tests for Federal employees.
LEAD: On the national day marking the Rev. Martin Luther King's 60th birthday earlier this month, Margaret Lalor of Glens Falls, N.Y., sent her first gift to The New York Times Neediest Cases.
LEAD: THEIR repertory is musically varied but subject specific. Their audiences are few but select. Their name says all. They are the Six Cuckoos.
LEAD: Manhattan Borough President David N. Dinkins will almost certainly run for mayor, say aides, politicians close to him and even potential opponents who have met with him.
LEAD: Tuija Hakkila, a pianist from Finland, offered a well-chosen and persuasively played program of 20th-century music in her New York debut recital Thursday evening at Merkin Concert Hall.

LEAD: To the Editor: My wife and I were recently in Venice, and although we had been forewarned, we found the high prices staggering. After spending over $100 each for a few dinners and even lunches, we discovered Do Mori, a charming restaurant on the Giudecca owned and operated by two ex-waiters from Harry's Bar.

LEAD: EARLY IN MY 20-YEAR CAREER at the Williamstown Theater Festival, I was taking notes at a rehearsal of the balcony scene from ''Cyrano de Bergerac.'' The director turned away briefly from a spirited dialogue with Cyrano, Christian and Roxanne, steered me into a corner and whispered: ''O.K., Stephen - get rid of that person.

LEAD: George Bush once said that he wanted to be President of ''all the people'' of the United States. Since this is a country with a remarkably, and often unnervingly, diverse citizenry, that's a tall order but an indispensable duty.

LEAD: In hearings last week on his confirmation as Secretary of Defense, John G. Tower provided a glimpse of the lucrative world of consulting which many Government officials enter when they leave public life. Mr. Tower, who retired from the Senate in 1984, founded Tower & Associates in 1986 and has since earned more than $750,000 in consulting fees from military contractors.

LEAD: NO one would ever mistake Fifth Avenue for the quad at old Ivy U., but a lot of people strolling up and down the avenue recently have had a certain collegiate air about them. Could it be the words of the Great Philosophers one often hears quoted in passing conversations outside Trump Tower, Bergdorf Goodman and Tiffany's?

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Philip B. Smith of Darien, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter Eleanor Batterman Smith to Kenneth Alden Southworth 4th, the son of Mrs. Morgan Kiker Jr. of Andover, Mass., and Mr. Southworth 3d of Edgartown, Mass. A June wedding is planned.
LEAD: To the Editor: Regarding the response to a question on tipping (Q & A, Jan. 1):

LEAD: Two brothers have been charged with invading a Queens schoolyard, one wielding a loaded semiautomatic gun that had been modified to resemble an Uzi, the Queens District Attorney, John J. Santucci, said Friday.

LEAD: SINCE a 28-inch-wide pipeline burst, spewing toxic substances into a residential neighborhood here in April 1984, residents' opposition to the Ciba-Geigy Corporation, which manufactures chemicals and plastics, has been unrelenting.
LEAD: BOSTON, Jan. 24 - As a boy, Daniel Kim dreamed of becoming an actor but was afraid his Asian background would bar him from many of the parts to which he aspired.
LEAD: When the season began it was reasonable to expect that Kenny Anderson would break the New York City and State high school career scoring records if he had a good year.

LEAD: Q. At the end of last summer, I moved a small chest away from the wall and discovered a lot of mildew on the wall. This is not an outside wall (the living room of another apartment is on the other side) and there are no water pipes inside the wall. I no longer keep the chest flush against the wall and the mildew has not reappeared, although this part of the wall does look darker in some spots.

LEAD: The engagement of Tracy Ellen Schafer to Todd Matthew Foreman, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Spencer Foreman of Scarsdale, N.Y., has been made known by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Seymour J. Schafer of Pittsburgh. The couple plan to marry in May.

LEAD: SO far, none of his subjects have tried rappelling down the building when they leave or taken any other similarly bizarre risks, but Victor M. Hesselbrock admits he has his hands full with his latest research project.

LEAD: Soviet officials disclosed today for the first time that in the 1962 Cuban missile crisis, Soviet nuclear warheads had already been deployed in Cuba and could have been launched at American cities within a few hours.

LEAD: SMOKING as a habit may be on the decline but as a flavoring it is more popular than ever. Restaurant chefs are using smoked foods - meats, poultry, seafood, vegetables and cheeses - in a variety of dishes. Many of the chefs are doing their own smoking with simple, improvised equipment.

LEAD: BUSH Administration officials and Congressional leaders are not counting on the National Economic Commission to grease the way to a compromise on reducing the Federal budget deficit. Rather, they are banking on the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law to bludgeon them into an agreement.

LEAD: As a result of the Yankees' determination to enter the 1989 season with the best possible pitching staff, seven pitchers, including some whose careers had seemed all but over, are getting a new chance to make their mark on the majors. They have been invited to try out at the Yankees' major league training camp even though the team has 17 pitchers on the roster.

LEAD: Marjorie Laura Schein and Brian Alexander Weston, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Vaughan H. Weston of West Lafayette, Ind., plan to marry in June. Their engagement has been made known by the future bride's parents, Carol S. Gill of Ardsley-on-Hudson, N.Y., and David S. Schein of West Nyack, N.Y.
LEAD: To the Editor: As a former year-round condo resident in south Florida (for nine years), I found many chuckles in Carol Cott Gross's article and the cartoons accompanying it.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: IN 1939, IT WAS THE MOST TECHNICALLY sophisticated color film ever made, but by 1987 ''Gone With the Wind'' looked more like ''Confederates From Mars.'' Scarlett and Rhett had grown green and blue, a result of unstable film stocks and generations of badly duplicated prints. Hair styles and costumes, once marvels of spectral subtlety, looked as though captured in Crayola, not
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: THOUGH Rudyard Kipling lived only five of his 70 years in Lahore, they were the most crucial years of his development as a writer. This rich confection of a city, whose great Mogul buildings and street life evoke the deep hues and sensuality of a miniature painting, was where the teen-aged Kipling cut his teeth as a newspaperman.

LEAD: A FLORIDLY engraved Victorian silver buckle, large in size and mounted as a brooch, originally belonging to my mother's mother and passed on to me when I was in college, began my fascination with British buckles. Among my most treasured possessions, a symmetrical pair of delicate Art Nouveau traceries, from the days when Liberty of London engaged England's leading designers for their silver, now clasps a suede belt.

LEAD: ST. JAMES Episcopal Church, a small (capacity 150), steepled white frame building in North Salem, carries with it some 125 years of history; the parish it serves is one of the oldest in the country, predating the American Revolution by nearly a decade. Two years ago, the church installed a 100-year-old pipe organ and decided to celebrate the new acquisition by beginning an annual chamber series.

LEAD: Q. At the end of last summer, I moved a small chest away from the wall and discovered a lot of mildew on the wall. This is not an outside wall (the living room of another apartment is on the other side) and there are no water pipes inside the wall. I no longer keep the chest flush against the wall and the mildew has not reappeared, although this part of the wall does look darker in some spots.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Ronald H. Brown, the Washington lawyer who will soon be elected chairman of the Democratic Party, professes not to think much about the history being made as his party begins to rally around him even here in the South.

LEAD: ''BROADWAY BOUND'' is about a young comedy writer who gets the first big break that puts him on the road to becoming Neil Simon. It is also about his restrictive family in Brighton Beach in the late 1940's, but mostly it turns out to be about his repressed mother who, in a revelatory mid-second-act monologue, recounts her moment in the spotlight: the night she danced with George
LEAD: Russell Baker's article ''Brown-Bagging It to Buckingham'' (Jan. 1), prodded my memory to relive the jubilation of Coronation Day, 1953.

LEAD: AL VECIO MULIN (the old mill) in Gradisca d'Isonzo, about six miles from the Italian-Yugoslav border, is always crowded with local residents who stop in to share a bottle of wine and some typical Friuli fare. The owner, Bruno Spessot, who turned the 200-year-old mill into an informal inn 25 years ago, offers top-quality hams, sausages and other cold cuts along with the local Montasio cheese and, from the nearby Collio wine region, tocai, pinot grigio and merlot.

LEAD: COMPOSERS HAVE LONG ENJOYED an uneasy, if lucrative, relationship with film. From such early idealists as Sergei Prokofiev to the populist experiments of the 1930's (Aaron Copland, Virgil Thomson et al.), serious composers have been attracted to the film medium.

LEAD: HEART SONGS: And Other Stories. By E. Annie Proulx. (Scribners, $16.95.) The men in E. Annie Proulx's nine stories, who have come to northern New England to seek self-renewal by grouse hunting, trout fishing or folk singing, are as harried by misery as the people who live there. Cut off from their spouses or harassed by their mothers and sisters, they are shy, battered, depleted men.

LEAD: The marriage of Amanda Tompkins Erskine, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard W. Erskine of New York, to David Charles Hutton, a son of William Hutton of Dallas and the late Sandra Van Buskirk Hutton, took place yesterday at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York.

LEAD: Eight anti-abortion protestors who were chained together by their necks and legs inside a women's clinic today resisted efforts by local authorities to remove them for nearly 12 hours, before they were dragged from the building by the police, who brought special equipment to break the shackles. At least 17 other protestors who were without chains inside the Medical Care Center were arrested and were to be charged with defiant trespassing for not obeying an order to leave the grounds, said Lieut.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Harry Forman of Merrick, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Marilyn Forman to Glenn R. Jacobowitz, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Walter E. Jacobowitz of Convent Station, N.J. Ms. Forman and her fiance, both fourth-year medical students at New York University, plan to marry in June.

LEAD: In front of the 840-year-old Cathedral of St. Stephen, Vienna's geographic and historic center, a bulging structure of concrete, glass and bright metal is nearing completion amid a fierce debate. Designed by the leading architect Hans Hollein, the new eight-story building, in bold contrast to the ancient church's Gothic lacework, will house 16 ground-floor stores, a gourmet market, offices and - what else ?

LEAD: Speed Skating Jansen Takes 500-Meter Race: Dan Jansen of the United States won the 500-meter World Cup race yesterday and finished second to Uwe Jens Mey of East Germany in the 1,000-meter event at Miola di Pine, Italy.

LEAD: The civil servant, surprised and tentative, invited his visitors to come in. He said he would not speak of politics, because as a Government employee he was not supposed to take part in political activities.

LEAD: THOSE of us who watched the Super Bowl on television last Sunday were witness to several special photographic effects. For starters, thousands of fans in the stands fired their flashes into the air at the opening kickoff. I presume this was pre-arranged by the broadcasting powers-that-be to provide a nice glitter around the players, since none of the exposures has a chance of turning out.

LEAD: To the Editor: Nothing reminds me more of the old Alphonse and Gaston routine than the Whitney's duo of Breuer and Graves [ ''The Whitney Paradox: To Add Is To Subtract,'' Jan. 8 ] . The two Frenchmen of old, simultaneously gesturing grandly in order to allow the other to pass first, always wound up slamming into one another as they both conveyed false gestures of yielding while truly feeling entitled to enter a room before the other.

LEAD: LUCID STARS. By Andrea Barrett. (Delta, Paper, $7.95.) In her first novel, Andrea Barrett enlists the whole empyrean - Orion through Libra through Pegasus - to serve as a backdrop for and sad commentary on a dissolving family. Her story opens on a Vermont mountaintop in 1955 when 19-year-old Penny Webb succumbs to the charms of a ski bum named Benjamin Day.
LEAD: Officials at Kent State University have broken ground for a scaled-down memorial to the four students killed by Ohio National Guardsmen in 1970.

LEAD: FOR A PUBLIC-TELEVISION station that was almost bankrupt seven years ago, KCET is celebrating its 25th anniversary in style. From ''Secret Intelligence'' - its current four-hour series on the underbelly of American espionage that documents United States attempts to assassinate Cuban leader Fidel Castro - to a new production of ''A Raisin in the Sun,'' KCET is flaunting its resurrection.

LEAD: Near rusting railroad yards and blackened smokestacks in this industrial town, Dr. Akinobu Kasami and a team of 50 researchers are working to transform the theory of high-temperature superconductivity into the business of practical electronic products.

LEAD: ''MYSTERY - THAT'S THE key word about Bobby. One thing he never talks about is his craft. He never does - that one area is a closed door.'' That is the director Simon Wincer, speaking by phone from his cattle ranch in Mooroolbark, Australia, half a world away, about the American actor Robert Duvall.

LEAD: A long-brewing controversy over whether brokers should place mortgages for home buyers may now be up to the incoming Congress to resolve. Earlier this month, the Department of Housing and Urban Development decided not to issue new regulations to govern the practice and left the problem to be settled by legislation.

LEAD: ON Feb. 7, Christie's will auction a New England shilling, one of the many coins from the salvaged ship H.M.S. Feversham lost in 1711. One of the rarest coins of the auction, the plain New England shilling is also one of the first coins minted in the English American colonies.

LEAD: A group dedicated to exposing Stalin's crimes, honoring his victims and eradicating lingering Stalinist practices moved today to legalize its standing and establish itself as a significant political force.
LEAD: A group of Hasidic Jews last week severely beat a homeless man suspected of robbing a Hasidic man in a Brooklyn housing project, the police said yesterday.
LEAD: Eleanor Bergholz's article on breast cancer was honest and moving, but the story is incomplete.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Sylvan R. Shemitz of Woodbridge, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter Allison Kate Shemitz to David Rounds Schieffelin, a son of G. Richard Schieffelin of New Haven and Billings, Mont., and the late Anne Rounds. A September wedding is planned.

LEAD: Melvin Konner writes that in a teaching hospital the hand that performs the surgery may belong, not to the famed senior physician, but to the young surgeon standing on the other side of the table (Body and Mind: ''Which Hospital?'' by Melvin Konner, Dec. 18). And that's O.K., says Dr. Konner, because ''it is not the hands, in most surgery, but the mind that matters.

LEAD: Early this month the Customs Service issued a ruling to increase tariffs tenfold on imported vans and sports-utility vehicles. The decision, which would give added protection to American manufacturers, was chiefly designed to end a tariff classification ambiguity and harmonize American procedures with those of other countries.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: WAR AND PEACE IN CENTRAL AMERICA By Frank McNeil. Illustrated. 310 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $19.95.

LEAD: A special Senate investigating committee has uncovered evidence of widespread corruption among some American Indian leaders and Federal officials who oversee Government programs on Indian reservations, lawmakers say.

LEAD: ONCE AGAIN, AS IN NINE previous years, the Grands Prix for audio have been announced. Under the aegis of Audio-Video International, a leading trade journal, a jury of technical experts chose outstanding audio components of 1988 from a list of nominations submitted through a nationwide poll of audio dealers.

LEAD: WHEN Kellogg's created its hugely successful ad campaign that turned a whole generation of breakfast eaters on to the ''Snap, Crackle and Pop'' of Rice Krispies, it must have been a quieter time. Morning munchers had to be able to hear not only one another talking, but also their cereal. I think things have changed, and I don't think for the better.

LEAD: The engagement of Claire Margaret Noumair to Gerald D. Smith, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Smith of San Jose, Calif., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. George J. Noumair of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, and Deal, N.J. A July wedding is planned.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Fiore of New York of the engagement of their daughter, Christina Barbara Fiore, to Philip Van Munching, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Van Munching Jr. of Darien, Conn. The couple plan to marry in October.

LEAD: A FEW old-timers in Stamford have fond memories of the night of June 2, 1927, when the Palace Theater on Atlantic Street opened with ''Rookies'' starring Karl Dane, George K. Arthur and Marceline Day. There was also a vaudeville show that included Dave Kramer and Jack Boyle, the ''Happy Go Lucky Boys,'' and the ''acrobatic sensations'' Janowski & Company.

LEAD: Dentist With a Heart SOME give candy for Valentine's Day, others flowers. Fred Danziger, a dentist practicing in Long Beach, believes in giving a more substantial gift. ''I like to give health,'' he said. And so on Valentine's Day, as on the past two Valentine's Days, Dr. Danziger will offer free dentistry.
LEAD: Mixed Concert

LEAD: When Clemson takes on Duke in Durham, N.C., today, don't be surprised if Dennis Hopf is wearing the cleanest Tiger uniform. Until yesterday, the 6-foot sophomore was the Clemson manager. He was pressed into service for today's game to help fill the void created by the surprise suspension of seven Clemson players, including two starters, apparently for skipping study hall.

LEAD: THE past and the future are colliding on Broadway this year, and nowhere so dramatically as on West 45th Street. As the construction of hotels, office buildings and retail space sets the stage for the new Times Square that will greet the 21st century, a close-up look at the projects in construction along a single street shows how the crosscurrents of law, business and public policy shape the growth of the city.

LEAD: THE young nurse had just finished taking my blood pressure - the only steady numbers my body gives off - and she turned her attention to my pulse. Her tiny fingers gently pinched my wrist searching for the radial artery. I remained quietly seated on the hospital bed as she stared at the simple gold chain bracelet on her otherwise naked wrist.

LEAD: THE HUMAN HAND HAS BEEN A recurring subject in photography - in part because, in an esthetic sense, photography renders the idea of ''the hand'' vestigial. Unlike other methods of representation, including drawing and painting, photography cannot claim to be an art of line, stroke or touch. To take a picture, all the hand need do is press the shutter button.

Rhodes of Westport. The Rev.

LEAD: The Department of Environmental Protection today lowered the limit on vapor-producing ingredients in gasoline sold in New Jersey between May 1 and Sept. 15 to control worsening ozone pollution. The new order limits volatility - a measure of gasoline's polluting potency - to nine pounds per square inch, compared to the 11.5 the state has averaged in recent summers, the department said.

LEAD: In the four years since a shuttered General Motors Corporation factory here re-opened as a joint venture with the Toyota Motors Corporation, the resurrected assembly plant has been hailed as proof that a labor and management utopia could be created in American heavy industry.

LEAD: The latest wave of Latin American immigrants now flooding Texas, California and Florida includes an increasing proportion of women and children, a phenomenon that is already beginning to strain housing, education and social services in some cities.

LEAD: Rupert Callender leaned over a small table in his makeshift trailer home, explaining to a visiting fire marshal why he thought his 8-year-old son Danny had burned down their ramshackle house in Little Neck, Queens, last month.

LEAD: AS he prepares his own battle plan for the war on AIDS, President Bush will be pulled in opposite directions. Advocates for victims of the epidemic see a larger AIDS budget as a logical extension of the President's recent signals that he will pursue a gentler brand of Reaganism. At the same time, some conservatives argue that the epidemic is being used to promote a liberal agenda that includes sex education, contraception, free needles for addicts and more rights for homosexuals.
LEAD: Former First Lady Stymied on Dunes

LEAD: ROBERT B. ANDERSON, Treasury Secretary in the second Eisenhower Administration, pleaded guilty in 1987 in Federal District Court in Manhattan to evading income taxes and operating an illegal offshore bank in the British West Indies. Judge Edmund Palmieri sentenced Mr. Anderson to a month in prison, five months' house arrest and five years on probation.

LEAD: WHEN bats moved into Lorraine Disburger's house in New London, N.Y., last summer, she moved out. The normally nocturnal bats were everywhere, even at midday: between the walls, beneath the floorboards, behind the curtains, scratching and wheezing and squeaking and swarming. ''It was like that movie 'The Birds,' '' she said at the time.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James B. Wager of Pittsburgh of the engagement of their daughter, Anita Andrews Wager, to George Oliver Richardson 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richardson Jr. of Darien, Conn. A September wedding is planned.

LEAD: Not too long ago, a young man slipped an engagement ring on a young woman's finger, and in an instant she was poring over a guide to proper wedding etiquette. She dutifully followed the book. She wore a white wedding dress with a ''conservative neckline, and sleeves preferably long'' (''The Amy Vanderbilt Complete Book of Etiquette,'' revised and expanded by Letitia Baldrige).

LEAD: AFTER 408 days, 6,000 arrests, at least 361 deaths and many thousands of injuries, the Palestinian uprising still rumbles steadily along, barely deterred by Israel's ever-changing tactics for suppressing it. But now for the first time, Israeli Army officers as well as other leading officials are acknowledging with frustration and despair that nothing they can do will end it.

LEAD: Leaders of the teamsters union today rejected a Government proposal to settle a racketeering suit that contends there is mob-sponsored corruption in the nation's largest union and that seeks to oust its top officials, union sources said.
LEAD: ''A PEOPLE'S CONTEST'' The Union and Civil War, 1861-1865. By Phillip Shaw Paludan. Illustrated. 486 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $27.95.

LEAD: A FEW months ago I had a mastectomy, but three weeks after that I celebrated. ''No chemotherapy needed,'' said my doctor, the department head of breast surgery at one of New York's major hospitals. ''No lymph nodes were involved, according to pathology, so you're home free on that score.''
LEAD: HONG KONG By Jan Morris. Illustrated. 359 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95.
LEAD: The last time the Utah Jazz saw the Knicks was on Dec. 15 at Madison Square Garden.

LEAD: It WAS 90 MINUTES TO CURTAIN TIME the other evening in the stately 104-year-old Comedy Theater on Panton Street, where Lee Blessing's two-character drama, ''A Walk in the Woods,'' has been playing since the first week in November. Here, the cast is Anglo-American. Early last year the play had modest success with an all-American cast on Broadway at the Booth Theater.

LEAD: THE PERFECT COLLAGE, LIKE the perfect crime, is the one that goes undetected. Almost anyone who takes a little trouble can put two unrelated images together with an effect that is amusing or disturbing (or both). It is the privilege of genius to suggest - as Max Ernst was able to do over a period of more than 50 years - that the wildest of incongruities can bespeak both a higher logic and a successful reordering of the experiences of every day.
LEAD: BUYERS who get used to using credit cards also get used to just signing for their purchases. Then the bills come.

LEAD: A human rights organization based in New York said today that while Cuba has improved its prisons and permitted some dissident groups to form, it continues to commit ''serious violations of human rights that victimize the whole Cuban population.''

LEAD: Some offices today are becoming homier. Credenzas are replacing metal filing cabinets, round meeting tables are replacing square ones, and sofas and coffee tables are preferred to clusters of chairs. Some offices even have fireplaces.

LEAD: LAST summer, Thomas Mazuzan became the first man to cross Lake Ontario and Lake Erie alone in a canoe. Now he is mapping out plans for solo crossings of Lake Michigan and Lake Huron this summer and Lake Superior in 1990.

LEAD: Mary Rogers and Richard Saltonstall Auchincloss Jr. were married yesterday at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Philadelphia. The Rev. Sharline Fulton performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Rudolph Moore.

LEAD: Dr. Elizabeth Ann Rudey, a professor of ceramic arts at Long Island University, and Kirk Arthur Ruebenson, a graphic arts cameraman for Quad Rite in New York, were married yesterday at the Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y. Cantor Raymond Smolover officiated.
LEAD: THE Soviet Union is not the same place it was when I left in 1980.

LEAD: Ronald H. Brown, a former aide of Senator Edward M. Kennedy and, briefly, the Rev. Jesse Jackson, says he has enough votes to be elected chairman of the Democratic Party when it meets Feb. 10. If so, the 47-year-old partner in a major Washington law firm will be the first black to lead a major American political party.

LEAD: IF you want to do some traveling in Europe - for warmth or for more intense winter - and can move fast, you can get some excellent air-fare buys right now. LEAD: ON almost every distant rock of empire - in India, in Africa, in the Caribbean - Britain tried as it withdrew from its possessions to leave a democratic system as its legacy. But in Hong Kong, which is to be handed over to China in 1997, the British Government is critical of a democratic movement that has sprung up on its own, and it seems determined not to introduce a fully democratic system in the remaining years of its rule.

LEAD: Citing accelerated cutting of redwoods by a lumber company, State Assemblyman Byron Sher says he will introduce legislation Monday to outlaw the practice of cutting down entire stands of ancient redwoods and impose civil fines of up to $50,000 for violations.

He warned his guests, a mix of prominent Democrats and Republicans, that he had heard that the film about a Wall Street

LEAD: THE Democrats who became Republicans after they moved from New York City to the suburbs have found that their havens are suffering from many of the same problems they thought they had left behind.

LEAD: Before Roy and Marjorie Parsell died two years ago within a few months of each other, the couple - both were in their 90's and childless - wanted to make a donation to their adopted town of Madison, Conn. They had moved there in 1972 after Mr. Parsell retired as a patent attorney at the old Winchester Arms plant in New

LEAD: IN 1866, the Norwalk Horse Railway Company was established in a new downtown brick terminal and storage barn. Through its arched bays passed a fleet of red plush-seated trolley cars and the horses that drew them.

LEAD: JERSEY CITY JAZZ Noel Pointer, that charming master of the electronic violin, will join Lonnie Liston Smith, a keyboard musician, Saturday evening for a jazz concert at Jersey City State College.

LEAD: THIS is a good month to schedule commercial tree work: arborists can prune to shape overgrown trees or cut down unwanted specimens that are crowding the landscape; use deciduous tree logs for firewood, but caution on using conifer logs in the fireplace or woodstove. Indoors start seed of impatiens, snapdragons, petunias, fibrous begonias, calendula and geraniums.
LEAD: AS a child, nothing caused me to tremble more than the pronouncement that it was time for my regular visit to the family dentist.

LEAD: WALT FRAZIER: One Magic Season and a Basketball Life. By Walt Frazier with Neil Offen. (Times Books, $17.95.) Although there have been memorable basketball teams led by greater individuals, there may have been no more remarkable combination of players than the 1970 National Basketball Association champions, the New York Knicks, led by their buttery-smooth point guard, Walt Frazier.
LEAD: Trans World Airlines is liable for civil damages to 3,000 former flight attendants who were replaced when they went on strike in 1986, a Federal district judge has ruled.

LEAD: The public might be less concerned over the participation of interns and resident physicians in their care if Dr. Konner had mentioned that morbidity and mortality rates have been shown to be significantly lower in teaching hospitals. This is underscored by the mortality rates for Medicare patients in New York-area hospitals, which were published in The New York Times in December.

LEAD: IN MAPLE HEIGHTS, OHIO, JUST OFF THE highway that leads to downtown Cleveland, at the building with the big red bell tower in front, a steady stream of traffic comes through every weekday morning from 6:30 to 9. Mothers and fathers drive up, unbuckle the baby seats, lift their children out and take them inside to one or another of the long, open, bright rooms.

LEAD: WHEN a commercial tenant watches his landlord disregard the spirit or the letter of their lease agreement, rancor builds quickly. And any landlord becomes equally upset when a tenant tries to withhold rent or sidestep restrictions incorporated into a lease.

LEAD: THIS year's campaign for Mayor of New York may well turn on issues at once daunting and inescapable: drugs, homelessness, the sorry state of the schools and, perhaps foremost, the persona of the three-term incumbent, Edward I. Koch.

LEAD: Literary Impact When Malcolm Cowley impulsively punched a Parisian cafe owner in the jaw, the effect on his French acquaintances was surprising. He describes this in ''Exile's Return: A Literary Odyssey of the 1920s'' (Penguin).

LEAD: YALE UNIVERSITY will provide a bountiful array this week, starting Tuesday at 8 P.M. The trio of David Golub, pianist; Mark Kaplan, violinist, and Colin Carr, cellist, will play Beethoven, Brahms and Schubert at Sprague Hall (432-4158). On Wednesday at 12:30 P.M., the Essex String Quartet, who hold fellowships, will give a short and free lunchtime concert at the Center for British Art.
LEAD: For the first time since 1950, the world Alpine ski championships, the ski-racing equivalent of the Super Bowl, will be held in the United States.
LEAD: The president of the North Carolina university system has asked four prominent citizens to investigate charges of wrongdoing in the North Carolina State basketball program.

LEAD: The tale that Martha told tumbled out in pieces, bits of a life breaking under an unbearable strain. Her 31-year-old daughter, a crack user and a dropout from a local drug rehabilitation program, had moved her four children into Martha's apartment and resumed her old ways - sudden disappearances, long absences, stealing clothes, appliances, even her own children's pocket money.

LEAD: Say you plan to marry this year and are 28 years old. Count your blessings, because you were born in one of the great vintage years of the century, 1961, and you might want to consider serving some 1961 wines at the reception. Of course, it would help considerably if one of you comes to the union rather well-heeled; a case of 1961 Chateau Lafite

LEAD: Last Monday the Supreme Court made a ruling that invalidated a law in Richmond setting aside 30 percent of all municipal contracts for minority-owned companies. The ruling by the Court cast doubt on other minority set-aside programs in more than 200 municipalities around the country. Four experts look at the implications of the Court's decision for minority-owned businesses.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: To the Editor: Mr. Kunstler's article will invite diverse interpretation, as we discovered while driving south from Fort Collins to Stapelton International Airport in Denver. With more than three hours to spare, we hastily calculated what we thought would be an easy detour west, promising much local color and scenery.

LEAD: RECENTLY, I read an article discussing how adolescence takes longer to go through these days. According to the researchers, not until children reach their mid-20's are they able to properly separate from their parents and accept them as human beings. Since our children range in age from 25 to 33, we know something about this phenomenon.

LEAD: IN 1963, Larry Aldrich put up for auction paintings and drawings that he had been amassing since 1937. Most were European - Picassos, Miros, Vuillards, Dubuffets, a Monet ''Water Lillies'' and an early Matisse landscape - but there were exceptions, like the circa 1949 de Kooning of two women.

LEAD: LOOK AT THE PHOTOGRAPH ON THIS page and you might muse upon the fact that all three men, still in their 20's, were trained in Europe, while the women are American. Yet, all eight dancers are performing in an American company, the New York City Ballet.

LEAD: With real estate prices soaring, many companies with bulging work forces are renovating their offices rather than relocating. In squeezing more workers into a given amount of space, companies ''are packing more punch per square foot,'' said Paul Cornell, the psychologist at Steelcase, which is spending $10 million on a new research and develpment center expected to open in

LEAD: Q. At the end of last summer, I moved a small chest away from the wall and discovered a lot of mildew on the wall. This is not an outside wall (the living room of another apartment is on the other side) and there are no water pipes inside the wall. I no longer keep the chest flush against the wall and the mildew has not reappeared, although this part of the wall does look darker in some spots.

LEAD: Two captions on page 27 of of the Arts and Leisure section today, with an article about movie music, are reversed in some copies. The performer shown in dark glasses is Brian Eno; John Lurie is shown without glasses. The caption on the same page about ''La Boheme'' misidentifies the male singer. He is James Busterud.

LEAD: SHAKESPEARE, ALLOWING RICHARD III to explain the origins of his villainy, had him announce that he had been ''Deformed, unfinished, sent before my time/ Into this breathing world scarce half made up'' (Act I, Scene 1). What could be worse than a birth defect, what tragedy greater than a baby born abnormal?

LEAD: The threadbare woolen jacket that William Luksenburg wore as a prisoner in a Nazi concentration camp has been hanging in the back of a closet in his home for 40 years. This month, Mr. Luksenburg took the jacket out and brought it to the new Holocaust museum being built here on the National Mall.
LEAD: BLIND FAITH By Joe McGinniss. Illustrated. 381 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $21.95.
LEAD: The Israeli Army's chief attorney said today that the new orders for opening fire against Palestinians were not only ''manifestly legal'' but under the circumstances just and fair as well.

LEAD: Lucinda Kingsbury Jenney, the daughter of Judy Atterbury-Jenney of New Canaan, Conn., and La Madera, N.M., and Ralph Royal Jenney of McLean, Va., and Edgartown, Mass., was married yesterday to John Henry Swanger 3d, a son of Julianne Clarke of Chester Springs, Pa., and Mr. Swanger Jr. of Lancaster, Pa.

LEAD: BULL DURHAM Starring Kevin Costner and Susan Sarandon (in photo), Tim Robbins, Trey Wilson, Robert Wuhl. Directed by Ron Shelton. 1988. Orion Home Video. 108 minutes. $89.98. Closed captioned. Rated R.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Emannuel M. Somers of Sands Point, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter Angela Jennifer Somers to Thomas Lawrence DiGaloma, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence R. DiGaloma of San Francisco. The couple plan to marry in June.

LEAD: A report last Sunday about the marriage of Barbara Ethel Otten and Bruce Edward Hood misstated the bridegroom's occupation. He is a partner, not an associate, in the New York law firm of Sann & Howe.

LEAD: Among the many applause lines in Mayor Edward I. Koch's State of the City Message last week was this: ''No one should turn away from the plight of the homeless. But neither should the homeless turn public streets, parks and buildings into de facto shelters. Under such a system no one is helped, nothing improves.
LEAD: Medicare is paying an average of about $60 million a year for mechanized lounge chairs that have questionable medical value, a draft report by the Department of Health and Human Services says.

LEAD: The last two weeks have been unsettling for the millions of Canadians who fly on the country's airlines or buy beer, paper products or gasoline. A spate of billion-dollar takeovers and mergers has swept these four important industries, threatening thousands of jobs and reviving concerns about the concentration of economic power.
LEAD: As Time Inc. positions itself to compete in the 1990's with communications empires like those of Rupert Murdoch and Robert Maxwell, books are playing an increasingly important role.

LEAD: I HAVEN'T checked it out completely, but if the Cleveland Cavaliers, who currently sport the best record in the National Basketball Association, go on to win the league title, then Wayne Embry will hold a singular distinction.

LEAD: In observance of Black History Month, the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West and 79th Street, is to present in February a series of programs on the cultural diversity of Africans and their descendants in the United States and the Caribbean. The series is to begin with ''Jazz Celebration,'' a concert by the Composers Workshop Ensemble, on Wednesday at 7:30 P.M.

LEAD: After 10 months of pretrial legal battles, Oliver L. North, the former marine who helped finance a guerrilla war in Nicaragua through arms sales to Iran, is scheduled to go on trial Tuesday on 12 criminal charges stemming from his activities.

LEAD: A. B. Yehoshua's new novel, ''Five Seasons,'' begins at 4 o'clock one autumn morning in the bedroom of an apartment in Haifa, Israel, as a middle-aged Israeli named Molkho watches his wife die after a seven-year struggle with cancer. The book, which has been a best seller in Israel and has recently been published to critical praise in the United States, follows

LEAD: President Bush will seek only a small increase in money for drug enforcement over Ronald Reagan's final budget, a rise that would fall short of the amount being sought in Congress, Administration officials said today.
LEAD: rrA new ski binding designed with a sliding heel is in the wings for the downhill ski market next season.
LEAD: Britain's merchandise trade deficit narrowed in December to $:1.66 billion, or about $2.92 billion, the Government said Friday.

LEAD: In the last decade, occupations ranging from steelworker to stockbroker have been transformed by the relentless application of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's free-market principles. But few of the changes have been so sweeping or created such an uproar as the Government's proposals last week to overhaul the legal profession.

LEAD: The thicket of microphones was off-putting at first, and the gold-and-silver costumes looked a little garish. The atmosphere on stage seemed placid to the point of noninvolvement with the audience and the material. But Odadaa, a company of 11 musicians, dancers and singers from Ghana, soon proved irresistible and its performance on Saturday night at Symphony Space was far too short a visit to New York City.

LEAD: It is an elite Washington club open to men only and with a number of political heavyweights as members, a tradition of tongue-in-cheek humor and a motto that in Latin translates roughly, ''He who picks up the check is blessed.''
LEAD: The stock market, which has tended to take its cue from interest rates since the 1987 crash, may now be a major source of strength for the credit markets, some analysts contend.

LEAD: A security guard and a cleaning aide at the Metropolitan Hospital Center in Manhattan were suspended without pay last week after a psychiatric patient there said they had sexually assaulted her, a spokeswoman for the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation said yesterday.
LEAD: Bankers and members of Congress criticized the Bush Administration today for insisting that a fee on deposits remains an option to rescue the savings and loan industry.
LEAD: Back on the South Side of Chicago, where Edward J. Derwinski's political career first flourished, veterans' organizations were threaded through the community fabric.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Orders for American-made machine tools, bolstered by continuing strength in foreign demand, rose 13.4 percent in December, to $316.4 million, according to a report to be released today by the industry's trade association.

LEAD: The New York City Ballet is presenting ''The N.Y.C.B. at 40,'' a series of seminars this month and in February, on aspects of the creative process. Robert Gottlieb, editor of The New Yorker, will serve as moderator this evening for ''Muscles and Memory.''

LEAD: An article on Dec. 20 about racial discrimination in the Navy erroneously characterized, in some copies, the jobs open 30 years ago to minority sailors. They served in a variety of jobs, not solely as mess stewards.

LEAD: The Panchen Lama, Tibet's most important spiritual leader after the Dalai Lama and a crucial figure in China's policy toward the region, died Saturday night during a visit to Tibet, China announced today. He was 50 years old. The official news organizations reported that he had died of a heart attack in his residence in Shigatse, now usually spelled Xigaze, the largest city in Tibet outside the capital, Lhasa.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Robert LeRoy Knudsen, a White House photographer from 1946 until 1974, died of a heart attack Friday at the Bethesda Naval Hospital in Maryland. He was 61 years old and lived in Annandale, Va.
LEAD: Confined to a former X-ray clinic hardly larger than a one-car garage, New York City drug counselors wait, sometimes all day, for intravenous drug addicts who come to get clean needles.
LEAD: In a baby boom of unusual complexity, thousands of lesbians around the country are having children.
LEAD: The Modern World Ten Great Writers By Malcolm Bradbury Illustrated. 294 pages. Viking. $18.95.
LEAD: A year ago executives at Spain's top seven banks had one concern: that merger fever could make them all takeover targets.

LEAD: A Lehman College freshman and three other people were shot and their throats were slit in a quadruple murder in a grocery store in the northeastern section of the Bronx early yesterday morning, the police said.

LEAD: Mayor Edward I. Koch said yesterday that his preliminary spending plan for the coming fiscal year calls for the layoff of 1,200 municipal employees and significant attrition in New York City's uniform services.

LEAD: Municipal elections in West Berlin today dealt a blow to the governing center-right coalition, while a small extreme-right party led by a former SS officer made an unexpectedly strong showing to gain its first parliamentary seats.

LEAD: The Government program to clean up toxic wastes relies too much on outside contractors, many of whom are making hefty profits while Government supervisors remain underpaid, understaffed and underqualified, a Congressional study says.

LEAD: QUESTION: With Tommy John released by the Yankees and seemingly out of baseball, is Nolan Ryan the last player in the major leagues who played in the 1960's and has a chance to play in the 1990's?

LEAD: Leading figures in the 1962 Cuban missile crisis ended an unusual meeting here this weekend having resolved some of the mysteries about that autumn of nuclear brinksmanship, but having added at least one puzzle: Did Fidel Castro urge Nikita S. Khrushchev to fire nuclear weapons at the United States?

LEAD: ABOUT 20 minutes after his team defeated Georgetown, 82-80, in the Superdome, Chris Jackson sat in a crowded room answering questions about his 26-point performance and L.S.U.'s exhilarating upset victory.

LEAD: An 11-year-old boy and a 24-year-old woman died of smoke inhalation yesterday morning in a small fire at their house in Brooklyn, the police said, but they were not discovered until family members went upstairs to awaken them for church.

LEAD: Representative Thomas A. Luken, Democrat of Ohio, who has helped lead the legislative battle against cigarette advertising, has announced an investigation of tobacco product placements in Hollywood movies.

LEAD: LAST spring, a melancholy feeling swept over this city like an unexpected, stubborn chinook. The Olympics had packed up and gone, leaving a lot of suddenly vacant hotels and a generally empty atmosphere of anticlimax. Worse, the Flames had been routed from the National Hockey League playoffs by their deeply resented rivals to the north, the Edmonton

LEAD: GOING for a walk is an easy way for a sedentary person to start a fitness routine, but sooner or later it will be raining or snowing, or it will be too hot or too cold, or there will be too much traffic. Any excuse not to go out will suffice.

LEAD: In the search for new ideas in publishing, Burke's Peerage Ltd., the 163-year-old chronicler of British nobility, with its hoary gaze on a gilded past, would appear to be the last place to look. But try this one from Harold Brooks-Baker, publishing director of Burke's: books peppered with advertisements.

LEAD: Warren E. Burger, who stepped down as Chief Justice of the United States in 1986 and has not heard a case since, stands to receive a $60,000-a-year raise because he chose to become a senior judge when he retired.

LEAD: ''Working Girl,'' a corporate Cinderella story, won four Golden Globe awards including the one for best comedy film, and ''Rain Man'' won two, including best dramatic film, to emerge as favorites in the race for Oscar nominations.

LEAD: GEORGE BLAKE, the editor of The Cincinnati Enquirer, does not usually count himself among the bettors on major sporting events, but recently he wagered $3,740 that the Cincinnati Bengals would make the Super Bowl in Miami.

LEAD: A West German Foreign Ministry official said today that the Government would thoroughly investigate assertions that Iran had used its embassy in Bonn to arrange supplies for the production of poison gas.
LEAD: A 33-year-old man has been charged with murder in the stabbing death of his wife, the New Britain police said yesterday.

LEAD: The Federal Communications Commission is expected to vote today on a proposal that would place a cap on the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's long-distance rates but would allow A.T.&T. to earn greater profits if it can cut its operating costs.

LEAD: Commercial bank-branch closings in the New York metropolitan region over the last three years have made it more difficult for blacks and other minorities to gain access to banking services, according to a study released yesterday.

LEAD: There is a tradition in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, a tradition almost as old as the sidecurls, beards and broad-brimmed hats that the Hasidic men who live there wear. The tradition is that when someone cries ''Chaptzum'' - the Yiddish equivalent of ''Grab him!'' - everyone obeys.

LEAD: Liszt taught us that virtuosity could be a purely musical tool. To its virtues, Busoni added excess. As a compositional device, excess upends our musical values, and indeed Busoni's music leaves us unprepared and threatened, like passengers who have unwittingly chosen a rowboat in which to face a tidal wave.

LEAD: The wedding of Dr. Susan Jennifer Mandel, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Louis Mandel of Tenafly, N.J., to Howard Robert Silberthau, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Silberthau of Tenafly, took place yesterday in Hackensack, N.J. Rabbi Jack Bemporad and Cantor Kurt Silbermann performed the ceremony at the Stony Hill

LEAD: The talking head has received its share of knocks over the years from television producers and reviewers who hold that programs relying on people talking to the audience or to other people on screen are not making the most of the medium's potential. For these critics, the pictures are the thing; lectures, debates, conversations are throwbacks to radio.
LEAD: Engineers have fixed a leak in a hydrogen fuel line on the space shuttle Discovery.
LEAD: Treasury financings this week are confined to the bill market, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of new three-month and six-month bills.

LEAD: Mark O'Meara, who had not won on the PGA Tour since having consecutive triumphs at the 1985 Bing Crosby Pro-Am and Hawaiian Open, rolled a 10-foot birdie putt right into the center of the 18th cup today to beat Tom Kite by a stroke in the current version of the old Bing Crosby: the $1 million A.T.&T.
LEAD: Jay Burson scored 29 points and 17th-ranked Ohio State rallied today for an 85-79 victory over No. 3 Louisville.

LEAD: Finally we have arrived at the beginning of Cezanne. For years his restlessly still Midi landscapes from the 1870's and 80's have been celebrated for their serenity and resolution. LEAD: Clemson, without six players who had been suspended, gave Duke trouble for much of the first half today before crumbling. Danny Ferry and Quin Snyder led a 32-5 spurt as the eighth-ranked Blue Devils broke a three-game losing streak with a 92-62 victory.

LEAD: As President Bush's aides begin their study of East-West policy options, they can safely dismiss two scenarios for the Soviet side of Europe in this century.

LEAD: When their jet touched down at Kennedy International Airport late yesterday afternoon, most of the Knicks, who had experienced the rigors of a long National Basketball Association road trip for the first time this season, felt relief.

LEAD: A member of a small Amish community who has refused to allow his 6-year-old son to be treated for cancer was sent to jail Friday on a contempt of court charge. The man, Danny Mast, argued that chemotherapy was not helping his son, Amos, who has abdominal cancer, and that the boy has done much better on the ''natural medicine'' like herbs and vitamins that the father learned at a clinic in Mexico.

LEAD: Four months after Gen. Augusto Pinochet lost a bid to extend his presidency by eight years, the political forces that led the campaign against him are themselves divided and feuding over whom to nominate for president.

LEAD: A 20-year-old man was charged today in five sniper attacks on eastern Long Island that left one man dead and three other people wounded, and created fear among residents of two towns, the Suffolk County police said.

LEAD: The Justice Department has asked President Bush to name a Federal appeals court judge as the agency's solicitor general, the Government's main legal representative before the Supreme Court, an Administration official said tonight.
LEAD: When National Basketball Association scouts scour college campuses in search of a center or power forward, their stops usually include Chapel Hill, N.C., Ann Arbor, Mich., and Lexington, Ky.
LEAD: * Everex, Fremont, Calif., a maker of personal computers and peripherals, to Tycer Fultz Bellack, Palo Alto, Calif., with a budget of roughly $5 million.

LEAD: An abandoned rail line here in the Harlem Valley will be converted into a public park under a complicated plan approved this week by New York State, Dutchess County and the private owner of the railroad right of way.

LEAD: A bus packed with schoolchildren toppled into a culvert during a thunderstorm on Saturday, and news reports said today that 48 passengers were killed and 75 injured. The storm had filled the culvert with water and many of the victims drowned, reports said.

LEAD: In New York City last year, 127 children died of abuse or neglect, the second-highest total in the 80's. Mayor Edward Koch insists that the city cannot prevent all child abuse deaths. But what about the recent deaths of Jessica Cortez and Michael Anthony Baker?

LEAD: Kathryn Ann Miller, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis A. Miller of Darien, Conn., and Robert Samuel Zalaznick, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Abner Zalaznick of Great Neck, L.I., were married yesterday at the Landmark Club in Stamford, Conn., by Rabbi Deborah Hirsch.

LEAD: Jay Rosenblum, an abstract painter, died Friday in St. Vincent's Hospital after suffering massive injuries in an accident with a bus while he was bicycling. He was 55 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: In an era when performance-enhancing drugs are used by too many athletes, golf has come out almost squeaky clean compared with football and track. But golf has not been completely free of experimentation with such drugs, according to a study reported in the February issue of Neurology, the publication of the American Academy of Neurology.

LEAD: Gradually the former top officials of the Reagan Administration are taking jobs elsewhere. Late last week the Carlyle Group, a merchant bank based in Washington, said the former Secretary of Defense, Frank C. Carlucci, had been named a vice chairman.
LEAD: Lebanon is sinking ever closer to disintegration in the worst crisis of its 14 years of civil war.

LEAD: Fifteen years ago, with empty land for garbage dumps disappearing, Connecticut became one of the first states to look to large incinerators as a way to dispose of trash. Today, the state is struggling to deal with the consequences of its own foresight.

LEAD: An article in The Living Section on Wednesday about beans described their cholesterol-lowering properties incorrectly. It is the soluble fiber, not the insoluble fiber, that reduces cholesterol in the blood.

LEAD: RUNNING an index fund would seem to be a dull way to make a living. But appearances can be deceiving, and last week index fund managers made big decisions that may have played a significant role in sending blue-chip stock prices up sharply.
LEAD: The political opposition in Pakistan made a strong showing this weekend in the first test of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's leadership since national elections in November.

LEAD: ''Moonlighting,'' the ABC television show, has always tried to be a little different from other television shows by combining action, mystery, romance and comedy.

LEAD: A military transport carrying 18 Canadian Forces soldiers to the United States Army's ''Brim Frost'' exercises crashed late today at Fort Wainwright, killing at least nine aboard, the authorities said.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article Saturday about President Bush's endorsement of a Congressional pay raise misattributed a remark defending the Speaker of the House, Jim Wright. It was another Democratic leadership aide, not Mr. Wright's press secretary, who said it was unfair that ''people have been laying it all at the foot of the Speaker.
LEAD: The United States Grand Prixfollowed the St. Louis Cardinals football team last week and moved from the Midwest to Phoenix.
LEAD: The dollar gained against the Japanese yen in morning trading today, while share prices reached a new high on the Tokyo Stock Exchange.

LEAD: The army released a leading Palestine Liberation Organization figure from prison today in an apparent attempt to promote the growth of a local Palestinian leadership that might one day enter negotiations with Israel.

LEAD: At the Ritz-Carlton Hotel in Washington, Jill H. Pace, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Pace of Jericho, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Albert Harris Teich, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Teich of Forest Hills, Queens. Rabbi Gerald Serotta officiated.
LEAD: You're traveling through another dimension, a dimension not only of sight and sound but of mind. Next stop, the town where Rod Serling grew up.

LEAD: There seemed to be two partisan groups at Carnegie Hall on Saturday evening, when the Cleveland Orchestra played the last of its three concerts there. One group came to hear the soprano Kathleen Battle sing, after which they cheered long and loud, then left the hall in order to avoid hearing the work the second group came for, Edgar Varese's ''Ameriques.

LEAD: Back in 1969, when law 'n' order was a sexy issue, we all had this great idea: Congress would pass and the President would sign a law making it a crime for mobsters to take over legitimate businesses. That new legal weapon would make it possible, we told each other, for crusading prosecutors to break the back of organized crime.

LEAD: Ivan Lendl had two New Year's resolutions: to win the Australian Open and to win Wimbledon. Now he has one. Lendl beat ninth-seeded Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia, 6-2, 6-2, 6-2, today for his first Australian Open title and regained the No. 1 ranking in men's tennis.

LEAD: In each of the last three years, Californians swore that they did not have a potential Kentucky Derby winner wintering in their midst. Most Eastern handicappers agreed with them. Then, of course, Ferdinand, Alysheba and Winning Colors all came out of California to win the last three Derbies.

LEAD: The Bush Administration, barely a week old, has already managed to throw more confusion into the savings and loan crisis. Incredibly, Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady has floated the notion of a ''user fee'' on bank and savings accounts to pay for insolvent savings and loan institutions. Predictably, he scared anxious S & L depositors, who started pulling their money out, and angered depositors everywhere.

LEAD: After a two-year fight to evict Ragtime, a 27-inch-high miniature horse that has the run of its owner's home here, the City Council of this Los Angeles suburb has voted to give up. ''From New York to Nova Scotia, people are telling us to stop picking on the horse,'' Mayor Larry Horner said Wednesday.
LEAD: ALTHOUGH they are far outnumbered by cross-country skiers, there are many who favor snowshoes for wandering in the winter woods.

LEAD: An exhibition titled ''From Seder to Stella: The Art of Passover in the Collections of the Jewish Museum'' is to open next Monday at the museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92d Street. The exhibition, which is to run through Oct. 19, includes ceremonial objects used in the observance of Passover and examples of work by 20th-century artists that was inspired by the Passover theme.

LEAD: Remember the 38th parallel? The New York Korean Veterans Memorial Commission has decided not too many people do, so it is releasing a jolting ad campaign, created as a pro bono gesture by Burkhardt & Christy Advertising. Included will be two television spots and six newspaper ads. The commission plans to build a memorial in Battery Park City to the 53,000 Americans killed in the war.

LEAD: For someone who has set 79 ballooning records, Julian Nott is having a hard time securing No. 80. That's because the 44-year-old British adventurer has an ambitious goal. He wants to become the first person to fly a balloon nonstop around the world.
LEAD: Unless United States District Judge David Doty grants an injunction to stop them, the National Football League's owners plan to institute a new policy on free agency Wednesday.

LEAD: The Soviet spacecraft Phobos 2 today entered into orbit around Mars, bringing it closer to landing on the Martian moon Phobos. The mission is the first in the Soviet Union's program to land a man on Mars in the next 25 years.
LEAD: The Foxmoor Specialty Stores Corporation, which operates 603 young women's apparel stores in the United States, will have two presidents starting Wednesday.

LEAD: At the annual meeting of the United Nations Human Rights Commission opening in Geneva on Monday, the Bush Administration will urge the panel to continue public monitoring of Cuba's human rights record for another year, American officials say.
LEAD: J. T. Moran & Company said Friday that it had reached a tentative agreement to buy control of Moore & Schley, Cameron & Company.

LEAD: Robert William Haymes, a composer and broadcast producer, died of Lou Gehrig's disease Saturday at his home in Hilton Head Island, S.C. He was 65 years old and also had a home in Greenville, S.C.

LEAD: Government and private experts who analyzed close-up photographs of the earth sold by the Soviet Union have concluded they were taken by satellites placed in orbit for military spying rather than scientific research.

LEAD: AT Z o'clock in the afternoon, every day but Sunday, three elderly people gather in the kitchen of a white clapboard house. One of the women mixes herself a vodka martini, using vodka from her bottle. The other woman makes a vodka and tonic, using vodka from her bottle. The man, the oldest at 94, is the only Scotch drinker among them, so there is no confusion about which is his bottle.

LEAD: An obituary by The Associated Press on Wednesday about Alfonso de Borbon y de Dampierre, the Duke of Cadiz, described a court action incorrectly. After a 1984 car crash in which the Duke's elder son was killed, a Spanish court granted the boy's mother temporary custody of the other son. But six months later the court ruled that the child could be returned to his father's custody.

LEAD: A Federal judge in Brooklyn ruled yesterday that a naturalized United States citizen accused in a 1986 terrorist attack on a bus in the Israeli-occupied West Bank could be extradited to Israel. Judge Edward R. Korman overruled a decision by a magistrate who had found the arrest of the man, Mahmoud Abed Atta, 35 years old, was ''impermissible.

LEAD: Scott Johnson is a post-modern rhapsodist. His compositions peregrinate from idiom to idiom, from Minimalism to progressive rock to electronics to snippets of speech to the sweet-and-sour melodicism of Milhaud or Prokofiev. But the music balances variety and continuity, as Mr. Johnson spins out musical ideas in a plausible yet unpredictable succession.

LEAD: Like a lot of small-town newspapers, the Glen Cove Record-Pilot tries to stress the good. If there's bad news, it usually gets played down. For example, last week there was just one paragraph on a Glen Cove man charged with attempted murder. The story did not name the man or his victim. Maggie Polk, the editor, says that in sensitive matters it's best not to.
LEAD: Emily and Brendan are in love. So are Allison and Joshua. Kira wants to be a dancer. They are attractive young people. But most of them love liquor more than they do themselves or one another.

LEAD: Anyone who still needed convincing that the Knicks made the right move last summer when they made Rod Strickland their top draft choice as Mark Jackson's backup got it last night at Madison Square Garden.
LEAD: Two workmen were seriously injured last night by an explosion in a manhole in midtown Manhattan, the police said.
LEAD: The fate of a comatose, pregnant woman has drawn supporters and opponents of abortion to a courtroom here for a case that both groups say could set legal and medical precedents.

LEAD: Money market mutual funds are more popular today than they have been in some time. Investors pulling back from recent volatility in the stock and bond markets have been using mutual funds as a parking place while they decide which investment route to take. Individuals are also using the funds as a savings or cash management tool, in addition to other kinds of investments.

LEAD: LOOK at it this way: there are an unlimited number of dire possibilities. What if a terrible snowstorm closes up the city? What if the supermarket is jampacked and the checkout line stretches to infinity? What if whatever you want is out of stock? What if you have an irresistible urge for soup at 2 A.M.

Investors were responding favorably to its efforts to focus on food and restaurants and to divest itself of unrelated businesses. But with the restructuring completed, do fundamentals or takeover rumors explain why the stock is trading on the New York Stock
LEAD: CAT'S EYE By Margaret Atwood. 446 pp. New York: Doubleday. $18.95.

LEAD: The Census Bureau's bold projection that the United States population could shrink in 50 years may prove as precise as a cloudy crystal ball. Or historians late in the 21st century may look back with astonishment at the accuracy of the forecast.
LEAD: The article, ''Taking a Scalpel to Health Care Costs'' (Jan. 8) prompted an unusually strong response from readers. Some of their comments follow. To the Editor:

LEAD: Giovanni Agnelli, Europe's most famous and most powerful business executive, has long been called the unofficial king of Italy. But it is only in the past year that his Fiat empire, which was on the verge of going under a decade ago, could also claim to have reached kingly heights.

LEAD: Recent charges that Robert E. Peary deliberately faked his assertion that his 1909 expedition was the first to reach the North Pole were based on a ''completely erroneous'' interpretation of a key document, according to navigation experts studying the dispute.
LEAD: Maitland Lee Griggs, a retired carpet company executive, died of heart failure Thursday at Phelps Memorial Hospital in North Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 86 years old and lived in Ardsley-on-Hudson.
LEAD: A TURN IN THE SOUTH By V. S. Naipaul. 307 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

LEAD: FOR weeks, the General Assembly and its tag-along army of lobbyists have trudged through the fog of pre-budget uncertainty, straining for a landmark or a sign that could reveal the outlines of the budget Gov. William A. O'Neill will propose this week.

LEAD: In the four decades since they lost the Chinese civil war, the Nationalists who have ruled Taiwan since then have been animated by a dream that has become a way of life: ''Recover the mainland!''

LEAD: They don't open spring training for nearly two weeks and the Boston Red Sox already have expended a season's worth of turbulent energy. The turmoil that has engulfed the team is, to a great extent, the result of an epidemic of foot-in-mouth disease. As soon as one player contracts it, another supplants him and becomes the focal point of the week.

LEAD: TRUE to predictions, 1988 marked the abrupt end of Wall Street's boom. But it also showed that the metropolitan region's six-year economic recovery still has some steam, especially outside Manhattan. Jobs are still being produced, though much more slowly than in the past, and economists expect growth to continue in 1989, though they are not sure for how long.
LEAD: By JOSEPH P. GRIFFITH

LEAD: The Federal Government has fallen steadily deeper in debt for eight years now, but the sky hasn't fallen. The nation prospers; interest and inflation rates remain subdued. Politicians, financiers and academics now dare to think the unthinkable: Could it be that deficits don't matter after all?

LEAD: When the Warsaw Pact revealed its inventory of troops and weapons this week in advance of the conventional arms reduction talks, it rejected assertions that the Soviet-led alliance vastly outnumbered the North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces.

LEAD: Thank you for printing Helene Verhaegen Buchen's thoughtful article, ''For Food Pantry Volunteers, All Is Not Peaches and Cream,'' about the mixed emotions she felt as she volunteered at a Church Food Pantry [ Opinion Page, Jan. 8 ] . She touches on the feeling many of us feel who volunteer to work with ''the poor.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James P. Barrett of Manhasset and Quogue, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Deirdre Ann Barrett to Donald Gregory Denihan, a son of Irene Denihan of Manhasset and the late Benjamin J. Denihan. The couple plan to marry in April.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: When CBS's sitcom heroine Murphy Brown, a star television journalist in her early 40's, first meets her new, 25-year-old executive producer, she doesn't ask him about his news experience or format plans. She simply demands, ''Do you know who the Shirelles are?''
LEAD: BODIES are George Boykin's business. Just a few feet from his desk and his less-than-flourishing philodendron plant reside the remains of several dozen Long Islanders.
LEAD: Abercrombie & Kent, 1420 Kensington Road, Oak Brook, Ill. 60521 (312-954-2944; 800-323-7308 outside Illinois).

LEAD: Danbury has another new restaurant, Ciao. It opened in November on Ives Street, which is being called Restaurant Row locally, and perhaps prematurely, as there are just two other eating establishments on this short street off Liberty Drive.

LEAD: A RUSSIAN IN HARTFORD A Soviet play with a Soviet director and an American cast will open at the Hartford Stage Company for previews on Saturday, to Feb. 16. The play, ''The Paper Gramophone,'' will run from Feb. 17 to March 18. The director, Yuri Yeremin, who has adapted the work from an unproduced screenplay by Alexander Chervinsky, is making his American debut with this production.

LEAD: The Bush Administration is considering a proposal to move quickly to take control of the nation's 350 insolvent savings and loan associations and place them under the management of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, industry officials said today.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Mets need to add nothing. With the team they have now, they could easily win the Series. But it would be nice to see a superstar like Joe Carter or Ellis Burks playing center field for the Mets. They should give third base to Jefferies, second base to Miller and Fernandez's slot in the rotation to West.

LEAD: LIKE many other rural New Jersey communities, Blairstown whirled through a frenzied period of house building and buying in the mid-1980's. The flurry of activity has slowed now, almost to a standstill in some parts of the market, and residents of this old-time dairy town are adjusting to the not so quiet life after the real-estate boom.
LEAD: Weather forecasters are able to predict with greater certainty today when and where lightning will strike ground.

LEAD: The president of the Carlsberg Brewery in Copenhagen once explained why he was busily selling franchises all over the world. ''Beer,'' he said, ''is 90 percent water. Why should I pay to send millions of gallons of water around the globe?''

LEAD: HAVE you ever taken pictures just after sunset and found later that they come out underexposed with an unattractive shade of green? Have you ever had some of your flash pictures come out darker than they should? If so, you may have been a victim of what's known as reciprocity failure.

LEAD: Pascali's Island Starring Ben Kingsley, Charles Dance, Helen Mirren. Directed by James Dearden. 1988. International Video Entertainment. 101 minutes. $89.95. Rated PG-13. Includes a flash of partial nudity and some violent deaths.
LEAD: THE first of what are to be 11 buildings in a mixed-use complex that has been more than 20 years in the making is expected to have its first tenants by April 1.
LEAD: Guy Lafleur was as graceful and productive as ever in his first game on Montreal ice since the Canadiens eased him into what turned out to be a premature retirement in 1984.

LEAD: A PARADOX comes to life here in Estonia, an example of a life and death question for the Soviet Union. Mikhail S. Gorbachev has taken off many restraints that have held the country back, but have also held it together. Will it fly apart without them?
LEAD: Three of South Africa's white anti-apartheid parties agreed today to end their fragmentation and form a unified multiracial political party to challenge the governing National Party.

LEAD: MIKHAIL TAL of the Soviet Union, who held the world championship in 1960, won the 1988 KRO Exhibition Match on Dec. 23 in Hilversum, the Netherlands, against the Dutch grandmaster Jan Timman. Tal scored 3 1/2 to 2 1/2 in the six-game contest sponsored by Katholieke Radio Omroep and the Interpolis insurance company.

LEAD: ON THE WALL OF GEOFFREY WOLFF'S JAMESTOWN, R.I., living room is an early American portrait of a Colonial matron whose half-smile suggests, improbably, a flinty New England Mona Lisa. Wolff refers to the painting as a ''generic ancestor portrait'' whose subject's ''knowing smirk'' has often made him wish that she were in fact a relative.
LEAD: HOUSING officials - city, state and Federal - say they hope the scheduled demolition of a high-rise public housing complex in New Haven is a further sign that a misguided era is over.

LEAD: It's called a ''murder board'' in the trade, and Dr. Louis W. Sullivan has been getting murdered regularly for the last week. ''Murder board'' is Washington jargon for a mock hearing, where officials who are about to face Congressional questioning train for the event.

LEAD: THE THREE FAMILIES OF H. L. HUNT. By Ardis Burst. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $19.95.) The late Texas oil tycoon H. L. Hunt was one of the great eccentrics of American business - a man who thrived on high-stakes gambling, both at the poker table and in his business dealings. He also played high-risk games in his personal life.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Frank A. Allen 3d of New York and Nonquitt, Mass., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Allen's daughter, Ann Standish Watson, to Joseph Carlton Lipham, a son of Wilma K. Rowe of Atlanta and the late Glynn E. Lipham. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: In a hailstorm at dawn recently, Joan Cusack was sitting with Melanie Griffith in a Winnebago trailer that was parked in the bowels of the Staten Island ferry. LEAD: Since Jan. 1, the New York City school system has violated a major provision of the school-decentralization law: 11 of the 32 locally run community school districts have fewer pupils than required by the state.

LEAD: IN a stirring and honest staging of ''Orphans,'' at the Boston Post Road Stage Company, the director, Douglas Moser, has located the heartbeat in a play that is known - to the extent that it is known - for its visceral sensations.

LEAD: SPIRITUAL CONCERT The Harlem Spiritual Ensemble will focus on authenticity when it presents a concert next Sunday afternoon at the Williams Center in Rutherford, performing such favorites as ''Swing Low, Sweet Chariot'' and ''Go Tell It on the Mountain.''

LEAD: THE talk here in recent weeks has been so relentlessly cordial and civic-minded that it sometimes appeared that the nation's leaders were trying to change a two-party system into a no-party system.
LEAD: Classes resumed today at the police academy where one cadet died and 16 others become ill after a strenuous workout last fall.
