LEAD: WALLACE STEVENS The Later Years, 1923-1955. By Joan Richardson. Illustrated. 462 pp. New York: Beech Tree Books/William Morrow & Company. $27.95.

LEAD: Both pieces on Friday's program by the Royal Philharmonic at Carnegie Hall belong to the 20th century, though the Mahler Fourth Symphony just barely. The newer of the two was the Shostakovich First, written some 25 years after the Mahler and played for the first time in 1926.

LEAD: Katrina Angela Yee, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rowan Yee of Sydney, Australia, was married yesterday to Bruce Rathie, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David H. Rathie of Brisbane, Australia, at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. Andrew J. W. Mullins performed the ceremony.

LEAD: For all the memories of the Panasonic Millrose Games Friday night in Madison Square Garden, few may be more lasting than the closing moments of the men's 3,000-meter race and the women's mile.

LEAD: For the next month, visitors to the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West and 79th Street, will be able to see eight Tibetan monks from the Gyuto Tantric Monastery create more than 25 pastel-colored butter sculptures. The sculptures, or the 15 Chupas, which are part of Buddhist ritual, will be on view for two to three weeks after their completion in late February.

LEAD: SUCCESSFUL building projects elude Westchester developers for 45 reasons, according to Kenneth Nadler, a partner in a Mount Kisco real-estate and development firm. Construction sites are in 45 different jurisdictions, he explained, and each village, town and city has its own say in what a builder can do.

LEAD: The law has become big business. Today, several firms have more than 1,000 attorneys, with gross revenues of $250 million or more. Modern ''mega-firms'' emphasize profitability, productivity and business generation in an atmosphere of competitiveness and bureaucracy. But as these firms grow, some of the values important to the practice of law have been sacrificed.

LEAD: The recent revival and current mini-boom of videodisks was sparked not only by the swift expansion of the disk repertory. The growing popularity of this hitherto neglected video medium owes a great deal to several excellent and versatile videodisk players by Yamaha, Sony and Pioneer. This radically updated playing equipment now makes videodisks attractive to a growing number of viewers eager for the utmost in picture quality.
LEAD: Joseph A. Califano Jr. has a good diagnosis of the Democratic Party's problems, but he doesn't offer much of a cure (''Tough Talk for Democrats,'' Jan. 8).

LEAD: The engagement of Lisa Beth Joseph to Daniel M. Zelson has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, William K. Joseph of New York and Carole Young of Westport, Conn. A January wedding is planned.

LEAD: ''PAUL ROBESON'' by Martin Bauml Duberman (Knopf, New York, $24.95) is a passionate, tantalizing book. Approach its 803 pages carefully; it returns the reader to yesterday's headlines, relentlessly opening and probing old wounds to pursue the larger-than-life story of one of the most significant black figures in American history.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: ST. MICHAEL'S EPISCOPAL CHURCH, at the northwest corner of Amsterdam Avenue at 99th Street, was built in 1891 with an unusual exterior and interior. Its Tiffany chancel and windows, for which it has long been famous, are now being restored.
LEAD: NINETEEN Connecticut communities have finally been put on the map.
LEAD: The Arizona State basketball coach, Steve Patterson, resigned yesterday, just one hour before the Sun Devils were to play at home against California in a Pacific-10 Conference game.

LEAD: For Olga Havel, the wife of the jailed playwright Vaclav Havel, the endless waiting, the uncertainty, the tortured doubts are the same. But she says there is a new quality to the Government's latest attempt to crush her husband's dissent.

LEAD: THERE has always been a trans-Atlantic difficulty, in bridge terms, about the meaning of protection. In Britain the word describes the act of reopening an auction that would be ended by a pass: The idea is to protect a partner who may have passed with a good hand.

LEAD: The Long Island Rail Road commuters can help the homeless in Penn Station. By purchasing a one-way ticket to Woodside ($2.50), the homeless person will now have a right to this public place -- Penn Station -- just as you and I. (Ticket good for one year).

LEAD: IS THE COLD WAR OVER? AND, IF SO, what does this mean for American policy toward the Soviet Union?

LEAD: Over the coming months, viewers of more than 250 stations affiliated with the Public Broadcasting Service will have an opportunity to re-acquaint themselves with the real-to-life dramas of Degrassi Junior High, site of the weekly half-hour program of the same name that has been remolding the pat-a-cake image of what the industry, with at least some sense of paradox, likes to call ''children's television.

LEAD: BY the standards of most functioning democracies, a rise of fever on the far right in times of stress is not a cause for undue alarm, unpleasant as it may be to acknowledge the tenacity of xenophobia and bigotry. But in West Germany the boundaries of political sentiment are still constrained by history and suspiciousness: While a shift to the left raises allied suspicions of a latent German longing for neutrality, a blip on the far right still touches off the ''neo-Nazi'' alarm.

LEAD: The revived Federal investigation of John G. Tower, the Secretary of Defense-designate, has not caused the White House to back away from its nomination of the former Senator, Administration officials said today.
LEAD: State Department officials today reiterated their hope that the new military regime in Paraguay would fulfill its vow to institute a more democratic government.

LEAD: Government officials have disclosed that, in a major policy switch, Brazil is willing to accept international funds to protect the rain forests of the Amazon.

LEAD: I have read Thomas V. Connors's letter (''Ban on Bow Hunting Is Without Logic'' Jan. 22) reacting to mine (''Deer Hunting on Fire Island'' Jan 8) urging a ban not, unrealistically, on hunting per se, but on bow hunting only. But I found myself distanced from understanding Connors's milieu even further by his reference to such weapons' use as a ''logical extension of hunting practices that outdate all but the cavemen's spear.

LEAD: Focusing on expertise rather than emotion, the doubles team of Bob Seguso and Ken Flach clinched a Davis Cup round for the United States today by beating Victor Pecci and Francisco Gonzalez of Paraguay, 6-1, 6-3, 6-4.

LEAD: A Sculptural Exchange WHO says Glasnost is limited to Moscow and Washington? If Peter Marbury has his way, Westhampton Beach and its resort counterpart in the Soviet Union, Sochi on the Black Sea, may soon open their borders to some new East-West understanding.

LEAD: IT is that time of year when pictures of palm trees appear in travel advertisements and cruise clothes decorate department store windows. People stare out from behind frosted windowpanes and dream of being somewhere else. Call it what you will - post-holiday depression, cabin fever, or the winter blahs - everybody feels crummy.
LEAD: The article, ''Taking a Scalpel to Health Care Costs'' (Jan. 8) prompted an unusually strong response from readers. Some of their comments follow. To the Editor:

LEAD: Talking with John S. Reed, the chairman of Citicorp, is a little like standing on the bow of an oceanliner and peering into the distance through a spyglass. There, just barely visible on the horizon, is the fuzzy outline of the Citicorp of tomorrow.

LEAD: AND NOW THE BIG news, strictly from the point of view of grammarians, about the Inaugural Address of President George Bush: he has legitimized and popularized the use of the conjunction >and to start a sentence.

LEAD: From Afghanistan to Paraguay, Poland to Cambodia, it is a time of extraordinary change in the world. Rooted positions are yielding to the logic of history. Might that begin to happen soon in the country that has for so long stood out against change, South Africa?
LEAD: GRAND ILLUSION Starring Jean Gabin, Pierre Fresnay and Eric von Stroheim. Directed by Jean Renoir. 1937. Connoisseur Video Collection. 111 minutes. $59.95.
LEAD: More than 200 Soviet Muslims marched from a mosque through the Uzbek capital of Tashkent to press the Government to take up their religious demands, Tass reported today.

LEAD: REFURBISHED CLASSIC A refurbished film print of ''Gone With the Wind,'' shown at the Radio City Music Hall last weekend, will run daily during the week of May 20 at the Paramount Theater in Peekskill. It is one of a series of twenty-four 1939 films at the theater at 8 P.M. Saturdays and 2 P.M. Sundays for the next few months.

LEAD: ''Comrade Deng Xiaoping believes that the main objective of the meeting is the following: to close the page on the past and open up the chapter on the future. His vivid thought also expresses what the Soviet leadership would like to do.'' - Eduard A. Shevardnadze, on a summit meeting with China.

LEAD: ''I understand too little too late/ I realize there are things you say and do you can never take back . . . .I'd like to reconsider please if it's not too late . . . '' speaks the singer Lyle Lovett in the middle of a song on his new record, ''Lyle Lovett and His Large Band'' (MCA 42263, all three formats).

LEAD: POLAND'S leader and his supporters had to threaten to resign in order to persuade the Communist Party Central Committee to talk to Solidarity. The tactic amounted, a Solidarity strategist said later, to a ''declaration of martial law on the Central Committee.'' But the hard part for Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski may be only beginning.

LEAD: The town of Guellen has fallen on hard times. Rich in cultural heritage (Goethe once spent the night in the local inn and Brahms composed a quartet there), Guellen has sold its one museum to America and its only asset is a broken typewriter in the Town Hall. There is nothing even left to tax.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Should we be excited that year two of the 92d Sreet Y's Schubertiade is upon us? Some think it a Quixotic idea - all the Schubert repertory performed over a 10-year span and in the order it was written. An endurance test? Spiritual weight-lifting? An ambition endearing but perhaps a little foolish?

LEAD: Joseph Califano said a lot of things that I, as a lifelong Democrat, did not want to hear. But I believe his diagnosis is accurate and that full recovery is possible only if the patient has the courage, the determination and the discipline to take the medicine he has prescribed. WILLIAM H. CROOK

LEAD: When it comes to amassing culture, Americans like to collect the complete set. This is the impulse that leads us to sign up for the Book-of-the-Month Club when it offers every last volume of Will and Ariel Durant, or to dial an 800 number when Vincent Price beckons us from the depths of cable television to purchase recordings of all the world's great music on the installment plan.

LEAD: Growers use a wide variety of toxic chemicals on the nation's apple crop to control pests or regulate the growth and appearance of the fruit, but there is sharp disagreement over whether they pose a risk to public health.

LEAD: The German strain of contemporary dance as it has manifested itself in the United States is usually overlooked if not unacknowledged. There is general agreement that modern dance, a 20th-century phenomenon, has been dominated by Americans. But it is also true that between the World Wars, Germany was a major center in the growth of the free dance, as the creative form outside the ballet tradition was formerly called.
LEAD: PEOPLE AND FOLKS Gangs, Crime and the Underclass in a Rustbelt City. By John Hagedorn with Perry Macon. Illustrated. 237 pp. Chicago: Lake View Press. Cloth, $29.95. Paper, $10.95.

LEAD: OUR son was coming home from California for a holiday visit, and as my husband and I drove out to meet him at Kennedy Airport, we heard the news of the Pan Am crash in Scotland. Like many of the friends and relatives of the passengers on Flight 103, we, too, were heading for the Pan Am terminal on that somber, rainy evening.

LEAD: Assembly-line housing is being put up in an unusual condominium project that straddles the Maplewood-Irvington Township border near Newark in Essex County, N.J. The first apartments in a cluster of 14 two- and three-story buildings are to be ready this month, with all 51 two-bedroom units finished by the end of the year.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Gaberman of Fairfield, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter Leslie Sue Gaberman to John Brooks Harkavy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Harkavy of New Rochelle, N.Y. Miss Gaberman, an associate at the Boston law firm of Nissen & Lumsden, graduated from Lafayette College and received a J.D.

LEAD: SEDUCTION BY LIGHT By Al Young. 338 pp. New York: A Seymour Lawrence Book/Delta Fiction. Paper, $7.95.

LEAD: DOUG ROSS, the director of the Michigan Commerce Department, met recently with his counterparts from other Middle Western states, and proposed a kind of industrial disarmament accord. If the other states would do likewise, Mr. Ross proposed, Michigan would stop using local property tax abatements as a lure to entice manufacturers and other businesses to relocate in his state.

LEAD: IN a nostalgic embrace of the excesses that helped shape the Roaring Twenties, builders today are erecting multimillion-dollar mansions on speculation, targeting buyers who want to step into opulent new surroundings without the bother of collaborating with architects and designers.
LEAD: China and the Soviet Union will hold a summit meeting in mid-May to achieve a ''complete normalization of relations,'' the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, announced here today.

LEAD: THERE is nothing like spicy food to take the chill off a gray winter day. From Italy, the American Southwest and from China, the following recipes are simple to make - and a little exotic. They are also light and extremely low in saturated fats.

LEAD: Conflict over Japan's winter whaling expedition heightened in recent days after a Greenpeace environmentalist boat collided with a Japanese whaling vessel in Antarctica, prompting a senior Japanese official here to charge Greenpeace with practicing ''terrorism on the high seas.''

LEAD: AMONG the new crop of Manhattan apartment buildings, none is more striking than the sleek glass giant called One East River Place, which Sheldon Solow is completing off 72d Street at the East River. But as modern as the design may be, the building is in a sense a throwback to the city's distant housing past.

No dropping of the jaw in amazement, no forehead slapping, no tiresome jeremiad about the accelerating tempo of modern existence. But the news did shake him up, I could tell. After all, the Moog in a museum?

But more and more, critics are raising questions about the atmosphere in which these decisions are rendered, given that one party in every case is the agency that employs the judge.

LEAD: The general in charge of the United States Central Command has recommended suspension of combat pay for sailors in the Persian Gulf, Pentagon officials say. The recommendation, under review by the Joint Chiefs of Staff, is the strongest indication yet that American defense officials believe the truce between Iran and Iraq may hold.

LEAD: THE BODY POLITIC. By Victor Gold and Lynne Cheney. (St. Martin's, $15.95.) When art seeks so blatantly to imitate life, one asks, at the minimum, that it be done creatively. In ''The Body Politic,'' a slim novel annotated with fictitious transcripts and official-looking memorandums that attempts to hook readers with its snapshots of power plays inside the White House and on Capitol Hill, it unfortunately is not.

LEAD: In some ways it seems not a decade but a lifetime since the East Building of the National Gallery of Art opened, so entrenched has this building become in the cultural life of the nation. I. M. Pei's crisp, hard-edged palace of pink Tennessee marble, its central atrium a glass-roofed space enlivened by a vast Calder mobile, has proved one of the great architectural draws of modern times.
LEAD: The staff at the Nixon Presidential Materials Project had seen nothing like it. In just a few days last summer, 12,000 requests for copies of the same item arrived.

LEAD: In ''Henry Lumper,'' Israel Horovitz's working-class Massachusetts version of ''Henry IV, Part 1 and Part 2,'' Hal and Hotspur (Harry Percy) were high school classmates. Hal, a star quarterback, fell in love with a pretty cheerleader, who later married Harry. This makes the Hal-Hotspur feud a triangle as well as a duel to the death.

LEAD: The head of Brazil's largest Roman Catholic archdiocese has provoked an outcry in conservative circles here by writing a letter to President Fidel Castro expressing the hope that he will always govern Cuba.
LEAD: Moving Expenses

LEAD: Q. Our clapboard garage is built on a cement-block foundation and is on sloping ground. On one side, the bottom row of clapboards is one foot above ground level, but on the other side the bottom row is nine inches below grade. This is one foot from our neighbor's property line, so it is impossible to regrade the soil.

LEAD: IN THE DIM LIGHT OF MY bathroom, I looked into a vial at a dozen oval, sky-blue sleeping pills. I was getting desperate. At 2 A.M., an emergency-room doctor at the hospital had awakened me to get some advice. Since then, my brain had buzzed without mercy. I tried all the rituals of the insomniac until 3:30, when I pulled out my rarely used bottle of Halcion with the anxiety of someone hesitant to plunge into the unknown known.

LEAD: RICHARD GREENBERG was recalling his first days at Princeton. ''Our resident adviser asked us to sit around in a circle and introduce ourselves. Everyone was saying things like, 'My name is Andy and I just got back from three years in Switzerland' and 'My name is Paul and I just got back from six months in China.

LEAD: Stylistic categories in music may not be disappearing, but they are certainly shifting with a frequency that alarms some and excites others. In recent months, three pianists who emerged from the world of jazz have released records that extend eagerly into the classical arena.

LEAD: Dwarfed by the bedraggled red curtain that covers the faded pink walls of the Hotel Intourist dining room here in the Soviet Far East, a Japanese businessman taps relentlessly through dinner at a shiny laptop computer. Continuing even after a stern, slow waitress flicks an abacus to tally his check, he is straddling two very different worlds: one breaking out of the late 19th century, another hurtling into the 21st.
LEAD: THE Long Island tax structure clearly reflects the overlayered Long Island governmental structure, a lack of foresight and an unfortunate loss for our children.
LEAD: President Ranasinghe Premadasa appealed today for an end to campaign-related violence that has killed hundreds of people and threatens Sri Lanka's first parliamentary elections in 11 years.
LEAD: FINES and tow-away threats hardly faze illegal parkers in New York City. But a garish, gooey piece of paper is making them pay attention, the Sanitation Department says.

LEAD: A July wedding is planned by Jane Lizabeth Mencher and Andrew Robert Gold, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Steven Gold of Princeton, N.J. Their engagement has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Stuart A. Mencher of Bethesda, Md.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THE YEAR OF SILENCE, by Madison Smartt Bell. (Penguin, $6.95.) In the author's fourth novel about depressed esthetes living in the cracks of New York's crumbling underside, an illustrator named Marian kills herself with a drug overdose. In 1987 our reviewer, Roberta Silman, said Madison Smartt Bell has ''an uncanny understanding of the way many people must struggle to live.
LEAD: LENIN By Ronald W. Clark. Illustrated. 564 pp. New York: An Edward Burlingame Book/ Harper & Row. $27.95.

LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Sander Vanocur of Washington have announced the engagement of Mrs. Vanocur's daughter, Daphne Boyer Wood, to Thomas Victor Hicks, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Hinshaw Hicks of Baltimore. A May wedding is planned. Miss Wood, also the daughter of James T. Wood 3d of Santa Barbara, Calif., is a graduate of Choate Rosemary Hall and the University of Vermont.
LEAD: Edward L. Mabry, retired chief executive of the Vick Chemical Company, died Wednesday at his house in Litchfield, Conn. He was 91 years old.

LEAD: A SMALL group of skiers had gathered in the Snowgoose Grille at the base of Big Mountain. It was the end of a full day of powder skiing on the alpine slopes of Whitefish, a small town in northwest Montana. The halogen lights of nighttime skiing shed an amber glow across the lower reaches of Hibernation, a favorite intermediate run.

LEAD: WAIT TILL NEXT YEAR: The Story of a Season When What Should've Happened Didn't and What Could've Gone Wrong Did. By William Goldman and Mike Lupica. (Bantam, $19.95.) There are those who still watch replays of the Mets' miraculous finish in the sixth game of the 1986 World Series or the Giants' drubbing of the Denver Broncos in Super Bowl XXI.

LEAD: As she often does on royal tours, the Princess of Wales mingled with high society and society's less fortunate on her three-day trip to New York last week to promote British products and the Welsh National Opera. There was the glitter of the opera at the Brooklyn Academy of Music and an elegant charity dinner at the Winter Garden of the World Financial Center.

LEAD: During last week's round-table discussion among Russians, Cubans and Americans who, like me, had lived through the Cuban missile crisis, the hope of coming closer to the origins and facts of the event was substantially realized.

LEAD: The grand inaugural get-together is a new Latin American tradition, a way of celebrating yet another peaceful and democratic transfer of power. It is now the seventh time in a row for Venezuela, but last week's gathering for the swearing in of President Carlos Andres Perez was something special.

LEAD: While the AIDS epidemic has spread to most of the world, Africa and the United States have by far the most cases and the widest spread of the deadly virus. The disease is gathering force in Latin America and Europe, experts warn, but so far Asia has been largely spared.

Donald Shoup, a United Methodist minister and an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at the Collinses' home.
LEAD: Major problems still plaguing the Air Forces' B-1B bomber may reduce its expected range and payload capability, says a report issued by an investigative agency of Congress.

LEAD: Beyond recommending changes in old programs, such as affirmative action and school busing, which have achieved more success than he seems willing to admit, Joseph Califano offers Democrats a strange prescription for winning the Presidency: in effect, become Republicans. RUTH MANSBERG Pound Ridge, N.Y.

LEAD: In the short film that accompanied his most recent show of women's fashions, Franco Moschino, Italy's self-appointed gadfly of the runways, publicly tweaked the establishment by declaring fashion ''full of chic.'' Moments earlier, the designer had cheerfully lampooned the existing order, trotting out onto the catwalk such affronts to good taste as a tight-fitting low-cut evening dress festooned with metallicized lampshade fringe.
LEAD: Keeping track of the winners of the annual audio Grands Prix, we reported last week on the top-rated loudspeakers and stereo receivers.

The Rev. John Derek Stubbs performed the ceremony.

LEAD: When Glenn Wong, the arbitrator, awarded Albert Hall a $250,000 salary yesterday instead of the $310,000 the player had bid for, Hall became the second player and the second Atlanta Brave outfielder to lose in salary arbitration this winter. Hall had the same salary last year. Dion James, the other Brave, is the only other player whose case has been decided in arbitration.

LEAD: A recital by the mezzo-soprano Mitsuko Shirai, scheduled for 5:30 P.M. today at Alice Tully Hall, has been postponed because the singer is ill. The recital will take place on May 10 at 8 P.M. All tickets will be honored on that date. Information: 362-1911.

LEAD: ''WINTER storm warning in effect.'' Just the sound of those words coming across the radio or television fills me with a sense of anticipation that makes me feel 8 years old again. And anything that can make me feel that age once more is to be treasured.
LEAD: Several companies have developed systems to bring real-time weather data from the Government's weather satellite to airlines.
LEAD: I CAN'T seem to shake loose the Home Party Syndrome. It's an incurable suburban disease and we all know the symptoms: a big heart, pocketbook, telephone, friends.

Peace of Middletown, N.J., and the late E. A. Twaits, took place yesterday at the Grosse Pointe United Congregational Church. The Rev. David Kaiser performed the ceremony.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Because of an editing error, a review of John Costello's ''Mask of Treachery'' on Dec. 25 misstated the year in which the spies Guy Burgess and Donald Maclean fled Britain for the Soviet Union. It was 1951.

LEAD: THE Tawana Brawley case is a matter of debate again. This time attention is not on the black teen-ager and her contention that she was abducted and repeatedly raped by several white men, but on the two lawyers who represented her.

LEAD: The question of how to reduce the chronic Federal Government deficit is on the front burner. The flexible freeze concept, which I developed in 1978 and presented to George Bush - who was running for President - at a meeting in Kennebunkport, Me., in August of that year. The freeze appeared then - as it does now - to be the most economically sound and politically feasible approach to reducing the deficit.

LEAD: If there is a Catholic equivalent of stumping, John Cardinal O'Connor is doing it. LEAD: A DEVELOPER is reviving plans for a residential development on Oahu that may include as many as 5,000 units.

LEAD: It was with great difficulty that I read William Squadron's article ''Two Lives on Hold'' (Dec. 18). A friend handed me the article, showing me Joan Longer's picture, and said, ''This is the woman who received Tiffany's heart and lungs.'' Tiffany was my daughter.

LEAD: Looking back on the Mets' 1988 season, it is apparent that they had all the tools to make it to the World Series. But superiority at the plate and on the field was undermined by the lack of consistency a championship team needs.

LEAD: An article on Jan. 8 about Shiite Muslim terrorist attacks on Saudi diplomats characterized the Hejaz region of Saudi Arabia incorrectly. It is not part of the eastern province and does not have a large Shiite population.
LEAD: Forty junior high school students from the Lower East Side of Manhattan gave a poignant twist last week to a near-universal rite of passage: the school play.

LEAD: It seemed to be all downhill for Frank L. McNamara Jr. after his appointment as the United States Attorney for Massachusetts in 1987. The Senate Judiciary Committee held up his confirmation because of questions about his income tax returns. Some of his staff complained that his decisions on key personnel matters were politically motivated.
LEAD: The first of what are to be 11 buildings in a mixed-use complex that has been more than 20 years in the making is expected to have its first tenants by April 1.

LEAD: VISITORS from England, Austria and Canada bracket the week at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers, with the pianist Stephen Hough giving a recital there today at 3 P.M. and the violist Thomas Riebl joining the Orford String Quartet at that same hour next Sunday.

LEAD: The founders of an athletic clothing chain and a California doctor were charged Friday with murdering a man in a $1 million insurance swindle in which the dead man was deliberately misidentified as one of the founders.

LEAD: BARRINGTON'S of East Islip does its best. Whether it's a special occasion or a special diet, it comes through. This is a restaurant that's warm, willing and welcoming. When diners call for reservations, they are often asked if a birthday or anniversary is being celebrated. If so, a cake may appear for dessert.

LEAD: A high-stakes cast change is coming to prime-time news. After more than a decade with CBS News, Diane Sawyer is leaving to become a co-anchor on a new prime-time news program on ABC. Ms. Sawyer, who has been a correspondent on ''60 Minutes'' since 1984, and Sam Donaldson, the former ABC chief White House correspondent, are to be co-anchors of a program that the network has been planning for several years and is likely to begin by this summer.

LEAD: Temperatures as low as 80 degrees below zero in Alaska over the last 10 days have wreaked untold damage - causing a few planes to crash, pipes to burst, utility wires to snap and industry to come to a virtual halt. But losses would have been greater, weather experts say, had the state been caught completely off guard.

LEAD: He has been banned from track and field for two years because of his positive drug test at the Seoul Olympics last year, but Ben Johnson is nevertheless preparing to compete in the 1992 Olympic Games at Barcelona, Spain, a report published in Spain said yesterday.

LEAD: ''If a baby wasn't safe from the maniacs in this city, then who was?'' Meyer Meyer, one of the conscientious cops of the 87th Precinct, gets no answer to this one in Ed McBain's gritty new police procedural. LULLABY (Morrow, $17.95) opens on New Year's Day with the double murder of a 6-month-old infant and her 16-year-old baby sitter.

LEAD: EGYPT AFTER NASSER: Sadat, Peace and the Mirage of Prosperity. By Thomas W. Lippman. (Paragon House, $22.95.) Drawing on his years as The Washington Post's resident correspondent in Anwar el-Sadat's Cairo, Thomas W. Lippman provides a dyspeptic survey of the failure of Egypt's political leadership to meet the growing needs of the country over the last 20 years.
LEAD: THE VILLAGE BY THE SEA By Paula Fox. 147 pp. New York: Orchard Books/Franklin Watts.

LEAD: IN a stirring and honest staging of ''Orphans'' at the Boston Post Road Stage Company in Fairfield, the director, Douglas Moser, has located the heartbeat in a play that is known - to the extent that it is known - for its visceral sensations.
LEAD: AMERICANS have an insatiable sweet tooth. Recent surveys show that we are a two-faced nation.

Dr. Ralph E. Brushaber performed the ceremony at the Oneonta Congregational Church in South Pasadena, Calif.

LEAD: FIFTY years ago Westport was known as the ''Hollywood of the East,'' with Bette Davis and F. Scott Fitzgerald making their homes in the bucolic town along Long Island Sound. Today, little has changed. Paul Newman and Phil Donahue live in secluded parts of town, and Main Street, which is lined with chic boutiques, is often referred to as ''the Rodeo Drive of Connecticut.

LEAD: My idea of movie hell is a place where the floors stick, the sound is half a second out of sync, the person behind me repeats every punchline to his companion and the only films to be seen are the kind that get released in January. It's well known that January films have a character that is, let us say, distinctive.

LEAD: The stock market, which has been climbing since the first of the year, last week rose to its highest level since the October 1987 collapse. On Friday, the Dow Jones industrial average closed at 2,331.25. The markets in London, Tokyo and Frankfurt have also risen sharply this year. Financial experts are debating whether this is the beginning of a new, global bull market or just the ''January effect'' - when stock prices rise at the start of a new year.
LEAD: LIKE the ugly duckling, the Pacific yew tree has a new image.
LEAD: The City of Winooski has been denied the right to tax neighboring Burlington for using the air over Winooski.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The New York City Ballet danced an all-Tchaikovsky program on Friday night at the New York State Theater, thereby honoring one of the ballet world's greatest composers. Curiously, not one of the three choreographic works was accompanied by a score specifically written for dancers. Yet Tchaikovsky's orchestral and instrumental music is so rhythmically supple and emotionally expressive that it can easily send dancers whirling.
LEAD: Since 1985, Dorothy Hayden Cudahy has wanted to be grand marshal of the St. Patrick's Day parade for the very good reason that she thinks the honor should go to the most qualified person.

LEAD: MORE than 4,000 miles south southwest of San Francisco lies a tiny volcanic island enveloped in the aura of a famous mutiny: the revolt led by Fletcher Christian against Lieut. William Bligh of the Bounty in 1789.

LEAD: He won't take over as National League president until April 1, but Bill White has already performed his first official duty: providing the Rawlings Sporting Goods Company with the signature that will appear on all National League balls.
LEAD: THERE are no quick solutions to the nursing shortage, but one group is converting ideas into action to try to improve the situation in the county.

LEAD: Vice President Dan Quayle's sharp warning Friday to the Salvadoran Armed Forces to respect human rights was aimed as much at the United States Congress and American audiences as at the army or any officials here, American officials accompanying the Vice President said.

It concerns a Hastings-on-Hudson resident named Stanley Wolfe, who since 1963 has been the director of the extension division of the famed Juilliard School in Manhattan. Mr. Wolfe teaches courses on composition, music theory and contemporary music, and has himself been a composer for more than 30 years.

LEAD: There is something about the Indiana Pacers that brings out the worst in the Knicks.

LEAD: Regarding letters bout Shoreham that recently appeared in yourcolumns, it is demagogic for N. Lawrence (or Governor Cuomo) to compare Chernobyl to Shoreham. Only the major difference is that Chernobyl had no containment vessel. Many Long Islanders are suffering from nuclear phobia, and they will pay dearly for it in increased power costs and increased pollution from more fossil fuel power plants.

You know the people I mean - those tardy trend-followers who have only now discovered Carribbean restaurants, Akitas and high-tech little telephones you can carry into the bathroom. For the rest of us, though, dumping on New Jersey has become extremely unfashionable (or ex-fashionable, which is far worse).

LEAD: MARDI GRAS is invariably associated with New Orleans. However, the event is a regional one and actually started in 1704 in Mobile, Ala., a smaller, more provincial city 150 miles east of New Orleans. As the celebration has flowered in Louisiana, Mobilians have become truculent and defensive about their party, which seems to have abandoned them like an ungrateful son who ran after a painted woman, settling down happily in the sin and carelessness of New Orleans.
LEAD: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan complained today that plans to build new Federal courtrooms in Manhattan were moving too slowly and that the city's war on drugs was sure to suffer as a result.

LEAD: An obituary last Sunday about Martin Popper, a New York lawyer who died on Jan. 27, omitted the disposition of a court action involving him. His conviction in 1961 for contempt of Congress, after he declined to tell a Congressional committee whether he was a Communist, was reversed in 1962 by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.

LEAD: President Bush and his spokesmen continue to express the hope that the Federal budget can be balanced using the ''flexible freeze'' approach that he outlined during his campaign. But at the same time they have shown no inclination to retreat from their commitments to leave Social Security untouched, keep real defense spending constant, and not raise taxes.

LEAD: THE CAGE KEEPER AND OTHER STORIES. By Andre Dubus 3d. (Dutton, $17.95.) The characters in this debut collection of seven stories are not a happy bunch. They include a teen-age girl who allows two boys to sexually abuse her, a waitress who cheats on her Vietnam-veteran boyfriend and a convict by the name of Forky who is not to be trusted handling eating utensils.

LEAD: The engagement of Edith Kupsaw to Dr. Timothy Lee Lawrence, a son of Dr. Ruth Lawrence and Dr. Robert Lawrence of Rochester has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Murray Kupsaw of Warwick, R.I. A May weddding is planned. Ms. Kupsaw, a research psychologist at the Mount Sinai Medical Center and the Bronx Veterans Administration Center, graduated from Brown University and received a master's degree in clinical psychology from Fordham University, where she is a candidate for a Ph.D.

LEAD: As the man who created the diving program at Indiana University, Hobie Billingsley has had his share of triumphs. Now, after 30 years on the job, he has decided it's time to take time to savor them. He announced that he would retire as coach at the end of the season but remain at Indiana as a teacher.
LEAD: THE ''Connecticut Art'' exhibition is the 19th of its kind to be displayed at the Stamford Museum and Nature Center in as many years.

LEAD: 'We came to believe that an illegal underground ''black market'' may exist in New York in the private placement of children for adoption.' - A Manhattan grand jury reporting on its investigation into how Joel B. Steinberg obtained Lisa, the child he was convicted of killing.

LEAD: The National Football League's new system of free agency, which gave more than 600 players the right to negotiate with other teams until April 1, left all 28 teams' scouting departments scurrying for statistics, charts and details as if they were doing homework for the college draft.

LEAD: As the first group of models glided down the runway at the Claude Montana spring show, the murmur of the audience was almost audible over the powerful drench of background music. There they were. Soft shoulders. Perhaps padded a bit, yet rounded. It was a silhouette shift that had been seen in Milan, New York, even London.

LEAD: A coalition of private and public groups is helping to subsidize a $5.9 million development of 48 two-bedroom condominium apartments at the interestion of Grand and Gates Avenues on the edge of the Clinton Hill Historic District in Brooklyn.
LEAD: COME tomorrow, for the Chinese and some of our other friends in Asia, it will be another Year of the Snake.

LEAD: The engagement of Emily Leah Silverman to Dr. Keith Elliot Mostov, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Philip Mostov of Groton, Conn., has been made known by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Silverman of New York. The couple plan to marry in April.
LEAD: In a few days, Michael N. Manley, who challenged United States policies in the 1970's and tried to bring democratic socialism to Jamaica, expects to once again become Prime Minister.

LEAD: Drive into this green and quiet town 40 miles southeast of Manila and groups of men will run alongside your car, banging on the windows, offering a choice of the local attractions: A boat ride to the scenic waterfall or a child prostitute.
LEAD: INTERNATIONAL/3-21
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: IS love lovelier the second time around? How about the first time, the second time around?

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: SOUTH KOREA's leading capitalist returned from his old hometown in the North last week with more than just a preliminary agreement for the first business ventures between North and South Korea. He also brought new momentum for a rush toward rapprochement that is leaving South Koreans both excited and unnerved.

LEAD: LAST week's up-and-down thermometer was especially difficult for plants because, to date, there has been no snow cover, nature's blanket, to protect them. Spring/summer will be wait-and-see seasons to assess any damage, particularly to buds, which may swell in ''false spring'' temperatures only to be clobbered by the cold.

LEAD: FOR 10 years, the Bureau of Consular Affairs in the State Department has been preparing, revising and rescinding informative notices to Americans about travel abroad. These information sheets, or travel advisories, to give them their official name, are based on reports from State Department people in the field.

LEAD: RATHER like the little Dutch boy with his finger in the dike, East Germany's leader, Erich Honecker, vowed recently that the Berlin wall would remain standing for 50 or 100 years since it was needed ''to protect our Republic from thieves, not to speak of those who are ready to disturb stability and peace in Europe.

LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Things are always getting worse. I made that pronouncement the other night after having to fill my own gas tank again.

Mookherjee, vice president and research director of natural products and exploratory research for International Flavors & Fragrances, is speaking about the technique he and a colleague, Bob

LEAD: Emily Rebecca Remes, a lawyer for the New York State Commission on Government Integrity, and Craig Andrew Stewart, an assistant United States Attorney, were married yesterday at the Loft in Manhattan. Judge Robert W. Sweet of Federal District Court officiated.

LEAD: On a cold winter day the fields betray little evidence of the grand scheme. But just beyond the turning edge of the plowshare lies the evidence of a vanished city believed to be the first elaborately designed urban center in North America.

LEAD: Q. Our clapboard garage is built on a cement-block foundation and is on sloping ground. On one side, the bottom row of clapboards is one foot above ground level, but on the other side the bottom row is nine inches below grade. This is one foot from our neighbor's property line, so it is impossible to regrade the soil.

LEAD: He was banned from competition for life after admitting to using steroids to improve his strength before the 1984 Los Angeles Olympic Games, but Jacques Demers, the Canadian weight lifter, will probably not have to give up the silver medal he won in the 165-pound class. That, at least, seems to be the feeling of many

LEAD: The well-written piece, (''Once Again, a Kiss Is Just a Kiss'' Jan 22) was amusing only on the surface. It failed to acknowledge that Americans are a varied lot. Some people are more warm-blooded than others. Ms. Keith should feel free to choose chillier friends. Mildred M. Jeffrey Melville

LEAD: Images from an American-art show: Adirondack lakes at sundown, brilliant apple-green water under a chrome sky. Winter light on snowy Connecticut hills. A tabletop bronze of society polo players, men and mounts tangled, twisting, falling. All bear a single signature: Frederic Remington. Remington? Where is the Wild West of horses and sagebrush?

LEAD: Leading politicians from four Protestant and Catholic parties in Northern Ireland have acknowledged secretly talking to each other since October about resuming a dialogue on ways out of the violence that has killed 2,700 people since 1969.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Next year's gubernatorial campaign is under way behind the scenes, and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo already has a war chest of $4,771,789, according to a report filed with the State Board of Elections by his continuing campaign organization.

LEAD: MEDALLIC art has changed since the first flattering portraits in metal commissioned by Italian princes and German merchants during the 15th and 16th centuries. The American Numismatic Society at 155th Street and Broadway is showing modern examples of the art from around the world. The exhibition will run through April 1.

LEAD: Beverly Joyce Deric and Eugene Francis Cowell 3d were married yesterday. Graduates of Yale University with the class of 1979, they are, respectively, a partner in the investment firm of Amster & Company and a senior associate in the law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell, both in New York.

LEAD: ARTHUR WINOGRAD ended his long tenure as the music director of the Hartford Symphony in April 1985, but on Tuesday and Wednesday at 8 P.M. he will return to the podium at Bushnell Hall. The maestro's son, the violinist Peter Winograd, will make a guest appearance and play the Second Violin Concerto of Prokofiev.
LEAD: A proposal for a $15 million sports and arts complex in southern Vermont was a plan without a home this week as the state's government drew fire over its handling of the matter.

LEAD: At the Epiphany Roman Catholic Church in New York yesterday, Constance Mary Ayars, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. Zeiger of Madison, Conn., was married to David M. LeMay, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michel J. LeMay of Millbury, Mass. The Rev. George Baker officiated.

LEAD: Health officials investigating the circumstances under which 27 babies and five of their mothers contracted the AIDS virus in a city 750 miles south of Moscow have tripled the number of people being tested there for the virus to 12,000.
LEAD: Four sailboats are at sea on a quest to beat the 135-year-old sailing record of the clipper ship Flying Cloud from New York to San Francisco.

LEAD: He may not have been the biggest money winner during his 25 years on the PGA Tour, but few golfers of his generation attracted as many devoted followers as Chi Chi Rodriguez. Now, at the age of 53, Rodriguez has become a big money man on the Senior Tour and has received some high-level recognition, too.

LEAD: WITH plastic miner's helmets atop their heads, 7-year-old Robby Brown and his brother, Danny, , age 6, sorted through their little paper sacks, seeking out glittering bits of amethyst and quartz with professional thoroughness. The boys gained their knowledge of gemstones through visits to the Rare Earth Gallery in West

LEAD: The first year Dorothy Hayden Cudahy asked for the job, the Irishmen said an Irishwoman could not even enter the race. In the second, third and fourth years, they allowed her to run, but a man defeated her each time.

LEAD: At St. Barnabas Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., Irene Victorine Robinson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander L. Robinson Jr. of Greenwich, was married yesterday to Daniel Francis Pallace, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Patrick Pallace Jr. of Baltimore. The Rev. Ralph R. Warren Jr. performed the ceremony, assisted by Msgr.
LEAD: AS mysterious as they may seem sometimes, toilets function rather simply. Most problems can be diagnosed and remedied easily.

LEAD: Statistical signs of strength in the economy heightened anxiety among those worried that the Federal Reserve may raise interest rates further to cool the economy and dampen inflation tendencies. The most startling figure was a 408,000 rise in the number of nonfarm jobs created in January. An increase of about 300,000, the monthly average gain last year, had been expected.
LEAD: Princess Yasmin Aga Khan and Christopher Michael Jeffries, a real estate developer, were married yesterday at the bride's home in New York by Judge Edmund L. Palmieri of Federal District Court.

LEAD: Erik Eckholm's article on river blindness in West Africa was interesting (''River Blindness: Conquering an Ancient Scourge,'' Jan. 8). I had the opportunity to travel some years ago in Upper Volta, and saw this devastating illness firsthand. William C. Campbell and his team, who discovered ivermectin, and Merck & Company, which is providing the drug without charge, are to be commended, along with the international team that is coordinating the dispensing of the drug.
LEAD: The answer to your question is: a ration of humility. S. E. BERGNER Edison, N.J.

LEAD: SPARROWS POINT Making Steel - The Rise and Ruin of American Industrial Might. By Mark Reutter. 494 pp. New York: Summit Books. $24.95. AND THE WOLF FINALLY CAME The Decline of the American Steel Industry. By John P. Hoerr. Illustrated. 689 pp. Pennsylvania: University of Pittsburgh Press.
LEAD: India plans to increase exports of its own arms industry to raise funds to import high-technology weapons systems and upgrade its military forces, the Defense Minister has announced.

LEAD: The Bowery Ensemble devoted most of its Tuesday evening concert at Cooper Union to new or recent music for the flute, played by Barbara Held. But as it turned out, the most striking work on the program was the only one not written for the flute, Bun-Ching Lam's ''After Spring,'' for two pianos.

LEAD: MARTIN, the dream has faded and it is now wake-up time. Twenty-one years have passed and our people are still in the dream state. Still singing, ''We shall overcome'' and still saying, ''We are living the dream.'' I'm beginning to wonder, whose dream are we living? It is time to rise from the world of dreams.
LEAD: In the beginning was the Astrodome, plopped down in 1965 like a wayward flying saucer in a sweltering pasture south of downtown Houston.
LEAD: On-board weather-monitoring computers are enabling captains of ocean fishing vessels not only to sail the safest routes, but to increase the size of their catches.
LEAD: Several Lebanese publications predicted today that some foreign hostages held in Lebanon will soon be released. One magazine said two of the nine missing Americans will be freed.
LEAD: Unquestionably, the injection of a right-handed power hitter to fill the void that is being created by the aging of Gary Carter.

LEAD: SUGGESTING that the economic renaissance Yonkers has been seeking for two decades is approaching realization, County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke and Mayor Nicholas C. Wasicsko announced last week that the largest operator of first-class suite hotels nationwide - Embassy Suites Hotels - is to operate a luxury hotel on the northern edge of the city.

LEAD: COLD weather is an occasion for luxury at N. Peal, the cashmere clothier based in London. N. Peal recently opened its first New York boutique, at 118 East 57th Street, ''the better to serve a 5,000-name mailing list in Manhattan,'' said Nancy Kravette, manager of the store. In addition to sweaters, dressing gowns and shifts, N.

LEAD: DURING the last decade, as centrally monitored electronic security systems were being installed in ever-increasing numbers in single-family houses - about 1 in 12 now has such a system, according to a 1988 survey by Security Distributing and Marketing magazine - they turned out to be something of a mixed blessing.

LEAD: IT is not just the rich and famous who are having cosmetic surgery these days. People from all walks of life are now asking surgeons to fix their physical flaws, big and small, said a Waterbury cosmetic surgeon, Paula A. Moynahan. For some, it means forgoing a vacation or a second car; for others, it is simply a quick dip in the savings or checking account.

LEAD: A siege of brutally cold weather gripping much of the country has delivered cruel punishment to farmers and cattle growers in the Midwest, a region already suffering from drought and drying winds.

LEAD: The wedding of Laura Gimbel Nathanson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Nathanson of New York and Fairfield, Conn., to Peter Thomas Knobloch, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin T. Knobloch of Jamesburg, N.J., took place yesterday at the Puck Building in New York. Acting Justice Thomas B. Galligan of State Supreme

LEAD: The deputy to C. Boyden Gray, the Presidential counsel and ethics aide who has maintained his chairmanship of a $500 million communications corporation, says he told Mr. Gray in November about a White House policy that prohibited involvement in outside business interests.

LEAD: MR. BRADLEY, MY neighbor from across the hall, offered me a ride to work the other day. Not a remarkable occurrence in itself: I'm sure people all over the country are offered rides to work every day. But this is New York City. Not only do people not offer you rides; most of them don't even own cars.

LEAD: Abby Aldrich Rockefeller's American folk art collection - the first ever presented in a comprehensive museum exhibition when it was shown at the Museum of Modern Art in 1932 - is back in Manhattan, part of the collection at least, installed at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

LEAD: An 18-story apartment house is rising on the north side of 86th Street near Second Avenue on the site of a cluster of Yorkville row houses, some part of the Rhinelander development of a century ago. When erected in the 1880's there were six buildings with the addresses 237-247 East 86th Street, but the structures had been modified considerably over the years before their demolition last year.

LEAD: Continuing the discusions of deer population control, Thomas V. Connors (Letters to the Editor, Jan. 22) pleads that logic should prevail in governmental decisions affecting animal conservation. However, he completely overlooks the basic crux of the controversy between hunters and animal rights activists -- that is, the pain and agony caused to the innocent deer.

LEAD: Sunday,'' said our interpreter, ''we are going to a feast at a friend's home in Tbilisi.''
LEAD: An unscheduled meeting of the Communist Party's Central Committee has been called for next week following serious public disagreement among the party's top three leaders.

LEAD: Hale Irwin, the 43-year-old two-time winner of the United States Open title, suddenly blossomed as the big crowd favorite today while putting his way into a tie for the lead during the incomplete third round of the Nissan Los Angeles Open.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Bombay is India's richest and most vibrant city, its capital of entrepreneurship, its fashion center, home to the country's movie industry and leader in the performing arts. The city's skyline resembles downtown Manhattan's, but the high-rise buildings of south Bombay, with their glittering jewelry and dress showrooms, contrast sharply with the hovels and poverty of sidewalk dwellers.

LEAD: IN 1979, as tens of thousands of Soviet troops streamed into Afghanistan, Moscow's strategy seemed straightforward and completely in line with its world view: A bold military strike, reminiscent of moves into Hungary and Czechoslovakia, would prevent insurrection and chaos from toppling a pro-Soviet and Marxist regime.
LEAD: ''A Footstep of Air'' was always one of Eliot Feld's jollier ballets, and Friday night's revival of this 1977 work - the first since 1985 - is a welcome one.

LEAD: Q. Our clapboard garage is built on a cement-block foundation and is on sloping ground. On one side, the bottom row of clapboards is one foot above ground level, but on the other side the bottom row is nine inches below grade. This is one foot from our neighbor's property line, so it is impossible to regrade the soil.

LEAD: The article on Medicare catastrophic coverage (Jan 15) indicates the disaster that this legislation portends for the elderly. On Long Island, where costs are high and more income is required to live, many more seniors than given will have to pay the maximum premium and tax of $3,125 pr couple in 1993.
LEAD: Michael I. Hirsch, an advocate for services to people afflicted with AIDS, died of complications of the disease on Friday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 34 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: Although many seacoast dwellers, particularly those whose locks are grizzled, become apoplectic when there is talk of saltwater sport fishing licenses, some states have them and others are edging in that direction.

LEAD: SOVIET PIANIST On her third private visit to the United States, Valentina Schubinskaya, a noted Russian pianist and composer, decided that it was time to play for the American public. And since it's Long Island she visits - her sister, Tamara Jouraweff, lives in Shirley - East Hampton is where she will make her American debut this afternoon.

LEAD: Claudia Brainard Repp, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Inslee Repp of West Hartford, Conn., and South Pomfret, Vt., was married yesterday at St. James Episcopal Church in Woodstock, Vt., to Michael Tupanjanin, the son of Else Aarestrup Tupanjanin and Vukosav Tupanjanin, both of Glen Rock, N.J. The Rev.
LEAD: THE MODERN SOCIAL CONFLICT An Essay on the Politics of Liberty. By Ralf Dahrendorf. 219 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $17.95.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mrs. John P. Jennings of Mill Neck, L.I., and Howard G. Cushing Jr. of Newport, R.I., of the engagement of their daughter Mary Ames Cushing to James A. Tollefson, a son of Mrs. John J. Egan Jr. of Newport and the late Dr. George A. Tollefson. A June 24th wedding is planned.
LEAD: A dramatic decline in the number of black men in college is raising concern that a gap in social and economic status is opening between black men and black women.

LEAD: The executive stands at the front of the meeting room. ''Regional sales,'' she says, and a spreadsheet appears on the projection screen. When she says ''bar chart'' the numbers are replaced with a graphical representation that resembles the Manhattan skyline.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Harry Palm of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nanci Joy Palm, to Frank Adi Giovannetti, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Adi A. Giovannetti of New York and Dix Hills, L.I. Miss Palm attended Marymount Manhattan College. Her mother, Audrey Palm, is the controller for Il Monello and Il Nido, New York restaurants owned by the future bridegroom's father.

LEAD: Stanislaw Skrowaczewski is to conduct the American Composer's Orchestra in the New York premiere of his own Violin Concerto, and the world premiere of Aaron Jay Kernis's ''Invisible Mosaic III,'' at Carnegie Hall at 3 P.M. today. Also on the program is the William Schuman Violin Concerto. Robert McDuffie is to be the soloist in the Skrowaczewski and Schuman works.

LEAD: People living close to the nation's No. 1 Superfund toxic-waste cleanup site, the closed Lipari landfill, were more likely to contract adult leukemia or produce babies with low birth weights than people beyond one kilometer, a state study has concluded.

LEAD: It's not always easy to tell what kind of game St. Anthony High School of Jersey City has been playing by looking at the scoreboard. Last Tuesday, for instance, it appeared that the Friars, the No. 1 high school basketball team in the country, had routed LaSalle Academy of Manhattan by 22 points, 69-47.

LEAD: If we Democrats follow Joseph Califano's advice, we will win national elections again. Our current Presidential nominating process guarantees Democratic defeat. The process forces candidates to appeal only to narrow segments of the electorate. A survivor of that undemocratic nominating process forfeits the chance to win the general election.
LEAD: FOR the first time in more than five years, owners of prime office buildings in midtown Manhattan are facing higher vacancy levels than those of their downtown counterparts.
LEAD: Island Wedding
LEAD: The No. 1 jinx hit Oklahoma today as the Sooners, in only their second game as the nation's top team, lost by 77-73 to Oklahoma State.
LEAD: The Islanders achieved a bittersweet victory over the Hartford Whalers tonight.

LEAD: Brooklyn is getting its second condominium parking garage, this one in the Cobble Hill neighborhood. A development group has bought a 50-year-old, three-story factory at 187 Pacific Street between Court and Clinton Streets and converted it into 130 condominium parking spaces priced at $27,500, $30,000 and $40,000, depending upon size - an average of about $262 a square foot.

LEAD: Mrs. John Andrew Glendinning of Bellerose Village, Queens, has announced the engagement of her daughter Victoria Jean Glendinning to Tristram Hooper Pough, a son of Dr. Richard H. Pough of Pelham, N.Y., and Chilmark, Mass., and the late Moira Flannery Pough. The couple plan to marry April 22.
