LEAD: The secret of making a successful movie is simple, according to the director Joel Schumacher: All you have to do is find a leading lady with whom everyone falls in love.

LEAD: Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York calls this the Decade of the Child. A blue-ribbon study group now seconds that commitment to children at risk, and urges spending priorities to save the next generation.
LEAD: THE COMING SOVIET CRASH Gorbachev's Desperate Pursuit of Credit in Western Financial Markets. By Judy Shelton. 246 pp. New York: The Free Press. $22.50.
LEAD: THE MEZZANINE By Nicholson Baker. 135 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $15.95.

LEAD: The University of Kentucky, in responding to National Collegiate Athletic Association allegations against its basketball program, will accept responsibility for a package of money said to have been sent to the father of a recruit, The Lexington Herald-Leader reported today.

LEAD: WITH President Bush still promising not to raise taxes and to cut the deficit at the same time, members of Congress are eager to see what he will say about Pentagon spending when he appears on Capitol Hill Thursday evening to discuss the budget for 1990.

LEAD: STILL HAGGARD AND GAUNT FROM his time in the mountains of El Salvador, the guerrilla official put a recording of a Haydn symphony on the stereo and sat down to talk. It was his 13th year of fighting to overthrow his country's government. As Haydn's reassuring tones filled the room, the rebel visibly relaxed, safe now in a nearby country outside El Salvador.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Two young men were killed and a teen-age girl was wounded early yesterday morning when two men opened fire outside a roller-skating rink in Harlem, the police said.
LEAD: HOSPITALS in the county, as in the rest of the state, are struggling to cope with the effects of a prolonged, nationwide shortage of registered nurses that shows little sign of easing.

LEAD: Murray Sockolow can hear the difference. The 71-year-old retired local civil servant in Tenafly, N.J., says he is getting ''10 times more calls'' these days from stock brokers and insurance agents than a year ago. The calls come from tiny independent offices as well as giants like Merrill Lynch and Dean Witter, and Mr.

LEAD: The General Assembly affects the lives of everyone in Connecticut, but until now, there was no way to learn about its history. Now, the past is in easy view, as visitors who stop at the new Legislative Office Building in Hartford will discover.
LEAD: With many questions about the future still unanswered, Paraguay returned rapidly to normal today after Friday's ouster of the country's long-ruling dictator, Gen. Alfredo Stroessner.

LEAD: Diane Ellen Seaman and Eric Mark Schwartz, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert R. Schwartz of Riverdale, the Bronx, plan to marry in March, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Burton S. Seaman of Lake Success, L.I., have announced.

LEAD: The 12-inch video version of the compact disk, which has been marketed under the name CD video for only a few months, already offers a catalogue of thousands of film, music and documentary titles with the high-quality sound, durability and instant access of the regular five-inch CD, and a cleaner, crisper video image than VHS or

LEAD: The runup in real estate prices over the past few years is leaving more and more owners with huge profits when they sell their properties. The tax bill on those profits will be put off for many of the owners when they file their 1988 returns in coming months and show that they rolled the gains into another house.

LEAD: Although hardly a stampede, a growing number of big corporations, including General Motors, American Telephone and Telegraph, Philip Morris and GTE, have been increasing the portion of their pension funds invested in foreign stocks.

LEAD: Roxanna Bodne Anspach and Michael William Devlin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Devlin of Baldwin, L.I., plan to be married in May. The future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Andrew A. Anspach of New York and Edgartown, Mass., announced the engagement.

LEAD: At St. Lawrence O'Toole Roman Catholic Church in Brewster, N.Y., Dr. Beatrice Anne Gray, the daughter of Mary A. T. Gray of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., and the late Dr. Nelson M. Gray, was married yesterday to John Johnson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Gronek of Penndel, Pa.

LEAD: Joseph Califano's talk to Democrats was not only tough, but so cynical it will fail to serve his party in any way. All he explains is how to take some votes away from Republicans. He does not address the larger problem: how to persuade the other half of the electorate - the half that does not vote at all - to go to the polls.
LEAD: IN 1988, the police seized 16,370 guns in New York City, about 9 percent more than the 14,600 they confiscated in 1978.

LEAD: WE were a half tank out of Orlando, somewhere near Yankeetown, heading north for Cedar Key, when the urge for oysters struck. With the top down on our rented red Chrysler, unfolding the road map was difficult. Fortunately, we were cruising through a part of Florida where it's hard to get lost: the Big

LEAD: A recent commercial for the state-run television company here has all the makings of a tear-jerker: a lonely evening, a grandmotherly caller, loved ones living abroad. But just as viewers pick up the phone to reach out and touch someone, the announcer adds a selfish suggestion: Don't pay for it yourself - call collect.

LEAD: A GIFT bestowed on Montclair State College in 1986 is currently the subject of an exhibition in the college's art gallery. It is a small selection of African and Oceanic wood carvings that come from a collection assembled by Paul Wingert, who died in 1974, and his wife, Emily.

LEAD: Some Jewish organizations are moving toward the conclusion that the United States should recognize the big increase in Jewish emigration from the Soviet Union in 1988 by removing some of the trade and tariff barriers imposed on Moscow in the last 15 years.
LEAD: THE HUNGRY GIRLS And Other Stories. By Patricia Eakins. Illustrated. 137 pp. San Francisco: Cadmus Editions. Paper, $8.95.

LEAD: A Federal district judge today found the Public Welfare Secretary of Pennsylvania and his deputy in contempt of court, saying they had not complied with an order for the state to pay for habilitative services to mentally retarded Philadelphians who live at home.
LEAD: In writing off New York ('The Late Great City' Jan. 8), Kathleen Kennedy appears to abandon her effort to 'balance the bad with the good' in the city.

LEAD: Mrs. Marie Oaklan and Norman Oaklan, both of Buffalo, have announced April wedding plans for their daughter Michelle Oaklan and John Michael McFaul, a son of John McFaul of Watertown, N.Y., and the late Mary McFaul. Miss Oaklan, a graduate of the Rochester Institute of Technology, is the director of public relations at Loews Hotels in New York.

LEAD: Lithe and lazy, good at cards and generous with a jug, fast moving when the bad guys act up and easily moved by a pretty lady or a pure-hearted sporting girl, Robert Duvall, a narrow smile glinting when he drawls an amiable put-down of a dim companion, ambles through ''Lonesome Dove'' as to the ranch house born.

LEAD: In percent Tax-Exempt Bonds 7.29 Bond Buyer 20-Bond Index Money Market Funds 8.76 Donoghue's Money Fund 7-Day Compound Yield Bank Money Market Accounts 6.33 Bank Rate Monitor Home Mortgage 10.55 Federal Home Loan Bank, national average Unsecured Personal Loans Minimum fixed rate, 3-year maturity Chase Manhattan, New York 16.90 Continental Illinois, Chicago 17.25 Bank of America, San Francisco 21.25
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: After an electrifying sermon that brought the congregation joyously to its feet, Riverside Church elected a new pastor yesterday who promised to lead the congregation and - through it, New York City - to ''release the song locked up in all of us.''

LEAD: A Federal district judge has awarded $1 million in legal fees to a Nicaraguan rebel leader, a former Central Intelligence Agency official and others who had been accused in a civil lawsuit of mounting an illegal scheme to aid the rebels.

LEAD: Italy's public finances, always messy and at times almost unfathomable, have fallen into fresh disarray, threatening the country's political stability and sending shivers through the financial markets in Milan.
LEAD: THE Reading Railroad paid nothing for its place in ''Monopoly,'' but half a century later Continental Airlines paid $30,000 to appear in a new children's game.
LEAD: A man on death row for killing two peo-ple in a shooting spree in Russellville goes on trial this week, charged with murdering 14 members of his family in the days preceding the rampage.

LEAD: Members of the University of Kentucky board of trustees were briefed today on the school's response to the National Collegiate Athletic Association's allegations of wrongdoing in the men's basketball program.
LEAD: GRANT FUHR has never met his mother. He believes he met his father once by chance in a bar, where they chatted and parted once again.

LEAD: Texas, which produces about a fifth of American beef, is putting pressure on Washington to resolve a trade conflict with the European Community over its ban on imports of meat treated with hormones.
LEAD: THE enlarged spleen of John Moore, a seltzer sales representative from Seattle, is vexing the biotechnology industry.

LEAD: A senior leader of the Afghan insurgents said in an interview here today that the 15 guerrilla groups had agreed to form a council and would meet in Islamabad, the Pakistani capital, within a few days to form a government.

LEAD: Science continues to get bigger. The titles tell the story - supercolliders, supercomputers, superconductivity. Unfortunately these superprojects are supercostly. President Bush would be rash, in the budget plan he'll offer this week, to approve all the science extravaganzas his predecessor endorsed.

LEAD: * Turkey and a Canadian-led group will sign a $500 million agreement today to build the first nine miles of a rail system in Ankara, a municipal spokesman said. A fifth of the lines will run underground. Canada's Urban Transport Development Corporation and its Turkish partners, Gama Endustri and Guris Insaat, were awarded the four-year contract in July.

LEAD: Three University of Iowa basketball players were enrolled in drug treatment programs last summer at a cost of more than $16,000, The Des Moines Sunday Register reported today. University officials said that the money came from a general expense fund in the athletic department, not from tax money.

LEAD: Joe Cirella didn't really want to look at the scoreboard that had just posted the result of Philadelphia's game against the Capitals, or at least he didn't want to be seen looking at it. Still, he looked and instantly regretted it, although he also realized that most of his Devils teammates had just done the same thing.
LEAD: An 11-year-old boy has been missing from his home in Harlem since he went jogging along Riverside Drive last Friday afternoon, the police said yesterday.
LEAD: More than two years after Federal funds were made available for a program to improve education about illegal drugs, the New York City Board of Education has yet to apply for its share.

LEAD: The Democratic effort to unseat Andrew P. O'Rourke as the Westchester County Executive was simplified today when the County Clerk, Andrew J. Spano, stunned a gathering of 800 party members at a Democratic ''victory breakfast'' by announcing that he would not be a candidate for the post.

LEAD: Some little dances can seem very grand. That was the lesson the New York City Ballet taught Saturday night at the New York State Theater when the program included works that, though small in choreographic or musical scale, nevertheless created great impressions.

LEAD: Few people know how much United States senators and representatives are paid each year, but that does not stop the majority of the public from opposing the proposed Congressional pay increase, a new Gallup Poll has found.

LEAD: Once considered little more than a source of manpower for New York City, New Jersey is emerging from the 1980's as an increasingly diverse and independent economic powerhouse that in many ways outshines New York.

LEAD: As the oldest of 10 children, P. J. Carlesimo has helped many people grow. That childhood has aided Carlesimo as Seton Hall's basketball coach. When he arrived on campus in 1982, the Pirates' program needed plenty of nurturing.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Jethro Burns, the mandolin-playing partner in the Homer and Jethro country music team, whose cornball humor and musical talents won the duo a Grammy Award, has died at 69 years old.

LEAD: International A2-7 Soviet troops completed withdrawal from Kabul, Radio Moscow reported, and the last Soviet soldiers are expected to cross into their homeland in a few days, ending Moscow's nine-year military intervention. Page A1
LEAD: The Pakistani Government has successfully tested two types of surface-to-surface missiles and may be within two years of producing its own tanks, the army chief said today.
LEAD: The Internal Revenue Service's Tele-Tax system allows taxpayers to call a toll-free number and hear tape-recorded messages on nearly 140 tax topics.
LEAD: The police raided city government offices here on Friday, reportedly looking for evidence of official misconduct.
LEAD: Liet. Gen. Donald Harry Cowles, retired, an Army deputy chief of staff in the mid-1970's, died Saturday at Alexandria Hospital. He was 71 years old.

LEAD: A touring production of ''Giselle' that is danced with the high style and purity of the one presented here this afternoon by the Donetsk Ballet from the Soviet Union is hard to come by. In short, this is a troupe with a beautifully schooled corps, stylistic coherence and an exquisite home-grown Giselle in its young ballerina, Inna Dorafeyeva.

LEAD: Representatives of Western relief groups aiding Afghanistan say that it may take two or three years before the five million Afghan refugees in Pakistan and Iran return after the last Soviet soldiers leave.

LEAD: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, extended his stay in Pakistan by an additional day today after a series of meetings with Pakistani officials on the shape of a future government in Afghanistan.
LEAD: It's been 12 years since he ended his career with the Knicks, so it should come as no surprise that at the age of 45, Bill Bradley is not the basketball player he once was.

LEAD: On the listener call-in line at the radio station KILT in Houston, it is the hottest topic since the bombing of the Marine barracks in Beirut in 1983. In Los Angeles, producers at the radio station KFI say callers will not let the talk show hosts discuss any other subject. And in Detroit, home of the

LEAD: WHOEVER said the unexam ined life is not worth living apparently never intended to go into book publishing, where there is almost no research and where much of the conventional wisdom is a pastiche of folklore, myth and wishful thinking. ''All the maxims are true,'' a former editor has said, ''until books come along that disprove them.
LEAD: Magic Johnson had 27 points and 13 assists and the Los Angeles Lakers broke open a close game tonight with a 21-5 run in the fourth quarter to beat the New Jersey Nets, 134-116.
LEAD: The two leading Spanish-language television stations in the nation's most concentrated Hispanic market are facing an intensified challenge for their viewers from English-language stations here.
LEAD: Contributions to the 77th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund have surpassed last year's record, with three weeks remaining in this year's campaign.

LEAD: John L. O'Grady, the former managing director of sales and trading for Salomon Brothers Inc., died of a heart attack on Saturday while skiing with his family. He was 46 years old and lived in Mt. Kisco, N.Y., and Delray Beach, Fla.
LEAD: An Air Force report on a B-1 bomber crash last November concluded that pilot error was to blame for the crash at Ellsworth Air Force Base in South Dakota.
LEAD: ''Pravda's special correspondents report that on Sunday the last Soviet soldier left Kabul.'' - Moscow radio. [ A6:2. ]

LEAD: The Alabama Retirement Systems, the $8 billion state pension fund, has applied to the Federal Communications Commission for the right to buy WSFA-TV, an NBC affiliate that is the oldest television news organization in Alabama.
LEAD: ''I want you to know I have always recused myself from anything to do with communications,'' insisted Boyden Gray, President Bush's longtime family friend, legal counsel and adviser on ethics.

LEAD: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Feb. 6, 1989: MONDAY General Mtrs Corp Zurn Inds Inc TUESDAY Central Ill Pub Svc Co Diamond Shamrock R&M Emerson Elec Co General Housewares Kansas City Pwr & Lt Co Monarch Mach Tool Co Source Cap Inc

LEAD: Michael N. Manley, the front-running candidate for Prime Minister of Jamaica, called today for the formation of civic patrols to assist security forces in preventing violence on election day Thursday.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Kate Ransom, a violinist, and Anthony Sirianni, a pianist, have been performing as the Highlands Duo since 1984. This year, the players are to become an ensemble in residence at Brevard College in North Carolina, and they are changing their name to the Brevard Duo.

LEAD: Robert Strauss stood with President Bush one recent night on the Truman balcony of the White House, overlooking the capital's gleaming monuments, and told him of the time he had chatted with President Carter on the same spot.

LEAD: Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center's decision to lay off 300 employees was a last-resort response to financial problems that are becoming more common for private hospitals treating poor patients, hospital representatives said yesterday.

LEAD: There was a time, well within the memory of most Americans, when one approached meals with a certain innocence. Provided the roast pork wasn't pink in the middle, one assumed that one was getting up from the table in the same good health as when one had sat down. According to the new wisdom, we were eating ourselves to death.

LEAD: Kent Maury, an affable executive with the glittering new Marriott hotel in Hong Kong, says that when he goes to meetings or parties with other hotel executives here, some assiduously avoid him and others, when introduced, will not even shake his hand.

LEAD: In an unusual move, the Food and Drug Administration is reconsidering its recent decision to require further studies before approving a drug used to treat a pernicious viral infection that robs many AIDS patients of their vision, a senior official at the agency says.

LEAD: In a case that had been watched by business groups and prosecutors around the country, the Illinois Supreme Court has cleared the way for criminal prosecution of five factory officials whose employees contended they were injured by unsafe working conditions.

LEAD: The night George Bush won the New Hampshire primary, he pledged that if he was elected President, when he stood on the steps of the Capitol for the swearing-in ceremony, he would deliver a tribute, four words that had meant a lot to him at the outset of the Presidential campaign:

LEAD: Already assured of victory, the United States still had a couple of points to make today in its Davis Cup rematch against Paraguay. First, the Americans made a point with their racquets, then Andre Agassi made another one with a gesture.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The growth rate of the nation's economy fell sharply in January to its lowest level in two years, the National Association of Purchasing Management said in its monthly report, scheduled to be released today.
LEAD: rrComing up with a new idea in golf clubs occasionally means rethinking the old.
LEAD: Hojatolislam Ali Khamenei, the Iranian President, today dismissed the prospect of an early improvement in relations between his country and the United States.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Joe Morrison, the head football coach at South Carolina and a star running back and receiver in a 14-year career with the New York Giants, died of a heart attack Sunday night. He was 51 years old.

LEAD: Mark Calcavecchia, fast becoming one of the most popular golfers on tour with his long drives and fearless attack on pins, utilized a couple of delicate chips into cups today to achieve his second PGA Tour victory in two weeks.
LEAD: Economic and Social Council
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Not many college basketball coaches have had players with epilepsy on their squads, but Nick Marachuck, the Fordham coach, has had two in the last few years. Both have been very productive.
LEAD: A pit bull terrier bit off a portion of the right ear of an 18-year-old girl who was playing with the dog in the hallway of a her Brooklyn apartment building yesterday, the police said.

LEAD: A 12-year-old Bronx boy died and his father was charged with driving while intoxicated yesterday after the car the father was driving crashed into a divider on the Bronx River Parkway, a police spokesman said.
LEAD: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday
LEAD: The two-week education of John H. Sununu as White House chief of staff has been a tough crash course in Washington politics.
LEAD: Said Aouita of Morocco today won his second race on a five-stop tour of the United States with the sixth-fastest time ever in an indoor 5,000-meter competition.

LEAD: Cuba has an unusual AIDS policy. A third of its population has already been tested for the virus, and the 240 people found to be infected have been put into quarantine. Since no cure is in sight, their isolation is indefinite.

LEAD: Mark Silverman, a producer of independent films, died of complications from acquired immune deficiency syndrome on Friday at the Beth Israel Medical Center. He was 36 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: An article on Nov. 15 about a meeting of the National Association of Scholars reported that many members of the group echoed complaints expressed in Allan Bloom's book ''The Closing of the American Mind,'' which accused liberal arts education and college students of letting interest groups alter the established curriculum and impede intellectual freedom.

LEAD: The Collegiate Chorale's performance of the Verdi Requiem at Carnegie Hall Saturday night originally offered the enticement of Sharon Sweet, an American soprano who has had significant success on Europe's opera stages.

LEAD: Basketball has brought out the best and worst in two brothers at Yeshiva University. The sport has triggered their competitive nature and allowed them to reach great heights. But their competitiveness has also resulted in violent fights.

LEAD: We are, as the Playbill announces, ''in the state of Alaska, in the middle of nowhere'' in Cindy Lou Johnson's new play, ''Brilliant Traces.'' The setting is a wood cabin more forbidding than Charlie Chaplin's in ''The Gold Rush.'' Outside is a howling blizzard; inside is one indistinct occupant, sleeping beneath a bundle of blankets.
LEAD: After a detailed weekend review of the savings and loan crisis, President Bush is expected to announce a plan on Monday to deal with the industry's problems.

LEAD: Gladys Buchanan North, who helped her husband, Sterling North, write popular and award-winning children's books, died of a stroke early yesterday morning at Morristown Memorial Hospital. She was 81 years old and lived in Harding Township, N.J.

LEAD: Ann Berman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mandell L. Berman of Franklin, Mich., and Longboat Key, Fla., was married yesterday to Daniel Feld, a son of Mrs. David Feld of Detroit and the late Dr. Feld. Rabbi David Lincoln performed the ceremony at the University Club in New York.

LEAD: They like to think of themselves as members of ''the people's House,'' and there was, in fact, something profoundly and zanily democratic about the House Democrats Saturday night, dressed up in the garb of the 1950's and 1960's, getting down to the Peppermint Twist.

LEAD: During a descent toward Teterboro Airport outside New York City recently, the No. 2 engine on a Falcon 50 business jet caught fire. The co-pilot, an instructor, quickly shut down the engine, radioed air traffic controllers that he would be making an emergency landing and then brought the airplane down safely using the two remaining engines.

LEAD: The case for cameras in the courtroom could almost rest on the Joel Steinberg trial, all its horrors notwithstanding. By shedding a brilliant spotlight on child abuse, the televised proceedings proved both dramatic and educational.
LEAD: ANY skier who has ever seen a tot whiz by knows that children can learn to ski. But children also learn differently from the way adults learn.

LEAD: Shortly before Phillip Moskowitz was murdered, Federal agents secretly recorded the Brooklyn gasoline wholesaler as he explained to another dealer how the Mafia shared in the theft of perhaps as much as $1 billion a year in Federal gasoline taxes in the New York metropolitan region.

LEAD: ''I got Charlie through the mail,'' Lawrence L. Horsch, chairman and chief executive of Munsingwear Inc., said last Friday. He was speaking about the new president chosen for the company's men's division, its principal unit.
LEAD: China said today that Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, would visit here from May 15 to May 18 for the first Chinese-Soviet summit meeting in 30 years.
LEAD: In the expensive seats just outside the Caesars Palace ring, the faces on the HBO executives were as long as Las Vegas Boulevard.
LEAD: The AIDS virus has reached deeply into the nation's black and Hispanic ghettos, devastating communities and families already overwhelmed with social and medical ills.

LEAD: Chiat/Day said it had reached agreement with the management of Mojo MDA to pay $67.2 million for all the outstanding shares of the publicly held Australian advertising agency. The bid is still subject to approval by the United States Foreign Investment Review Board and by Mojo's shareholders.
LEAD: After a long hiatus and one spectacular failure, Time Inc. has finally succeeded in getting a new magazine off the ground, with more modest expectations this time.

LEAD: Barbara Bush says she fears guns and, despite her husband's membership in the National Rifle Association, favors banning the rapid-fire assault weapons used in a wave of gang killings and the California school shooting that left five children dead and 29 wounded.

LEAD: Gov. James J. Blanchard of Michigan says he will institute a state savings program that will guarantee first-time homebuyers the money for down payments on houses of their choice, regardless of how much housing prices rise.

LEAD: Sixty hours after being overthrown and arrested, Paraguay's former dictator, Gen. Alfredo Stroessner, was today flown out of the airport here that still carries his name and sent into exile in neighboring Brazil.

LEAD: Arthur Ellis, a photographer for The Washington Post for 47 years until his retirement in 1977, died of cardiac arrest Friday at Sibley Memorial Hospital in Washington. He lived in Washington and was 77 years old.
LEAD: Maria Walliser of Switzerland, who won the World Cup downhill title the past two seasons, today won her second world Alpine downhill championship.
LEAD: More than four decades after the ruling Communist Party proclaimed that it had eradicated poverty, recent television and press disclosures of widespread hunger and need have shocked Hungarians.

LEAD: The discourse between two of the most important men in New York City began last week with Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin accusing Mayor Edward I. Koch of divisiveness and bad development policies, and ended with Mr. Koch comparing Mr. Goldin's tactics to Nazi propaganda.
LEAD: Jaren Jackson scored 27 points, but it was stifling man-to-man defense that lifted sixth-ranked Georgetown to a 69-55 victory over Villanova today in a Big East game.
LEAD: Much has been said and written and otherwise observed about the difference in Presidential tone between George Bush and Ronald Reagan.
LEAD: Thanks to Lintas: World-wide, Europeans will have the opportunity to watch locally produced and culturally rele-vant versions of the American game shows ''Jeopardy'' and ''Wheel of Fortune''.

LEAD: The word was out on Sharon Sweet. This 37-year-old soprano from Gloversville, N.Y., had been singing professionally for only three seasons, but in those three she had moved to the top of the field about as fast as one can move in the world of opera. Fans, impresarios and managers from all over the country were lined up in eager expectation to hear her American debut in the Verdi Requiem, with the Collegiate Chorale Saturday night at Carnegie Hall.

LEAD: Every four years, it is suggested in this corner that the new Administration could double the efficiency of its public-relations operations by cutting the Federal P.R. budget in half. This modest proposal is usually reversed by the Government's doubling the budget and cutting its efficiency, but the suggestion is still valid.

LEAD: Columbo is back. His raincoat looks as if it has been slept in for the dozen years since the long-running series about the shrewd and shambling homicide lieutenant met its end. And Peter Falk, tie askew and eyes asquint, still looks as right in the role as the cigar that he occasionally lights but rarely puffs looks between his teeth.
LEAD: John Vanbiesbrouck blamed himself for what happened to the Rangers last night, and he could trace that blame back to the very first shot the Minnesota North Stars fired at his net.

LEAD: As taxpayers begin filling out their 1988 returns in the next few weeks, many will be paying at the lowest rates since World War II. The reason is that 1988 was the first year in which the rate reductions of the Tax Reform Act of 1986 were fully effective.

LEAD: Soviet Muslims have mounted a campaign to oust the Islamic leader of Soviet Central Asia, charging him with drinking, womanizing and excessive subserviance to secular authorities, according to Muslims interviewed here today.
LEAD: Satellite television became available in Britain today with much fanfare but few viewers.
LEAD: The shape of this city's future and the faded elegance of its past are entangled in a controversy that, to some Dubliners, is pitting preservation against progress.

LEAD: Each year, the Solomon Award is awarded to the best-played hand of the year by the International Bridge Press Association. The 1988 winner, announced in Venice in October, was Trond Rogne of Norway for his play of the diagramed deal. The key bid was North's three-diamond cue-bid, which showed a strong interest in reaching game in the light of the previous auction.

LEAD: Two top executives and a former client of the Geographic Marketing Group, which specializes in regional marketing strategies, have acquired the agency from Tracy-Locke, Dallas. Mel R. Korn, president of G.R.G.; Margaret P. Dembowczyk, its executive vice president, and Arthur Broll, a former Pepsi Cola franchise holder, bought the agency for an undisclosed sum.

LEAD: The Chrysler Motors Corporation said today that it would restructure its vehicle engineering operations to focus product development on an entire vehicle rather than on its individual components.

LEAD: For the second time in three months, an organization that monitors white supremacist groups is warning that the movement is being revitalized by the emergence of volatile gangs of neo-Nazi youths with close-cropped hair.

LEAD: WINTER can be a gloomy season at Aqueduct, especially on frigid days when swirling seagulls outnumber the railbirds and flying chunks of frozen earth sting the faces of jockeys unlucky enough to be in the chase instead of the lead. But the cold and quiet haven't daunted Diane Nelson, the scene's latest ingenue and the only jockey here to sport a chestnut ponytail that rivals those of the horses she pilots.

LEAD: Most of the attention this week will be focused on the Treasury's quarterly refunding, which includes $9.75 billion of new 3-year notes, $9.5 billion of 10-year notes and $9.5 billion of 30-year bonds. The week will begin with today's regular weekly auction of new three-month and six-month Treasury bills.

LEAD: The United States Army laboratories responsible for defending American troops against biological weapons are testing potential treatments in China and Argentina, the laboratories' commander has disclosed.

LEAD: Richard T. Aab, chairman and chief executive of the ACC Corporation, a small long-distance communications company based in Rochester, made two announcements last week. The company filled the posts of company president and president of a subsidiary, and it said it has no intention of resuming merger talks it had terminated with the much larger Rochester Telephone Corporation.

LEAD: Along the bustling gold coast between Los Angeles and San Diego, two small but weighty museums of contemporary art are finding the economic climate highly conducive to growth. Backed by the increasing availability of corporate and individual money, the La Jolla Museum of Contemporary Art and the Newport Harbor Art Museum have each hired big-name architects to expand their buildings, and embarked on campaigns to raise construction and endowment funds.

LEAD: Seated on the edge of the stage of the Westside Arts Theater are Kathy Ann Najimy, 31 years old, and Maureen Elibebeth Gaffney, 30. Standing between them is Albert Finney. Albert Finney? ''Our good friend Al Finney,'' Ms. Najimy says, and strokes his head gently.
LEAD: From the outside the old stone castle looks like an Ivy League college building. It is, to be sure, an institution devoted to the learning of lessons.

LEAD: NO amount of skill at decoying or calling Canada geese is of much value to hunters if the weather doesn't cooperate, a fact that was hammered home to me during a special coastal zone season that ended Saturday for those birds in Massachusetts.
LEAD: * Bell Atlantic Corp., Philadelphia, has elected the former Secretary of Defense, Frank C. Carlucci, to its board of directors.

LEAD: Bush's Style: The Personal Touch Representative Thomas E. Coleman and his wife, Marilyn, in a snapshot President Bush took in the Lincoln Bedroom of the White House. Mr. Bush is using informality to ''enfold.'' Page A13. Airline Booking Merger American and Delta will market a joint worldwide reservations system that is likely to strengthen their positions at some airports.
LEAD: A plan by Coca-Cola to re-enter the Indian soft-drink market is being challenged by Pepsi-Cola's Indian partners in a major food-processing and soft-drink project.

LEAD: A memorial service for John Duka, a former style reporter and columnist for The New York Times who later headed a public relations agency, will be held at 11 A.M. Thursday at All Souls Unitarian Church, 1157 Lexington Avenue, at East 80th Street. Mr. Duka, who was 39 years old, died Jan. 21.
LEAD: An island on the island of Manhattan is being planned by the New York City parks commissioner, to bring a touch of Lake Placid to the edge of Harlem.

LEAD: Soviet troops completed their withdrawal from the Afghan capital of Kabul yesterday, Moscow radio reported, and the last columns of Soviet soldiers were expected to cross into their homeland shortly, ending the Kremlin's nine-year military intervention in Afghanistan.

LEAD: Joseph G. Raposo, a creator of the children's television show ''Sesame Street'' and a composer, died of complications from lymphoma yesterday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 51 years old and lived in Bronxville and Chatham, Mass.
LEAD: Four days after it began, the process of choosing a jury for the criminal trial of Oliver L. North indicates some of the strategy Mr. North's lawyers may use in his defense.

LEAD: The Public Service Company of New Hampshire disclosed Friday that it had agreed to pay $2 million to four former owners of the Seabrook nuclear power plant to prevent them from suing the utility over its management of the stalled project.

LEAD: In a bold move to strengthen their competitive positions, American Airlines and Delta Air Lines Inc. announced yesterday that they would form a partnership to operate a global computer reservation system.

LEAD: After all the shouting and threats among the members of a hung jury, the final hours of deliberation in the murder trial of Joel B. Steinberg came down to persuading three jurors to end their holdout against the verdict they would ultimately reach last Monday - first-degree manslaughter.

LEAD: There was nothing tentative or hesitant about Vreni Schneider as she walked across the hotel lobby. This was a supremely confident young woman. A ski racer who had won 10 consecutive slalom and giant slalom races on the World Cup circuit.
LEAD: Israeli troops killed five armed Palestinian guerrillas in a firefight on the edge of Israel's border zone in Lebanon early today, the army reported.

LEAD: A forthcoming public-television docudrama that holds the Japanese Emperor Hirohito fully responsible for the attack on Pearl Harbor has prompted scholars and experts on Japan to denounce the program and call for its cancellation.

LEAD: Horse Racing Nasr El Arab Wins Strub Stakes: Nasr El Arab captured the $500,000 Charles H. Strub Stakes for 4-year-olds at Santa Anita yesterday under Patrick Valenzuela. He covered the mile and a quarter in 2:02 1/5, scoring by four lengths over Perceive Arrogance, with Silver Circus third in the field of seven.

LEAD: Doug Bradbury, coach of the snowshoe softball team from the local lumber yard here and one of the four Bradbury brothers on the team, shrugs at his squad's perennial shortcomings in the town's annual Snowshoe Softball Tournament.

LEAD: Glenna Collett Vare, a pioneer in American women's golf before the professional era and a charter member of the Women's Golf Hall of Fame, died at her home in Gulfstream, Fla., on Friday. She was 85 years old.
LEAD: The cocker spaniel, the most popular dog breed in this country since 1984, remains on top, according to registration figures compiled by the American Kennel Club.

LEAD: ALL we knew about the 22-year-old Patrick Ewing when he was drafted by the Knicks in 1985, the first college player chosen by the pros that year, was that he would be one of the greatest players ever, save the sinking team, and return a lusted-after winner to Gotham.

LEAD: Bruce Phillip, Manhattan College's standout senior sprinter from the Caribbean island of Dominica, easily defended his 500-meter title at the 47th Metropolitan Intercollegiate indoor track and field championships at Seton Hall's Brennan Gymnasium.

LEAD: Criticism of 'Nightline'
LEAD: QUESTION: Before there was a New York Rangers' franchise in the National Hockey League, wasn't there a team called the New York Americans? How successful was it?
LEAD: Coca-Cola discovered what can happen when you tinker with success. Now it's Kitty Litter's turn.

LEAD: It was only a single incident, perhaps even an aberration: the shooting here the other day that left four students wounded and crying for help on the front walk of a high school in one of the city's quietest and most affluent neighborhoods.
LEAD: Led by the United States, major industrial nations may set in motion soon - perhaps as early as this week - a coordinated round of interest rate increases, credit market analysts said.
LEAD: Young & Rubicam has won back the Motorola corporate advertising account that its Chicago office had lost to Lintas: U.S.A. a year ago. The budget is about $5 million annually.
LEAD: Robert C. Maynard, the owner, president and editor of The Tribune, has spent nearly six years trying to cut costs, woo advertisers and improve the long-struggling newspaper.

LEAD: A DECADE ago, Ralph N. Elliott was a forgotten stock market analyst. Then two men of different generations resurrected his ideas and gained growing public attention with the forecast that the 1980's would see a surging bull market, perhaps topping out in 1987 with the Dow Jones industrial average near 2,800.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: ''We're sitting there,'' said a longtime employee of the State Department, ''waiting for the government to start.''

LEAD: CARL ALLEN, a trainer at the Vertical Club, a Manhattan health club, looked out over the people toiling on stationary bicycles recently and summarized his philosophy of getting a sedentary person started on the road to fitness.
LEAD: Tom Fitzgerald's first National Hockey League goal proved to be the game-winner as the Islanders beat the Quebec Nordiques, 3-2, tonight.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Vince Dooley, who retired as the Georgia football coach in December, said tonight that he would not run for governor and would remain as the university's athletic director. Dooley was to step down as athletic director March 1.

LEAD: There are times when a performer seems to own the moment. At Madison Square Garden on Saturday night, the singer Bobby Brown, whose album ''Don't Be Cruel'' has sold more than three million copies and is lodged in the No. 1 spot on the Billboard pop chart, owned the moment.

LEAD: Almost as powerfully as Proust's uneven paving stones managed to do, the following memorandum from President Richard M. Nixon to Mrs. Nixon, written early in his first term of office, recaptures a lost time:

LEAD: After a year studying the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission, a special panel has concluded that the open-ended process by which buildings become landmarks should be conducted under time limits and in a more systematic and predictable way.

LEAD: An old Washington hand, Ambassador Ali Bengelloun of Morocco, has returned for his third tour of duty in Washington. He and his wife, Jackie, were a popular team on their first tour, in the Kennedy and Johnson years, early 1962 until mid-1965. They returned in 1977 for seven years and made their embassy residence popular with dinner parties at which guests dipped their fingers into a common pot of bastilla (pigeon pie).

Make Luck was runner-up in the field of six, 2 1/2 lengths ahead of Dancing Pretense. Socially Informed, the favorite, covered six furlongs on the fast track in 1:09 4/5 to earn $21,600 for James Riccio with his second victory in three starts this year.

LEAD: To some academic historians, Barbara Tuchman was flawed. She lacked a Ph.D., and indeed had not been improved by any graduate education. Unforgivably, her books - at least six of them - were best sellers. But she wrote superlatively, with a strong narrative line, and brought ancient controversies and forgotten leaders back to life.

LEAD: If an expert sits down to kibitz someone he does not know, he can usually tell after one deal whether he is watching an experienced player. But he may receive mixed signals: The bidding and the play may point in opposite directions. In such cases, the play is a better guide. An expert may make a bad-looking bid because of some partnership understanding or because he is riding a hunch, but he is very unlikely to make a bad play.

LEAD: Irene Mattone, a teacher and president of the Queens division of the American Cancer Society, died of breast cancer Tuesday at Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 56 years old and lived in Douglaston, Queens.

LEAD: New York City's Schools Chancellor, Richard R. Green, said yesterday that a Bronx school board member who was accused of bribery in an indictment last month was ''voluntarily'' taking a leave of absence, and Dr. Green commended him for the action.

LEAD: Last Dec. 13, the Klein family of Upper Brookville, L.I., suffered a terrible tragedy. Nancy Klein, 32 years old, the mother of a child and about two months pregnant, was in an automobile accident that left her severely brain-damaged. She has been in a coma ever since, and her doctors don't hold out much hope.

LEAD: Andres Diaz, the cellist who won the Naumburg Competition in 1986, displayed a strongly personal interpretive vision at his recital at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday evening. There were times when that vision was downright quirky, but the cellist's views always seemed deeply considered rather than superficial or manufactured.

LEAD: In the days of crisis over John G. Tower's nomination as Secretary of Defense, President Bush has been gripped by the twin pressures of Washington politics and a three-decade relationship with Mr. Tower born when Texas Republicans joked about holding conventions in a telephone booth.

LEAD: Patrick Purdy, the Stockton, Calif., schoolyard killer, might have inspired national soul-searching about violence in American life. Instead he inspired a bonanza in gun sales. On learning that Mr. Purdy had used a $400 Chinese-made military assault rifle to kill five children and wound 30 others, Californians jammed the stores and within days had snapped up the inventory of such weapons.
LEAD: The New York Stock Exchange has formally opposed the Securities and Exchange Commission's proposal to expand the private placement market and has made some counterproposals of its own.
LEAD: A former financial planner, Henry Gherman, who fled to Asia last summer with nearly $10 million in investors' money, pleaded guilty Tuesday to Federal embezzlement and mail fraud charges.

LEAD: Less than a year after a devastating writers' strike, the movie industry is reluctantly preparing for a potential work stoppage by its 72,000 actors in the Screen Actors Guild. The actors brought movie and television production to a halt in 1980 with a 10-week strike that the industry said cost it more than $100 million.
LEAD: To bolster public confidence and demonstrate that it can regulate itself, the Chicago Board of Trade said today that it would consider a number of changes in its trading procedures.
LEAD: There was a celebration of sisterhood in Washington today as some 50 black women, the subjects of an evocative photographic exhibition by Brian Lanker, gathered at the Corcoran Gallery of Art.
LEAD: An experimental brain operation to treat Parkinson's disease has produced moderate improvement for some victims but not the ''miracle'' that an earlier report suggested, a researcher said.

LEAD: A Somerset, N.J., investor, Arthur M. Goldberg, reported he had acquired a 5.8 percent stake in the Di Giorgio Corporation and said he might seek control of the San Francisco-based food concern. LEAD: Wayne Gretzky, who had just been awarded a car after being named the most valuable player in the National Hockey League's 40th annual All-Star Game, was asked what he planned to do with his latest prize. It was the 14th car he had won in his career, Gretzky said, and he planned to give it away.
LEAD: The University of Louisville has scaled back a policy that put restrictions on smoking to satisfy state lawmakers who threatened to cut the school's budget if the policy remained unchanged.

LEAD: To crack down on penny-stock fraud and high-pressure sales tactics, the Securities and Exchange Commission today approved for public comment a rule that would set tough procedures for brokers trying to sell risky stocks to new customers.

LEAD: The two top contenders in the Democratic mayoral primary here are entering the final weeks of a campaign that seems conspicuously out of character for Chicago: low-key, civil and notably without the racial appeals that have scarred the city's recent history.

LEAD: No one has really figured out the super G. It is a cross between the downhill and giant slalom, shorter than one, longer than the other. When the gates are set, it is very often more of one than the other.

LEAD: NOT so long ago, it was possible to build an entire house with $10,000. Today, according to a 1988 survey by the American Society of Interior Designers, the average cost of a residential decorating project is $68,200. At Blair House in Washington, America's official residence for visiting dignitaries, the decorator Mario Buatta managed to spend $20,000 on a pair of silk curtains - albeit elaborately swagged and draped curtains.

LEAD: The wedding scene that opened Jean-Charles Tacchella's blithe 1976 romantic comedy ''Cousin, Cousine'' was a warmly familial affair, and the one that opens the American remake, ''Cousins,'' is also jam-packed with festive relatives. LEAD: THE blues has innumerable faces. It can be a stomping, three-chord exorcism or a sophisticated jazz excursion; it can be dance music or tormented introspection. It can slip between the lines of a cabaret song or ennoble a rock truism. The blues binds together American popular music because while its essence is unmistakable, its form is flexible - it respects no pigeonhole.

LEAD: ''La Fille Mal Gardee'' has led a charmed life. It was first produced in 1789 with choreography by Jean Dauberval - choreography that was forgotten long ago. But for the last 200 years, other choreographers have been inspired to do their own versions of this ballet, which shows how two young lovers, Lise and Colas, outwit the attempts of Lise's mother to marry her off to Alain, a wealthy nitwit.

United States District Judge Odell Horton said he agreed with the jury's verdict that Kirk was guilty of cheating on his taxes and trying to intimidate a grand jury witness.

LEAD: New York State's highest court refused today to hear an appeal by abortion opponents seeking to block a Long Island man from ordering an abortion for his pregnant comatose wife. Afterward, doctors at a Long Island hospital began preparing to perform the operation on Saturday.

LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said that it had interrupted production at an assembly plant this week, its first such shutdown in years. Bert Serre, a spokesman for Ford, said the plant, in Hermosillo, Mexico, would resume production of the Mercury Tracer subcompact on Monday. The car had been accumulating on dealers' lots, a rare problem for Ford, which for years has produced all the cars it could and sold all that it produced.

LEAD: Browsing in The New Yorker, I find two distinguished citizens expressing faith in the singular American character of apple pie.

LEAD: A table yesterday with a front-page article about President Bush's budget for the fiscal year 1990 misstated differences between some of President Ronald Reagan's proposed spending for the year and President Bush's in the same categories.
LEAD: Depositors at the nation's savings and loan associations withdrew $8.1 billion more than they deposited in December, setting a monthly record, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today.

LEAD: Rosemary Clooney exudes comfort, coziness and serenity, just as her friend and champion, Bing Crosby, once did. If her delivery is not as soft as that of a crooner, she also never really raises her voice. The tone she adopts for both ballads and uptempo songs is warm but matter-of-fact. Like Crosby's, her technical proficiency is such that her singing seems nearly effortless, though of course it isn't.

LEAD: For players in New York City, this weekend presents the most varied program in the annual calendar. Last night, novices played with experts at the Beverly Club, 130 East 57th Street, in the annual Pro-Am event. Today, mixed foursomes with rotating partnerships will play in the Betty Kaplan Team event, and the Swiss Team qualifying stage of the Grand National

LEAD: Although the Long Island Lighting Company emerged the clear winner in yesterday's Federal court decision, officials said that the utility is still likely to agree to a proposed settlement whose provisions are the same as those it was considering when it faced the possibility of multibillion-dollar damages in the case.
LEAD: Barbara Blodgett, one of the few comatose women in medical history to give birth, began a recovery in December that has confounded her doctors.

LEAD: Many thanks to the developer Karl Kehde and the Ohly family for their enlightened approach to land use (''Home Plan Saves Land for Refuge,'' Jan. 15). As a native of New Jersey, I watch the bulldozing of farms and woodlands and wildlife habitat with dismay.

The jealousies and rivalries of a wealthy family on Boston's Beacon Hill.

LEAD: EXPERTS agree that the savings and loan industry's 20-year slide toward its current crisis can be linked in one way or another to the Federal Government's role. Whether the industry was over-regulated or under-regulated is open to debate; few question that it was misregulated.
LEAD: ''YOUTH will be served,'' the English proverb has it, and since 1912 Switzerland has been serving youth through the issuance of stamps to raise money for children's causes.

LEAD: HOMER referred to it as a ''land of 90 cities,'' but Crete today is an island of hundreds of villages and small towns. Of its fabled ''90 cities,'' only three remain, all on the north coast: Iraklion, the modern capital, a busy port city, sophisticated and self-conscious; Chania, to the west, in the shadows of the White Mountains overlooking Souda Bay, and between them, on a spit of rock that curves out into the Sea of Crete, Rethymnon, smaller and poorer than the others, but fiercely spirited, perhaps the best reflection of the complex mixture of past and present that is modern

LEAD: THE winter hockey season is more than half over and the basketball season is approaching its halfway point, but Cablevision viewers still cannot watch either the New York Knicks or the Rangers. Each team is having its best season in years. While talks on the programming dispute have been continuing between Cablevision and the Madison Square Garden Network, Richard Kessel, the mediator, said, ''The bottom line is that nothing has changed and the programming is still not on.
LEAD: People guilty of parking violations here would no longer be considered criminals and threatened with arrest if the City Council approves a proposal by Mayor W. Wilson Goode.

LEAD: The Jan. 8 article ''Theater in the State: A 'Coming of Age' '' ignores one of the most versatile, diverse theatrical resources in New Jersey: the nonprofit, nonprofessional theater. In central New Jersey alone, where our organization has existed for more than 35 years, there are more than 15 such theaters, run by volunteer members united in common devotion to an art form.
LEAD: The Bush Administration asked the Supreme Court to stay the trial of Oliver L. North or risk ''irreparable injury'' to the national security.

LEAD: Additional resources for the International Monetary Fund and a bigger role for Japan in the 151-nation lending agency were projected this week by the chairman of its policy-making Interim Committee, Finance Minister H. Onno Ruding of the Netherlands.

LEAD: ''THE ASSIGNMENT,'' SAYS C. Martin Smith, ''was to design a two-wheeled bicycle. The design was to be market-driven. That is, students would first identify an area of the market,'' and then tailor a design to it. Standard homework, perhaps, for students of industrial design. But Smith, associate chairman of the industrial design department at Art Center College of Design, in Pasadena, Calif., says: ''We felt there was an opportunity to change the way a bicycle was manufactured.

LEAD: How cool is coldness? For the British band New Order, near ly a decade of cold standoffishness, musically and otherwise, has paid off with one of rock's most dedicated cult followings. New Order songs have become standards for college radio stations and rock dance clubs and moved on to more commercial outlets; despite a stage presence best described as efficient, New Order concerts are dependable sellouts.

LEAD: Diamonds are what Gerald A. Browne knows about, and diamonds are what he writes best about, starting with the spectacular caper he dreamed up for ''11 Harrowhouse'' in 1972. In his latest book, HOT SIBERIAN (Arbor House/Morrow, $19.95), the subject again is diamonds - but this time Russian diamonds.
LEAD: Ban on Dishwasher

LEAD: In its zeal to demolish rundown subway newsstands and stores, New York's Metropolitan Transportation Authority ignores the se-curity, convenience and life that concessions can provide. That earns the M.T.A. a big worm.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. John M. Wardell of Bay Head, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Amy Dickenson Wardell, to George Dudley Iverson 6th, a son of Ellen B. MacNeille of Chevy Chase, Md., and Mr. Iverson 5th of Washington. The couple plan to marry in April.

LEAD: It is budget season in Washington and Herbert Stein, one of its veterans, has published a new book about budgeting that should make some of his friends wince. ''Governing the $5 Trillion Economy,'' (a Twentieth Century Fund essay, Oxford University Press) makes the case that the budget deficit is not the primary problem.
LEAD: Back in 1974 the dam across the Kennebec River here broke in a heavy rainstorm, and a section of the river suddenly looked as it did before the dam was built in 1836.

LEAD: THERE are 35 students enrolled in each year of the program at the Center for Advanced Technology in Telecommunications on the Polytechnic University campus in Hawthorne. Classes are kept small, the school said, to encourage interaction between the students and instructors.

LEAD: Although on the surface it would appear that more than a third - about 600 - of N.F.L. players will be free to negotiate with any team between Feb. 2 and April 1 in attempts to better their respective situations, the jury will be out for quite some time before the verdict is in as to how well free agency is working.

LEAD: Iran's President today publicly recognized the existence of divisions among Iranian leaders, but asserted that the nation remains committed to the ''revolutionary ideas'' that marked the birth of the Islamic revolution 10 years ago.

LEAD: Mrs. Chester Alexander of Gloucester, Va., has made known the engagement of her daughter, Anne Stokes Alexander, to Davis Ratcliffe Marshall, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Beverley R. W. Marshall of Gloucester. The couple plan to marry in April.
LEAD: Anna Saminskaya arrived Thursday afternoon at the voters' meeting in the Moscow House of Scholars, a wishful skeptic on the subject of Soviet politics.

LEAD: Computer-aided design and computer-aided engineering, or CAD-CAE, used to be done almost exclusively on powerful work stations costing tens of thousands of dollars. Today, most CAD work is done on personal computers, especially on machines that are powered by the Intel 80386 processor. That chip has enough muscle to display and redraw complex graphics and drawings.

LEAD: G. Van Standifer chose a Tuesday night in June 1986 for the debut of his Midnight Basketball League, a summer program to get young men off the streets and into the gym. But he did not choose the weather. It was sweltering.
LEAD: As the last Soviet military units in Afghanistan headed home, reports relayed from the front today by Soviet newspapers and television pictured an army that was rolling up like a carpet.

LEAD: AMERICA. By Jean Baudrillard. Translated by Chris Turner. (Verso, $24.95.) Tourists, beware. Although the French philosopher Jean Baudrillard has drawn inspiration from his travels around the United States, and has included verbal snapshots of New York City and Los Angeles, Monument Valley and Salt Lake City, his illustrated book contains little in the way of travel writing - that is, the sights, sounds and textures of daily life.
LEAD: Q. I have a stall shower that has tiled walls up to the painted ceiling. Every two or three years this paint peels and flakes and we have to repaint. Is there a special paint I can use?

LEAD: FREDERIK W. DE KLERK, who succeeded P. W. Botha as the new leader of South Africa's governing National Party, rose in Parliament last week to assume the mantle of an ailing leader and call for new thinking. He envisioned ''a South Africa free of domination or oppression in whatever form,'' declared his party ''against domination of any one group by others,'' and added: ''White domination, insofar as it exists, must go.

LEAD: ON Valentine's Day, it's dinner for two. Lavishing care and attention on such a mini-feast can be extremely rewarding, perhaps in more ways than one.
LEAD: A team of doctors here performed an abortion today on a comatose Long Island woman, ending a bitter two-week court battle between the woman's family and opponents of abortion.

LEAD: A man who Federal officials say is a member of the Irish Republican Army is being held on charges of carrying $13,500 in counterfeit $50 bills at La Guardia Airport, where he was arrested last week.

LEAD: THE O'Reilly Brothers Warehouse is something of a one-note building, but the note is exquisite. Now vacant and boarded up, the nine-story structure at the northeast corner of 123d Street and St. Nicholas Avenue is fairly plain, without ornament, but it presents a rich interplay of orange brick and brownstone.
LEAD: A 97-ROOM condominium hotel is rising in this rapidly growing suburb of Burlington, Vermont's largest city, as part of the first phase of the ongoing Lang Farm development.

LEAD: A STEP INTO THE PAST The most distinguished document in the ''Liberties and Legends'' exhibition on the 350-year history of the state is the original Fundamental Orders of 1639.

LEAD: Nothing ever said in this column drew more dismayed reaction than an opinion expressed on Jan. 8, when it was suggested that inherent drawbacks of the LP hastened its decline in the face of competition from compact disks.

LEAD: What are America's most pressing domestic needs? In his new budget, President Bush lays out these answers: (1) to increase productivity; (2) to invest in people; and (3) to end the scourge of drugs. Admirable. Many Americans share these goals. But there's a problem. Though the captain's new chart plots a sensible destination, his boat is too small to get there.

LEAD: ON the same day that the Governor of Massachusetts announced several austerity steps to help close a state deficit, the Massachusetts Division of Capital Planning and Operations reported that it had earmarked $1.1 million over the next seven years to beautify state prisons with art.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A Federal judge yesterday dismissed a racketeering case against the Long Island Lighting Company, ruling that the question of whether Lilco had lied to obtain rate increases belonged before state utility regulators and should never have been tried under Federal law.
LEAD: THERE are mornings when Coral Goldstein of Stamford feels that she just will not be able to get through the day.

LEAD: Kenny Walker of the Knicks almost skipped today's Gatorade Slam-Dunk Contest at the Summit because his father died Wednesday. But he decided to participate, saying he would dedicate his performance to his father.

LEAD: ON OUR OWN BEHALF: Women's Tales From Catalonia. Edited by Kathleen McNerney. (University of Nebraska, $24.95). It's probably no great surprise that even a collection of work as specialized as one devoted to contemporary feminist women writers of Catalonia could bring together such characters as a vagabond, a lapsed lesbian and a woman who says her rosary during sex.

LEAD: Abraham Lincoln's birthday, actually today, will be observed tomorrow. Below are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Government offices: Federal and state offices open, local offices closed. Post offices: Regular delivery. Banks: State-chartered banks have option to close; federally chartered banks open.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: On Monday, President Bush announced a plan to bail out the troubled savings and loan industry. To pay for the plan - which is projected to cost taxpayers about $60 billion - the Government will sell bonds and raise premiums for Federal deposit insurance. In addition, the Government would take control of 350 troubled savings associations.

LEAD: ''DON'T try it,'' would surely have been James Thurber's advice to me if I'd asked him about picking up his traces in Paris. A literary man, he had little use for the literary pilgrimage and had dropped few handkerchiefs for the pilgrim on his trail. But I thought I was entitled to at least try.

LEAD: YESTERLINGO IS the fondly remembered language of the recent past. Nostalgia may not be what it used to be, as Simone Signoret suggested in the title of her autobiography, but the ghost words of our youth haunt us still.

LEAD: Here are some of the most notable releases of the last few months. BELLMAN AND TRUE - Richard Loncraine's tale of a computer systems engineer (Bernard Hill) and his stepson (Kieran O'Brien) forced by gangsters to pull off a bank heist. ''An unexpectedly upbeat and satisfying film.'' (Maslin) 1987.
LEAD: LAST January, after years of happy commuting on Metro-North, I traded my timetable and train buddies for a job in Westchester that required that I drive.

LEAD: Although it is officially banned, trekking across the ice bridge that forms at the base of the Horseshoe Falls in frigid weather is a thrill that some people compare to going over the falls in a barrel.

LEAD: A British development company has stolen a march on its American competition by capturing a prime corner on Fifth Avenue for the site of a new office tower. The Greycoat Real Estate Corporation of London has bought 546 Fifth Avenue, at 45th Street, and will erect a 22-story building that is being designed by the architectural firm of Emery Roth &
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. John Barclay Rodgers of Delmar, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Cynthia Joanne Rodgers to Dr. Barry Miles Belgorod, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Howard H. Belgorod of New York. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: BACK when ''the telephone company'' was the only game in town, corporate managers simply called the American Telephone and Telegraph Company when they had problems with their telecommunications. But after the A.T.&T. divestiture five years ago, information systems changed so dramatically, that managers soon found they needed specialized training.
