LEAD: Peter MacDonald, chairman of the Navajo tribe, says he acted in accordance with a traditional custom of accepting gifts; but Congressional investigators suspect he was following a custom of more recent origin - accepting bribes. Mr. MacDonald, who has invoked the Fifth Amendment in declining to appear before a Senate committee investigating allegations that he took kickbacks, went on the radio last week to defend himself.

LEAD: FOR years, my vision of Greece consisted exclusively of naked, sun-scorched rock and pristine sugar-cube villages rising out of an expanse of blue sea. Then, gradually, I became drawn to another, more subtle Greece, not Mediterranean but Balkan; an autumnal land of fir forests, stately poplars and dark green mountains grooved with snow, evoking the background of an old master's painting rather than the usual watercolor sketch of sea and stone.

LEAD: ''These are fossils of the past,'' said Anita Spertus, describing the collection of Indonesian textiles that she and her husband, Jeff Holmgren, have acquired over the last 16 years. An exhibit from their holdings opens at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Tuesday and runs through May 14.

LEAD: SATURDAYS at the library are different from other days of the week; a certain lightness fills the air. Cartoon-pitched children's voices float brightly over the muffled sound of rustled pages emanating from the reading room. One can feel the staidness lifted; the building swarms with frisky Lilliputians, who might easily erupt in giggles if told reading was for anything but fun.

LEAD: FROM the beginning, the strategy to put through a 51 percent raise for members of Congress, Federal judges and senior officials was based on the presumption that there was no way to convince the public that this was a good idea and therefore no way to win a vote for it in Congress.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Luther H. Haibt of Katonah, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Carolyn Mitchell Haibt, to Edward Colburn Norton, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard A. Norton of Hingham, Mass. An October wedding is planned.
LEAD: New York City health officials closed two gay theaters in Manhattan last week in an effort to halt the spread of AIDS.

LEAD: A 26-acre tract in central New Jersey that had been farmed for more than a century and that still retains an 1832 farmhouse is being developed into a 76-unit complex of town houses and apartments. The tract is two miles north of downtown Princeton on Mount Lucas Road.

LEAD: ''When I was young,'' the pianist Russell Sherman said, ''I came across a statement made by Jung, who said that it is the function of an artist is to rectify the imbalances of the period in which he happens to live. I feel - and this is perhaps my prejudice and imprint - that ours is an age which is lacking in soul.
LEAD: THE AMORALISTS & OTHER TALES Collected Stories. By Cyrus Colter. 283 pp. New York: Thunder's Mouth Press. Cloth, $19.95. Paper, $10.95.

LEAD: It was a weekend in which alcohol abuse sent eight students to the infirmary, including two whose moderate poisoning required a transfer to a hospital, but Princeton University officials were relieved. ''It was a minor affair,'' said a university spokeswoman, Jacqueline Savani. ''It was nothing like last year.

LEAD: FAR and away the busiest orchestra in Westchester, the Philharmonia Virtuosi, presumably refreshed from its nearly two months of vacation, returns to plunge into the year with four county concerts this month - and two more in Manhattan in the same period.
LEAD: To the Editor: Articles on Turkey, clipped over the last four years, took slight space in my baggage and added to the scope and economy of my Elderhostel tour of Turkey this fall.

LEAD: Margaret Mary Byrne and Frank Philip Christian 3d plan to be married April 1. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Terence C. Byrne of Hackettstown, N.J., and Mr. and Mrs. Christian 2d of Clarks Summit, Pa.
LEAD: SPECIAL RELATIONSHIPS A Foreign Correspondent's Memoirs From Roosevelt to Reagan. By Henry Brandon. Illustrated. 436 pp. New York: Atheneum. $24.95.
LEAD: IN the Nevada desert, geologists and engineers are beginning a task that will take decades, preparing an underground repository meant to isolate radioactive wastes for at least 10,000 years.

LEAD: IN recent years, some courts have ruled that psychotherapists and other professionals may be legally responsible for crimes committed by people in their care. Now a lawsuit is testing whether the parents of an emotionally unstable adult can be held to a similar standard.
LEAD: Books may never be sold there again, but the inside of the Scribner Book Store on Fifth Avenue is likely to become an official New York City landmark, which would be welcomed by its owners.
LEAD: Following are excerpts from a preliminary ruling by Judge Jack B. Weinstein of Federal District Court in Brooklyn in the civil racketeering case against the Long Island Lighting Company:

LEAD: As a novelist whose five books have had respectable but not staggering sales, I cannot help but wish that Clayton Curtiss, in his essay, ''Parents Should Teach a Love of Books'' (Opinion Page, Jan. 15), had not concentrated exclusively on the best-seller list.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: THIS past year was a big one for Barbie. Like the baby boomers who were first presented with this wondrous creation, the Barbie doll has finally hit ''thirtysomething.''
LEAD: Salvador Dali's last joke is reverberating across Spain, sowing the kind of consternation and dissension that the Surrealist master succeeded in creating so successfully in his lifetime.
LEAD: New cribs lined the children's ward at Infectious Diseases Hospital No. 2 here, each with a fresh set of linens, and a bed nearby for each child's mother.

LEAD: Thirty-four years ago, I lived in the Wil-Mar trailer court in Allentown, Pa., and the guy across the way was the service manager for Dahl Ford. I had bought a car from him, a '48 Mercury, and I thought it was the sexiest thing on wheels.

LEAD: The Communist Party Central Committee today endorsed a compromise to end a leadership dispute over whether the 1956 Hungarian uprising, which was crushed by the Soviet Army, was a popular uprising or a counterrevolution.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: SEVENTEEN years after fleeing a prison in Louisiana, where he had begun serving 15 years for manslaughter, Henry Staggs was recaptured in Columbia, Tenn., apparently a changed man. During his freedom he had built a solid reputation as Douglas Gillette, the hard-working owner of an auto repair shop and a law-abiding family man.

LEAD: Carl Bosch is understandably distressed at his 6-year-old daughter's awareness and fear of terrorism, following the crash of Pan Am Flight 103 (''What Do You Tell Children About Terrorism,'' Opinion page, Jan. 15). So what does he do about it? He compounds the terror and brings the fear straight home by insisting that she fly with her parents, against her will, to that ''shrine of childhood, Disney World.
LEAD: A March 11 wedding is planned for Rebecca Wendling Adams, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Banks Tolson Adams Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and Paul Macrae Montgomery.

LEAD: The Dec. 18 article ''Two Lives on Hold,'' by William Squadron, husband of Dr. Joan Longer, described the heart-lung transplant undergone by Dr. Longer, in July 1987, to correct the ravages of cystic fibrosis. Dr. Longer died on Jan. 19 in Papworth Hospital, Cambridgeshire, England, from the consequences of organ rejection.
LEAD: MARY SHELLEY Romance and Reality. By Emily W. Sunstein. Illustrated. 478 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $24.95.

LEAD: ''Mr. Prime Minister, to achieve order in the casbah I have to act brutally toward people free of crime, too. I feel humiliated by this behavior. The situation has become a catastrophe. It's breaking us and strengthening the Arabs.'' - - Israeli soldier, when Prime Minister Shamir visited troops in the West Bank city of Nablus last month.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: AFTER Mao and Khrushchev bumped egos for the last time, during celebrations for the 10th anniversary of the People's Republic of China in 1959, the Chinese leader set a punitive schedule for relations between the world's two great Communist powers. The Soviet Union had earned 10,000 years of hostility from

LEAD: IT isn't just that Reizl Bozyk steals the show ''Social Security'' at the Forum Theater as, last summer, she stole the film ''Crossing Delancy.'' Mrs. Bozyk simply is the show, the whole show, and that's that.
LEAD: Lloyd McNeill, a flutist, brought a quartet to Birdland on Thursday night to play a set of pleasant, unobtrusive Brazilian music.

LEAD: ARMED with a sheaf of environmental studies of river currents, sunlight penetration, fish migration and other aspects of aquatic life, the Koch administration is preparing a campaign to let developers build office towers, apartment buildings and other large structures on piers and platforms over the East and Hudson

LEAD: After nine years of war in Afghanistan, most of the guerrilla groups have raised public relations to a fine art. Each of the seven guerrilla parties based in Pakistan has its own English-speaking press and political officer and issues English translations of its publications.

LEAD: Most dramatizations of the United States Government's internment of Japanese-Americans during World War II fall into one of two categories. They are either documentaries or they are based on personal memories. In contrast to previous treatments of the subject at the Pan Asian Repertory Theater, R.
LEAD: THE EDGE By Dick Francis 324 pp. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $18.95.

LEAD: SUSAN B. ANTHONY: A Biography of a Singular Feminist. By Kathleen Barry. (New York University, $27.95.) Those who dimly recall Susan B. Anthony as Tonto to Elizabeth Cady Stanton's Lone Ranger will be surprised, and perhaps provoked, to read in ''Susan B. Anthony: A Biography of a Singular Feminist'' that Anthony was a charismatic leader who was, for decades, the heart of the women's movement, that she often had to cajole or blackmail her older friend into political participation and that she may have desired Stanton sexually.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Dwight Gooden, owner of the best pitching record in major league baseball, says that being with the New York Mets is ''like a family thing.'' Last week, he got his allowance raised. The 24-year-old Gooden agreed to a three-year, $6.7 million contract that will make him the highest paid Mets player in history and, at least briefly, the highest paid player in baseball.

LEAD: Every year, the police here receive two or three reports of highway shootings. But ever since Michael K. Warner was shot and killed on Interstate 75 south of Detroit around midnight Nov. 19, the shootings have multiplied and the reports have multiplied even more. The police say that the shootings seem to be unrelated and that some are imaginary; often stones or debris are the culprits.

LEAD: The Strand Theater, an Art Deco cinema in downtown Summit, N.J., dark for about five years, is being redeveloped into a 12-store shopping arcade. The 40,000-square-foot building is scheduled to open this spring, according to Peter Kalkus, president of the Lamar Companies of Morristown, N.J., which is undertaking the $10 millon project.

LEAD: ANJELICA HUSTON PAUSED AND STUDIED a charcoal drawing of a woman in profile. The scene was the Metropolitan Museum of Art; the 37-year-old actress was taking an afternoon off from working on Woody Allen's latest movie to see the Degas show. The drawing was of a handsome, dark-haired, strong-featured woman with a long, aristocratic nose.

LEAD: AFTER creating a great first impression in the early 1980's, ''smart'' office buildings flunked real-life testing. Now less-grandiose strategies for computerized automation are reshaping the way buildings work.

LEAD: THE SOCK DRAWER was a large drawer to the right of our kitchen sink, just below the knives and forks and next to the junk drawer. It was my mother's solution to the laundry. The name was a euphemism, for, although it did house the entire family's abandoned mateless socks, its chief function was to contain the underpants of the female offspring.

LEAD: FOR the United States, the word Afghanistan once evoked obscurity. One of the world's most isolated countries, it has no railways, no navigable rivers, no outlet to the sea, few natural resources and a history notable primarily for its turbulence. Before the Soviet occupation nine years ago, the United States imported little more than sheepskins and carpets from Afghanistan in exchange for

LEAD: The Iraqi Airways flight was supposed to be nonstop from Baghdad to Rome. But the plane was barely airborne one day several months ago when a sudden strike by air controllers at the Fiumicino airport outside Rome forced a detour to Cyprus.

LEAD: I BELIEVE in life. I believe in choice. I am pro-life and pro-choice. I see no contradictions in combining the two. The only problem I see is with the people who use those words, but who do not understand the underlying reality and concept behind them.

LEAD: When the list of high school players who signed letters of intent to play football at Division I-A colleges next fall came out last week, it was not surprising to find some of the best New York-area players going to some of the top-rated teams.

LEAD: The engagement of Kathleen Ann Cranton to Peter Carlisle Thomes, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell F. Thomes Jr. of New York and Southold, L.I., has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Norman W. Cranton of Groveland, Mass. An April wedding is planned.

LEAD: Under a withering African sun that scorches the pale green acacia trees and tawny earth in the Ngong Hills not far from here, Bob Rafelson, a multicolored wool cap protecting his head, is directing two actors dressed in tattered Victorian garb. One is on crutches; the other appears quite spry. Both are sweltering in heavy coats and gaiters as they say farewell to each other.
LEAD: FORBIDDEN TERRITORY The Memoirs of Juan Goytisolo, 1931-1956. Translated by Peter Bush. 235 pp. San Francisco: North Point Press. $18.95.

LEAD: NORTHERN Litchfield County is fighting to keep development at bay in what a real estate broker who specializes in the Northwest Corner calls ''the last bastion of beautiful land in Connecticut.''

LEAD: Kristi Yamaguchi, the 82-pound teen-ager who won the national pairs championship Friday night with Rudi Galindo, skated a dazzling freestyle program today to become the first American woman in 35 years to qualify for the world figure-skating championships in two events.

LEAD: The five permanent members of the Security Council appear to have succeeded in reducing the size and cost of the peacekeeping force the United Nations will send to Namibia this spring, diplomats said Friday.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Charles Schnabolk's ''Cheers for the Lower Half'' (Opinion Page, Jan. 8) should be criticized not so much for the points it makes, but for the way it goes about making them.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: SONG AND DANCE MAN By Karen Ackerman. Illustrated by Stephen Gammell. Unpaged. New York: Alfred A. Knopf.

LEAD: The design of products has been recognized as a major competitive resource by the Europeans and the Japanese for years. Product design is not only appearance, but also - and just as important - the ease with which the product is understood, used and serviced. The product also represents the company.
LEAD: Scholarship Benefit
LEAD: A sizable population of juvenile sea turtles still calls Long Island home, three scientists reported today.

LEAD: Vreni Schneider wasn't taking any chances in the giant slalom today. Going into the world Alpine ski championships, she had a reputation for winning in the second run of World Cup slalom and giant slalom races.

LEAD: New York area carpenters' unions have purchased a former Western Electric building on the western fringe of Greenwich Village for use as a headquarters for their district council and as a center for their pension and benefits office. The 10-story building at 395 Hudson Street, the blockfront between West Houston and Clarkson
LEAD: Electra Preston and George Watkins Ahl 3d were married yesterday in Bedford, N.Y. The Rev. Richard Visconti performed the ceremony at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church.
LEAD: Blocked heater pipes spread deadly fumes through a house, killing four men and leaving a woman in critical condition, the authorities said Friday.
LEAD: This tiny city of 5,123 people, and the track that shares its name, bridge two nations, two states, and two breeds of race horses.

LEAD: Jessye Norman took half the night off at the Metropolitan Opera on Wednesday, relinquishing the role of Judith in Bartok's ''Bluebeard's Castle'' but appearing as usual in ''Erwartung,'' the Schoenberg monodrama that fills out this new double bill.
LEAD: Elections used to be simple things here. The ruling party would nominate candidates who would win elections, and candidates would wear clothes.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A little more than two years ago, Joseph J. Pinola, chairman and chief executive of the First Interstate Bancorp, made an audacious bid to buy the BankAmerica Corporation. BankAmerica was more than twice First Interstate's size, but it was in shambles - its stock was depressed, its capital base weak and its management surprised by a series of loan losses and other misfortunes.

LEAD: IT was 10 years ago this weekend that Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, Shah of Shahs, Light of the Aryans, and America's anointed policeman of the Persian Gulf, left Iran, carrying a small jar of his native soil, an aide kissing his head in a last obsequious gesture. In his place came Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the implacable exponent of a new theocracy of Shiite
LEAD: St. John's found out tonight just how much a healthy all-America point guard and a home crowd of more than 32,000 mean to the fortunes of the Syracuse Orangemen.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A grandmother who hadn't visited New York for a year arrived during the bustling holiday season via the Metroliner from Wilmington. She emerged from Penn Station prepared, as usual, to engage in dubious battle for a taxicab on Seventh Avenue (she'd long ago learned to avoid Eighth).

LEAD: The State Supreme Court is being asked to decide when a belch is intentional and willful, especially when it skews the results of a blood-alcohol test being given to a driver suspected of being drunk.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Walter M. Noel Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter Corina Monica Noel to Andres Piedrahita, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Piedrahita of Bogota, Colombia. The couple plan to marry in May.

LEAD: The United States and its NATO allies continue to espouse a policy of first use of nuclear weapons. We believe the President, Congress and the American public should reject this policy, including the early use of nuclear weapons in a crisis. It is not credible to our enemies and it increases the risk of nuclear war.

LEAD: He's heard his share of lectures on how tennis players should conduct themselves, so it should come as no surprise that John McEnroe, the one-time enfant terrible of the sport, takes some of his younger competitors to task from time to time, especially after he's lost a match.

LEAD: DINING on grilled lobster in the splendid salon where President Kennedy once greeted Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethopia and President Roosevelt received King George VI and Queen Elizabeth of England. Or shopping and browsing for one-of-a-kind works of art and jewelry in a setting of Romanesque columns and

LEAD: A play called ''The Paper Gramophone'' opened to previews last night at the Hartford Stage Company and brought full circle a cultural union between the artistic director of the Hartford and an artistic director from Russia.

LEAD: AS Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d tours Western Europe this week, he is scheduled to divide his time equally among the 14 members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. But schedules can be deceiving. If the trip were organized not on the basis of protocol, but on the basis of which NATO country was most preoccupying the Bush Administration, then Mr.
LEAD: Amid Blue Hens, Buffalo Roam

LEAD: IT'S difficult to believe, but there are people who don't talk to themselves. They think the things that many others say aloud, they form sentences and phrases in their minds, and occasionally they go so far as to move their lips - but no sound emerges. In fact, these people are apt to consider those who do talk to themselves a rather strange lot, next door to street mutterers and just a few degrees away from the men and women who carry on loud and rambling conversations with phantoms on buses and subways.

LEAD: THE other day my wife and I went to the Condo - not to stay, just to look it over. The salespeople made us admit that the house we've lived in for the last 20 years is too big for us, that we are tired of mowing the lawn and shoveling snow. But I don't think we're ready for the Condo. Not just yet.

LEAD: IT is 18 months since Lichtman's bakery closed, 20 since the projector sputtered to a halt at the Thalia theater and nearly four years since the New Yorker bookshop shut down - all victims of creeping development and galloping rent rises.

LEAD: IN 1981, Larry McMurtry wrote an essay for the Texas Observer that set off furious howls throughout Texas. Mr. McMurtry virtually dismissed all of Texas literature, saying Texas writers were unduly fixated on the past and largely because of that had produced almost nothing of lasting value. He lamented that he had been far too optimistic when he predicted 14 years earlier the demise of literature extolling the rural glories of wide-open spaces and yahoos on horseback.

LEAD: SOMETIMES the irritating noise is made by young children dragging toys across a hardwood floor, sometimes by a teen-age drummer determined to become the next Ringo Starr. Then there are the mavericks who run the washing machine at midnight and people who unwind by slamming doors.

LEAD: IF Bugbee & Brownell seems familiar, it's because it is. The relatively new restaurant, on the Post Road in Darien (next to Friendly's, just off Exit 13 of Interstate 95), is actually the old Harper's and has simply changed its name. The new name, inspired by an old Boston tea company which has no connection to the restaurant, is meant, in one waitress's words, ''to sound good, as part of our upscaling.

LEAD: A GOOD play can withstand a battery of assaults by the combined theatrical cannons of inept direction, poor acting, incompetent set designers and audience members who have uncontrollable urges to crinkle cellophane-wrapped candy. In some cases, it can even stand up to bizarre translations and wacky adaptations.

LEAD: The New York University Chamber Music Society has hit on an imposing format for its concerts this year. Six - the first of which was held at Merkin Hall Thursday night - will be given over to contemporary Soviet composition and are to bear a blanket title, ''The Year of Russian Music.''

LEAD: The wedding of Patrice Soriero, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Soriero of New Hope, Pa., to Jeffrey Stambovsky, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lazar Stambovsky of Springfield, Mass., took place last evening at the Steps Dance Studio in New York. Rabbi David B. Kahane officiated. The bride, a graduate of Pennsylvania State University, is a choreographer and the artistic director at the studio, of which she is the co-owner.
LEAD: A picture caption on Jan. 15 with an article about Katmandu misidentified the site shown. It was the Ranipokhari, the Queen's Pond, not the royal palace.

LEAD: LIVES OF THE TWINS, by Rosamond Smith. (Avon, $3.95.) After Molly Marks moves in with her psychotherapist, she embarks on a secret affair with his estranged identical twin. Written pseudonymously by Joyce Carol Oates, this is ''a marvelous metaphysical novel,'' Susan Fromberg Schaeffer said here last year.

LEAD: A recent article in the Westchester Weekly section prompted me to put down some thoughts of my own. [ ''Daughter Follows Mother's Footsteps,'' Westchester Opinion, Jan. 29. ] A mother of a 21-year-old girl in college wrote saying how she's preached choice to her daughter for 20 years. The daughter is headed for a promising career in museum work and at the same time has announced her engagement.

LEAD: Choreographic modesty was one of the virtues of Shelley Lee's ''Maize'' Thursday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio, but it was responsible for some bland sequences in the hourlong work offered by Shelley Lee and Dancers.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A Frenchman on a vacation fishing trip in the Caribbean was rescued after drifting 37 days across the Caribbean and watching his son die of thirst and hunger, the French Embassy said. The man, Fernand Samson, 36 years old, and his son Jeofere were off the island of Guadeloupe in a 19-foot motorboat when the motor went out on Dec.

LEAD: Speculation that Buck Williams of the Nets will be traded before the Feb. 23 deadline is continuing this weekend. The latest rumor has Williams, a 6-foot-8-inch forward, being traded to Portland in exchange for Jerome Kersey and the Trail Blazers' first-round draft pick in 1989.

LEAD: BIOGRAPHICAL BOON Scholars, students and the public may avail themselves of an unusual collection of 15,000 biographical books recently donated to the Manhattanville College Library in Purchase by Emery Allain of Greenwich. Mr. Allain, retired chief financial officer of Great Northern Nekoosa paper company, collected biographies as a hobby.

LEAD: Mozambique has told South Africa that the United States should not try to mediate in the insurgency in Mozambique, but that some other ''constructive role'' by it or another nation would be welcome.
LEAD: I would like to clarify some points in ''Opening a New Era in Garbage Disposal'' [ Jan. 15 ] .

LEAD: An enlightened contemporary minister of a Protestant church in an upscale academic community is about to enjoy a dinner his wife is preparing on the backyard charcoal grill, when he - a somewhat aloof intellectual graduate of Yale Divinity School - is shaken and disturbed by this experience he neither expects nor wants.

LEAD: Branford, Conn. $119,000 151 Monticello Drive 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, town-house condominium; 10 years old, end unit, fully finished family room on lower level; monthly common charges $117, taxes $1,102. Madison, Conn. $185,000 84 Woodsvale Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 20-year-old ranch; wooded lot, large screened porch, swimming pool, 1 acre; taxes $1,610.

LEAD: WHENEVER camera journalists get together, there's always one wag in the group who remarks, ''Well, the next thing you know, they'll make a camera that automatically composes the picture for you.'' I used to think this was a joke. Welcome, friends, to the brave new world of the ''automatic programmed zoom composing system.
LEAD: Jason Matthews scored 24 points and Pitt held No. 2 Georgetown to 8 points in the final 10 minutes to upset the Hoyas, 79-74, today in the Big East Conference.

LEAD: DURING most of the year, the door to the Connecticut Afro-American Historical Society is locked, and entrance is by appointment only. There is no money to hire someone to run the society. Instead, a handful of dedicated people volunteer their time - 10 to 20 hours a week each - so that the place can simply exist.

LEAD: AS I followed the Alley Pond Park nature trail that February morning, evidence of the last snowstorm was practically gone, save for traces under the thicker underbrush. The ice of the stream melted into a still pond of brownish water topped with a few floating leaves.
LEAD: Greg Millen stopped 33 shots for his sixth shutout of the season and Brett Hull had a goal and two assists, leading the St. Louis Blues to a 5-0 victory tonight over the Islanders.

LEAD: The engagement of Jennifer Lee Stafford to John Glen Farrow, a son of Glenn W. Farrow of Thousand Oaks, Calif., and Dorothy Kilkenny of Woodland Hills, Calif., has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. John R. Stafford of Essex Fells, N.J. A June wedding is planned. Miss Stafford, a screen and television actress, is a graduate of the Pingry School and Northwestern University.
LEAD: Prince Norodom Sihanouk has decided to resume his post as president of the Cambodian coalition fighting the Vietnamese occupation forces, Thailand's Foreign Minister said today.

LEAD: An article on Feb. 5 misidentified the broker in a sale of 66 acres on the Long Island Expressway in Islandia to Related Properties of Manhattan. He was Paul Amoruso, president of Oxford & Simpson in Jericho.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Stanley I. Buchin of Boston have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda Chase Buchin, to Michael Hobart Sullivan, a son of Dr. Hobart B. Sullivan Jr. of Philadelphia and Maria G. Sullivan of Berwyn, Pa. An August wedding is planned.

Tower said in a divorce deposition in 1987 that he advised a unit of British Aerospace about commercial aviation sales and about the sale of military systems to the Pentagon, according to Administration officials. But last month he gave a statement to the Senate saying he could not ''recall'' any military work for British

LEAD: AS Gen. Alfredo Stroessner entered his fourth decade in power in 1984, the shadow of Cuba and Nicaragua - countries where rightist caudillos were swept away by Marxist revolutionaries -began to haunt Paraguay. Since he allowed no room for moderate opposition, it was argued, leftist extremism would inevitably appear here.

LEAD: French-Japanese, California-Italian, Mediterranean-American, Southwestern-French - defining cuisine today isn't easy. In restaurants in the United States, ingredients, cooking techniques and presentation styles overlap and blur. A torte of black beans is as likely to appear on the menu at a French restaurant as creme de cresson.

LEAD: Exactly 15 years ago tonight, a club called the Bottom Line opened its doors at Mercer and Fourth Streets in lower Manhattan. It's still there, going strong, and its adaptability and sheer survival prompts some reflections on the institution of the pop-music club.

LEAD: Appeals Court Supports Fanelli THE County Executive has lost another round in his battle to dismiss the County Probation director, Marino J. Fanelli - the first department head Mr. O'Rourke has attempted to remove in the six years of his administration. A unanimous decision by the State Supreme Court's Appellate Division upheld a State Supreme Court ruling that dismissed the county's legal arguments for removing Mr.
LEAD: MY daughter was for sale last year. Did I love her? Yes! Did I like her? No! I didn't know exactly where to place the ad, but ''Help Wanted'' was the area that I deemed to be most appropriate.

LEAD: Roger Cardinal Etchegaray, a special envoy from the Vatican, turned away from the altar toward the hundreds of people crowded into the Cathedral of Havana and asked what message he should take back to the Pope.

LEAD: The president of Niagara University, the Very Rev. Donald J. Harrington, was chosen last week to be the next president of St. John's University. He will succeed the Very Rev. Joseph T. Cahill, who is completing almost 25 years as president of St. John's.

LEAD: MIA FONSSAGRIVES-SOLOW, right, was in the fashion business with the designer Vicky Tiel in Paris in the 1960's. When she returned to the United States she became a sculptor, making larger-than-life-size animals. Recently she has interpreted animal shapes as jewelry, including walking cats, swinging monkeys, butterflies with folded wings, lions' heads and standing meerkats (African mongooses).

LEAD: Tatiana Troyanos will sing songs from Hugo Wolf's ''Spanisches Liederbuch,'' Falla's ''Siete Canciones Populares Espanolas,'' and works by Brahms, Ravel and Mahler in a recital on March 6 at 8 P.M. at Alice Tully Hall. Warren Jones will be her accompanist. Tickets from Miss Troyanos's canceled recital on Dec.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: On Friday, the day before his first long-distance shootout on foreign shores, Rimas Kourtinaitis, the mustachioed and innocently controversial Lithuanian guest of the National Basketball Association, was asked, ''Are you nervous?''

LEAD: THE power center of bridge in Europe has been slowly moving North for the past two decades. In the 1950's and 1960's Italy, Britain and France regularly contended for the top honors in European Championships. Nowadays that threesome is still in the hunt, but the Poles and the Scandinavians frequently emerge with the medals.

LEAD: Very few things sound as archetypically American as the sound of a Fender Telecaster guitar abusing a Fender amplifier into hysterics. It's the sound of early rock, of harsh metallic blues, of the new music that changed the sound of American pop in the 1950's.

LEAD: The State House of Representatives has passed a bill repealing a 200-year-old law that makes adultery a crime punishable by a year in jail. The measure, passed 201 to 149 on Thursday, goes to the Senate, where a similar bill was defeated two years ago. Supporters of repeal said the law was unenforceable, while their opponents said repeal would lead to a perception that New Hampshire tolerates adultery.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. John J. Toffey 4th of Great Barrington, Mass., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Hannah Toffey, to James Christopher Mauro, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Mauro of Massapequa, L.I. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 3 MIDNIGHT, by Dean R. Koontz. (Putnam, $19.95.) Inexplicable deaths and strange horrors take over a once idyllic California town. 2 2 13 THE SANDS OF TIME, by Sidney Sheldon.

LEAD: Not long ago, after the Soviet troops had gone, Mohammad Sadiq went back to the village in Afghanistan where he was born. The setting bestowed on it by nature and the structures built by men had been reduced to desolation.

LEAD: Judging from Carl Bosch's own bewilderment over terrorism (''What Do You Tell Children About Terrorism,'' Opinion page, Jan. 15), I don't wonder that he was unable to explain it to his daughter.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John A. Allen of Westport, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter Emmary Armstrong Allen to Lawrence Bruce Carlson, a son of Mrs. Bruce Carlson of Wilton, Conn., and the late Mr. Carlson. An April wedding is planned.

LEAD: As the final touches were being put on the budget proposals President Bush delivered to Congress Thursday night, a disagreement developed between Jack F. Kemp, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, and Nicholas F. Brady, the Treasury Secretary.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Outside Princeton University's two all-male eating clubs last week, protesters greeted sophomores arriving to participate in ''bicker,'' the equivalent of fraternity rush. ''Women as Members, Not Just Dates,'' the protesters' signs read.

LEAD: The first pleasure in the Museum of Modern Art's new architecture exhibition, ''Emilio Ambasz/Steven Holl,'' is the extent to which it makes the never-ending debate about style seem tiresome, even trivial. The work of these architects is too original, and too good, to be bound by stylistic labels.
LEAD: The Government in Prague has moved to quash dissent within its ranks, dismissing the editor of the Communist Party's cultural weekly.

LEAD: With Valentine's Day approaching, this is as good a time as any to point out that Cupid doesn't always shoot straight. Sometimes he creates star-crossed lovers of the sort that Hollywood adores, lovers who meet under the most inopportune circumstances imaginable. The couple in the 1963 LOVE WITH THE PROPER STRANGER (Paramount Home Video, $19.95), which is newly available on videocassette, are especially star-crossed, since the salesgirl (Natalie Wood) is already pregnant by the footloose musician (Steve McQueen) when the film begins.

LEAD: A homeless man named Ruben Rodriguez who lived in Hicksville, L.I., was recently killed in a traffic accident. Carla and Joseph Samodulski, also from Hicksville, sent a donation to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund in Mr. Rodriguez's memory with the request that it be used ''to help another homeless person.

LEAD: Why did Dorothy Huntley-Flint sneak back into the clubhouse on Friday after getting a hole-in-one at a local club at Barton-on-Sea, England? Because it was her fourth hole-in-one, and she couldn't face another round of congratulations? Because at the age of 90 she'd had enough excitement in her life?

LEAD: CYNTHIA H. ADAMS has been teaching health courses at the University of Connecticut in Storrs for 16 years and has counseled hundreds of students with eating disorders like anorexia nervosa and bulimia.

LEAD: IF you go to the mall only to shop, chances are you have never seen them. They are there at dawn, hours before the first cash register rings, often before the first janitorial shift. Clad in sweat suits and jogging shoes, they come to walk the store-lined corridors, back and forth, over and over. They are mall walkers, and for them, the suburban shopping mall, with its controlled climate, security guards, level floors and restrooms, is the perfect exercise track.
LEAD: THE CLOSED CIRCLE An Interpretation of the Arabs. By David Pryce-Jones. 464 pp. New York: An Edward Burlingame Book/ Harper & Row. $25.

LEAD: Key members of Congress responsible for setting foreign aid levels say that Israel's treatment of Palestinians in the occupied territories is unacceptable and could weaken Congressional support for American aid to Israel.

LEAD: WITH HIS MOP OF black hair and his brown ankle-high boots, Dr. Etienne-Emile Baulieu comes across at once as a different kind of scientist. His breezy, almost brash manner and hyperkinetic nature give him the air more of a populist politician than of a meticulous medical researcher, an expert in hormones at France's National Institute of Health and Medical

LEAD: COUNTY CLERK ANDREW J. SPANO earned the gratitude of Westchester's Democratic Party leadership last week with one simple but agonizing move - withdrawing as a candidate for County Executive - on the occasion of the party's biggest celebration.

LEAD: Most consumers think nothing of conducting an exhaustive time-consuming search for the best deal on such items as a compact disk player or an air conditioner. But insurance? That's a different matter. ''Insurance is about negative, troubling ideas, like your house burning down, your car being stolen or someone dying; no one wants to face it,'' said Kevin Foley, Deputy Superintendent of the New York State Insurance Department.
LEAD: YOU might want to take a closer look at any Valentine you receive or send this year. There could be more there than the message - there could be a hedge against inflation.

LEAD: INDOORS start seed of impatiens, begonias, snapdragons, petunias and any wild flowers; be sure the pots are clean and the seed starting medium sterile to avoid any fungus diseases. This month is ideal to contract with professional arborists to have overgrown shade trees pruned, trimmed or thinned.

LEAD: Who says real estate has seen the end of ''boom times'' in Fairfield County? (Real Estate Bids Goodbye to Boom Times, Dec. 25). A few buyers who couldn't ''steal'' a house? A few sellers who are still on the early spring price kick of 1986? A few brokers who have to work harder to make and keep sales together?
LEAD: Christine Nell Heikkenen and William Fletcher Ludington Jr. were married yesterday at Castle McCulloch, a historic site in Jamestown, N.C., by the Rev. Dr. Robert Cook, an Episcopal priest.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: ACROSS much of the United States, trash is still disposed of in the old-fashioned way, with bulldozers and open landfills. But the metropolitan areas of the Northeast were forced by geography to move farther and faster toward large-scale incineration and, more recently, recycling.

LEAD: The Khmer Rouge is earning tens of thousands of dollars a week by selling passes to people who want to mine rubies in areas it controls inside Cambodia, numerous Cambodians interviewed in this refugee camp just inside Thailand say.

LEAD: In this era of eternal youth, speeding up the aging process may seem like a strange idea, but it has become big business in the design world. It is now possible to get the feeling of perfectly faded fabrics or the rich patina of century-old woods without paying the price of time. The tricks, to be sure, are theatrical: soaking freshly printed chintzes in vats of tea; smearing mud into shiny surfaces; mixing eggshells, finely ground dust or coffee grinds into paint; beating fabrics with stones.

LEAD: Laura Midge Mestel and Frederic Ellis Rubin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Burton Rubin of Woodmere, L.I., plan to marry in December, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Mestel of Bayside, Queens, have announced.
LEAD: ''I will obey Christ and serve in His name.'' - Bishop Barbara C. Harris. [ 26:1. ]
LEAD: The answer could be (a) Dwight Gooden, (b) Gary Gaetti, (c) Eddie Murray, (d) Gary Carter or (e) Dan Quisenberry. The question: Just who is the highest-paid player in baseball?

LEAD: WOODWORKING chisels and at least one hand plane have a place in almost every household tool kit. However, if you own such tools, learning how to sharpen them is as important as learning how to use them. Dull cutting tools are ineffective. They are also dangerous because they require more effort to use than sharp tools and so are more difficult to control.
LEAD: Corporate art collections are proving to be valuable vehicles through which companies can communicate with their employees and even change the corporate culture.

LEAD: Dr. Sheryl Ann Ross, a resident in obstetrics and gynecology at the University of Southern California Medical Center in Los Angeles, and Dr. Mitchell Douglas Becker, a resident in internal medicine at the University of California at Los Angeles Medical Center, were married last evening at the Beverly Hills Hotel.

LEAD: YOU know those cardboard sheets in airline seat pockets - the ones with pictures of the life jacket and oxygen mask and diagrams of exit doors? I now read them with a lot more interest and even put a book down and watch the flight attendants' talk with something like curiosity.

LEAD: THE 15 students who signed up for an unadvertised and unofficial meteorology major at Western Connecticut State University last September are apparently already adept at determining which way the wind is blowing.
LEAD: Q. I have a stall shower that has tiled walls up to the painted ceiling. Every two or three years this paint peels and flakes and we have to repaint. Is there a special paint I can use?

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Robert N. Koch Jr. of New York and East Orleans, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Peggy A. Koch to Briggs S. Palmer Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Palmer of Fort Myers, Fla. A September wedding is planned. Ms. Koch, a freelance film production coordinator, graduated from the Nightingale Bamford School and the University of Vermont.

LEAD: ROCKET LAUNCHERS ARE STACKED IN A CORNER of the cramped windowless room and Kalashnikov assault rifles hang on hooks along the walls. Outside, dusk has fallen and the blue-white lights of Kabul off in the horizon outline the skeletal remains of nearby bombed-out houses. The winter stillness is interrupted at regular intervals by the dull thud of artillery.

LEAD: RESIDENTS of this mile-square section of Dover Township in Ocean County are closing in on their five-year goal of turning the little oceanfront community into New Jersey's 568th independent municipality.

LEAD: WHEN she heard her town was setting up mandatory recycling, Carlene E. Kulisch, the head of the Branford Condominium Association, thought it would be difficult to separate her trash. After a few weeks of putting aside cans, bottles and newspapers, Ms. Kulisch said that although the task was not so difficult, the recycling program will not be universally liked when it is fully instituted next month.

LEAD: On the morning of Jan. 4, 1945, an Englishwoman in her mid-30's walked up the stone steps of a grim office building in the Prinz Albrechtstrasse in Berlin to offer herself for interrogation by the Gestapo.

LEAD: Picture this and try not to laugh: A soulful ballerina enters onstage from her yellow stucco tract house. In the distance, a curved portion of freeway overhangs a fairground, where her lover guzzles a bottle of Air Wick. Death and romance suffuse the air.

LEAD: He could hit, he could run and he had good hands. One of the first to enjoy baseball's free-agent bonanza more than a decade ago, he signed a five-year contract worth more than $1.5 million. But that big money somehow slipped through the fingers of those good hands. He had a job but in the chill of a hard winter, his wife and two children were shivering.

LEAD: IS a glass of champagne more romantic than a mug of hot cocoa? I don't think so. That's why, when a writer friend recently interviewed me for her article on ''Keeping Romance Alive in Marriage,'' she was slightly disturbed at my answers.

LEAD: Samuel Victor Constant, a retired colonel in the United States Army, died of pneumonia Thursday at DeWitt Army Hospital in Ft. Belvoir, Va. He was 94 years old and had moved recently to Alexandria, Va., after living in Manhattan.

LEAD: ROBED, barefoot figures with faces shielded. Respectful bowing, advancing and striking. Shouted expressions of self-mastery and spirit. All this is part of kendo, the Japanese martial art with roots in the samurai tradition.

LEAD: Clare Louise Hollensteiner, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Hollensteiner of New York, and Dr. James Patrick Smyth, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Smyth of Pearl River, N.Y., were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Jean Baptiste in New York. Msgr. Eugene Clark performed the ceremony.

LEAD: The moves - the stutter steps, fakes and jukes that leave defenders leaning the wrong way - have become so refined that they often go unnoticed. But Chris Mullin has not gone unnoticed. He has been recognized as an All-Star for the first time in his four-year pro career.

Dr. Konner's article indulges in a cross-cultural romanticism that I, as a parent, am tired of. Sleep with your children until they leave home, if that's what pleases you.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Martin B. Stahl of Edison, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter Dana Marci Stahl to David Max Mermelstein, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon B. Mermelstein of Bear Creek, Pa. An April wedding is planned.

LEAD: IF ever a coin could be called endearing, the Lincoln cent earns the title hands down. Celebrating its 80th year, more than a quarter-trillion of the coins have been minted. Although it is known commonly as the penny that term is an anachronism from British colonial times.
LEAD: Leon Festinger, a leading professor of psychology who developed the theory of cognitive dissonance, died of liver cancer yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 69 years old.

LEAD: ALONG the East River in an industrial pocket of the Bronx, James Granito and his partners in the Con-Agg Recycling Corporation crush rocks. They have been doing it for about five years on five acres of formerly idle, rubble-strewn urban-renewal land leased from the city.

LEAD: THE growing shortage of affordable housing in New Jersey is now a serious concern for tens of thousands of young working people unable to buy a home, for thousands more who cannot afford skyrocketing rents and, of course, for the 25,000 of our citizens who are homeless.

LEAD: The Bush Administration, turned down in two lower Federal courts in its efforts to delay the trial of Oliver L. North, today asked the Supreme Court to stay the case to avoid risk of ''irreparable injury'' to the nation from uncensored testimony and argument about intelligence matters.
LEAD: A long investigation into the death in detention of a black youth leader two years ago has again pointed up the lack of medical attention given political detainees.

LEAD: Ira Levin, who scared us to death with ''Rosemary's Baby,'' ''The Boys From Brazil'' and ''Deathtrap,'' has come up with a new supernatural twist: a play about a ghost that doesn't go ''Boo!'' but instead chants in Hebrew.

LEAD: NAVY BAND CONCERT The United States Navy Band, one of the world's truly fine musical organizations, will perform at 8 P.M. on Feb. 22 in Lakewood High School. Tickets for the free concert must be ordered by mail.

LEAD: The free agency will do to football what it did to baseball: It will make millionaires out of mediocre players. Big-city teams with big-city budgets will become a collection of overpriced underachievers. Owners will be tried and found guilty of collusion in an effort to stop the bidding madness. And the fans will enjoy it all from their $500 seats, while waving their $25 programs, eating their $15 hotdogs, and sipping their $5 sodas.

LEAD: The engagement of Elizabeth Hansen Cohen to Stephen Mather McPherson Jr. has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Kip H. Cohen of Bristol, R.I., and Long Boat Key, Fla. Mr. McPherson is a son of Mrs. Gregory A. Sharp of Northford, Conn., and Fishers Island, N.Y., and Mr. McPherson of New York.

LEAD: The N.F.L. has opted to go for a field goal instead of a touchdown in the area of free agency. By protecting three-quarters of its roster players from being eligible for free agency, it has kept the stars on the sidelines. About the only players eligible will be expendable members of the kicking teams, plus the aged and the malcontents.
LEAD: The program Anne-Marie McDermott chose for her Wednesday evening piano recital at Alice Tully Hall was neatly divided between the athletic and the poetic, and was offered in that order.
LEAD: In what has come to resemble an intramural display of Soviet air power, Sergei Bubka regained the world indoor pole-vault record yesterday from Rodion Gataullin.

LEAD: A defendant awaiting trial in a molestation case involving preschool children will soon be freed after five years in prison on $1.5 million bail raised by his friends.

LEAD: DURING the dreariest days of winter, it seems as though half of Long Island is making a beeline for sunny climes. The other half might find some small compensation at Hempstead's Caribbean Cafe.

LEAD: Unlike some other time-worn towns, Savannah doesn't believe in keeping the family treasures in a display case, to be seen but not touched. House museums, frequent private tours and friendly homeowners offer a hands-on history lesson. Laid out by Gen. James Oglethorpe 256 years ago, Savannah has the country's largest urban National Historic Landmark District, which includes free-standing mansions, row houses on Gordon, Jones and Gaston streets and 22 park-like squares.

LEAD: For 14 months operators of a huge radar installation in central Georgia that is part of the United States' defense warning system have had to turn off the system while military aircraft landed at a nearby base.

LEAD: Carolyn Anne Trepel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Trepel of Belle Harbor, Queens, and Robert Fain, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sigmund Fain of Brooklyn, were married yesterday at Temple Sholom of Mill Basin in Brooklyn. Rabbi Avner German performed the ceremony. Mrs. Fain, a special-education teacher at Public School 279 in Brooklyn, graduated from Brooklyn College, as did her husband, who also received an M.B.A.
LEAD: The Government today banned all protest meetings intended to show solidarity with 300 black detainees who are refusing food to protest being held without charge.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: In the few months since George Bush's election, there has been a remarkable swing of sentiment on the Federal budget deficit. In November, a sharp drop in the financial markets was regarded by some as signaling a deficit ''crisis.'' Former and present Federal Reserve Chairmen Paul A. Volcker and Alan Greenspan, former Presidents Gerald R.

LEAD: FEDERAL budgets are pies of taxpayer money that the President and Congress slice up and pass around to aircraft builders, disabled miners, urban transit authorities and, directly or indirectly, to virtually all the other participants in the economy. Usually the pie grew from year to year, so that even less favored sectors and constituencies could get a little more than before.
LEAD: As counsel to Robert McFarlane, I find much that is objectionable in Brock Brower's article ''Bud McFarlane: Semper Fi.'' (Jan. 22).

LEAD: Richard Biles enterprisingly choreographed big works and little, solos and ensembles, for the program his Richard Biles Dance Company presented Friday night at the Nikolais/Louis Choreospace. But only a few of those dances were theatrically effective.
LEAD: Additional titles of interest:
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: With their aggressive agendas, Ivy League pedigrees and boyish good looks, the young Governors of Mississippi, Arkansas and Louisiana have forged an alliance that is raising both their national visibility and that of their often lagging states.
LEAD: TIFFANY EXHIBIT

LEAD: Melvin Konner does not take into account that, in 1989, the term ''parents'' frequently refers to one natural parent and one stepparent. My own memories of blissfully drifting into sleep with my mother and father at age 4 stand in contrast to recollections of being placed in bed between my divorced father and his new wife just three years later.
LEAD: Walhalla High School's basketball team lost more than its 23d game of the season Friday night. The Razorbacks also lost their bus after the 87-66 loss to Chapman in Inman.

LEAD: WHEN residents of Cumberland, an affluent suburb of Portland, voted in December not to buy the 25-acre estate known as Conifer Ledges, they confirmed what many there have felt for some time: Oceanfront property has become too expensive for public agencies. The estate would have given the community its only waterfront park.

LEAD: The prime rate increased last week by a half a percentage point, to 11 percent. The move by banks to raise their base lending rate, which influences borrowing costs to consumers and small and medium-size businesses, was no surprise. Over the last few weeks, the Federal Reserve Board has increased the Federal funds rate on overnight loans.

LEAD: THERE is nothing so much to be wished for by a player trailing in a short match than a novel gambit to unsettle the opponent and make up the lost ground. But producing one when you need it is a rare achievement.
LEAD: A map on Jan. 22 with an article about private dining clubs in London located Harry's Bar incorrectly. The club is on the east side of South Audley Street.
LEAD: TWO Romeos with their Juliets, Summer Music in winter and Brahms are just a few of the highlights on this week's music calendar.

LEAD: To the Editor: Milena Jovanovitch (''California's Tranquil Ojai Valley,'' Travel, Nov. 6) has fulfilled one of my fondest dreams, that of returning to my former home. In such fully detailed descriptions did she so aptly convey the soul of the Ojai Valley that I was permitted once again to savor the experience of that wonderful place.

LEAD: A picture caption last week with an article about Citicorp misidentified the executives pictured with the chairman, John S. Reed. The photograph showed, left to right: Richard S. Braddock, head of the consumer bank; Michael A. Callen, in charge of the investment bank, and Lawrence M. Small, head of the corporate bank.

LEAD: IN hollows all over Vermont members of a new generation of wool growers, heirs to the state's 19th-century wool industry, are offering hand-spun and machine-spun yarn from their own flocks. Spinners can buy an unprocessed soft mound of wool freshly sheared from the sheep.

LEAD: When we first meet Jana, Jena and Jinna Gimmel, the identical triplets who reek mischief in Jeffrey Essmann's madcap comedy ''Triplets in Uniform,'' the scene is Prussia and the year 1919. The simpering adolescent trio has just returned for another semester to the forbidding Kaiserina Wilhelmina School for Girls, whose stern headmistress, Frau Fotze, has an inexplicable phobia about mirrors.

LEAD: The new use of old historic buildings is a wonderful idea. It allows people to enjoy the beauty of architectural landmarks in different and creative ways. In the article ''Stamford's Old Town Hall May Have a Future in Art'' (Jan. 22), where the proposal to convert a virtually empty landmark edifice into a museum is discussed, is a plan which deserves serious consideration.

LEAD: The corporate and Wall Street communities are wrestling not only with the issue of profitability, but also with the more difficult and subtle issue of ethical behavior. A number of tools have been designed to bring ethics to the forefront of business development training.
LEAD: John Morton scored 23 points tonight to lead 11th-ranked Seton Hall past Villanova, 83-77, for the Pirates' first victory on the Wildcats' home court in 15 years.

LEAD: Rabbi Samarious Gourary, the executive director for the past 48 years of United Lubavitcher Yeshivoth, the educational arm of the Lubavitcher Hasidim, died after a brief illness at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center yesterday. He was 91 years old and lived in Montclair, N.J.
LEAD: Sharon L. Bass's interview with Caroline O. Dinegar (Connecticut Q&A, Jan. 15) brings out an all too typically skewed view of what the overused word ''terrorism'' means and who practices it.
LEAD: MANY people like sugar, but too many people feel guilty about consuming it, the Sugar Association believes.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Oyster Bay Burger Battle JOE DELLAMONICA is thinking of taking his hamburger fight to the President of the United States. ''Maybe I should see Bush,'' he said. ''After all, we're talking discrimination here.''
LEAD: I NEEDED pots and pans. After eight years of marriage and what seems like dozens of cheap, on-sale sets of generic brands, I decided it was time to invest in quality cookware.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: A report last Sunday about the engagement of Leslie Sue Gaberman to John Brooks Harkavy misidentified the prospective bridegroom's undergraduate university. It was Brown.

LEAD: We tend to describe the course of art history during the 16th and 17th centuries in Europe almost exclusively through paintings, sculpture and architecture, but it was hardly less through the humbler medium of the print that art was experienced at the time. When King Francis I commissioned an elaborate decorative program for the palace at Fontainebleau from the Bolognese painter Francesco Primaticcio, it was the influence of Parmigianino that could everywhere be felt in the result.

LEAD: Game birds, including pheasant, quail, mallard ducks, turkeys, chukar and Hungarian partridge, have been appearing on the menus of posh restaurants with greater frequency in recent years, according to Herbert Jordan, a poultry scientist with Pennsylvania State University.
LEAD: There can't be many predicaments more daunting than the one in which the Devils found themselves tonight at the Forum. A scant four minutes into the second period, they were behind by 5-0.
LEAD: Abercrombie & Kent/Continental Waterways, 1420 Kensington Road, Oak Brook. Ill. 60521 (312-954-2944; 800-323-7308 outside Illinois).

LEAD: Contemporary bed sharing might be regarded as an important social adaptation among families with working parents. Nesting in the family bed may be a way to find some of that elusive ''quality time'' as well as compensation for the separation that occurs during the day. FRANCES LEVINE THOMAS W.

LEAD: Because of the influence of professional art advisers, corporate art collections today include more than the traditional paintings and drawings. Large-scale works custom-designed for particular sites - and therefore almost always commissioned - have become widespread.
LEAD: BLACK and Hispanic people and women make up a disproportionate number of AIDS patients on Long Island, mirroring recent national statistics.
LEAD: 'LANDSCAPES'' is the title of the current show at the Pelham Art Center and landscapes are what it consists of - 39 of them by four artists.

LEAD: Companies have a new rationale for assembling art these days. Not only are they amassing beautiful objects to decorate their offices and for the sake of investment. They are also using art to make statements. And the developments are not only influencing the art companies are buying, but corporations' roles in the art world.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Roger C. Schmutz of Bailey Island, Me., and Marco Island, Fla., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Anne Elizabeth Schmutz, to Donald Campbell Hovey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald O. Hovey of Saint Davids, Pa. The couple plan to marry in July.

LEAD: President Bush had planned to stay quietly at home today, going over some paperwork, chatting with Brent Scowcroft, his visiting national security adviser, and unpacking some boxes of winter clothes.

LEAD: For the last three weeks, the Kitchen has been host to a new-music series it is presenting with Roulette, the smaller downtown Manhattan performance space that has eclipsed the Kitchen's musical reputation in recent years. Thursday was the first of three nights of concerts with Fred Frith, the English art-rock avant-gardist.

LEAD: Lori Barbara Katz and Michael Jon Goldstein plan to marry next month. The future bridegroom's sister, Laura Megan Goldstein, and Mark David Yumkas are to be married in September, and Marc David Goldstein, the brother of Michael and Laura Goldstein, is to marry Elaine Miriam Gendel in December. The engagements were announced by the parents of the future brides, Mr.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Calhoun Bond of Lutherville, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter Louise Cover Bond to Robert William Heck, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Heck of Venice, Fla. A May wedding is planned. Miss Bond, a social worker at the Catholic Home Bureau in New York, graduated from Trinity College in Hartford and received a master's degree in social work from Hunter College.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Hubert J. Brandt of Lido Beach, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Karen Rose Brandt to Kenan Onel, a son of Miriam Onel of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Dr. Joseph Onel. An April wedding is planned.

LEAD: FAMILY NATURE Since this is between seasons on the Sunday television front - you know, after football, but before Steinbrenner - it is a great time for some family togetherness in yet another area. Nature, for example. And the Environmental Centers of Setauket-Smithtown have just the program to fit the bill today: ''Dinosaurs for the Family.
LEAD: After 20 years the nation's first planned community has a final sign of maturity -its own cemetery.
LEAD: Nicaragua says it has formed an international group of experts to study the construction of a canal to link the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans across Nicaragua.

LEAD: Two of 17 jailed terrorists whose release is the major demand of kidnappers holding American hostages in Lebanon have been freed after serving five-year prison terms, Kuwait's Interior Minister said today.

LEAD: In a deeply moving three-hour ceremony here marked by loud and joyous acclamation and strong protest as well, the Rev. Barbara Clementine Harris, a 55-year-old priest, today became the first woman consecrated as a bishop in the Episcopal Church.
LEAD: Faced with the increase in AIDS among minority groups, women here and elsewhere are turning an old concept, the Tupperware party, into a medium for sex education.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Harry Poulakakos, the owner of Harry's Bar in the Wall Street area, received a ballot in the mail last month from the New York Telephone Company that asked him to choose a company to provide long-distance service to the seven pay telephones in his establishment.

LEAD: Older Americans already paying higher premiums and a surtax this year for expanded Medicare coverage are angrily discovering that supplementary private insurance, which they thought would become less expensive, is costing more, too.

LEAD: Parents who sleep with their babies are likely to spend more time touching them, and there is much scientific support for the benefits of touching. Touching has profound effects on growth and development. Studies of the benefits of touching in humans have led to changes in hospital procedures for premature and boarder babies.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Mario C. Rattazzi of Port Washington, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Claudia G. Rattazzi, to Ron Papka, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Papka of South Paterson, N.J. A June wedding is planned. Ms. Rattazzi, a writer and freelance editor, graduated magna cum laude from Columbia College, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa.

LEAD: In the political arena, in 1877, Rutherford B. Hayes was serving his first year as President. In the racing world, the Kentucky Derby had its third running, with Baden Baden winning a $3,300 purse. In canine circles, the Westminster Kennel Club held its first show.

LEAD: Residents of Nassau and Suffolk Counties have more Long Island television news available to them now than ever before. Cablevision's News 12 Long Island provides 24-hour news service for subscribers - about half the television households on Long Island.

LEAD: Willie Burton scored 5 of his 27 points during a 33-second span late in the game to put Minnesota ahead for good, and the Gophers continued their string of home upsets by beating 10th-ranked Michigan, 88-80, today.

LEAD: Well over half the people surveyed at a public meeting last month in White Plains said race relations in Westchester County were getting worse. And almost half of those questioned believe there is a great deal of racial prejudice in the county.

LEAD: It has been 19 years since he broke in with Houston, and now at the age of 37 and two years into apparent retirement, Cesar Cedeno is attempting a comeback with the Astros. He has been invited to spring training to try out as a pinch-hitter. ''We need bench strength from the right side of the plate, and we think he might fill that void,'' said a club spokesman, Rob

LEAD: I HAVE been married to the same man for more than 40 years, so naturally you would assume that I have become resigned to his no-nonsense ways. Not so. I must confess that I have spent years trying to mold him into the Prince Charming of my romantic fantasies. A case in point is Valentine's Day.

LEAD: Jacquot Wins Title: Rene Jacquot became the first Frenchman in 30 years to win a world boxing championship by scoring a unanimous 12-round decision over Donald Curry of the United States for the World Boxing Council super-welterweight title last night at Grenoble, France. The scoring by the judges was: Sid Nathan of Britain, 117-113; Justo Vasquez of Spain, 118-115, and Jesus Arias of Mexico, 118-116, all in favor of Jacquot.

LEAD: President Bush's first formal foreign trip, marking the importance of relations with Japan, will be to attend Emperor Hirohito's funeral later this month. But Mr. Bush is starting off on the wrong foot, having inherited an impending deal on fighter aircraft production that is decidedly unfair to the United

LEAD: With Workfare I read with interest the article ''Few Show Up for Workfare Jobs'' [ Jan. 29 ] . I'm not surprised. Since the beginning of December I've been visiting the Elmsford Motor Lodge almost daily - trying to get people off welfare. And, the results have also been discouraging.

LEAD: The 1989 Tanglewood Music Festival in Lenox, Mass., is scheduled to open on June 30 with a concert by the Boston Symphony Chamber Players at the festival's theater. The first concert by the full Boston Symphony will follow on July 7 in the shed.

LEAD: Dr. Daniel Tranel, a neuroscientist at the University of Iowa College of Medicine, has been awarded a $20,000 grant from the Rita G. Rudel Foundation of New York City. The funds will support his research in the field of behavioral neurology.

LEAD: George J. Feeney, the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation's senior vice president for advanced development, leaned across the table in his utilitarian Manhattan office and talked about, of all things, oil.

LEAD: The composer Christian Sinding (1856-1941) is remembered for one of music's great chestnuts, ''Rustle of Spring,'' which brought his name into many a genteel parlor in Europe and the Americas. His symphonies, sonatas and concertos are overshadowed today, even in his native Norway, by those of his greater compatriots, Svendsen and Grieg.

LEAD: The Good Mother 1988. Touchstone Home Video. 1 hour, 44 minutes. $89.95. Closed captioned (CC). Rated R. Diane Keaton stars in Leonard Nimoy's drama, based on the novel by Sue Miller, about a recently divorced woman who unwittingly risks losing her daughter when she takes a lover. With Liam Neeson and Jason Robards.
LEAD: Q. I have a stall shower that has tiled walls up to the painted ceiling. Every two or three years this paint peels and flakes and we have to repaint. Is there a special paint I can use?

LEAD: Some of the most memorable songs on Broadway this season were written by an all but forgotten lyricist, Andy Razaf. The American-born son of an Malagasy nobleman, Razaf wrote the words to more than 500 tunes, mostly in the 1920's and 30's, before he died in 1973. Among them are seven songs in the long-running ''Ain't Misbehavin' '' and five in the recently opened ''Black and Blue'' - including the title songs.

LEAD: While corporations have long patronized the arts, they are much more active participants in the process these days. ''They are not merely lending works to museum shows, but are organizing shows and sponsoring tours drawing from their own collections,'' said Judith A. Jedlicka, president of the Business Committee for the

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Stephen B. Judlowe of Murray Hill, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter Karen Toby Judlowe to Spencer Gary Smul, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sanford Smul of New York. The couple plan to marry in November.

LEAD: ''She dances not as a gypsy but as a lady, and within this range her mastery of nuance, the accuracy with which she makes her point, is unparalleled. The lightest of ironies colors her suggestion of passion, of speed, of grace. And it keeps her performance within the bounds of what may be done with good taste in public.

LEAD: ENCOURAGED, perhaps, by the New Jerseyans who commute to Manhattan, three of the state's museums are visiting there. To be precise, the Montclair Art Museum, the Newark Museum and the State Museum in Trenton, have sent samplings of their permanent collections to the International Business Machines Corporation's Gallery of Science and Art, 590 Madison Avenue, at 56th
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: During the last 15 to 20 years, art historians like Robert L. Herbert have changed art history. They believe that nothing can be understood apart from its social context and that absolutely everything in art has meaning. Each splash of color, each odd angle and each straight line is seen as a product of intention and choice.

LEAD: As the race for governor heats up, candidates are beginning to confront the high cost of automobile insurance, an issue that infuriates almost everyone in New Jersey and is understood by practically no one.

LEAD: There are times when musical history seems determined to repeat old tunes, as if hoping this time to get them right. There was something hauntingly familiar, for instance, about the situation in which Daniel Barenboim found himself recently when, in the midst of acrimonious wrangling over his dismissal as music director of Paris's Bastille Opera, the news broke of his appointment as music director of the Chicago Symphony, effective in 1991.

LEAD: As scandals mount in the financial and commodities markets, economists theorize that the market determines one's ethicality. If ''everybody'' cheats, those who don't will be wiped out. Like much economic writing, this conclusion is not based on factual observations of ethical traders who went bankrupt, but on abstract theories about ''perfect competition.
LEAD: A Superior Court jury convicted Peter T. Trepanier today on 27 counts stemming from sniper attacks that terrorized northern Rhode Island two winters ago.

LEAD: Hats off and kudos to the Suffolk County Department of Health and Community Hospital of Western Suffolk for bringing safe, available and competent prenatal care to hundreds of needy mothers-to-be [ ''Midwives Gaining L.I. Role,'' Jan. 22 ] .
LEAD: Time and again during his eight years as President, Ronald Reagan depicted the Federal Government as a wasteful monster that needed to be cut down to size.

LEAD: When residents of this affluent suburb of Portland voted in December not to buy the 25-acre estate known as Conifer Ledges, they confirmed what many here have felt for some time: Oceanfront property has become too expensive for public agencies. The estate would have given the community its only waterfront park.
LEAD: For one brief shining moment, officials of a small central Arkansas city thought they were sitting on a gold mine of potential garbage pits.
LEAD: Twenty years ago, Representative Donald E. (Buz) Lukens was a rising star in Ohio Republican politics, a man many envisioned as a future Governor or United States Senator.
LEAD: A 48-year-old man has been sentenced to death for the murder of 14 members of his family near this northwest Arkansas town a year ago.

LEAD: Two despondent 15-year-old boys carved their own tombstones from plastic foam and wrote suicide notes, then fatally shot themselves in a wooded area near their homes, the authorities say. The bodies of the boys, Phillip Gomiser and David Olive, who disappeared a week ago, were found Wednesday night by Phillip's father.

LEAD: INCH by inch, the fallen tree was crafted into a four-ton white oak shaft to drive the gristmill at Philipsburg Manor here. Soon the song of the water wheel at the Upper Mills will be heard once more on the Pocantico River, where a replica of an 18th-century mill demonstrates the power of falling water.

LEAD: New York farmers grew more apples, tomatoes and pears last year than in 1987 but smaller quantities of sweet corn, cabbage, cherries and onions, according to a series of year-end reports issued by the New York Agricultural Statistics Service here.

LEAD: Someone asked Charles Barkley if the National Basketball Association All-Star Game Sunday would be entertaining even though Magic Johnson and Larry Bird would not be playing, because of injuries. When Barkley heard the question, his face twisted into a menacing grimace, the type of look he usually saves for referees after they whistle a foul on him.

LEAD: Islene Pinder and her Balinese American Dance Theater presented a program of contemporary dance inspired by Balinese theater on Friday night at the Marymount Manhattan Theater. In her program notes, Ms. Pinder writes of attempting to produce a blend of Balinese theatricality and Western abstraction that will have a universal resonance.
LEAD: After spending hundreds of thousands of dollars to develop a radial tire for the Nascar circuit, Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company has had to admit that the tires are just not up to speed.

LEAD: Three mysterious fires broke out within hours of each other in metropolitan Manila, razing 2,000 houses and leaving up to 15,000 people homeless, police said today. The first fire broke out Friday afternoon in Tondo, a Manila slum district, destroying about 2,000 houses in a four-block area. Several people, mostly children, were missing but there were no reports of deaths, police said.

LEAD: By self-appointment film purveyor to the world, Hollywood, in turn, has always welcomed artists from abroad. Some great directors, such as Jean Renoir and Max Ophuls, came and went. F. W. Murnau, Billy Wilder and Fritz Lang, among others, stayed, responded to the environment and prospered. Each in his own way enriched the American movie idiom.

LEAD: At night, the American Embassy here is one of the city's most spectacular sights. Bathed in brilliant spotlights, surrounded by double fences of curved steel spikes and coiled razor wire, it stands out in gleaming relief against the dark background of the city.
LEAD: ''ALL we do is meet about the drug problem,'' said Police Chief Maurice T. Turner Jr. of the District of Columbia. ''It's driving the resources of the metropolitan police department.''

LEAD: The engagement of Bonnie Hope Rattner and Robert Alan Klugman has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Michael Rattner of Wheatley Heights, L.I. Mr. Klugman is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Klugman of New Rochelle, N.Y. A June 30 wedding is planned.
LEAD: THE ECONOMICS OF CHAOS On Revitalizing the American Economy. By Eliot Janeway. 402 pp. New York: Truman Talley Books/E. P. Dutton. $22.50.

LEAD: The world can expect widespread economic decline and social disruption in the 1990's unless national leaders make a serious commitment to reverse the deterioration of the earth's environmental systems, a Washington-based research group said today.

LEAD: The New York Daily News asked the State Supreme Court in Manhattan Friday to force a special prosecutor, Charles J. Hynes, to disclose details of his inquiry into the source of a disclosure to The New York Times in the Tawana Brawley case last year. Mr. Hynes said in January that he could not establish how The Times obtained summaries of evidence in the case.

LEAD: A NEW building for adolescent alcohol and drug abusers that will have all the equipment, treatment, schooling and resident experts that their physical, mental and behavioral disorders will require is under construction at South Oaks Hospital.

LEAD: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that the United States had decided not to break off its dialogue with the Palestine Liberation Organization now, despite an appeal from Israel. The Israeli appeal followed a clash between P.L.O. guerrillas and Israeli troops last weekend in southern Lebanon.

LEAD: CHRISTMAS may be long gone, but there are still fancy wrappings around town. Most are long and sumptuous, covering up evening dresses in a turn-of-the-century manner. As we approach the year 2000, perhaps that's entirely appropriate.

LEAD: In the swirling fog at the corner of Neon and Lonely Streets, by the bar of the Heartbreak Hotel, a ghostly figure in a trenchcoat and slouch hat steps out under a blue streetlight. Launching into a smoky jazz-flavored ballad, James Taxi, a pint-size private eye, huskily drawls out an ode to rain-soaked streets at 2 in the morning, whisky and shining saxophones.

LEAD: One day melds quietly into the next here at the Last Post, a lovely 37-acre wooded retreat for elderly cats. Many of the cats spend entire days lounging in one of the 60-foot-long pine-paneled cat sitting rooms, with the skylights, ceiling fans and large wood beams trucked in from Maine. Hundreds of happy cats rest on the sitting room armchairs, couches and tables.
