LEAD: The young West German pianist Andreas Bach returned to the 92d Street Y on Saturday night playing Bartok, Beethoven, Schumann and Liszt. A look at Mr. Bach's brief biography in the printed notes suggests that he is not the product of high-powered conservatories, but has studied quietly with the same teacher for the last nine years.

LEAD: Card magic comes in two varieties: the physical illusions of the card manipulator, and the technical brilliancies of the card player. Sidney Lenz, a great star of the past, could bring off both kinds of tricks. That is why he never played bridge for a money stake.

LEAD: WHEN HDM, the unusual hybrid offspring of Young & Rubicam, Dentsu of Japan and Paris-based Eurocom, was born a year and a half ago, skeptics said it would never work. The three parents had such different cultures that the infant would be pulled apart, they cried. Worse, clients would surely ignore it in favor of its elders.

LEAD: Talk about the power play and the Rangers' locker room instantly resembles an encounter group for millionaires suddenly gone bust. The players sit, palms upturned, expressions downcast, unable to say where the millions and the magic have gone.

LEAD: Tonight, ''Nova'' returns to Chernobyl, the site of the world's worst nuclear accident, to explore what happened the morning of April 26, 1986, and what has been happening since -and, as an aside, whether it could happen here. LEAD: The Coastal Corporation extended its $2.6 billion cash offer for the Texas Eastern Corporation by 10 days after the deadline for its original offer expired Monday. Coastal officials extended the $42-a-share offer to next Thursday, a spokesman, Robert Wells, said. Both companies are based in Houston.

Grieg's familiar Ballade and Christian Sinding's B-minor Sonata were there. Also played were newer pieces by Finn Mortensen, Arne Nordheim and Antonio Bibalo.

LEAD: The National Credit Card Trust 1989 is offering $750 million worth of debt securities backed by Citibank Visa and Mastercard receivables through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

LEAD: The governing body of the pilots' union at Eastern Air Lines Inc. issued a strongly worded resolution yesterday recommending that its 3,500 members respect any picket line set up by the airline's other unions.
LEAD: Charles S. Gage, a retired treasurer of Yale University, died Sunday at Yale-New Haven Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in Hamden, Conn.
LEAD: The British screenwriter T. E. B. Clarke, whose screenplays included the Academy Award-winning script for ''The Lavender Hill Mob,'' died of cancer here on Saturday. He was 81 years old.

LEAD: * Ann-Margret, the film actress, is the spokeswoman in a public service ad campaign created by the Venet Companies, a subsidiary of GMI Group Inc., for the Myasthenia Gravis Foundation. Myasthenia gravis is a neuromuscular disease.

LEAD: Ending a legal battle over compensation for victims of the world's most deadly industrial disaster, the Indian Supreme Court today ordered the Union Carbide Corporation to pay $470 million in damages for the toxic gas leak at Bhopal.

LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Banks is offering $6.38 billion in bonds, including a competitive issue, in five parts. All are priced at par, except for the competitive deal, which went to an underwriting group led by Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.
LEAD: The singer Diana Ross has become a part owner of Motown Records and has agreed to resume recording for the label she helped propel to popularity in the 1960's.
LEAD: In the final hours of the Soviet military withdrawal from Afghanistan, the Soviet Union seemed braced today for a rapid deterioration of the military situation it is leaving behind.

LEAD: The Environmental Protection Agency has barred its employees from inspecting the Government's uranium processing plant in Ohio because of the risk of exposure to radioactivity, an agency spokeswoman said today.

LEAD: Police officers escorting suspected drug dealers from the building at 447 Vermont Avenue in the East New York section of Brooklyn yesterday morning. Later in the day, the building was torn down, left. Page B2. (NYT/Nancy Siesel)

LEAD: On a recent visit to El Salvador, Vice President Dan Quayle demanded a thorough investigation of an incident in which 10 peasants were killed last year, and American officials said today that evidence strongly suggested that the Salvadoran Army was responsible.

LEAD: Rubin Postaer & Associates, known best for its largest client, Honda automobiles, has taken in another Japanese account: Seiko Instruments U.S.A., a division of Hattori Seiko, which makes consumer electronics products. This is Seiko Instruments' first consumer ad agency. The account is expected to bill $5 million.

LEAD: ''In a Pig's Valise,'' the ''hard-boiled yarn with music'' at the Second Stage, is an homage to detective fiction by a playwright whose affection for Raymond Chandler and Dashiell Hammett may be second only to his love for the sound of his own voice. The playwright is Eric Overmyer, the author of the widely produced ''On the Verge,'' a work of such relentless erudition that its icy intricacies of diction linger long after the play's subject and human mouthpieces have evaporated.
LEAD: Suffolk Balks at Lilco Deal

LEAD: The Central Intelligence Agency denied today that the communications machines at the American Embassy in Moscow had been subject to electronic eavesdropping by Soviet agents, an assertion made in a new book on security lapses at the embassy.

LEAD: The wife of John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, has been hired by the Republican Governors' Association to prepare a book and do political fund raising, the director of the association says.

LEAD: William Garbe, an artist known for his large-scale watercolors of birds, flowers and seashore life, died last Thursday on the way to St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 41 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: Grey Advertising reported that its 1988 earnings rose 13.6 percent, to $11.7 million, or $8.88 a share. This figure excludes the one-time earnings lift from the sale of foreign and domestic subsidiaries. Grey's net income was $10.3 million in 1987. The company's gross billings in 1988 were $2.48 billion.

LEAD: Bud G. Holman, the lawyer who led the defense of the Union Carbide Corporation against lawsuits arising from the Bhopal disaster, learned of the resolution of the four years of litigation in a telephone call from India at 3:30 yesterday morning to his Manhattan home.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The headline of a report in the Sports People column yesterday misstated plans for physical examinations of Kiki Vandeweghe, the Portland Trail Blazers' forward. He will undergo exams, but one has not been scheduled by the Knicks.
LEAD: A penny-stock firm accused of defrauding thousands of customers has halted its operation, citing the financial pressure from a flood of investors seeking their money back.

LEAD: An article on Saturday about the removal of State Senator Israel Ruiz of New York after his Federal felony conviction described state law on the removal process incorrectly. It specifies that the post is vacated when a legislator is convicted of a felony; it does not require that the crime be considered a felony under New York State law.

LEAD: Before Paula Howard could sniff the dozen red roses she received for Valentine's Day yesterday, they had to be flown from California to Newark with thousands of others, trucked through the Holland Tunnel to Manhattan, sorted on West 28th Street, driven to Second Avenue and delivered to 59th Street and Lexington Avenue.

LEAD: A Federal district judge today rejected a proposed agreement by the Justice Department and the independent prosecutor that would have limited the ability of lawyers for Oliver L. North to disclose state secrets at his criminal trial without prior Government approval.

LEAD: THE BHOPAL SETTLEMENT Union Carbide was ordered to pay $470 million in damages for the December 1984 toxic gas leak in Bhopal, India, ending a legal battle over compensation for victims of the world's deadliest industrial accident. The Indian Supreme Court's settlement proposal was accepted by Carbide, and all suits against the company and its former chairman, Warren Anderson, were dropped.

LEAD: A 19-year-old man sought in the fatal stabbing of a high school student at a party last weekend in New Jersey was captured by the police in New Mexico last night after an hour-long car chase, officials said.
LEAD: Joan Wetmore, an actress who portrayed many elegant women in her nearly 30 years on Broadway, died of cancer Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 77 years old.
LEAD: New York City residents and businesses would be required to separate their garbage into three categories under a proposed recycling law submitted to city officials yesterday.
LEAD: Dr. Alan Saul Pomerance, a dentist, died of lung cancer Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 62 years old.

LEAD: As a teen-ager in the 1930's, Jack B. Weinstein played bit parts in Broadway shows and was briefly one of the bad boys in the original ''Dead End.'' In those same years, the future law professor and judge delivered milk and worked at a trucking company to earn money for school.

LEAD: The regulator designated by President Bush to oversee about 200 insolvent savings institutions said today that property values in the Southwest would not suffer as a result of quick sales of troubled institutions or portions of the thousands of failed projects they financed.
LEAD: When fire damaged the house of Robert C. McFarlane on Sunday, the former national security adviser to President Ronald Reagan became temporarily homeless.

LEAD: Misdiagnoses by doctors, faulty prescriptions and improper use of drugs by patients have created widespread problems among the elderly, a new Government study has found. For example, 51 percent of deaths from drug reactions in this country involve people 60 years of age or older, even though they account for only 17 percent of the population, the report said.

LEAD: A sleek, elegant red Doberman bitch, Ch. Royal Tudor's Wild as the Wind, C.D., who answers to the name of Indy, last night was named the supreme winner of the 113th annual Westminster Kennel Club show in Madison Square Garden.

LEAD: One of the more mysterious characters in bridge literature is a lady named ''Sylvia,'' who appeared frequently in the bridge columns of B. Jay Becker. He died in 1987, after one of the greatest careers in the history of the game, but Sylvia, one hopes, lives on.

LEAD: Dr. Helane Susan Rosenberg and Dr. Yakov Michael Epstein, both faculty members at Rutgers University, were married last evening at the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue in New York. Cantor Philip Sherman performed the ceremony.

LEAD: The Tandy Corporation, a consumer electronics manufacturer and retailer, announced today that its new division, the Grid Systems Corporation. would take over marketing the company's computers to corporations and governments.
LEAD: Preparations for the 1994 World Cup, the first to be held in the United States, are barely under way and a change has already been made at the top of the organizing committee.

LEAD: The Government announced today that Central Americans seeking political asylum would be processed at a remote detention center near here, and within hours dozens of aliens began setting up a primitive camp in the brush outside the gates.

LEAD: In a rising tide of religious fervor that might have been unimaginable only a week ago in Pakistan, Islamic leaders today called for nationwide protests on Friday, the Muslim Sabbath, against the wider publication in the West of the book ''Satanic Verses.''

LEAD: Belgium's central bank increased a key interest rate today for the fourth time this month and the sixth time this year. The bank raised the rate on the three-month Treasury bill by 0.15 percentage point, to 8.10 percent. The bank also raised the rates on one- and two-month Treasury bills by 0.10 percentage point each, to 7.7 percent and 7.9 percent, respectively, and the rate on four-month certificates by 0.35 point, to 8.10 percent.
LEAD: Borough President David N. Dinkins of Manhattan announced his candidacy for mayor yesterday, saying that he can unite a divided city.

LEAD: The dollar tumbled against leading foreign currencies yesterday, largely in response to President Bush's remarks opposing further tightening of credit by the Federal Reserve Board. The statement coincided with indications that the Japanese and West German central banks are about to raise interest rates.
LEAD: * British Airways P.L.C., London, said it would begin daily flights between London and Newark starting in the spring of 1990.

LEAD: A gathering of millions of Hindus for a major festival has served as an impressive display of the hold that faith continues to have on the life of this young nation and ancient land.

LEAD: An article by The Associated Press in some editions on Tuesday about a court ruling on transit service for the disabled misidentified the lawyer who argued before a Federal appeals court. He was Timothy M. Cook, director of the Washington-based National Disability Action Center.

LEAD: Voytek Matushevski, a pianist from Poland, devoted his Sunday afternoon Alice Tully Hall recital to music by four composers who were also virtuoso pianists. LEAD: A half century, 50 years, more than 26 million minutes ago. Most of a man's life. LEAD: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said Tuesday that he would sell his personal stock holdings and those of his wife and a minor child to avoid any appearance of a conflict of interest. Questions have been raised about his substantial holdings in the Chemical Banking Corporation of New York. When he was Treasury Secretary, Chemical had large investments in loans to third-world countries that were being pressured by the Treasury to repay their loans, and as Secretary of State, he may have to consider issues involving third-world finances.

LEAD: It violates minimal comity among nations for the leader of one state to clamor for the murder of citizens of another. Ayatollah Khomeini goes further. LEAD: ''BLACK coffee and a cinnamon doughnut,'' I said to the man behind the counter. ''No sugar, right?'' he replied. All I could think of was the day a little girl I used to escort around town ushered me up to the newsstand where she bought her comic books and said grandly, ''They know me here.

LEAD: A long, graying ponytail and a fondness for marijuana are all that remain of Eddie Dodd's 1960's idealism - these, and a reflexive tendency to stick up for the underdog, no matter how disreputable the underdog might be. So Eddie, who once had the reputation of a brilliant and courageous lawyer and is still thought of as a very clever one, makes it his business to defend the constitutional rights of drug dealers - drug dealers who are apt to drive away from the courthouse in their sports cars, smiling.

LEAD: BEFORE television, before newspapers, even before alphabets, news was spread and history recorded by song. Melodies and rhythms turned raw data into art; rhymes, verse structures and repetitions (like Homer's ''wine-dark sea'' and ''rosy-fingered dawn'') were aids to memory. While modern telecommunications and general literacy have challenged music's monopoly on carrying information, they haven't eliminated that role.

LEAD: UNTIL spring, most New Yorkers would probably prefer to forget that there even is an outdoors, a place where chill winds nip mercilessly at bundled-up strollers. LEAD: Everything appeared to be in place at Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening for a memorable performance of ''La Damnation de Faust.'' The Orchestre de Paris and its music director of 14 years, Daniel Barenboim, could be expected to have the idiom of Berlioz's ''dramatic legend'' in their bones. This was, furthermore, not the usual collection of orchestral excerpts, but the complete score, with the orchestra's own 163-member chorus imported for the occasion.

LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said today that its 1988 profits would generate $460 million in profit-sharing payments, or more than $2,800 per employee, the second highest since the payments began six years ago.

LEAD: A picture yesterday with an obituary of William H. Baumer, an industrial executive and former United States Army officer who helped plan the World War II invasion of Normandy, was published in error. It showed Maj. William H. Baumer, an Air Force officer captured during the Korean War.

LEAD: More than 350 members of the United States Olympic Committee's house of delegates will vote Saturday for the six officers who will lead the organization through the 1992 Olympic Games in Albertville, France, and Barcelona, Spain.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Peter MacDonald, chairman of the Navajo Indian Nation, who said Thursday that he would take paid leave of absence amid accusations that he had taken kickbacks, reversed himself today and said he would stay in the job.

LEAD: A Soviet ballet instructor smashed his head through a glass window and jumped to his death from an apartment building a day after his arrival in the United States, the police here said today. Boris Sinitsyn, 55 years old, apparently committed suicide Thursday morning by jumping from the 35th story of the Galaxy Towers complex, where he and his wife, Mina, 69, also a ballet instructor, had been visiting relatives, the police said.

LEAD: He has won 73 Winston Cup races, but none at Daytona International Speedway. ''If I win, I'm gonna spike my helmet in the winner's circle, and then I'm gonna do the Ickey Shuffle,'' Waltrip said yesterday.

LEAD: The engagement of Alison Ramona Wylegala to Stephen Joseph Lewis, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Lewis of Honesdale, Pa., has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Raymond V. Wylegala of Buffalo. The couple plan to marry in April. Miss Wylegala is an associate producer in New York with GTG/East, the producer of ''USA Today on TV,'' a nationally syndicated program.

LEAD: MUSHROOMS have always been the stuff of fairy tales but in Kennett Square, Pa., the noble fungus is a way of life. The town is the heart of Chester County, which calls itself the world's mushroom capital. According to the Federal Department of Agriculture, two-thirds of the country's annual crop of nearly 400 million pounds is produced in the county by 160 growers, the largest concentration anywhere.

LEAD: IF you order tea in one of the Ramada Istanbul's several spacious restaurants, you will notice pink tulips on the cups and saucers - for the handsome new cream hotel, combining modern atriums with beautiful Turkish design, is at the center of the Laleli district, and lale is Turkish for tulip. As with tulips (said to have arrived in the Netherlands from Turkey), life in Laleli is always a treat for the eye.

LEAD: A basic rule for picking a loudspeaker is to allow plenty of time for listening comparisons. LEAD: HE hums a pretty fair ''Yogi Bear'' theme and loves He-Man and potato chips. His smile glows from within, and giggles start from unknown places. He loves to sit on the windowsill and stare out at a world he cannot comprehend. Every day of my life he breaks my heart - and makes my heart sing, as well.

LEAD: To the Editor: Safaris in Kenya and Tanzania are often very expensive, as you highlighted on Dec. 4. Many of your readers might, therefore, be interested to learn that South Africa offers the same safari experience for a substantially lower price. For example, the cost of a night in Kruger National Park ranges from approximately $20 to $40 a person a night.

LEAD: ''Coney Island of the Mind: Images of Coney Island in Art and Popular Culture 1890-1960'' will be at the Whitney Museum of American Art, downtown, at Federal Reserve Plaza, from Wednesday through April 21. The work of painters and photographers like Joseph Stella, Margaret Bourke-White and Diane Arbus is to be included among the approximately 90 paintings, drawings, prints and photographs.
LEAD: On Thursday, the Justice Department made it official: An undisclosed number of traders on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange were being investigated for illegal trading.

LEAD: ONE of the longest, bitterest conversion fights in Manhattan apartment house history has ended with the imposing Century Apartments at 25 Central Park West becoming a condominium, huge profits for both the sponsors and residents and the payment of millions of dollars in legal fees.
LEAD: The stereotype - conjured in the black and white of 1930's Hollywood prison pictures - is of a piggish brute, blackjacking cowering prisoners in the dark, dank cells of solitary.

LEAD: THE question of what to do about acid rain has pitted region against region and produced an angry stalemate in Congress for the better part of a decade. Now, with President Bush backing action and with a realignment of forces on Capitol Hill, a revised Clean Air Act with strong acid rain controls is a distinct likelihood, perhaps as early as this year.

LEAD: I HAVE always known that I was adopted. It is a constant in my life, like being left-handed, an accident of fate over which I had no control at all. I don't know what it feels like to have Aunt Jessie's smile, Uncle Jack's mean temper or Grandma's legs: my smile, temper and legs are mine alone and although I am aware that somewhere out there the matching set exists I am not constantly reminded of them.
LEAD: One thing Marxist rebels and the far right in El Salvador agree on is that U.S. policy in Central America is a resounding failure. Of course they have opposite reasons.

LEAD: As a champion of the interpreter's individual rights, Russell Sherman, I hope, will not mind this writer's own explanation of why Friday's piano recital at the Metropolitan Museum was so strangely ordered.
LEAD: AT black-tie dinners, on a beach in Florida, even in his sleep, David Mintz is thinking tofu - that spongy white substance with an origin no one seems quite sure of.

LEAD: ON most days, residents of Shady Lake Park do not have far to travel to pick up their mail: there are 14 mailbox clusters in this lakeside community at the foot of the Ramapo Mountains. But in winter, they say, the hilly, winding roads coated with snow and ice sometimes become impassable and dangerous.

LEAD: John Cassavetes, who died two weeks ago, will be as appreciatively remembered for what he didn't do as for what he did. In conceiving, writing, directing, financing and sometimes distributing his own films, Mr. Cassavetes most definitely did not play ball. He did not get along with either conventional Hollywood or the New York avant-garde, and he did not set much stock in an acting career of which others would have been proud.

LEAD: Vince Damphousse's two third-period goals rallied Toronto and Mark Osborne scored the winner on a power play as the Maple Leafs defeated the New Jersey Devils, 5-3, tonight.

LEAD: EVER since Marble Hill was severed from the rest of Manhattan by the construction of the Harlem Ship Canal nearly a century ago, the 52-acre enclave has led an isolated existence. Its narrow, winding roads, lined with one- and two-family houses, give it the feel of a small village.

From March 5 to April 16, the ship will sail between San Juan and Tampa, calling at Grand Cayman Island, Santo Domingo, St. Croix and St. Martin.

LEAD: Art curators, once as anonymous as starving artists, have stepped into the spotlight of contemporary art. With them comes a new definition of the job. While curators of tradition are academically trained art historians who work in museums behind doors that say ''No Admittance,'' many of the new curators are young, often fashionable, art-world operators who are more a part of the scene than an establishment.

LEAD: THE report that appeared in an official Polish publication last week attesting that Soviet troops were responsible for the wartime executions of 4,443 Polish officers in the Katyn forest was hardly a revelation. The entire Polish nation has known this for decades. It was a fact of life that grandmothers routinely told grandchildren.

LEAD: ORDINARILY, this is the time of year when I would be writing about how to adjust your exposure when photographing snow or how to carry your camera while cross-country skiing. But the weather has conspired against these topics.
LEAD: A Long Island man died late last night after being shot during a robbery on a Greenwich Village sidewalk, the police said.

LEAD: To the Editor: The article said that at the Empire Tearoom, High Tea is available and then described it as consisting of sandwiches, scones and jam, cake, etc. This is Afternoon Tea. High Tea is a larger meal eaten later in the afternoon or evening, is often a cooked meal and nowadays is more likely to be the family supper.

It's a celebration of the delightfully warm, sunny days of midspring, before the blistering sun of the Southwestern summer makes a midday outdoor excursion an ordeal. It's an extra excuse to search out the weathered, old wood and stone homes, stores and churches that form classic landscapes in the

LEAD: THE IMMORTAL BARTFUSS, by Aharon Appelfeld. Translated by Jeffrey M. Green. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $7.95.) A retarded daughter helps a concentration camp survivor break out of his bleak inner world. Last year our reviewer, Leonard Michaels, said the novel ''offers an extraordinary adventure in character portrayal that is reminiscent of 'The Stranger' by Albert Camus, but more extreme in its vision of alienation, more daring in its art.

LEAD: At Miami Edison Senior High School, many black students who came from Haiti share a common lie, insisting that they really came from the Bahamas. They are trying to avoid the ridicule of some American blacks, who denounce Haitian blacks as obsequious.

LEAD: In the hours leading up to last Wednesday night's Knick-Cavalier game, Wayne Embry, the Cleveland general manager, was askedwhether the Detroit Pistons or the Dallas Mavericks got the better of the Adrian Dantley-for-Mark Aguirre trade earlier in the day.

LEAD: Much of the program presented by Daniel Lepkoff on Friday night at Performance Space 122 might have inspired the most loyal of mothers to wonder why she'd sent her boy to dance school. In ''Boneyard,'' for instance, Mr. Lepkoff and Paul Langland progressed from sitting and performing simple arm gestures to sitting and pulling at each others' mouths and poking fingers through the curling fingers of each others' hands.

LEAD: Let me encourage Leonard L. Riskin, who shows no interest in team sports (About Men: ''Unsportsmanlike Conduct,'' Jan. 22) . Indeed, working at a large university more frequently known for its athletic teams than for its intellectual accomplishments, I am aware of the magnetic force fields that radiate from the stadium; they are the greatest of a long list of academic diversions that make up modern university life.
LEAD: WHY DID THE HEAVENS NOT DARKEN? The ''Final Solution'' in History. By Arno J. Mayer. 492 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $27.95.

LEAD: AS the full spring moon climbed over the silhouetted Livingstone Mountains, the lakeshore quieted. Under the cover of darkness, Fiordland's Lake Te Anau had been alive with brown and rainbow trout cruising the shallows. But, as if a light switch had been thrown, they stopped feeding and the elusive trout retreated to darker, deeper waters.

LEAD: WHEN I was my daughter's age, I used to enjoy sketching room plans for my house-to-be. (I think this followed hot on the heels of fashion layouts and bridal dress.) Usually the rooms were spacious and numerous, with no regard for such construction details as plumbing, insulation and electricity. The houses had conservatories and morning rooms, and money was no object.
LEAD: On a recent morning near the airport here, Cuban soldiers filed into a military medical center, rolled up their sleeves and gave blood for tests for the AIDS virus.

LEAD: ON a recent ''wish list,'' The Northern Westchester Guidance Center cited a need for dollhouses and dolls, especially ''families'' of dolls. The toy houses and imagined families serve as essential clinical tools to help troubled children and adolescents communicate about the often indescribable reality of physical and sexual abuse, suicidal depression or serious illness.
LEAD: The local Veterans Council has sparked cries of anti-Semitism and the possibility of legal action by refusing to amend its charter to admit a local Jewish veterans group.

LEAD: Allow me to add my appraisal to those voiced in the article ''Fairleigh Dickinson's Core Curriculum Appraised.'' I had a chance to observe Fairleigh Dickinson students in 1980 and 1981 when I earned an M.B.A. on Saturdays in the university's ''M.B.A. for data- processing professionals program,'' an excellent concept that I wish could be expanded to the Ph.D.

LEAD: Stephanie Mariette Cabot, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Powell M. Cabot of Greenwich, Conn., is engaged to Marcus Lovell-Smith, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Lovell-Smith of Taunton, Somerset, England, the future bride's parents have announced. The couple plan to marry in June.

LEAD: Adela Holzer, a Broadway producer, has put on one act too many, according to the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau. Ms. Holzer, who was the toast of Broadway two decades ago as the producer of the rock musical ''Hair'' and other theatrical hits, was arrested last week on charges that she swindled investors out of $280,000 while posing as David Rockefeller's ''secret'' wife.

LEAD: WHEN I first moved to Galveston in the summer of 1984, it was less than a year after Hurricane Alicia and the building boom that insurance money had brought to the island. The people I met would invariably steer conversations to the aftermath of Alicia: the swimming pool lifted six inches out of the ground by a spin-off tornado, the water marks on the den paneling.

LEAD: In every life we have some trouble, When you worry, you make it double. Don't worry, be happy.

LEAD: DEAF THEATER COMEDY The National Theater of the Deaf will give two performances of Philip de Broca's ''King of Hearts,'' based on the French film of the same name. A romantic comedy originally released in the 1960's, the movie has become a cult classic.

LEAD: At 2:45 A.M. on Jan. 20, a flash of flame engulfed a silent house in a sleeping northeast Kansas City neighborhood, and six people died, victims of a firebomb and the country's narcotics plague.

LEAD: SPURRED by growing concern over the spread of Lyme disease, Northeastern legislators, led by Representative George J. Hochbrueckner of Long Island, have introduced companion measures to channel $10.5 million into fighting the tick-borne infection.

LEAD: William Sharp, a baritone who hails originally from Kansas City, Mo., won the 1987 Carnegie Hall International American Music Competition, and Monday night he was presented for a song recital in the main hall.

LEAD: Tennis Becker Beats McEnroe: Top-seeded Boris Becker of West Germany defeated third-seeded John McEnroe, 6-2, 6-3, yesterday in the semifinals of the Stella Artois indoor tournament in Milan, Italy. LEAD: The Shakespeare marathon has been characterized in this newspaper [ ''Peaks and Valleys in Papp's Marathon,'' by Frank Rich, Feb. 5 ] as an enterprise lacking a unifying vision and having no unifying principle other than ''Joseph Papp presents.'' Needless to say, I consider such charges baseless and I resent them.
LEAD: Few theater composers can claim as broad a stylistic grasp as Micki Grant, whose body of work is being celebrated in a new revue, ''Step Into My World,'' at the Amas Repertory Theater.

LEAD: Q. My wife and I recently bought a 63-year-old house and we are planning a number of renovations. The heating system is covered with asbestos, so we have done some air quality tests. There are no dangerous levels of asbestos in the air. Should we put removing the asbestos at the top of our priority list?

LEAD: FOR many years, a real estate brokerage's path to commissions on the sales of cooperative apartments was built on contracts to manage the buildings. That insider's edge led many firms to serve as managing agents for New York apartment houses at little or no profit, or even at a loss, as long as fat brokerage fees were coming in.

LEAD: Word has been wafting through the perfumed Paris air that Yves Saint Laurent is up to something big. Now, here it is, show time on the next-to-last day of the spring 1989 Paris couture collections. In the ornate velvet and red gilded ballroom that Saint Laurent traditionally uses to present his season's oeuvres, a runway stretches beneath the low-hanging chandeliers from a stage smothered with red and purple bougainvillea.
LEAD: George Steinbrenner's involvement in sports expanded today when the United States Olympic Committee house of delegates elected him as one of three vice presidents to serve through 1992.

LEAD: FOR THE NEW YORK METS, spring training has just gotten under way in Port St. Lucie, Fla., but Bob Ojeda, a left-handed starting pitcher, has been warming up almost daily since the cast came off his throwing hand in mid-November. By now, Ojeda says, his arm is strong, the muscles in his hand have been resuscitated by exercise, and his catchers are telling him his ball is moving as well as it ever has.

LEAD: Bertha Hope, a pianist who brought a quartet to Birdland on Thursday night, has a terrific rhythmic sense. Working with the be-bop vocabulary, she smacks a series of syncopated notes, throws in descending series of chords, and lets her left hand rumble.

LEAD: I agree with Geraldine M. Fox [ Topics, ''Abuse on TV,'' Jan. 29 ] . Afternoon and evening expose and talk shows are not in the business of educating the public. They are in business, period. Dollar signs dance before them as they probe open wounds before the eyes of the morbidly curious.

LEAD: ''WE never fade,'' reads the caption under the picture of a grinning little black boy straddling a spool of Clarks black thread. Standing nearby on the floor is a painted wooden figure, also a smiling black child, this one clutching a piece of hose.

LEAD: Jerome Robbins, master choreographer, famed Broadway director, is leaning against a piano and singing. The words are not from his new show, ''Jerome Robbins's Broadway,'' which opens next Sunday at the Imperial Theater. Nor are they from any of the many musicals he directed and/or choreographed on Broadway from 1944 to 1964, from ''On the Town'' to ''Fiddler on the Roof'' - 11 of which are represented in this new production.
LEAD: Peter Ueberroth grimaces at the word ''caretaker.'' He thinks of himself as an activist who ran baseball as a chief executive officer for four full years, and is leaving profits behind.

LEAD: EVALUATING the qualifications of a home inspector has never been easy. And it may become even more difficult in the coming months as professional and trade groups battle over who is more competent to make inspections.

LEAD: After more than a year of trying to assure travelers that the Holy Land is safe - that Arabs and Jews aren't fighting on every corner - tourism officials here admit that 1988 was a terrible year and agree that Israel's tourism woes will not be solved until its political problems are.

LEAD: A decade after Parliament legalized abortions in this fundamentally Roman Catholic country, the law is under increasing attack on all sides, from those who believe it is too liberal to those who say it creates too many obstacles for women.

LEAD: Although he was sitting on the bench with his team, the Lincoln High School basketball coach, Bobby Hartstein, declined to take any credit for his Railsplitters' 56-36 victory over Midwood yesterday in the opening round of the Public Schools Athletic League championship tournament.

LEAD: The 80-year-old RKO Keith's Prospect Theater in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn, where many actors and vaudevillians started their careers, is itself taking on a new role. The 500-seat theater, which once featured the Marx Brothers, the Three Stooges, Burns and Allen and other stars of pre-electronic entertainment, is being converted with an existing supermarket into the 19-unit Park Plaza Condominium.

LEAD: A woman who was given the option of losing 100 pounds to wipe out a fine on a marijuana conviction has failed to do so and must pay $500. Judge Michael Fisher told the woman, Tina Usinger, last year that she could reduce her fine by $5 for each pound she lost, but when she returned to court this week, she still weighed 265 pounds.

LEAD: Two historians and a writer have sought to prove that a major work by the prominent military historian S.L.A. Marshallwas based on faked evidence. At issue is whether a majority of American foot soldiers in World War II actually fired their weapons in battle.

LEAD: Midway through last Friday's hearing that would determine Tim Teufel's salary with the Mets this season, the arbitrator, Richard Bloch, saying ''I've never done this before,'' halted the proceedings.

LEAD: The needlessly dramatic plight of the Donetsk Ballet from the Soviet Union, stranded in Baltimore after its American producers ran out of funds, is part of a tangled and cautionary tale. United States-Soviet cultural exchange will now have to take into greater account the differences that exist between our two societies.

LEAD: SMITHTOWN'S Casa Rustica is a champion among Italian restaurants on an island loaded with contenders. Some of the also-rans may be ritzier or have snappier service, but a look at the menu and a taste of the food separate Casa Rustica from the pack.
LEAD: When the public gets what it wants, it moves on to other things, as members of Congress have been reminded in their 10-day recess.

LEAD: Schubert's Piano Sonata in B-flat Major, D. 960 (Op. post.) and Impromptus, D. 899 (Op. 90) Carol Rosenberger, piano. Delos 3018, CD.

LEAD: Tone Loc: 'Wild Thing' Delicious Vinyl/Island, 12-inch single. A massive dance club hit, ''Wild Thing,'' which has a silly rap about seduction, mixes the glittering, silvery sound of club music, a little grinding rock-and-roll and hip-hop. Tone Loc (Tony Smith) is part of a blossoming Los Angeles hip-hop scene, and his rap has a nice sort of amble to it.
LEAD: MY PLACE By Sally Morgan. 360 pp. New York: Seaver Books/Henry Holt & Company. $19.95.

LEAD: Like Deutsche Grammophon, EMI has begun its new digitally recorded ''Ring des Nibelungen'' with ''Die Walkure.'' The EMI version, conducted by Bernard Haitink, features Eva Marton, Cheryl Studer, James Morris, Reiner Goldberg, Matti Salminen, Waltraud Meier and the Bavarian Radio Symphony (EMI CDS 7 49534; four CD's and LP's three cassettes).
LEAD: A small-town doctor who was the model for a well-known illustration by Norman Rockwell retired today on his 83d birthday.

LEAD: AT the same time that computer scientists are thinking of their machines as organisms, biologists are thinking of organisms as though they were computers. In fact, some physicists have come to believe that the universe itself is a kind of giant calculating machine.
LEAD: MORT JANKLOW TELLS THIS story to illustrate how far the balance of power in book publishing has tipped in his favor:
LEAD: ''SKI SOUTH POLE,'' say the T-shirts, ''two inches of powder, 10,000 feet of base.''
LEAD: WHEN the musical trio Fidelio formed two years ago in Hartford, its members had a problem. ''There's almost no existing music for our combination,'' said Harry Clark, the group's cellist.

LEAD: A New Jersey man responsible for a string of armed robberies in elevators in midtown Manhattan office buildings was arrested Friday evening after a woman he was trying to rob resisted, the police said.

LEAD: On one side of Latin pop - the commercial side - are handsome young crooners who deliver internationalized ballads. On the other are unglamorous bands that play salsa for dancers. Luis Enrique, a Puerto Rican singer who opened a week of New York engagements on Tuesday at S.O.B.'s, seeks to bring together both audiences.

LEAD: A matchup of Marcus O'Sullivan and Said Aouita in the mile did not materialize Friday night at The Los Angeles Times meet in California, and it will not happen this indoor season. After Aouita won the mile in 3 minutes 54.99 seconds and O'Sullivan finished second in the 3,000 meters in 7:51.56, Aouita announced that he was cutting short his United States tour and returning home to Morocco.
LEAD: R.E.M.: 'Green' Warner Bros. 25795-1, all three formats.

LEAD: Moments after his team's abysmal performance against the Maple Leafs on Friday night, Michel Bergeron was a confused, concerned coach. He admitted he might have overestimated his players, that he might have been misled by the Rangers' remarkable first half of the season. There were a lot of questions to be resolved.
LEAD: A one-time member of the Black Liberation Army has pleaded guilty to wounding two police officers in a 1974 bank holdup, ending the oldest criminal case in Connecticut's courts.

LEAD: RACIAL tensions in the nation's largest police department, already inflamed by accusations of racism by white officers in a Queens precinct, seem to be multiplying. Last week the leader of a fraternal officers' group for blacks criticized the leader of a Hispanic officers' group over accusations that Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward is insensitive toward Hispanic New Yorkers.

LEAD: Randy Myers was back home in Vancouver, Wash., but 22 other pitchers and 6 catchers opened the Mets' 28th spring training camp today with a show of force and probably the best young arms in baseball.

LEAD: Simply Red: 'A New Flame' Elektra 60828-4, all three formats.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Vietnam is seeking American tourists and trade, and the Presidency is becoming a dim memory for Democrats. And now Jane Fonda and Tom Hayden are saying it's over for them, too. When they were married in 1973, Ms. Fonda and Mr. Hayden formed a union emblematic of the antiwar movement and the pop-leftist politics that grew out of the Summer of Love.

LEAD: On Friday, the Board of Elections is slated to mail letters to 300,000 New York City residents telling them that, as required by state law, they are being removed from the voter rolls because they have not voted in the last four elections. Each letter will include a new registration form and a postage-paid return envelope.

LEAD: CAROL BOTWIN, a co-founder and co-director of the Westfield-based Better Relationship Training Institute, is the author of ''Men Who Can't Be Faithful.'' In the book - as in her earlier works like ''Is There Sex After Marriage?'' - she writes about relationships between men and women.

LEAD: Elvis Costello's sheer productivity used to trip him up. A dozen full-length albums from his 1977 debut, ''My Aim Is True,'' to the new ''Spike'' (Warner Bros. 25848, LP, cassette and CD) haven't been enough to hold his output. But with ''Spike,'' his first album since 1986 (when he released two), Mr.
LEAD: Astronomers applying Einstein's general theory of relativity to three-dimensional space believe that the universe is curved and has no center.
LEAD: It was a milestone in the bitter history of South Africa. A hunger strike by hundreds of prisoners held without trial moved the Government.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: It was an abandoned shell of a house with a trailer parked in the front yard. Inside, the floors were nothing but gravel, and rather than finished rooms, exposed two-by-fours formed a skeletal interior. Still, Mark McDonald and Ralph Cutler, owners of the Manhattan store Fifty-50, were taken with the building and with the Hudson Valley site.

LEAD: George Washington's birthday, actually Feb. 22, will be observed on Monday. Here are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only; main office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Banks: Option to close. Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended.

LEAD: Deborah Lynn Stone and Daniel J. Grossman, third-year law students at Duke University, are planning an August wedding, the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Michael B. Stone of Atlanta, have announced. Mr. Grossman is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sanford Grossman of Chappaqua, N.Y.

LEAD: Connecticut has 166 school districts spread out over its 169 independent towns, but the numbers disguise a deep imbalance: More than 80 percent of all minority children in the state - most of them black and Hispanic - are concentrated in just 14 districts in the largest cities, while elsewhere the schools are overwhelmingly white.

LEAD: COMING HOME AND OTHER STORIES. By Farida Karodia. (Heinemann, Paper, $7.50.) In ''Coming Home,'' Farida Karodia's collection of stories set in South Africa, home is where the hate is. From the townships to the large cities, the remote villages to the white suburbs, Ms. Karodia, a South African writer who now lives in Canada, depicts a land deformed by rage and random violence.
LEAD: MAJESTIC in flight, intriguing in habit and a mess to clean up after, the Canada goose arouses passionate emotions.
LEAD: THE future of the 1923 Naumburg Bandshell on the Mall in Central Park, while not exactly a controversy, presents a messy problem nonetheless.

LEAD: AN entire collection of United States ''entires'' probably does not exist. But this certainly does not prevent a hobbyist from trying to build - who knows - what might become the first such collection.

LEAD: If you are planning to attend the Metropolitan Opera's new production of Strauss's ''Salome,'' which opens tomorrow evening, don't expect to see such familiar trappings as palm trees, ancient robes, a brightly shining moon, or even the cistern in which John the Baptist is held prisoner. Prepare instead for a glassy, high-rise palace with

LEAD: Michael Sovern endorses recently-enacted legislation that exempts from taxation the interest earned on Series EE savings bonds when the proceeds are used to pay for a family member's college education. Mr. Sovern is certainly correct in recognizing this as a highly attractive vehicle for college savers.
LEAD: PROFSCAM Professors and the Demise of Higher Education. By Charles J. Sykes. 304 pp. Washington: Regnery Gateway. $18.95.

LEAD: There is a fifth ''R'' in addition to the four ''R's'' in the Jan. 29 article on reduction in force (''The Plight of Long Island Defense Workers'') and that is: Reincarnate as an entrepreneur. (The story said: retire, retrain, relocate or get rehired by another company.) From my knowledge of NASA cutbacks in the Boston area, I believe that 10 to 20 percent of ''riffed'' (reduced in force) workers at all levels of previous employment have the potential for a significantly better-than-average probability of success as entrepreneurs.

LEAD: In the view of a California jury, there are certain secrets that lovers must share. The jury said it was ''outrageous'' of Rock Hudson, who died of AIDS in 1985, to have concealed his disease from his lover, Marc Christian.
LEAD: THE smell of the border, the sweet, dirty aroma of the Rio Grande, stuck to two Nicaraguan teen-agers as they crawled toward a confusing encounter with the land of their dreams.

LEAD: THERE is a war in the news these days and the wounded are almost all women and children. This is not a war on foreign shores fought between fanatical factions. It is going on right around us between women and the judicial system, and the object of the war is the children, who are the victims.
LEAD: THE MUSHROOM-PICKER By Zinovy Zinik. Translated by Michael Glenny. 282 pp. New York: A Thomas Dunne Book/ St. Martin's Press. $16.95.

LEAD: ON a basketball court, Jenny and Krissy Kuziemski resemble each other in so many ways that it is difficult to tell them apart. In fact, if it were not for the difference in their uniform numbers, it would be virtually impossible to tell them apart at all.

LEAD: The Beethoven of the early 1820's, the time of the Missa Solemnis, presents one of the unforgettable portraits in artistic history. Here is the old master, deaf, unkempt, bewildered, buffeted by life, poring over the old masters of sacred music, pressing relentlessly inward and outward the frontiers of his own creative realm, composing a mass for the ages (''singing, howling, stamping'' it, in one famous account), while he slides recklessly into debt and negotiates duplicitously with half a dozen publishers for rights to (and advances on) the work.
LEAD: Scott Haffner scored 65 points - tied for sixth-most in a Division I game -and led Evansville past Dayton, 109-83, in a Midwestern Collegiate Conference game today.

LEAD: The order of the State Supreme Court requiring the owner-contractor James Patrick Kennedy to remove the 26-by-47-foot addition on his home in order to preserve the integrity of the Grove Street Historic District in Tarrytown [ ''Preservationists Praise Tarrytown Ruling,'' Jan. 22 ] is a prime illustration of a worthy objective gone awry.

LEAD: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 3 THE SHELL SEEKERS, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (Dell, $4.95.) The jealousies and rivalries of a wealthy family on Boston's Beacon Hill.
LEAD: JOHN DOLLAR By Marianne Wiggins. 214 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $17.95.

LEAD: President Eisenhower's warning about the dangers of a military-industrial complex continues to have relevance for succeeding generations. The issue has become increasingly urgent as the United States struggles to adjust to the challenges of a new internationally competitive environment.

LEAD: As I read the interesting article, ''Chinese Films Offer New Perspective'' (Jan. 22), I pondered the question of why we Long Islanders accept some foreign products eagerly while avoiding others. We clasp alien cars, television sets and home appliances eagerly, while avoiding others. When it comes to entertainment, though, we seem convinced that nothing on our screens is worthy of attention unless it is of domestic origin.

LEAD: It is positively amazing to consider the misinformation spread regarding what might happen if there was an accident at the Shoreham nuclear plant. The latest is the article which appeared on the Opinion page Jan. 29 under the title ''Shoreham Evacuation: Like the Blizzard of '86?''
LEAD: Kara Lynn Glover and John Philip Billhardt2d were married yesterday at the Marble Collegiate Church by the Rev. Dr. Robert Williams.

LEAD: ''As author of 'The Satanic Verses,' I recognize that Muslims in many parts of the world are genuinely distressed by the publication of my novel. I profoundly regret the distress that publication has occasioned to sincere followers of Islam. Living as we do in a world of many faiths, this experience has served to remind us that we must all be conscious of the sensibilities of others.

LEAD: THERE is plenty of ocean south of Long Island, but there are closer, more intimate seas in our marshes; seas of reeds, penetrated by tidal creeks whose vistas coil through acres of spartina grass and giant phragmites in paths hidden from casual observers, but open to explorers in canoe, johnboat or sneak box.

LEAD: The Adirondack Park Agency, a New York State regulatory body, criticized the United States Air Force Friday for scheduling low-level flights over the park.

LEAD: People in France may be perfectly happy hopping from store to store - in one shop for a loaf of bread, another for a few sausages and yet another for a bar of soap or a box of lily of the valley dusting powder.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: EVER since I read that five or six games - Ping-Pong for one - had been added to the long list of sporting events included at the Summer Olympics in Seoul, I've been wondering how I could promote one of the most popular but least recognized games for inclusion in the 1992 games in Barcelona. That sport is wastebasket ball, the game we all play in the home, at work, in the classroom or wherever there is a wastebasket.

LEAD: Dr. Harvey R. Nova, a neurosurgeon at Englewood Hospital in New Jersey, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Tenafly, N.J. He was 53 years old.

LEAD: WRITERS ON ARTISTS. Edited by Daniel Halpern. (North Point Press, $25.) Proust on Chardin, Sartre on Tintoretto, Huxley on El Greco, Hemingway on Miro - writers discussing painters hold the irresistible promise of insight beyond formal analysis, interpretation beyond conventional art history. But writers commenting on painting is tricky business: they risk turning visual images into words, replacing the art under study with their own.

LEAD: THE end of 1988 completed a dozen years of uninterrupted growth for metropolitan New Jersey and New York. Though the rate of growth may moderate, there is every reason for confidence that 1989 will bring continued prosperity to the region.

LEAD: At age 71, he's as lean as the backboard pole in the playground below his fifth-floor Harlem apartment. But arthritis had Pop Gates sitting on pillows on the long curved couch in his living room. Asked if he would rather move to a favorite chair, he smiled.

LEAD: The Commerce Department's report early this month on January employment was seen by some economists as one more sign that wage increases are about to accelerate, adding to inflationary pressures. Hourly wages, for example, rose at an annual rate of more than 7.6 percent. Also noteworthy was the addition of 408,000 to the nation's payrolls in January, an unexpectedly sharp increase that was only partly explained by unseasonably mild weather.
LEAD: Dear Mr. President:
LEAD: A former grand wizard of the Ku Klux Klan, narrowly defeated his opponent to win a seat today in the Louisiana Legislature after a campaign peppered with charges of racism.
LEAD: The state's highest court has ruled that New York City was not liable for injuries to two teachers assaulted on school grounds.

LEAD: IN her recent book ''AIDS and Its Metaphors,'' Susan Sontag reflects on how the sudden emergence of computer viruses evokes many of modern society's most primal fears. Just as AIDS has unnerved people by conjuring up earlier visions of human plagues, she suggests, the advent of the computer virus is undermining the public's faith in the information revolution and changing the way people think about computers, as organisms rather than machines.
LEAD: William Altman clearly loves teaching history, classics and philosophy at the local high school, but for the past 17 months the community has been rent over his ethics and classroom behavior.

LEAD: Because of a distributor's change, an article on page 17 of Arts and Leisure today about the film ''Rachel River'' misidentifies the theater. It is at the Gemini.

LEAD: Pernell Whitaker,the 1984 Olympic gold medalist, won the International Boxing Federation lightweight title today when he beat the champion, Greg Haugen, on a unanimous 12-round decision at the Hampton Coliseum.

LEAD: Six United States warplanes on a low-level training flight changed course without warning last Tuesday and flew dangerously close to six passenger jets, a magazine reported today.

LEAD: A RESTAURANT writer could keep busy reviewing Connecticut's Chinese restaurants alone. It is not just the reviewing, but the need for re-reviewing, as nothing in the food service industry seems to change faster than the personnel in a Chinese restaurant kitchen. ''Very good'' today can turn into a mere ''satisfactory'' in a matter of weeks; such is the speed of the chef's revolving door.

LEAD: A LAWSUIT filed by a captain in the Belleville Fire Department alleging that the department's lack of an adequate communications system constitutes a serious safety and health hazard has highlighted the need for mandatory, statewide firefighting procedures and training, fire union officials say.

LEAD: ''This gives me chills.'' says Joseph Abboud, the New York men's-wear designer, who has been leafing through a volume of Norman Rockwell illustrations. He finds what he is after, a 1940's Saturday Evening Post cover, whose subject, he admits, never fails to stir him. Rockwell's depiction of a war veteran turned scholar is abrim with nostalgic detail.

LEAD: Dr. Lori Beth Zimmerman and Scott Richard Benson were married last evening at the Harmonie Club in New York. Rabbi Miriam Shapero and Cantor Jacob Yaron officiated.

LEAD: IT is likely that there are more horses in Monmouth County than in any other part of New Jersey. This may be true, yet no statistic can indicate the adventure of having a farm adjoining one of a horse trainer.

LEAD: A major Canadian pharmaceutical house is going to build a $70 million headquarters in Ridgefield, Conn., for two of its American subsidiaries in an innovative structure that will accommodate 700 employees. The company, Pharma-Investment Ltd. of Toronto, will erect the 266,000-square-foot building for the administrative staffs of its wholly owned subsidiaries, the Boehringer Ingelheim Corporation and Boehringer Ingelheim Pharmaceuticals Inc.

LEAD: GEORGE BUSH never cheats at tennis. Unlike many highly competitive players, the President does not even give himself the benefit of the doubt on marginal line calls. His parents instilled in him such strict standards of personal behavior that some old Texas friends have been known to complain that he is ''too ethical.

There are no dangerous levels of asbestos in the air. Should we put removing the asbestos at the top of our priority list?

Gator, after going 22-6 in 1985, hit a dismal stretch of bad luck, late signings, operations, poor offensive support. These boys have got a lot more wins in 'em and they both deserve to stand tall on that hill 'cause they sure ain't over it.

LEAD: PAKISTAN'S Prime Minister, Benazir Bhutto, should have come back from her first official visit abroad last week to a welcoming crowd.
LEAD: The St. John's coach, Lou Carnesecca, tried to keep his mind off how DePaul had come back to beat his Redmen two years ago.

LEAD: The article ''Elderly Are Offered Reverse Mortages'' [ Jan. 29 ] is misleading. The mortgages described are home-equity loans that place a second or possibly first mortgage on a house based on the house's value without regard to income and must be repaid in full with interest at the end of 10 years.

LEAD: Considering what a disaster his last visit turned out to be, it's a wonder that Lloyd Honeyghan wants to go back to Nevada. The British boxer not only lost his World Boxing Council welterweight title to Marlon Starling there on Feb. 4, he also flunked the post-fight drug test when traces of the banned painkiller lidocaine were found in his urine.

LEAD: To the Editor: We came back from Madrid just in time to see Mr. Pujol's letter and can offer a sad second to his comments about the city's hotels. We stayed at the Grand Hotel Victoria, part of the Tryp chain, which is architecturally grand and has a helpful staff, but otherwise left much to be desired.
LEAD: Thirty of President Bush's first hundred days are gone, yet he still has no government capable of managing foreign affairs and national security.

LEAD: To the Editor: The airlines should offer a discount fare to relatives who have to fly on short notice when a family member dies unexpectedly. It would be a plus to the airlines and create a better feeling among passengers, showing that the airlines have a humanitarian feeling.

LEAD: NORTH FORK MUSIC Just in time to bring some cheer to the winterbound North Fork, the Oysterponds Historical Society begins its series of occasional concerts at Poquatuck Hall today. Opening-day honors go to Anima, a Baroque ensemble that was lured back after a successful performance last summer.

LEAD: A Presidential commission has warned that the country is dangerously short of the transport ships it would need in a major war and has proposed a 10-year, $13 billion construction program to start filling the gap.

LEAD: WHEN a house has at least 70 rooms, 30-foot-high ceilings, walls two feet thick and a dining room that can seat 200 guests, is it a chateau, a mansion, a castle, or perhaps a hotel? Realty people called the house, in Huntington, L.I., one of the largest private homes in the nation.

LEAD: The engagement of Kimberly Gail Waldorf to Brian Krick Mercer has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Helmuth Waldorf of Brookville, L.I. A March 18 wedding is planned.

LEAD: A newborn boy, a mere patch of flesh with a tangerine-sized head and limbs like splinters, lay tethered to a thicket of tubes on a heated table in a special ward for premature infants at New York Hospital.

LEAD: THIS is American Music Month, but the British are coming. Expect visits this week from the composers Thea Musgrave and Nicholas Maw, plus two unusual vocal ensembles: Electric Phoenix and the King's Singers.
LEAD: TEN Fairfield County towns expect to save thousands of dollars a year by letting someone else do the initial screening of their police applicants.
LEAD: UNLIKE the budget battles of Ronald Reagan's first term, President Bush's first engagement with Capitol Hill is not a fight for fiscal direction so much as a dance around political blame.

LEAD: Towson State University is to participate in an unusual exchange with the Rimsky-Korsakov Leningrad State Conservatory in the Soviet Union. Under terms of an open-ended exchange announced last week at the university in Towson, Md., Towson dance students and students in the conservatory's ballet school are to study for a semester at each others' schools in 1990.

LEAD: It is always comforting when things come full circle. Ashes to ashes, dust to dust, bass to bass. This thought is prompted by news that a stretch of Manhattan's deteriorated West Side Highway is about to assume a new identity - as an ocean reef for sea bass and other marine life.

LEAD: The Music View column on page 27 of Arts and Leisure today describes a concert performance of excerpts from ''Tristan und Isolde'' incorrectly. It is Act II that will be performed - tomorrow night, by the Orchestre de Paris under the direction of Daniel Barenboim at Avery Fisher Hall.

LEAD: Billy Ard of the Giants, one of the National Football League's newly created free agents, has talked to several teams. He said he liked some of the things he saw. One of those teams, the San Francisco 49ers, said it was interested in Ard.

LEAD: MANY of the technical moves in cardplay seem to have straightforward parameters until examined closely. Then they begin to blur around the edges. A finesse is difficult to define satisfactorily. An endplay can occur at the first trick. A squeeze can operate in a single suit, and the declarer can be the victim.

LEAD: An undetermined amount of radioactive gas was inadvertently released today from the Connecticut Yankee nuclear-power plant, but a plant spokesman said the amount was probably well below hazardous levels.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The author Salman Rushdie, facing a death threat from Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini of Iran, said today that he regretted the distress that his novel ''The Satanic Verses'' has caused Muslims.

LEAD: To the Editor: Regarding Paul Delaney's article (Travel, Jan. 1) on the national inns of Spain, the system is no longer government owned and has not been for several years. The system is now independent, although like all of Spain's hotels the paradors are subject to strict regulation as to quality and prices.

LEAD: The Portland Trail Blazers dismissed Coach Mike Schuler today and replaced him on an interim basis with an assistant coach, Rick Adelman. Schuler, 48 years old, was named the National Basketball Association's coach of the year in his first season at Portland, in 1986-87, when the Blazers had a 49-33 record.
LEAD: I don't believe Tommy John can help the Yanks. He was a great pitcher, but at age 45 he is just taking up space and depriving some youngster of a chance to make the team.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Ralph R. Popkin of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Dr. Catherine D. Popkin to Marc I. Berens, a son of Yolana Berens Somlo of Miami Beach and the late Julius G. Berens. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: Four months after the enactment of a Federal law banning sludge dumping at sea by 1992, New York City is exploring a range of alternatives, including transforming sludge into artificial soil, injecting it deep into the earth and burying it beneath the ocean floor.

LEAD: A dispute over a troubled Brooklyn elementary school has flared into a rancorous fight involving a principal who says he fears for his life, a local school board seeking to dismiss its superintendent and a new parent association that wants to topple the official one.
LEAD: A Soviet factory ship stationed two miles off the coast has been a boon to local fishermen who find herring plentiful but buyers scarce.

LEAD: Mozart Piano Concertos No. 26 ''Coronation'' (K. 537) and No. 27 (K. 595) Mitsuko Uchida, piano. Jeffrey Tate, conductor. The English Chamber Orchestra. Philips 420 951.
LEAD: New York State's highest court has issued a ruling that could curtail efforts by groups to use Freedom of Information laws to obtain lists of potential members from the government.

LEAD: George Grande, who has broadcast baseball for CBS Radio and ESPN, will join Phil Rizzuto for Yankee telecasts on WPIX this season. In teaming with Rizzuto, who will return for his 33d season, Grande replaces Bill White, who becomes National League president April 1.

LEAD: It was on his second voyage to the New World, in 1493, that Christopher Columbus spotted the oval island that he would call Santa Maria la Antigua in honor of a church in Seville. Today his experience is shared in some small measure, by the tourists who decend upon Antigua by plane and cruise ship.

LEAD: To the Editor: I hope that mine is not the only voice to reply in outrage to Roxana Robinson's novelesque description of a vacation in the south of Kenya, entitled ''Investing in an Absence of Civilization'' (Travel, Dec. 4).

LEAD: Rather than apologizing for not being interested in sports, why not show your individualism (surely, as American a virtue as spectator sports): proudly do yard work, in plain view of the neighbors, during some championship game. Boldly tell co-workers of the book you read last night - when everyone else was tuned to ''the game.
LEAD: THESE questionable winter mornings are for the birds. The world outside looks black and white but whether or not to venture out is anything but.

LEAD: Yes, the Yankees can use Ronnie and T. J. My presumption is that they have sufficient expertise to give the club the aid the team needs in securing that long-needed pennant. FRANK BERTE West Paterson, N.J.

LEAD: Negotiators for the United States and the European Community today stepped back from a confrontation over trade in hormone-injected meat with compromises that could lead to the easing of American sanctions against $100 million worth of European farm exports.

LEAD: CONSTRUCTION is proceeding on a $100 million resort hotel that is part of the evolution here from a community with dozens of small poolside bungalow hotels to one that serves convention-goers as well as tourists.

At her elbow, Sydney Bachman, a fashion consultant to Bloomingdale's, cooed her approval of a particularly lavish design.
LEAD: A predominantly Polish Roman Catholic Church was closed indefinitely today, hours after the city's bishop summoned police to evict dissident parishioners who had occupied the church for a week.

LEAD: The Yankees have picked up a lot of ''young'' arms during the off season but what they basically have are ''new'' arms, not ''good'' arms.

LEAD: AT WASHINGTON'S HQ George Washington's birthday will be celebrated in 18th-century style at the general's headquarters in North White Plains today. From noon to 4 P.M. the 18th-century farmhouse property where his troops where stationed during the Battle of White Plains in 1776 will be filled with costumed soldiers, their women and children, all carrying out their respective duties and chores.

LEAD: New York City's infrastructure - the manmade web of steel and concrete that holds the five boroughs together and links them to the rest of the world - has loomed before the public lately as a series of problems that need to be fixed.

LEAD: It is precisely individuals like Moreton Binn (''Muttontown Zoning Opposed,'' Jan. 22) who confuse and disrupt the effort to retain a reasonable quality of life on Long Island, and whose boundless and tasteless greed spreads like a virus to other landowners.

LEAD: The news these days is full of references to Times Square, and a lot of them seem contradictory. There are reports that the massive city-state renewal project at the corner of 42d Street and Broadway - a project that was announced in 1981 but which after eight years has yet to begin construction - is about to get a major boost with the decision of one of the city's biggest banks to relocate its headquarters in the project.
LEAD: The Bush Administration is expected to name Adm. James B. Busey 4th as head of the Federal Aviation Administration, according to Government and aviation industry officials.

LEAD: The violence is over at Motorola Korea Ltd. - at least for now. There are no more workers dousing themselves with paint thinner, barricading themselves in the computer room and threatening to die for the right to form a union. But the fledgling union and management are no closer to agreement than before.
LEAD: THE BEAR HUNTER'S CENTURY By Paul Schullery. Illustrated. 252 pp. New York: Dodd, Mead & Company. $19.95.

LEAD: Adrian Dantley, acquired by the Dallas Mavericks last Wednesday from the Detroit Pistons in a trade for Mark Aguirre, has requested a meeting with the Mavericks' owner, Donald Carter, before he will report. Dantley's agent, David Falk, informed the owner of Dantley's wish by telephone yesterday.

LEAD: Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, President Bush's nominee to head the Department of Health and Human Services, said today that the Administration was ''looking at'' establishing a goal of 25 percent minorities and women in senior positions in the Government.
LEAD: Jerome Alper, a lawyer in Newark for more than 50 years, died Tuesday at the Van Dyk Manor in Montclair, N.J. He was 91 years old and lived in Montclair.

LEAD: With the announcement that Maynard Jackson is seeking to be Mayor of this city again, the lines have been drawn for an election that may turn as much on differences in the histories and styles of the candidates as on promises for the future of the city.
LEAD: The Rangers, who missed the playoffs last season but may be headed that way this spring, have announced a lottery to allocate tickets for the first three playoff rounds.
LEAD: Miracles and the Messiah are being restored to the liturgy of a small but influential movement in American Judaism that has spurned supernatural concepts for more than 40 years.
LEAD: In a national game of word association ''Delaware'' is most likely to be followed by ''DuPont,'' the giant chemical company based here.

LEAD: WHEN the Me Generation came along, I knew instinctively that it would affect primarily Them, and when the Now Generation was announced, I was still working on the day before yesterday. With the onset of the No Generation, I am hopelessly out of touch. It appears we are living in a society whose parameters are defined by negatives, bringing out the worst in us all.
LEAD: About 175 people trapped on a mile-long stretch of ice on Lake Erie that broke free and floated about a mile out on the lake were rescued today by helicopters and boats, officials said.

LEAD: It is only poetic justice that Nina Wolff (''Sneezing Beauty in a Raccoon Coat,'' Jan. 29) should have to suffer physical discomfort from wearing her new garment. After all, many innocent animals had to suffer the tortures of the damned to satisfy her desire for glamour and status.

LEAD: Anchored by the massive adobe landmarks of St. Francis de Assisi church on the south and by Taos Indian Pueblo on the north, Taos seems comfortably settled into winter. Cozy interiors are a specialty here in New Mexico's high desert country, with beehive-shaped kiva fireplaces, Indian rugs, wooden beams overhead - and the sprinkling of hot tubs to be expected in a ski town.
LEAD: Colt Industries has dropped its Federal lawsuit against the city's new ordinance banning possession and sale of semiautomatic assault weapons, the city attorney said Friday.

LEAD: Janet Panetta and John Jasperse depicted compulsive behavior in the dances they presented Friday night at St. Mark's Church under the auspices of the Danspace Project. Both choreographers took obvious pains to devise elaborate tics and tremors. Yet neither managed to make them consistently interesting.

LEAD: I never cease to be amazed at my generation (''Small Tots, Big Biz,'' by Tamar Lewin, Jan. 29). The same parents who will pursue any avenue during pregnancy to assure a ''perfect'' baby will readily institutionalize that same baby during its most vulnerable developmental period.

LEAD: A human rights monitoring group says Rumania's two million Hungarian-speaking citizens are the victims of a Government campaign to destroy their separate cultural identity.
LEAD: Thirteen families were left homeless last night after a three-alarm fire heavily damaged a six-story building in Chinatown, fire officials said.

LEAD: Mrs. James H. Thomas 3d of Yarmouth Port, Mass., has announced the engagement of her daughter Lynn Bryson Thomas to Bradley Craig Heinbach, the son of Mary Ellen Heinbach of Cincinnati and Edgar Heinbach of Oak Brook, Ill. A May 6 wedding is planned.

LEAD: From Washington to Wall Street, and increasingly in the halls of academe, a growing chorus of economists and other financial experts is arguing that there is little justification for a separate savings and loan industry.

LEAD: FOR an easy inexpensive meal, you can't beat chicken. Because of its fairly bland taste, it is probably the most versatile food in the kitchen. It goes with almost any kind of flavor, with herbs and mustard, or with Oriental, North African or Latin American spices.

Walker of Waterloo, Iowa, and Longboat Key, Fla., was married last evening in New York to Dr. Steven Harris Schoenberger, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Stanford L. Schoenberger of Livingston, N.J. Jean S. Kotkin, a leader of the Ethical Culture Society in New York, performed the ceremony at the Four Seasons.

LEAD: To the Editor: Sorry to inform you that your tea time in London article (Travel, Jan. 1) was incorrect. The Ritz no longer has Sunday tea dances. This I know because I have just returned from London and am an avid tea dancer. ANITA ARNOLD ADLER New York

LEAD: Back in mechanical drawing class we would labor for hours to create front, top and side views of a flange. (No one was ever quite sure what a flange was, but we had to draw one nonetheless.) Three views required three drawings and usually resulted in at least three inconsistencies.

LEAD: When the Palestinian uprising in the Israeli-occupied lands broke out, a Jewish businessman here said, he found that his Muslim friends at first did not want to discuss the issue lest the passions of distant conflict blight their relationship.

LEAD: Two thousand years ago, in a cave near the Dead Sea, somebody buried a small clay jug of the oil used to anoint Israeli kings. Last summer, an archeologist unearthed it. The jug is still whole and the oil is still fluid, but the fragrance is gone forever - as is the ancient persimmon plant from which it was extracted.

LEAD: A June wedding is planned by Suzanne Rae Burnette and Cloyd Laporte 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Cloyd Laporte Jr. of New York. Their engagement was announced by the future bride's mother and stepfather, Mr. and Mrs. Jerry F. McGehee of Kingwood, Tex.
LEAD: To the Editor: Sandra Maury wrote that she was overcharged on her Bangkok purchase when she came through customs.

LEAD: HOW do you ''draw'' with a flashlight? Why do rays of light sometimes turn the world upside down? Such questions spanning science and art are imaginatively answered in the school programs and family workshops sponsored by the Katonah Gallery in connection with its current show, ''Stopping Time.''

Is the Mayor being honest, or merely modest? Can David N. Dinkins thwart Mr. Koch's attempt to secure an unprecedented fourth term, and in the process become the city's first black mayor?

There are no dangerous levels of asbestos in the air. Should we put removing the asbestos at the top of our priority list?

LEAD: The engagement of Mary Anne Garrity to Mark Anthony Whitney, a son of Mrs. Richard Whitney of Exeter, N.H., and the late Mr. Whitney, has been made known by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. James L. Garrity of Rye, N.Y. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: ''People I think like to try always - whoever's President - to drive a wedge between the President and the chairman of the Fed. It's one of the best fights in town.'' - President Bush, in an interview denying that he has substantial differences with Alan Greenspan.

LEAD: As I read Bill Earls's essay, ''More Feed, More Line, More Wood: Down (and Out) on the Farm'' (Opinion page, Jan. 22), I'm convinced of one thing; namely, the more things change, the more they stay the same.

LEAD: An article last week about Joyce Copleman's role as a member of the Lawrence Township Planning Board was outdated in describing her tenure. She recently lost a bid for reappointment to the board.

LEAD: BASEBALL season doesn't start until April, but from all appearances baseball-cap season is a year-round affair. A Yankee cap, for instance, is a perfect midwinter match for a full-length fur coat, and it doesn't look too bad with something more casual, like a windbreaker and turtleneck. For men, the recommended attire is pin stripes or a bomber jacket, or both.

LEAD: SO YOU WANT TO MAKE A MOVIE? Most people at one time or another dream about it, but that's all they do, particularly if they don't happen to have gone to film school, worked at one of the major studios and eventually made their way up to director, which can take some time.

LEAD: ELIZABETH HOLTZMAN, the Brooklyn District Attorney, tells of a recent rape prosecution: A 21-year-old woman had gone to her former boyfriend's apartment at his request to pick up some belongings. As the jury heard it later, he tied her wrists with telephone cord, raped her and broke her nose. The jury convicted him of assault and acquitted him on the rape charge.

LEAD: The Notre Dame School, the 77-year-old Upper West Side high school that was to close in June, has found new life in the East Village. The girls school will move to 104 St. Marks Place, near Tompkins Square Park, according to a letter sent to parents and alumnae last week.

LEAD: Ten years ago, I received a Ph.D. in Engineering, and have been working in industry, primarily because there have been few faculty openings available. Demographics show that we will have a shortage of faculty in the 1990's; however, I believe there is a relatively simple solution to the problem.

LEAD: Re Barry Edelson's ''Shoreham Evacuation: Like the Blizzard of '86?'': Mr. Edelson raises the possibility that Long Islanders will behave in an irrational manner if there is a nuclear accident at the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

LEAD: In 1862, when New York City was Manhattan only and Queens was a separate area with towns and villages like Flushing, the Flushing Town Hall was built as a center of civic and social life in that community.
