LEAD: IT was a brilliant morning on a two-lane farm road about 50 miles southeast of Houston, not far inland from the Gulf of Mexico. The big Texas sky was bright and blue, the air still except for the occasional passing of a clanky pickup truck. We had stopped our car along the side of the road to show out-of-state guests a spectacle worthy of a cowboy's boast.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Otis Benson Davis of Kent, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Alexandra Davis to Anthony Francis DiPentima, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Pantaleone Rocco DiPentima of Sunrise, Fla. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: White House officials said today that President Bush had stiffened his support for John G. Tower as the Administration prepared for what the aides described as a critical week in the nomination of Mr. Tower as the Secretary of Defense.

LEAD: Britain's track and field team did not do very well at the 1988 Summer Olympics, and the poor showing is going to be costly. Partly as a result of the Olympic disappointment, the British Amateur Athletic Board announced that it was cutting its budget for payments to athletes by more than 25 percent to $700,000.
LEAD: Faith J. Frankel, a senior financial analyst at Macmillan Inc., and Dr. Howard I. Levy, a physician, plan to marry May 20.

LEAD: In the first public acknowledgement of death squad activity in Mexico, a former Mexican Army soldier is maintaining that he was part of a secret military unit that executed at least 60 political prisoners here in the late 1970's and early 1980's.
LEAD: An article in The Times Magazine today discusses the Democratic primary race for Mayor of Chicago, in which Acting Mayor Eugene Sawyer and Richard M. Daley are the front-runners.
LEAD: A MANAGER IS NOT as big a deal as an >executive. If you do not understand this, you will never get ahead in business or in the media.

LEAD: A new charter for Iona College, recognizing its consolidation with Elizabeth Seton College under the Iona name, has been approved by the New York State Board of Regents.

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: To assure the economic competitiveness of industry in an international marketplace increasingly dominated by government-assisted foreign competition, we need a strategy that focuses on key technologies. Responsibility for such a strategy would cut across agencies that deal with trade, defense, employment, capital markets, science and technology, and the international relations of the United States.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Murray A. Meltzer of Tenafly, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Lori Glazier Meltzer to Peter Desider Starer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Starer of Tenafly. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: Many Israeli Army officers feel that the Palestinian uprising in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip is subsiding, and they say that their soldiers can cope with any major new outbreak of violence.

LEAD: While cities in northern France are vying with each other to get on the high-speed rail link between Paris and London when the channel tunnel opens in 1993, towns and villages in southeastern England are up in arms against it, fearing permanent damage to their environment, eardrums and the English way of life.
LEAD: A program to capture sea lions in Puget Sound and move them down the coast is being re-evaluated after two of the first four animals died.

LEAD: ON the banner outside the Yale University Art Gallery, ''German and Austrian Contemporary Art From the Bareiss Collection'' is proclaimed in a benign, Helvetica-like typeface. Behind the legend are dribbles of dull red mixed with gray that for some reason seem like the automatism of defacement rather than of high art.

LEAD: To the Editor: It would be a pity if the negative comments about Spanish paradors were to cause anyone to pass up one of the great travel experiences of Europe. In more than 80 locations in all parts of Spain, these inns offer an opportunity to relive history amid charming and often spectacular settings.

LEAD: SOONER or later, every United States Administration learns a basic truth about relations with Mexico: more often than not, what you do matters less than what the Mexicans think you have done. For George Bush that lesson has come earlier than usual, and in a particularly instructive set of circumstances.
LEAD: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, met in Damascus today with President Hafez al-Assad in what Syria depicted as a show of support for its policies in the region.

LEAD: ONE expects a stage musical to entertain, enlighten or excite. But ''Singin' in the Rain'' has to do more. It has to justify its existence.

LEAD: THE music scene in the county resumes its busy post-holiday pace next weekend, with chamber concerts leading the way. For starters, there is an intriguing program organized by the Improvised Music Collective, at 9 P.M. Friday in the Bedford Presbyterian Church.

LEAD: To the Editor: I enjoyed your article in the Dec. 4 issue on the high cost of trekking in Africa. I did a photo safari a few years ago to Kenya and Tanzania with Mountain Travel.
LEAD: John H. Jackson, a retired vice president and copy chief of Geer, DuBois Inc., an advertising agency, died of a heart attack Monday at his home in White Plains. He was 73 years old.

LEAD: An article on page 27 in some copies of Arts and Leisure about the soprano Mirella Freni carries an outdated reference to a recital at Carnegie Hall today. It has been canceled because of illness.

LEAD: Hobbled by political scandals, wounded by jokes about his private life, plagued by doubts about his health, Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou has invoked the time-honored sports maxim that the best defense is a good offense.

LEAD: The problem for research universities like Columbia is not, as Michael Sovern contends, finding more money, and his suggestion that professors are going to start leaving these secure havens for rewards outside is laughable. A low-level opening in the humanities produces 80 to 100 applications, even in a second-rate university.

LEAD: ON THE SOUTH SIDE OF CHICAGO, in the lobby of a former union hall, there hangs an old photograph. Striking stockyard workers, blacks and whites, are huddled together for solidarity, and perhaps for warmth, against the fierce winter wind that whips off Lake Michigan, an infamous gale known here as ''The Hawk.
LEAD: Only minutes into ''The Way of the World,'' William Congreve's Restoration play set in a fashionable London chocolate shop in 1770, a leading character orders: ''Bring me some chocolate.''

LEAD: What's she doing now? Whatever will she do next? Ellen Cornfield raised such questions in two quirky solos she presented as part of a program of dances and video works on Thursday night at the Dia Art Foundation.

LEAD: To the Editor: I read with interest the lament of Sandra Maury (Letters, Nov. 13) about the lack of knowledge among customs agents regarding duty exemptions. My experience was similar to hers. I came through customs on Oct. 18, 1988, in San Francisco. I, too, bought items that were handmade works of art that I fully believed to be (and previously were) exempt from duty.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Yellow Fever Alert Issued In Trinidad

LEAD: The Pakistani Air Force, concerned about the possibility of Afghan or Soviet air attacks to the west and wary of the military power of India to the east, is modernizing its inventory of fighter and trainer aircraft, according to diplomats and news reports here.

LEAD: THE director of the Central Intelligence Agency has always had broad authority to discharge any employee deemed a security risk, and that authority was acknowledged last year by the United States Supreme Court. But, the Court added, the power is not unrestrained.

LEAD: As a young black man starting out in the record industry during the early 1970's, Jheryl Busby regarded Motown Records as more than just ''Hitsville U.S.A.,'' the nickname the label justifiably bestowed on itself during its glory days.

LEAD: RUMORS. By Catherine Mann. (Delacorte, $18.95.) Hollywood is so replete with real-life caricatures that it would seem superfluous to create a mannerist portrait of them. Yet Catherine Mann, herself a one-time Hollywood reporter, has done exactly that. ''Rumors'' has all the hallmarks of a perfunctory nod to the literary form en route to the big payoff: the television mini-series.

LEAD: When Flaviano Melo, the young Governor of Acre, holds up his favorite map, it shows a new highway stretching west from the Amazon rain forest, across the Peruvian Andes and down to the Pacific coast. There it joins a giant arrow pointing to Japan.

LEAD: TO the list - never long enough - of what to do with children on winter weekend afternoons can be added some instructive alternatives: visiting factories, studios or plants to see how things are made.

LEAD: President Bush's proposal to cut the tax rate for capital gains faces an uphill battle in Congress. But investment experts say if such a cut were enacted the big winners would be the stocks of young companies whose earnings are growing rapidly but which pay out very little in dividends. Even without a tax cut, however, many Wall Street professionals believe that such stocks currently represent some of the best bargains around.

LEAD: BEFORE it moves into a new office tower in downtown Manhattan, Salomon Brothers, the brokerage firm, intends to spend nearly two years and more than $200 million cutting out floors, adding elevators, reinforcing steel girders, upgrading power supplies and making other improvements in its million square feet of space.
LEAD: Trent Jackson scored 27 points today as Wisconsin jumped to a 14-point halftime lead and crushed No. 5 Illinois, 72-52, clinching its first winning season in 9 years.
LEAD: For a moment, Brent Sutter felt almost nostalgic about the victory, and not just because he was the Islander who scored the game-winning goal.
LEAD: Can supercomputers help social scientists unravel the mysteries of how people make decisions?
LEAD: A report in the Q & A column on Jan. 15 about renting apartments in Paris misstated the rents quoted by agencies in Paris and in the United States. The apartments rent for $70 to $700 a day.

LEAD: After 49 years of pioneering programs in support of children, minority groups and the poor, the Field Foundation is deliberately spending itself out of existence, hoping to leave a legacy of organizations to carry on its work.

LEAD: SERIOUS LIVING. By Tom Lorenz. (Viking, $17.95.) Tom Lorenz, the author of the highly praised 1980 novel ''Guys Like Us,'' has returned to print with a rewarding coming-of-age story set in Chicago. ''Serious Living'' is the comic but also poignant tale of 21-year-old Ritchie Kohler, high school graduate and truly ordinary guy.

LEAD: To the Editor: The articles on luxury travel in Kenya were fascinating reading. But I'd hate for your poorer readers to come away with the idea that reasonable comfort on safari is out of their price range.

LEAD: Mary Louise Nowell Crisp, the law clerk to Judge Marvin Wooten of Federal Bankruptcy Court in Charlotte, N.C., and Otto Wescott Lowe, an assistant vice president of the First Boston Corporation in New York, plan to be married April 22.

LEAD: On the European museum circuit this winter the most important single event has been, beyond question, the exhibition called ''Prague in 1600: Art and Culture at the Court of Rudolf II.'' First seen in Essen, West Germany, as one of a series of historical evocations of great European cities, it arrived at the Kunsthistorisches-museum in Vienna in a much enlarged form toward the end of November.

LEAD: The Bush Administration's recently announced plan to float $50 billion of bonds to bail out failing savings and loan institutions would add yet another security to a wide array of fixed-income obligations issued by Federal agencies. The agencies - including the Farm Credit System, the Federal National Mortgage Association (Fannie Mae) and the Federal Home Loan

LEAD: THE gap in understanding between a resurgent, faith-filled Islam and a secular, pluralist West became a yawning chasm last week when accusations that a novel called ''The Satanic Verses'' was blasphemous led to riots and deaths in Pakistan and India, huge demonstrations in Iran and a death sentence pronounced on its author, Salman

LEAD: A SPECIAL group of young people has been climbing the stairs to the music rooms of the Hackley School in Tarrytown this month. Recent graduates of Hackley, they were once students in the school's conservatory program. Now, as prizewinning professional musicians, they have returned to help current undergraduates prepare for a concert.

LEAD: A spokesman for Viking Penguin yesterday condemned ''censorship by terrorism and intimidation,'' and he coupled his remarks with criticism of the major bookstore chains that have pulled ''The Satanic Verses'' from their shelves.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH reconstruction of the interchange of the Northern State and Meadowbrook State Parkways is proceeding on schedule - the completion date is Oct. 31, 1991 - the $61 million project has met with resistance from the Village of Westbury.

LEAD: A caption on page 5 in some copies of the Arts and Leisure section today with an article about the theater director Ruth Maleczech reverses the two actors' identities. Roger Guenveur Smith, who has a beard, is on the left; Tomas Milian is on the right.

LEAD: In remembrance of her parents and her sister and brother, killed during the Holocaust in Poland on Aug. 19, 1942, Tonia Rotkopf Blair of Manhattan sent a contribution of $20 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

LEAD: More than 300 residents of the Town of Yorktown in upper Westchester County are applying for inclusion in a new program that will provide a few modestly priced homes for applicants who are qualified and who win a special lottery. Five semi-detached two-bedroom homes costing $119,000 each will be available this summer.

LEAD: IN the final scene of a new documentary called ''Wound,'' dozens of young Soviet war invalids hobble down a beach to the sea, tossing their crude wooden crutches into a pile as they splash into the waves. A viewer recoils at first from the unsightly stumps of legs, and then asks, as the filmmakers intend the audience to ask, and as one of the damaged veterans has already asked the camera: ''Za chto?

LEAD: STILL boop-a-dooping after all these years, ''The Boy Friend'' has got to be the English theater's quintessential giddy musical. And by now, it has conquered American audiences in sufficient numbers to qualify as our daffiest one, too.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A new satellite computer link between the United States and the Soviet Union is opening a new phase in communications between the two countries. Scientists, academicians, business executives and even computer hobbyists have begun to exchange messages and data over the channel.
LEAD: SQUEAKS in a wood floor are annoying. However, the condition is seldom more than an inconvenience and repairs are usually easy, even for the inexperienced.

LEAD: Willie Haynes hit a 16-foot jumper with 11 seconds to play tonight to give St. Peter's a 50-49 victory over Fordham in a Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference game. The victory was the third straight for St. Peter's (19-6, 11-2) and its 11th in 12 games.

LEAD: JUST 50 years ago, almost every Catholic church in Italy had an area set aside on one of its interior walls for displaying ex votos, small flat silver figures giving visible testimony of the initiation or fulfillment of a believer's vow (voto).

LEAD: LONGING. By Paul Reed. (Celestial Arts, $14.95.) A crucial test of a good writer is whether he or she can take a basically trite story and turn it into something memorable. In his second novel, Paul Reed passes that test. If ''Longing'' were the sort of teen-age saga that's devoured by 10-year-old girls, its plot would go like this: A girl moves to a new city, looking for love.

LEAD: It is probably by chance rather than an attempt to shock us with yesterday's sensations that three of opera history's most celebrated events will be paid homage this week on New York stages. The Metropolitan unveils its new production of Strauss' ''Salome'' tomorrow evening, the Philadelphia Orchestra offers a concert version of Verdi's ''Nabucco'' at Carnegie Hall the same night, and on Saturday, also at Carnegie, Herbert von Karajan and the Vienna Philharmonic present Act I of Wagner's ''Tristan und Isolde.

LEAD: THE WAY TO THE WESTERN SEA: Lewis and Clark Across the Continent. By David Lavender. (Harper & Row, $22.95.) It is a thrill to read ''The Way to the Western Sea,'' an intimate account of the cross-continental expedition up the Missouri River, then on to the Pacific Coast undertaken by Meriwether Lewis and William Clark from May 14, 1804, to Sept.

LEAD: The Yanks have many question marks such as Leiter, Jones and Eiland. If any one of these guys can't cut it, John and Guidry might be able to step right in. John didn't have that bad a season last year, and he does need only 14 games to reach 300. If that isn't enough incentive to win I don't know what is.

LEAD: About a month ago, Andy MacPhail wanted to talk to Craig Fenech about Frank Viola. ''There are a couple of shoes to drop,'' Fenech, Viola's agent, told the Minnesota general manager. ''I think I'll wait.''

LEAD: Suddenly, John Eliot Gardiner seems to be everywhere. At the moment, he and his Monteverdi Choir and period-instruments English Baroque Soloists are in New York, an early stop on a world tour that's taking them from London to Calcutta, and there are ambitious recording projects on three labels, with repertory ranging from Monteverdi to

LEAD: Thomas H. Cook triumphs at teaching an old dog some new tricks in FLESH AND BLOOD (Putnam, $17.95). When we met the series hero (in ''Sacrificial Ground''), Frank Clemons was a homicide detective working for the Atlanta police and nursing an obsession with a teen-age murder victim. Clemons has since turned private eye and relocated to New York, where he is again fixated on a homicide victim.

LEAD: A few weeks back, we tossed off an informal classification of top California wines based - as was the famous 1855 Bordeaux classification -mostly on track record. The wineries that made the cut: Beaulieu, Beringer, Caymus, Clos du Val, Chalone, Diamond Creek, Grgich Hills, Heitz, Inglenook, Mayacamas, Stag's Leap, Robert Mondavi and

LEAD: Although the number of fish that returned to the rivers of New England to spawn last year was disappointingly low, Alan Erdossy, coordinator of Trout Unlimited's Atlantic Salmon Task Force, is not depressed.
LEAD: WHAT do an American comedy about child-rearing by a lesbian couple and a Russian docudrama dealing with the devastating effects of the 1986 nuclear disaster at Chernobyl have in common?

LEAD: AFTER eight years of war and an almost obsessive loathing for Ronald Reagan, Sandinista leaders started this year apparently determined to reshape American-Nicaraguan relations. And a month into the new Administration of George Bush, they have taken advantage of the Washington transition to make striking progress toward that goal.

LEAD: In 1982, when I was playing with the St. Louis Cardinals, Bob Watson pinch-hit against me and I struck him out. That was rare; he was a good right-handed hitter who had had success against me. The next day Watson saw me and said, ''Hey, that was really a good change-up you struck me out on.'' But it wasn't a change-up.

LEAD: CONCERNED Larchmont and county officials predict that the doubling of the northbound toll to $1 at the New Rochelle toll plaza of the New England Thruway, scheduled to take effect this week, will cause traffic tie-ups in neighboring communities and further burden the heavily used Hutchinson River Parkway.

LEAD: Although the number of fish that returned to the rivers of New England to spawn last year was disappointingly low, Alan Erdossy, coordinator of Trout Unlimited's Atlantic Salmon Task Force, is not depressed.
LEAD: WHAT do an American comedy about child-rearing by a lesbian couple and a Russian docudrama dealing with the devastating effects of the 1986 nuclear disaster at Chernobyl have in common?

LEAD: AFTER eight years of war and an almost obsessive loathing for Ronald Reagan, Sandinista leaders started this year apparently determined to reshape American-Nicaraguan relations. And a month into the new Administration of George Bush, they have taken advantage of the Washington transition to make striking progress toward that goal.

LEAD: In 1982, when I was playing with the St. Louis Cardinals, Bob Watson pinch-hit against me and I struck him out. That was rare; he was a good right-handed hitter who had had success against me. The next day Watson saw me and said, ''Hey, that was really a good change-up you struck me out on.'' But it wasn't a change-up.

LEAD: CONCERNED Larchmont and county officials predict that the doubling of the northbound toll to $1 at the New Rochelle toll plaza of the New England Thruway, scheduled to take effect this week, will cause traffic tie-ups in neighboring communities and further burden the heavily used Hutchinson River Parkway.

LEAD: On paper, the A.K.A. Petroleum Sales Corporation appeared to be a thriving wholesale gasoline dealer, doing business throughout the New York metropolitan region. In its first five months of existence, the company bought and sold eight million gallons of gasoline and $10 million flowed through its bank accounts.
LEAD: Edgar Bronfman Jr., a young man who has moved rapidly ahead in his father's business, is getting more respect these days as a business executive and the heir apparent to the Seagram empire.

LEAD: Seven barges carrying gasoline broke free from a towboat on the Ohio River today, spilling an estimated 40,000 gallons of fuel into the river after striking a railroad bridge piling, officials said.

LEAD: House investigators today questioned a State Department security official for more than seven hours about his 1986 inquiry into alleged misconduct and security breaches by members of the American arms control delegation in Geneva while John G. Tower was a negotiator there.
LEAD: While Columbia University's football team remains mired in a seemingly endless rebuilding cycle, one Columbia squad has come full circle: the men's swimming and diving team.
LEAD: The wait continued yesterday as another day passed and Kiki Vandeweghe was still a Portland Trail Blazer, waiting to learn about his future.
LEAD: The Don Quixote of Washington magazines is celebrating an anniversary this month, having tilted at this city's bureaucratic windmills for 20 years.

LEAD: Two weeks after the start of talks between the Government and the outlawed opposition, both sides say they have reached ''fundamental accord'' on allowing the Solidarity-led opposition to control as many as two-fifths of the seats in Parliament through pre-arranged elections.

LEAD: The 24th annual City University of New York tournament, which opens today at City College's Nat Holman Gymnasium, is a throwback to the days when students played basketball for fun and nobody dreamed of making a big impression on the National Basketball Association. And Steve Mack, a 6-foot-1-inch City College sophomore, is a throwback to the American work ethic.

LEAD: With little fanfare and so far little opposition, the General Assembly is considering what legal experts say would be the most comprehensive law in the United States to give workers the right to take time off during periods of family crisis or joy.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: IN a 1931 photograph in the book ''The American League: An Illustrated History'' by Donald Honig, three strapping young ballplayers, three Yankees, are smiling into the camera. In the middle is Lefty Gomez, his glove, looking as big as a cushion (baseball gloves were puffier in those days), is thrown over the right shoulder of Bill Dickey, and Gomez's left hand - the one that won all those games - rests on the left shoulder of Lou

LEAD: The $8.15 million awarded to a woman who said a birth control device sold by G. D. Searle & Company had left her infertile was not so ''shockingly excessive'' as to force a new trial, a judge has ruled.
LEAD: Not long ago, the gutted building at 755 Dawson Street in the South Bronx was an example of the neighborhood's neglect and abandonment. For years, it stood empty, dark and useless.

LEAD: Sirhan Sirhan, in his first television interview, said he felt betrayed by Senator Robert F. Kennedy's support for Israel in the 1967 Arab-Israeli war and said he killed Mr. Kennedy out of concern for the Palestinians.
LEAD: Joseph Wheelwright, a sculptor in Boston, has taken his work on human anatomy out of the studio and into the streets.

LEAD: Heavy snow this winter has brought much-needed moisture to the Northwest, the northern Great Plains and the Rockies, leading the Agriculture Department's chief meteorologist to tell the White House and Congress that another serious drought is unlikely this year in the United States.

LEAD: The savings and loan sickness gets worse by the day. Bankrupt thrifts continue to pile up losses -more than $1.5 million every 24 hours - while solvent thrifts bicker about President Bush's plan to rescue their industry. Critics say the President's plan is inadequate. But there should be no doubt that he is on the right track.

LEAD: A strong earthquake hit the capital and much of northern Japan today, killing one person and injuring another, shaking buildings and briefly halting some train and airline service, officials said.

LEAD: The Philip Morris Companies announced the formation Friday of the Kraft General Foods Group to combine Kraft Inc. and the operating companies of the General Foods Corporation into one organization.
LEAD: The Closed Circle By David Pryce-Jones 464 pages. An Edward Burlingame Book/Harper & Row. $25.

LEAD: Colleagues and friends of Richard M. Nixon are being urged not to cooperate in the production of an ABC Entertainment adaptation of ''The Final Days,'' the book by Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein about the Watergate scandals and the end of the Nixon Presidency in 1974.

LEAD: Brooklyn Tech, led by Conrad McRae, its 6-foot-9-inch all-America center, eliminated Lafayette, 78-75, yesterday in overtime in the opening round of the Public Schools Athletic League playoffs. Boys and Girls defeated Grady, 79-73, in the other game at Canarsie High School with a little help from an unearned point.

LEAD: Set in New York City, ABC's ''Gideon Oliver'' is not likely to do much for the city's tourist trade. Tonight's premiere, at 9 on Channel 7, offers in detail a satanic cult specializing in black masses, child pornography and murders brazenly committed in public. The next installment features brutal Tong wars in Chinatown.
LEAD: Suppose that you drop in to a major tournament and sit down in the South-West position to kibitz a team event. At the table are four players you do not know, and you wonder how good they are.

LEAD: Looking back over the last three years, in which crack use in New York City has grown to epidemic proportions, Bronx Borough President Fernando Ferrer found a metaphor. He said it was like a balloon filled with water: ''When it's squeezed on one end, it expands in another.''

LEAD: In City of Richmond v. J. A. Croson Co., the United States Supreme Court dealt a severe, perhaps fatal blow to local minority set-aside programs, the practice of reserving a fixed percentage, or quota, of public contracts for companies owned by minorities.
LEAD: What with a Honus Wagner fetching $100,000 or so and other rare items selling for penthouse prices, it's a bit late to get in on the ground floor of baseball card collecting.

LEAD: Considering that this year's salary arbitration group produced the four largest raises ever gained by baseball players, it should come as no surprise that the group's overall percentage of salary increase was greater than it was a year ago.

LEAD: A Yugoslav and an Italian have been arrested in Italy on charges of acquiring classified military information for the Soviet Union, including documents on a computer system being developed for NATO, news reports said today.

LEAD: Members of the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra ratified a contract late Saturday night that assures a minimum $1,040 a week in the 1991-92 season and ends a 22-week strike, the longest in American symphony history.
LEAD: Don't think for a minute that Fay Wray's encounter with an enormous gorilla atop the Empire State Building back in 1933 has made her leery about visiting New York. No, indeed.
LEAD: A Jewish businessman has been ordered to pay $5.5 million after a court found he forced a Florida restaurateur out of business by falsely accusing him of anti-Semitic conduct.
LEAD: International A2-7

LEAD: Steffi Graf won the first 20 points, then capitalized on two late service breaks in the second set to win the Virginia Slims of Washington tournament today with a 6-1, 7-5 victory over Zina Garrison.
LEAD: The Lost World By Edwin McDowell 217 pages. St. Martin's Press. $15.95.

LEAD: In a policy change that will help many elderly people and may also significantly increase nursing home revenues, the Federal Medicare program has begun to pay the nursing home charges for thousands of people who had not previously qualified for the benefits.
LEAD: Fire swept through four buildings in Manhattan and Brooklyn over the weekend, killing one man, injuring at least 40 firefighters and leaving more than two dozen families without homes.

LEAD: Couple of years ago, the publisher of a novel of mine had a good idea to promote sales. She took me up to Stamford, Conn., to meet the most powerful man in American letters today: Harry Hoffman, boss of Waldenbooks, the chain of 1,200 bookstores that has brought modern merchandising techniques to the archaic book business.

LEAD: Mayor Koch chose well in appointing David Todd to head New York's Landmarks Preservation Commission. He is an experienced architect who combines sense with sensibility. Further, he has the ability to distinguish landmarks from dross without abusing the city's architectural heritage or giving in to obstructionism.
LEAD: The bell tower high above St. Michael the Archangel Roman Catholic Church rang out in perfect harmony this morning, but the church below was closed and the members were in deep discord.

LEAD: THERE are 23 of them in camp, and if you laid them end to end it is possible they would stretch halfway to Cypress Creek Road, just north of the ball park. Some of them have been through the rigors of spring before; some are simply new to the whole thing, their names unfamiliar to the fans who come here early every morning to see the
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Riding in a taxi to his newly acquired savings and loan association here, Lewis S. Ranieri was trying to explain exactly what he had received for his $200 million investment. Mid-conversation, he turned to the driver and asked whether he was riding in a Yellow Cab. Told yes, Mr. Ranieri let out a howl of laughter.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Native elk and bison from the two largest natural herds of their species in North America are dying at rates unheard of in recent times due to subzero cold and a shortage of winter feeding range.
LEAD: QUESTION: Does Nolan Ryan hold the record for most one-hitters pitched in a career, as well as the mark for no-hitters?

LEAD: The British publisher Robert Maxwell canceled an important address Friday about the introduction of his English-language newspaper, The European, saying his editorial team was not yet ''pursuing shared goals and a unified concept.''
LEAD: When Carrefour, S.A., the owner of France's largest chain of hypermarkets, decided to break into the United States, it hardly received a warm Yankee welcome.

LEAD: Mighty Sam McClain, the opener on a soul-blues double bill at the Village Gate, delivered the show's real blues power in Saturday's early set. Mr. McClain, who recorded soul music around Louisiana during the 1960's and was rediscovered in the early 80's, plunged immediately into songs of pain-wracked romance and distant hope, pleading for release and redemption with the dramatic timing of classic blues.

LEAD: The seven teen-agers who live with their babies in the Bleibtreu Residence, in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx, are poor and poorly educated. At least one of them is abusive, a second may be dangerous to her child and a third has tested positive for the AIDS virus.

LEAD: Robert A. Mosbacher Sr., the Commerce Secretary who was finance chairman of President Bush's campaign, says he is distressed that more campaign fund-raisers have not been rewarded with political appointments.

LEAD: For decades Harper & Row used outside designers, artists and typesetters to help prepare its book catalogues, and the process often took six to eight weeks. Now Harper's catalogues take only a few days to produce, at a savings of more than $200,000 a year.

LEAD: What an ugly afternoon, right from the pre-game shoving and insults - a ritual used by the Flyers to let opponents know that domination is the name of the game played here - to the fencing match between the Islanders' Randy Wood and the Flyers' Ron Sutter at the game's end.

LEAD: The Soviet Union's first major Middle East initiative in years gathered momentum today with word that Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze is to meet separately with both the Israeli Foreign Minister and the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization this week to discuss revived proposals for peace.

LEAD: A month after news of an undercover ''sting'' operation shook the commodity futures industry, defense lawyers here are predicting that the charges resulting from the investigation will involve a few minor technical trading violations rather than numerous felonies.

LEAD: Passengers flying overseas on United States airlines may have to learn new habits to avoid inconvenient searches for bombs in common electronic devices like coffeepots with electronic timers, cameras and lap-top computers.

LEAD: David Duke, former Ku Klux Klan Grand Wizard, fresh from winning a seat in the state legislature despite opposition from President Bush, today took on the chairman of the Republican National Committee.

LEAD: Olympic Effort Faulted A report asserts that the United States has inadequately developed Olympic athletes. SportsMonday, C1. Doctor's Second Thoughts Eight years after Ronald Reagan was shot, his doctor says Presidential power should have gone temporarily to Vice President Bush. Page A13.

LEAD: She was South Africa's most celebrated heroine, hailed as the ''mother of the nation,'' a woman so revered for her courage that she was nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize and offered academic honors from abroad.

LEAD: Eric F. Goldman, chronicler of 20th-century America, special consultant to President Lyndon B. Johnson and an immensely popular author and lecturer at Princeton University, died of complications after a stroke yesterday at Princeton Medical Center. He was 73 years old and lived in Princeton.

LEAD: A study by a special commission headed by George Steinbrenner has concluded that the United States Olympic Committee and its affiliated organizations have done an inadequate job developing and supporting Olympic-caliber athletes.
LEAD: Putnam County's choice of Patterson, its smallest town, as the preferred site for a modern garbage landfill has run into a mountain of old-fashioned outrage from the town's residents.

LEAD: Ben Steyger, who immigrated to the United States not long ago, finds living in New York City to be a struggle. Nevertheless, he has a place to stay, food to eat and a job and is ''happy to be able to live here and share the American Dream with countless others.''

LEAD: Steel imports declined 16 percent in December from a year earlier, to 1.42 million tons, but imports for all of 1988 rose 4.9 percent, to 20.89 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute said Friday. Despite climbing from 19.92 million tons in 1987, imports last year represented a 20.3 percent share of the United States market, down from 20.9 percent.
LEAD: For Muslims and Arab in the United States, the uproar over ''The Satanic Verses'' has caused embarrassment and indignation. Page A6.
LEAD: General Assembly Meets at 10:30 A.M.

LEAD: From the looks of the place, George Washington wouldn't want to sleep there now. The house at the end of the muddy lane is unremarkable, run down and badly in need of paint, certainly not a colonial original. All else is bramble and scrub.

LEAD: As they gathered here tonight to discuss a peace settlement, the warring Cambodian factions faced not only the frayed politics of the moment but the tangled and emotional residue of almost 20 years of betrayal, revolution, genocide, invasion and civil war.

LEAD: The Israeli Foreign Minister, Moshe Arens, has accepted an invitation from his Soviet counterpart, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, to meet him in Cairo this week to discuss proposals for peace in the Middle East.
LEAD: A Boston stockbroker whose disappearance led to the discovery that millions of dollars of his clients' funds were also missing was arrested Friday by customs agents in Massena, N.Y.

LEAD: The E. W. Scripps Company announced Friday that it had completed the sale of The Sun-Tattler, a newspaper in Hollywood, Fla., to DTH Media Inc., which owns The Dallas Times Herald. Terms were not disclosed.

LEAD: * Egypt will keep its oil prices unchanged for the rest of February, with the top Suez and Ras Bahar grades at $14.75 a barrel, a spokesman for the state-owned Egyptian General Petroleum Corporation said. Egypt, which is not a member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, sets prices twice monthly, based on market trends.

LEAD: Louis Silverstein, longtime publication designer for the New York Times Company, has announced that he is retiring as a consultant to the company's regional newspaper group and opening a design firm in Manhattan. The firm, Silverstein Design Associates, will specialize in promotion, graphics and publications in the United
LEAD: WITHIN a week or two, you should be seriously engaged in tying the flies that you will be using this spring, summer and fall.

LEAD: The National Park Service has arranged to have some of the favorite music of George Washington's time played today at Arlington House, on the grounds of Arlington National Cemetery, in honor of the 257th anniversary of his birth. A quartet accompanied by a violinist and a pianist will perform in the main parlor room of the home that was built by Washington's adopted son, George Washington Parke Custis.

LEAD: Diane Sawyer will reportedly earn $7.5 million under her new five-year contract with ABC, which hired her away from CBS with the offer of an anchor's chair. CBS is negotiating with Connie Chung of NBC for a job that will give her more visibility and most likely more than a million dollars a year. And in New York two weeks ago, the CBS flagship station hired away Ernie Anastos, an anchor at the A

LEAD: A United Airlines Boeing 727 was forced to make an unscheduled landing today, after a pilot noticed vibrations in one of the jet's three engines. Flight 597 from Albany, bound for Chicago, was diverted to Syracuse about 35 minutes after an 8:27 A.M. take-off. ''One engine developed a vibration,'' said an airline spokesman, Joseph Hopkins.

LEAD: Darrell Waltrip ended 16 years of frustration today with a victory in the crash-filled $1.7 million Daytona 500, winning the biggest race of his life by taking perhaps the biggest chance of his career.
LEAD: The Bush Administration reacted cautiously today to moves by Afghan guerrilla leaders to form an interim regime that would take control in Kabul if the Soviet-backed Government fell.
LEAD: Dante Caputo, the Foreign Minister of Argentina, has called his Government's response to a raid by an armed band on a military outpost last month a victory for democracy in Latin America.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The Milwaukee Bucks brought Mike Dunleavy, an assistant coach, out of retirement today and sent him into a close game with the Chicago Bulls in the final seconds.

LEAD: Where are some of the best steps in New York? One of the worst building entrances anywhere? Which city has the worst record of preserving its sun and light? The tallest blank wall? Which city boasts the most street-smart pedestrians in the world?

LEAD: Karen Marie Muller, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph J. Muller of Syracuse, and Albert Hansen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Christian R. Hansen of Briantown, Md., were married yesterday at St. Paul the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan. The Rev. Stephen Connor officiated.
LEAD: Chris Brooks scored 22 points and Ray Foster 17, leading 14th-ranked West Virginia past Rhode Island, 90-66, today and extending the nation's longest winning streak to 21 games.

LEAD: Eight years after Ronald Reagan was shot and seriously wounded, his doctor at that time says he now believes Presidential power should have been temporarily transferred to Vice President George Bush.
LEAD: Muslim and Arab figures in the United States have expressed different views about the Salman Rushdie novel ''The Satanic Verses'' and the reaction to it in the Islamic world.
LEAD: Al Frantz wants his Boy Scouts to look up to George Washington. At Washington Plaza in Brooklyn, they usually look up and see only the top of his hat and the back of his horse.
LEAD: Sidney G. Albert, a philanthropist and former board chairman and president of the Albert Pipe Supply Company, died of cancer Friday at his home in Clearwater, Fla. He was 80 years old.
LEAD: AROUND the country, editors, reporters and commentators who produced exceptional material last year are agonizing as they await the announcement March 30 of the Pulitzer Prizes in journalism.
LEAD: The Defense Department said Thursday that it would soon raise the dollar amount for contracts listed in its daily report to the public and Congress.
LEAD: ''We will start shooting the children on the St. Magdalen schoolyard real soon,'' the letter began. ''Thought you should be there.''

LEAD: MOMENTS after a magistrate selected Kimba M. Wood to preside over the criminal case against Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., a throng of reporters and lawyers went to her fourth-floor office to obtain legal papers that the investment house wanted to keep confidential.

LEAD: At a time when pieces of fine art are being sold for breathtaking prices, a unit of the Chase Manhattan Bank is seeking to raise $300 million from large pension funds to invest in paintings and other works.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Last summer, Nguyen Minh Phuong climbed into a tiny sailboat with four other Vietnamese and made his way across the South China Sea to Hong Kong, a journey that took almost two months. Now, that same young man has volunteered to return to the country he risked his life to flee.

LEAD: Dr. Francis Xavier Reynolds, a surgeon, educator and former chief of trauma service at Fordham and Misericordia hospitals, died of heart failure Saturday at Montefiore Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived in Bronxville, N.Y.
LEAD: Four top officers from two of Mexico's biggest brokerage firms were indicted Saturday on charges of illegal trading and criminal fraud.
LEAD: At age 81, Fay Wray is still in love with the gorilla.

LEAD: The job crunch on the Mets' pitching staff sent Rick Aguilera into Davey Johnson's office today with another plea to be traded. But 20 minutes later, the 27-year-old pitcher left the office, still with no job and no promise to be traded.
LEAD: They met in the Maine Legislature on the Republican side of the aisle, she a raven-haired representative from Auburn and he the handsome young floor leader from Bangor.
LEAD: The National Weather Service is facing a shortage of money and a reorganization that could lead to the closing of many local weather offices in the next several years.

LEAD: Charles Berger has resigned as vice president of integrated systems at Apple Computer Inc. and has joined Sun Microsystems Inc. of Mountain View as vice president of product marketing in the entry systems group. Mr. Berger, 35 years old, is the eighth top executive to leave Apple in its recent reorganization.

LEAD: IF your running needs a change of pace, or you would just like to come in from the cold, try working out at an indoor track in your area. They offer excellent opportunities to improve running form, experiment with speed training and receive expert coaching.

LEAD: The United States and the European Community have begun a new effort to resolve differences over long-term agricultural policy changes that caused a breakdown in talks on global trade liberalization two months ago in Montreal.

LEAD: This season's run of Donizetti's ''Lucia di Lammermoor'' at the Metropolitan Opera came to an end with the Saturday matinee. The cast featured performances by two young singers who had joined the production earlier in the week.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Michel Bergeron had difficulty controlling himself all night. He hurled a water bottle into the stands, climbed atop the sideboards, rattled the protective glass, and taunted Pittsburgh players and officials alike.

LEAD: James J. Reilly, a former personnel director of the New York City Housing Authority, died of kidney failure Saturday at New York Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived in Forest Hills Gardens, Queens.

LEAD: EVER wonder how many calories a cookie contains? One typical cookie contains around 80 calories, meaning that an innocent snack of six chocolate-chip cookies and a glass of milk probably has at least 600 calories, depending on how full of chocolate and nuts the cookies are. A middle-aged male who is 6 feet and 180 pounds probably needs between 2,500 calories a day to meet his nutritional needs without gaining weight.

LEAD: As a comedy duo, Mike and Spike are no Laurel and Hardy. For starters, Spike Lee does all the talking, while Michael Jordan restricts his efforts to 360-degree reverse slam dunks and other forms of basketball artistry.

LEAD: Forgetting speed for the moment, Alfredo Rego realized his goal at the world Alpine ski championships in Vail, Colo. He entered the combined slalom, the super G, the giant slalom and the special slalom, and he finished each race. Last, to be sure, but Rego finished.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL REPORT A new effort has begun to resolve U.S.-European differences on farm policy. A proposal by Trade Representative Carla A. Hills has raised hopes of progress in the GATT talks with the European Community. The U.S. has previously insisted on the elimination of all farm subsidies.
LEAD: Operation Sludge began in 1983 as a major drive by Federal and New York State law-enforcement agencies to stop gasoline-tax evaders.

LEAD: WHEN casual racing fans first heard that this year's Breeders' Cup races would be held in Florida, they may have envisioned a backdrop of flamingos at Hialeah instead of the condominiums towering behind Gulfstream Park.
LEAD: Spain's largest and most profitable industrial company, Repsol S.A., plans to begin this spring the country's most ambitious share offering ever.
LEAD: The Carl's Jr. fast-food chain's general accounting director has been indicted by a Federal grand jury on one count of securities fraud in connection with insider trading.
LEAD: It is no secret that the United States Commission on Civil Rights has been stalemated in recent years by ideological quarrels, but lately some of the criticism has become personal.

LEAD: President Bush knows the part of the world he will visit soon better than any previous President, having served in the Pacific in World War II and lived in China as Ambassador in the mid-70's. Thus, he is in a better position than most Americans to comprehend the vast changes sweeping over the region, and the opportunities and challenges that
LEAD: A single-engine plane crashed and burst into flames today in a heavily wooded area of Washington County, killing one man and seriously injuring another, investigators said.

LEAD: When White House advisers were sitting around recently trying to decide what color the budget book should be, they went through as many colors as a paint store palette. The color of the budget book changes every year, so the one color they wanted to avoid was the one used by Ronald Reagan for his 1990 budget book, royal blue.
LEAD: How could a man who dedicated his personal and professional life to trying to preserve a museum end up accused of trying to destroy it?

LEAD: NEW YORK Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only; main office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Banks: Option to close. Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation: No collections or street cleanings. Schools: Closed.
LEAD: To the Japanese, the American tempest over the FSX fighter is a puzzling tale of what happens when two of the world's closest military allies are also two of its fiercest commercial rivals.

LEAD: GOLF First for Twiggs: Greg Twiggs shot a three-under-par 69 yesterday for a two-stroke victory in the $700,000 Shearson Lehman Hutton San Diego Open. It was his first victory in five years on the PGA Tour. Twiggs, who had a four-day total of 271 at Torrey Pines Golf Course in La Jolla, Calif., won $126,000.

LEAD: Terry DeVries is a bicycle racer from Fairbanks, Alaska. Lori Rea is a world-class swimmer and a graduate student at Wichita State. Matthias Sikowski, at 6 feet 10 inches and 245 pounds, is the world's largest oarsman. Jack Fucci is a former college football player who is now an exercise physiologist for a

LEAD: ''Shadow's Breath,'' Eliot Feld's most recent and ecstatically tinged premiere, continues the creative surge manifest in the unusually large number of new and inventive works he has choreographed this season for his company.
LEAD: A few weeks ago near Tokyo's famous Meiji Shrine, Takeshi Mitsu, a 21-year-old college student, got a taste of what happens these days to those who cross Japan's increasingly jittery police.
LEAD: * Essef Corp., Mentor, Ohio, a plastics manufacturer, said John B. Calfee Jr. had been appointed vice president and chief financial officer.
LEAD: Jay Edwards made a 3-pointer at the buzzer today, sending ninth-ranked Indiana past No. 13 Michigan, 76-75, and giving the Hoosiers a 15-game home winning streak.
LEAD: Ronald K. Linde, chairman and chief executive of Envirodyne Industries Inc., is waiting for details of an unsolicited offer for the company he founded in 1970.

LEAD: One of the best books about fly tying, published this month, is titled ''Poul Jorgensen's Book of Fly Tying: A Guide to Flies for All Game Fish'' (Johnson Books, Boulder, Colo.; $19.95 paperback and $34.95 hardbound). It is superbly organized and illustrated and written with delightful clarity. It includes descriptions of tools and materials and detailed instruction on how to create flies for all situations.
LEAD: Stock, bond and futures markets are closed today in observance of Presidents' Day. Government offices and most banks are also closed, as are many businesses.

LEAD: The incidence of an illness known as simulator sickness appears to be growing among military pilots who spend long sessions at sophisticated computerized airplane simulators. Although the causes remain poorly understood, the illness appears to be related to conflicting sensations.

LEAD: Behind a dirt-streaked store facade here, Ambrosio Pereira da Gama welcomed a visitor to his well-lit, air-conditioned office. He briskly proffered a new triple-tone, fold-out business card and started talking rapid-fire about his growing business empire: ice cream, baked goods, health care and tourism.

LEAD: What used to be known as George Washington's Birthday never was an excuse for big parades and fireworks. But in elementary school classrooms all over the country it was the day you took construction paper and blunt scissors and cut out your version of a cherry tree and a hatchet. Then you pasted them on the classroom window.

LEAD: ''Even if Salman Rushdie repents and becomes the most pious man of time it is incumbent on every Moslem to employ everything he's got, his life and wealth, to send him to hell.'' - Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini [ A1:4. ]

LEAD: For five days ending yesterday, Park Avenue at 67th Street was the hottest gallery scene in town. The precincts where art is usually sold - 57th Street, SoHo, TriBeCa - were by no means deserted. But the real action was at the Seventh Regiment Armory as dealers, their clients and thousands of other art trippers disported at ''The Art Show,'' New York City's first high-level art fair.

LEAD: As a child, Bunny Briggs danced outside a record shop on 137th Street and Lenox Avenue. ''All the people came around to hear 'Amos 'n' Andy' on the radio,'' Mr. Briggs recalls. ''They'd stand around in the street and listen. Then the man who owned the shop would put on a record and I'd dance. People would throw money, and I'd take it home to my mother.
LEAD: Laura Dean's ''Space,'' which the New York City Ballet presented Saturday night at the New York State Theater, unites logic and passion.

LEAD: American military women serving in Southern Europe have been sexually harassed by European and American men, have mistakenly thought they would be evacuated in wartime and have weakened their units by being absent while pregnant, an unpublished report says.

LEAD: Mark Price scored 27 points and Larry Nance blocked seven shots today as the Cleveland Cavaliers used a relentless defense to beat the Houston Rockets, 110-90. It was the Cavaliers' 18th consecutive victory at home.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: After a decade of pretending that American racing was getting better by the year, the committee that designates the relative importance of the year's top races has finally reversed itself and begun to tell the truth.

LEAD: Except for a few players and some coaches, the clubhouse was virtually empty when Don Mattingly arrived in camp this afternoon, changed his clothes and began to lift weights. He had been in town since last Thursday, but he was here now, ready to work under the warm Florida sun, although unwilling to offer the predictions of the past.

LEAD: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. urged President Bush today to intervene in the bitter dispute between Eastern Airlines Inc. and its machinists by appointing an emergency mediation board to avert a strike that could take place on March 3.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Like the bamboo shoots that emerge everywhere after a spring rain, to use a Chinese simile, democracy is sprouting again in China.

LEAD: The known population of one of the rarest plants in North America has been increased more than tenfold by the discovery of about 100 more. Before the discovery of the additional Aleutian-Shield ferns, biologists thought only six of the plants remained. The fern is unique to two of the Aleutian Islands.

A.There is no evidence of any link between warm winters and flu deaths, said Dr. Walter J. Gunn, an epidemiologist with the viral diseases division of the Centers for Disease Control in

LEAD: Europeans boast that the European Fighter Aircraft, one of the continent's most ambitious military projects, is a prime example of international cooperation that will spread costs among nations and heighten their aerospace expertise.
LEAD: LIT America Inc. has named David J. Vogel as its chairman and chief executive and John J. Ruth as its president and chief operating officer.

LEAD: SKIING Sweden Sweeps 15K Freestyle: Gunde Svan skied to an expected victory and Jari Puikkonen flew to an unexpected triumph yesterday at the world Nordic championships in Lahti, Finland. Svan, the Swede who has been the world's best cross-country skier this decade, led the men's 15K freestyle race from start to finish.

LEAD: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday None Wednesday Consumer Price Index ... Jan. Thursday Durable Goods ... Jan. Friday None
LEAD: * Child World Inc., Avon, Mass., a toy-store chain, said Leo Crowley and David Stewart had been named senior vice presidents.
LEAD: Amer Group Ltd., a diversified company based in Finland, said yesterday that it would acquire the Wilson Sporting Goods Company, the largest sporting goods maker in the United States.
LEAD: Five people died and a sixth was injured critically Sunday in the crash of two small private planes in the Adirondack Mountains in upstate New York.

LEAD: AFTER two decades of progress, the campaign to control smog from cars and trucks is now losing ground because of an enormous increase in the number of vehicles on the road. Experts believe that new anti-pollution strategies may be needed to hold hazardous exhaust emissions in check.
LEAD: Debt

LEAD: All firearms, whether military assault rifles or civilian pistols, are classified into three broad categories: fully automatic, semiautomatic and other. The groupings are based on how the weapon fires and loads bullets into its chamber for the next firing.
LEAD: Dr. Edith Taglicht Schmidt, founding director of the Educational Institute for Learning and Research, died Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 88 years old.
LEAD: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh has found himself confronting a new adversary: the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson.
LEAD: America's largest Tibetan Buddhist group has been thrown into turmoil by allegations that its leader knew he had AIDS and transmitted it to his sexual partners.
LEAD: Librarians are protesting a proposal that would take the Government out of the business of interpreting and organizing some of its computerized information.

LEAD: Walter A. Shields, an inventor, designer and manufacturer of pharmaceutical machinery, died of cancer Sunday at Palms of Pasadena Hospital in St. Petersburg Beach, Fla., where he was vacationing with his wife. He was 82 years old and lived in Floral Park, L.I.

LEAD: New York City principals say they are beleaguered by daily stresses and frustrations - comforting children frightened by the surrounding streets and plowing through mounds of paperwork - that hamper their ability to run effective schools.

LEAD: Had Antonio McKay run in indoor track meets Friday night in Los Angeles or Saturday night in Cleveland, he would have earned handsome appearance fees. He also would have probably earned points that would have given him a better chance to win the $16,000 prize as the men's overall winner in the indoor Grand
LEAD: Two men convicted of armed robbery escaped from the Bergen County Jail annex today through a hole less than a foot wide and two feet high, the Sheriff's Department said.

LEAD: In nominating John Tower to be Secretary of Defense, President Bush accepted the controversy and confirmation fight that he knew would follow. For this willingness to do battle for the man he believes best qualified to lead, Mr. Bush deserves praise. Most new Presidents would have chosen a less controversial - and less capable - nominee.
LEAD: The American public is evenly split over whether Oliver L. North should go to trial or the charges against him should be dropped, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

LEAD: The Giants, who had been looking for a defensive backfield coach, ended their search yesterday in an unusual way. They hired Al Groh as linebacker coach and said that Bill Belichick, the defensive coordinator, would double as defensive backfield coach. Len Fontes, who coached the Giants' secondary for six years, resigned after last season.

LEAD: Is the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, in demanding the execution of Salman Rushdie, really defending the faith of Islam, which he contends was blasphemed by certain passages in Mr. Rushdie's novel ''The Satanic Verses''?

LEAD: The Prime Minister of Afghanistan resigned today in a move seen by American experts as symbolizing the failure of efforts to establish a broad-based coalition government of national reconciliation.

LEAD: An investigation into charges linking the Westchester Republican Party to a corruption scandal at the Playland Amusement Park in Rye has become a factor in the county race for district attorney, as the Republican incumbent has asked Gov. Mario M. Cuomo to appoint a special prosecutor.
LEAD: A Presidential commission is considering a radical simplification of financial disclosure forms as part of changes it recommends in the nation's ethics laws, a member of the group said today.
LEAD: Dinah Halpern, a Yiddish actress who appeared in New York, Chicago and Europe, died of cancer on Saturday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Chicago. She was 79 years old and lived in Chicago.

LEAD: Life becomes lonely for New York's lieutenant governor if he doesn't get along with the governor. The rapport between the state's present Lieutenant, Stan Lundine, and Gov. Mario Cuomo has spared Mr. Lundine such isolation. It also underscores the importance of a governor choosing his own running mate.

LEAD: Promising ''a scoop'' to a correpondent visiting him last week in the White House, President Bush disclosed that, previous reports to the contrary, he refers to his wife as ''the Gray Fox'' and not as ''the Silver Fox.''

LEAD: The 1949 Oklahoma football team announced yesterday that it has canceled its April reunion to express embarrassment over recent problems plaguing the university's football program. In a letter, James D. Owens, co-captain of the 1949 team, said he did not plan to take part in any reunions on campus ''until a drastic change in leadership takes place.
LEAD: INSECT wings grown in laboratory dishes from a few dissected cells are being used in research aimed at producing environmentally sound ways of halting the development of crop-damaging pests.
LEAD: THE President may be a very special patient, but that does not guarantee dependable handling of his medical records. Consider the case of the missing X-rays.

LEAD: Thayer Cumings, an advertising executive who worked for Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborne and a predecessor agency for more than 30 years, died Sunday after a long illness at his home in York Harbor, Me. He was 84 years old and also had a home in Manhatttan.

LEAD: A Connecticut truck driver was arrested on the New Jersey Turnpike after he crashed into four cars, two of them police cars, while reportedly fleeing a drug arrest, a state police spokesman said yesterday.

LEAD: FAX modems and fax boards are valuable tools for certain specialized applications on personal computers. These tools are widely misunderstood, though, and under no circumstances should they be considered a substitute for a stand-alone fax machine.

LEAD: The Treasury's schedule of new issues for this holiday-shortened week include today's regular weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills. New two-year notes will be auctioned tomorrow and five-year notes will be sold on Thursday.

LEAD: ''No, 'feminist' is not the right word for it,'' said Claire Bloom, speaking of the series of three readings entitled ''These Are Women'' that she will present at the New York Public Library beginning tonight.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: VARIETY INKS 4-COLOR FUTURE; NIX ON PIX IS EIGHTY-SIXED

LEAD: In 1981 a teen-ager from Long Island handed over her newborn daughter to her obstetrician and his lawyer, Joel Steinberg, believing she was doing the best thing for her baby. In 1986 another Long Island teen-ager handed over her newborn son to the same lawyer and the physician who took over the previous obstetrician's practice.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Paul Brown, the vice president and general manager of the Cincinnati Bengals, has been named the Gold Medal honoree of the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame. Brown, 80 years old, will receive the award at the foundation's annual dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Dec. 5. After coaching at Ohio State and the Great Lakes Naval Training Station, Brown became the first coach of the Cleveland franchise in the All American Football Conference after World War II.

LEAD: The Texas Eastern Corporation, a major pipeline company that transports natural gas to the Northeast from the Gulf Coast, has accepted a friendly takeover offer valued at $3.2 billion from the Panhandle Eastern Corporation, the companies said today.

LEAD: In a two-year project started last week, a group of experts is updating research guidelines for manufacturers in an effort to speed the approval process for antibiotics to treat infectious diseases.
LEAD: On the 180-mile pockmarked road that connects this coastal town on the Indian Ocean with landlocked Zimbabwe, there are good zones and bad.
LEAD: A Boeing Company subsidiary may have curtailed testing of nuts and bolts for the Air Forces' new B-2 stealth bomber in order to save money, according to a report published Sunday.

LEAD: WHAT'S the difference between a marriage that gets happier as time goes on and one that grows more miserable? In many cases it is fights, according to a new study that pinpoints exactly which kinds of arguments help a couple grow closer and which split them apart.

LEAD: Duane Sutter of the Chicago Blackhawks was suspended for five games yesterday by the National Hockey League for a stick incident involving Neil Sheehy of the Washington Capitals. With five seconds left in the game Feb. 15, Sutter struck the Capital defenseman with his stick. He was assessed a high-sticking major and a match penalty, and the foul prompted a videotape review by Brian O'Neill, the National Hockey League executive vice president who handles discipline.

LEAD: The Federal Government announced plans today to detain Central Americans who file invalid claims for political asylum and hold them in a tent city it will erect near here with space for 5,000 people.

LEAD: A court order has been issued in Chicago in the yearlong contract dispute between Mary Cheever, the widow of the writer John Cheever, and Academy Chicago Publishers, a small independent publishing house. The order says Mrs. Cheever fulfilled her obligations to the publisher by providing 15 uncollected stories of her own choosing for an Academy Chicago edition of Cheever works.
LEAD: Jesse Jackson called to talk about what was most on his mind. This is the gist of what he had to say:
LEAD: It's that time of year - winter receding, spring not quite here - when everyone's wardrobe could use a little fashion pick-me-up. This season consider a colorful handbag.

LEAD: TO many, the White House physician may seem to hold a glamorous government position. But to Dr. Daniel Ruge, who was the physician during Ronald Reagan's first term, the job of caring for a healthy President is ''vastly overrated, boring and not medically challenging.''
LEAD: The Nets have so many injuries these days, their locker room resembles a hospital ward.
LEAD: National Guard troops in combat fatigues bathed and fed patients today at a state hospital after nurses and attendants walked out in a contract dispute.

LEAD: Ernest Hemingway might have worn a Swatch Watch, if the company's new ad campaign is any indication of the type of person who owns the trendy timepiece. While the ads do not feature bullfighting, they depict some of the more dangerous leisure activities in the world, including paraponting over thousand-foot waterfalls.

LEAD: John H. Blair, the chief spokesman and lobbyist for Connecticut's insurance industry who was previously an aide to Gov. Ella T. Grasso, died of a heart attack today at John Dempsey Hospital here. He was 44 years old and lived in Farmington.
LEAD: A study in which students carried electronic beepers and recorded their feelings whenever researchers signaled them indicates that some stereotypes about the adolescent psyche are false.

LEAD: Despite statements by the Republican national chairman that a former Ku Klux Klan member elected in Louisiana under the Republican banner should be driven from the party, Republican officials said today that the party would not pressure Republicans in the state to exclude him from their legislative caucus.

LEAD: One week after starting to work at the White House, Sichan Siv remains awe-struck. ''It still is a dream,'' said Mr. Siv, the only Cambodian-American working as a senior official in the White House, a 40-year-old who endured his own version of the killing fields of his homeland.

LEAD: The amount of alcohol consumed over a lifetime contributes to heart and muscle weakness, according to a study conducted by Spanish and American researchers. The study involved 50 chronic alcoholics and 50 healthy men of similar age. Nearly half of the alcoholics suffered weakness of their shoulder and pelvic muscles and a third had damaged heart muscles.
LEAD: Whether the subject is baseball or commodities, Chicago is a city that breeds different styles at its rival institutions and fierce loyalties among their supporters.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: President Bush reviewed the latest F.B.I. report on John G. Tower today and concluded that there was nothing in it to prevent the former Texas Senator's confirmation as Secretary of Defense, the White House said.

LEAD: Representatives of El Salvador's main political parties today began their first formal talks with leaders of the guerrilla movement that has sought for nearly a decade to bring down the country's American-backed Government.
LEAD: Here on Connecticut's Gold Coast, where scores of company headquarters relocated in the 1970's and early 1980's, the great corporate migration from Manhattan has all but ended.

LEAD: The Chicago Board of Trade has begun talks with the London International Financial Futures Exchange about the possibility of hooking up their similar electronic trading systems, an exchange official said.

LEAD: Secretary of State James Baker has broken an unbecoming silence on the Sudan. Pressed by Congress, Mr. Baker has issued a written statement expressing ''profound concern'' about ''massive human suffering'' caused by the Sudan's six-year civil war: ''Most of the war's victims are civilians who are displaced and impoverished, or who starve to death for lack of delivery of available food.

LEAD: WHEN Lance D. Tane tries to get employers to focus on an oft-ignored benefits problem, he sometimes encourages them to think back on the gasoline crisis of the 1970's. Mr. Tane, a consultant at the Wyatt Company, asks his clients to remember the long lines for service, the sharp inflation eating into family money that could have gone for food, clothing and housing.
LEAD: THE Federal Trade Commission is expected to change some rules on cooperative advertising, a move that may upset some smaller retailers and discounters.

LEAD: Who is to say which is the greatest performance a specific ballet has ever received? It is an impossible question. But a possible answer with respect to ''Serenade'' lies with the power and passion that a new cast led by Darci Kistler, Kyra Nichols and Valentina Kozlova swept into this Balanchine classic over the weekend.

LEAD: Archbishop John F. Whealon, urging Roman Catholics not to become ''paralyzed by fear and hopelessness,'' has established an office of AIDS ministry in the Archdiocese of Hartford, church officials said today.

LEAD: Suzanne Braun Levine, a former editor of Ms. magazine, has been appointed editor of The Columbia Journalism Review. She succeeds Spencer Klaw, who left the magazine after the January-February issue and who will retire at the end of this month from his faculty responsibilities at the Graduate School of Journalism at Columbia

LEAD: Frederick Weitzen, a bookseller who pioneered in mail-order techniques and who was a founder of the Marboro Books retail chain, died of lung cancer on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 77 years old. Mr. Weitzen, with Frank Bang and Henry Exstein, started Marboro in 1946 as a mail-order enterprise, advertising extensively to promote sales of popular books at low prices.

LEAD: Significant progress has been made toward settlement of a wide variety of civil charges brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission against Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., people involved in the talks said yesterday.
LEAD: John Morrell & Company today imposed a contract cutting the wages of 2,000 workers at its strife-torn meatpacking plant by up to 18 percent.

LEAD: The dollar rose today against all major currencies in European trading, subdued by the closing of United States markets for the President's Day holiday. Gold prices also moved higher. Dealers said the dollar received a slight lift from Friday's announcement that the United States trade deficit narrowed to $11.9 billion in December from a revised

LEAD: Even before William J. Bennett takes office to lead the Federal effort against illegal drugs, key officials who championed the new post are skeptical that he will acquire sufficient influence to succeed in what many regard as a kind of Mission Impossible.

LEAD: Although clashes between evolutionists and creationists continue to generate heat around the United States, they do not set off intellectual sparks these days. As ''God, Darwin and Dinosaurs'' reports, the nation's scientific community dismisses the belief that man was created in more or less his present form as based on faith in the Bible rather than in the findings of laboratory or field.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: JAMES SIMMONS says he has seen it all before, and he isn't worried. ''I've been here 30 years, and this is the fourth real estate downturn that we've had,'' said Mr. Simmons, chairman of the Valley National Corporation, the owner of Arizona's largest bank.

LEAD: The 'Young' and the Hopeful

LEAD: Slide a shiny red coat lined with small red and white gingham checks over a skinny white wide-wale pique jump suit, and you're ready to face the sunniest spring day. In case it's windy and cold instead of balmy, the coat is roomy enough to slip on over a bulky sweater or even a jacket.
