LEAD: State mental health officials are investigating charges that adolescent patients at Kingsboro Psychiatric Center in Brooklyn used abandoned rooms on the aging 28-acre campus to have sex and to use drugs.

LEAD: The brief dances that Sara Pearson and Patrik Widrig presented Sunday night at the Ethnic Folk Arts Center resembled cartoons. Not animated cartoons or comic strips, which can develop narratives at length, but newspaper or magazine cartoons: isolated drawings that are funny in themselves.

LEAD: ''The Foreign Ministers view those threats with the gravest concern. They condemn this incitement to murder as an unacceptable violation of the most elementary principles and obligations that govern relations among sovereign states.'' - The European Community Foreign Ministers, on Iranian threats against the author Salman Rushdie.

LEAD: The marriage of Hillary Fabian, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Fabian of Forest Hills, Queens, to John Senise, the son of Adeline Senise of Little Neck, Queens, took place last evening at the 5 and 10 No Exaggeration restaurant in SoHo. Rabbi Milton Goodman officiated.

LEAD: Continued economic growth, a weak dollar and relatively low cost pressures helped to swell Corporate America's bottom line in the fourth quarter and pushed profits at many companies to levels that surprised Wall Street.
LEAD: Writers, publishers and human rights organizations in London formed a committee today to challenge the death sentence proclaimed by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini on the author Salman Rushdie.
LEAD: * Apple Inc., a drug treatment agency, has selected Bergelt Litchfield, Inc. to handle its public relations and advertising.
LEAD: The aftermath of his unprecedented feats became more difficult than the feats themselves, Orel Hershiser said today as he sought the seclusion of spring training.
LEAD: Just three weeks into his New York City mayoral campaign, Ronald S. Lauder has already spent $500,000 for television advertising and has hired a 12-person staff and at least five consultants.
LEAD: MATHEMATICIANS and physicists have discovered that a major tool in knot theory, a branch of mathematics, applies as well to elementary particle physics.

LEAD: There is no sound-and-light show in Persepolis anymore. Tourist buses no longer crowd the entrance to these magnificent ruins. Those palaces and temples built 2,500 years ago by the descendants of Cyrus the Great to glorify their Persian empire stand serene, surrounded by the majesty of the Zagros mountains.

LEAD: The criminal trial of Oliver L. North begins Tuesday morning in Federal District Court here, promising more political and legal drama than insights into the scandal that gave birth to the case about 28 months ago.
LEAD: The Lebanese Army appears to have gained the upper hand after a week of violent clashes with militia fighters for control of Christian areas of Lebanon.

LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev ventured anew into the streets of a Soviet city today to drum up support for his policies, only to be confronted with a barrage of complaints about living standards, nuclear power and the people's fears of speaking out for change.

LEAD: Federal dietary guidelines urge Americans to ''choose lean meat'' to avoid heart disease. Yet current labeling rules leave consumers confused about ground beef - which contributes the most fat to the American diet.

LEAD: Mike Tice, the Seattle Seahawks' veteran tight end, has signed a three-year, $1.1 million contract with the Washington Redskins. 4 million. Tice was the first of 19 Seahawks left unprotected under the National Football League's new free-agency plan to sign with another team.(AP)
LEAD: Trap doors on shrimp nets save the lives of sea turtles, but they significantly reduce the shrimpers' catch, researchers have found.
LEAD: AN outplacement expert, a management consultant and a management recruiter have some encouraging words for middle managers who have lost their jobs: maybe they will be better off changing jobs.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 The recall of diplomats from Iran was agreed upon by the 12 European Community nations to protest Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's death threats against Salman Rushdie, author of ''The Satanic Verses.'' Page A1

LEAD: Mideast Diplomatic Moves The Soviet Foreign Minister, in Cairo, claimed new Arab support for Moscow's latest proposals, but he faced little prospect of Israeli assent in talks later in the week. Page A6. Gorbachev in Kiev The Soviet leader ventured into the streets of Kiev to drum up support for his policies, only to be confronted with complaints.

LEAD: Four young children in two families, apparently playing with matches in a bedroom whose door was blocked with a mattress, were fatally burned in an apartment fire in Brooklyn yesterday as their mothers cried hysterically from the street.
LEAD: Senator Pete Wilson, who won re-election to his second six-year term just three months ago, today announced his candidacy for the Republican nomination for governor in 1990.

LEAD: Holden Caulfield, the disaffected teen-ager of ''The Catcher in the Rye'' who fretted about where the ducks in Central Park go for the winter, need not have worried this year. They didn't go anywhere. Elsewhere in Central Park, it has been so warm that people taking cross-country skiing lessons from the Park Rangers have had to practice indoors.

LEAD: The overseas investment arm of South Africa's Anglo American and De Beers group today began a new, record-setting bid for Consolidated Gold Fields P.L.C. of Britain that values the company at $5.65 billion.

LEAD: Soon after Gen. Alfredo Stroessner seized power in Paraguay in 1954, he began reducing the country's links to Argentina and set about building what eventually became a relationship of economic, political and military dependence on Brazil.

LEAD: An economical form of benevolence, guaranteed to bring instant happiness, is to give someone some match-points. That is one possible explanation for South's bid of three no-trump on the diagramed deal in the face of a three-club opening. Alternatively, he may have misheard the bidding, believing that his partner had opened or that the opening bid was three of some other suit.
LEAD: A West German company suspected of playing a key role in building a poison-gas factory in Libya said today that it produced and shipped an illegal drug known as Ecstasy to the United States.

LEAD: Are the spotted owls that live in the ancient forests of the Northwest really endangered or are they being victimized by the miniature radio transmitters that scientists use to track their movements?

LEAD: Amid growing concern in the markets on the direction of interest rates, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, faces Congress today in the start of two days of testimony on the Fed's outlook for monetary policy, the economy and inflation.

LEAD: The Soviet Foreign Minister claimed new Arab support today for Moscow's latest Middle East proposals in Egypt, but he faced little prospect of Israeli assent in discussions here later in the week.

LEAD: Farley Inc. extended its $1.53 billion tender offer for the textile giant West Point-Pepperell Inc. on Friday, the second time in a week and 12th over all, setting the latest deadline for midnight Tuesday. The expiration of the $52-a-share offer had been extended from midnight Wednesday to midnight Friday earlier last week.
LEAD: The nine-year legal battle over whether Princeton University's two all-male eating clubs should be forced to admit women could end soon before the New Jersey Supreme Court.
LEAD: More than 50 soldiers escaped injury today when they were evacuated minutes before a series of explosions extensively damaged their barracks in central England.

LEAD: The Bush Administration, putting the final touches on the savings bailout plan it will present to Congress this week, has made a number of modest changes that will make the proposal somewhat less onerous for the banking and savings industries, an Administration official said today.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Lonny Strum, a senior vice president of BBDO Worldwide, will go south next month to become president of Earle Palmer Brown & Spiro, a Philadelphia agency. Mr. Strum supervised major ad campaigns for Polaroid, General Electric and Du Pont in his 11 years with BBDO. Walter A. Spiro, the chairman of the agency, said Mr.
LEAD: THERE are a lot of computer orphans out there.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about a Soviet appeal for American help in securing an Afghan cease-fire misstated remarks by Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, about Soviet advisers in Afghanistan.

LEAD: In celebration of the American Recorder Society's 50th anniversary, the Music Before 1800 series at Corpus Christi Church presented a concert by the Amsterdam Loeki Stardust Quartet, a Dutch recorder ensemble, on Sunday afternoon. The program was devoted the transcriptions of late Renaissance viol music and Baroque works originally composed for strings or organ.

LEAD: If there are two marked men in the training camp of the Mets, they are Gary Carter and Keith Hernandez, the captains, aging stars with the best records on the team, both earning $2 million a year, both entering the final year of their contracts at the age of 35 with everybody wondering: Is this the end?
LEAD: The Rangers signed another finesse-style defenseman, Miroslav Horava of Czechoslovakia, yesterday in an attempt to improve their power play or enhance a trade.

LEAD: The first player to score in a short match, as in the recent six-game elimination quarterfinals for world championship candidates, is supposed to have a great advantage, yet the results did not bear that out.
LEAD: A man said he was not at all tempted to find out what was in two locked canvas bags he discovered on a street over the weekend, but his interest was piqued when he learned what was inside.

LEAD: rrThe other day, W. H. Ferry was making his quarterly visit to his longtime acquaintances, the Mumfords, when the subject turned to suicide. Writing had been everything to Lewis Mumford, the great architectural critic and urban historian who is now 93 years old. He wrote 29 books, the last when he was in his mid-80's.

LEAD: While the Indiana Pacers altered their chemistry yesterday with one trade, Donnie Walsh, their general manager, said he was still hoping to get Kiki Vandeweghe before the trading deadline Thursday. The Knicks have been pursuing the Portland Trail Blazer forward for more than six months.

LEAD: Twenty-eight months after the Iran-contra scandal broke, the trial of the central figure in the case, Oliver L. North, begins today. But it promises more political and legal drama than insight into the scandal because of successful Government objections to the use of secret material. Article, page A19.

LEAD: A table on Friday showing reading scores in New York City schools omitted the year-to-year change in scores for several schools and omitted one school, Junior High School 99 in District 4. A corrective table appears today on page B6.
LEAD: As the playwright Vaclav Havel and eight other opposition figures prepare to go on trial Tuesday, the Czechoslovak Government is under pressure to expand political freedoms.

LEAD: The list of players injured or suspended was lengthy and therefore the possibility existed that the Rangers might spend the afternoon against the Devils discovering a large assortment of excuses to match.
LEAD: Twelve people were arrested and 100 pounds of heroin was seized during raids on three homes in College Point, Queens, last night, the police said.
LEAD: THE patient was already in the hospital when he suffered a massive stroke that paralyzed his entire left side. It began about 10 P.M.

LEAD: Huddled in a wheelchair against a warm radiator, lifeless legs tangled beneath her, 19-year-old Zuhriyeh Naji thought aloud about the life that lay ahead, and her despondency bordered on despair.

LEAD: One Oliver North trial has already ended - the trial over whether there would even be a trial. Today, after three weeks of jury selection and arguments over classified documents, a second Oliver North trial begins. The former Marine lieutenant colonel faces charges of lying to Congress about the Iran-contra affair.
LEAD: Arena Football will suspend operations this year while attempting to restructure, the general manager of the Detroit Drive said today.
LEAD: In the age of the blow-dried candidate, of politicians packaged to look and sound good on television, Chicago's Democratic mayoral primary endures as a kind of reassuring anachronism.

LEAD: Helene Eliat van de Velde, a psychologist and writer who elucidated Freudian insights into the literary portrayal of human behavior, died of cardio-respiratory failure on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 95 years old.

LEAD: rrWith his usual bluster, George Steinbrenner has offended the purists who think the Olympic ideal still exists. The essence of his Olympic Overview report is that the United States Olympic Committee needs to turn pro.

LEAD: A woman whose body was found in a motel room here over the weekend was the victim of a homicide, the Nassau County police said today. Tabitha Vaughn, 19 years old, of Hempstead, was strangled, the police said, and investigators are seeking a man who checked into the Hempstead Motor Inn at 131 Hempstead Avenue with her at 8:40 Saturday morning.

LEAD: The following table supplements information released Thursday by the New York City Board of Education on the reading tests given in the city's public elementary and junior high schools in May 1988. It gives information about schools' performance compared with their performance the previous year, omitted from a chart published in The Times on

LEAD: In seeking to hold together a coalition that will replace Cambodia's Vietnamese-installed Government, Prince Norodom Sihanouk seems unhappily and awkwardly to have become the chief advocate of his longtime adversary, the Khmer Rouge.

LEAD: From President Fidel Castro to the most anonymous of students, Cubans are awaiting an American television station that is expected to bring them news, sports, music videos and soap operas whether they like it or not.

LEAD: John Eliot Gardiner belongs to the first circle of England's busy early-music leaders, and his presentation of Handel's ''Israel in Egypt'' at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday afternoon gave many reminders of why. It was almost nothing like the Handel oratorio performances most of us grew up on, and it was very beautiful at its best.
LEAD: Over the din of a nearby commuter train roaring from the elevated line into a tunnel in Brooklyn, the voice from a megaphone intones in Arabic: ''Allah is great. . . . Come to prayer. . . .''
LEAD: Brian Shorter scored 30 points as Pittsburgh squandered a 16-point lead, then rallied to beat Villanova, 73-72, tonight for the Panthers' fourth consecutive Big East victory.

LEAD: It took a year for George Steinbrenner and his Overview Committee to develop a report that addresses many of the problems facing the United States Olympic Committee. It probably will take another year for the recommendations to go into effect.

LEAD: New Yorkers have seen celebrated performers of traditional and iconoclastic modern Japanese dance and theater forms. But ''Japan's Traditional Dance - Now,'' presented on Saturday night at the Carey Playhouse of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, was something new. LEAD: THE threat from Africanized ''killer'' bees arises from their mass attacks rather than their venom, according to research reported in a recent issue of the journal Nature.
LEAD: When the Academy Award nominations were announced last Wednesday, the list included ''The Music Teacher,'' a Belgian film that few academy members had seen and most had never heard of.

LEAD: In the roughest neighborhoods of cities besieged by the drug trade, where buildings are pocked with bullet holes and the streets ring with gunfire, hospitals have become urban MASH units, with paramedics and doctors treating wounds once seen only on the battlefield.

LEAD: The Phoenix Suns activated Dan Majerle, a rookie guard, putting him into uniform before their game last night with the Utah Jazz and putting Steve Kerr on the injured list to make room for him. Majerle had missed the previous 28 games, having been stricken by mononucleosis in mid-December. (AP)

LEAD: Tom Foley left the White House in a driving rain but he paused, as House majority leader, to make a simple statement of Congressional power and prerogative. What of the budget, the reporters asked? ''The regular process will go forward,'' he replied.
LEAD: Of course there are lions and wildebeests in the Serengeti Plain and the Ngorongoro crater. The surprises were caramel custard and guacamole.
LEAD: A Czechoslovak court today convicted the playwright and dissident author Vaclav Havel of inciting illegal protests and obstructing the police and sentenced him to nine months in prison.

LEAD: Representative Bill Grant of Florida switched today from the Democratic Party to the Republicans, saying that he could ''better represent the values and priorities'' of his constituents in his new party. But Democratic leaders here said his conversion was part of a much broader battle over Congressional reapportionment for the 1990's.
LEAD: Stock prices ended mixed yesterday, with blue chips gaining and the broader market showing weakness.
LEAD: Interest rates rose again yesterday at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper.

LEAD: In a surprisingly critical review, the Federal regulator of commodity exchanges said today that the Chicago Board of Trade had done a poor job of detecting fraud and other violations on its trading floor.

LEAD: The Metropolitan Opera's new ''Salome'' is a schizoid affair. In this Nikolaus Lehnhoff production, the musical and theatrical elements of Strauss's biblical horror story lead parallel lives, never really making contact. Fortunately for those who care about such things, the score's exhausting musical challenges were met triumphantly on Monday evening, particularly by Eva Marton in the grueling title part.

But those who opted for the concert performance of the second act of Wagner's ''Tristan und Isolde'' by the Orchestre de Paris at Avery Fisher Hall picked wrong. Even with some first-rate singing, this was a most disappointing 75 minutes of music making.

LEAD: THE 19th-century whale and cod fisheries drew Portuguese sailors to southeastern Massachusetts. The textile factories kept their descendants there. Today, about 60 percent of Fall River's 92,000 residents are ethnically Portuguese, which keeps the city's dozen or so Portuguese bakeries doing a brisk business.

LEAD: Mac O'Grady, who has always been a refreshing difference on the PGA Tour, may become the first man in PGA Tour history to play one or more rounds of competitive tournament golf from the opposite side of the ball to which he normally plays. In his case, he may tee off Thursday in the Ryder Doral Open by playing left-handed instead of right-handed.

LEAD: Because the first full moon after the Tibetan new year occurred Monday night, the eight Tibetan monks from the Drepung-Loseling monastery who are now touring the United States gave the first performances in the West of excerpts from Mon-lam Chen-mo, the Great Prayer Festival. LEAD: Le Reve, a major Long Island winery, is reportedly in financial trouble. But the owner, Alan Barr, said it was not in danger even though a bank has taken steps to foreclose on a loan that he characterized as ''slightly more than $6 million.''

LEAD: After an initial period of sputter and stall, the public indignation of writers, librarians and civil libertarians grew yesterday in response to the death threats against the author Salman Rushdie and the removal of his novel from many bookstores.
LEAD: Steve Yzerman, the multi-talented center for the Red Wings, set a club record for points and tied the record for goals in a season tonight in Detroit's 6-5 victory over the Islanders.

LEAD: Dr. Cecil Mantell, a gastroenterologist and a founder of the Skylight Center, a new psychiatric rehabilitation center on Staten Island, died of complications from leukemia Monday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 74 years old and lived in St. George, S.I.

LEAD: The winning bidder for West Point-Pepperell Inc., the big textile producer, may be announced as early as today, executives close to the deal said yesterday. Pennwalt, a diversified chemical company based in Philadelphia, said it regarded Centaur's proposed price as inadequate.

LEAD: It's too soon to say whether New York City's new system of public campaign financing will reduce candidates' reliance on wealthy favor-seekers. But the latest filings are encouraging. LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Ernest Fred Easterbrook, a retired Army major general who was the son-in-law of Gen. Joseph Stilwell, died Sunday. He was 80 years old. General Easterbrook served in World War II as an infantry instructor of Chinese troops under General Stilwell, the commander of United States forces in China, Burma and India.

LEAD: Baseball BOSTON (AL) - Agreed to terms with Mike Greenwell, outfielder, on a two-year contract, and Luis Rivera, infielder, on a one-year contract. LEAD: Jonathan Miller first produced and directed ''Rigoletto'' in 1975. Instead of placing the action in 16th-century Mantua, as tradition would have it, he moved it up to the 19th century, which he felt would be more compatible with Verdi's score. LEAD: Secretary of State Baker has returned from his tour of NATO capitals having learned how hard it is to hold a nuclear umbrella over Europe when many Europeans fear the risks and some doubt the need.

LEAD: New York City shelters for homeless adults provide inadequate and costly services, State Comptroller Edward V. Regan said in releasing audit reports yesterday.

LEAD: The Long Island Rail Road is so lacking in management capabilities that it can no longer qualify for Federal grants for capital projects, Alfred DelliBovi, the Urban Mass Transit Administrator, said today.

LEAD: Yesterday's editorial ''On Second Thought, Courage,'' about the reaction to Salman Rushdie's novel ''The Satanic Verses,'' referred to an advertisement elsewhere in The Times. LEAD: The United States wheat stockpile is expected to be whittled this spring to one of the smallest since the end of World War II, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday. LEAD: After five months of relaxation in Tokyo, the composer and saxophonist John Zorn has returned to New York. A performance guerrilla, he hits small clubs and spaces all across the city, improvising with visiting Soviet musicians, playing with his fellow downtown improvisers, working with a repertory group dedicated to the compositions of the jazz pianist Sonny Clark, or with another dedicated to the tunes of Ornette Coleman.

But New York was in scoring position several times after that, so we continued to scream at Don, Dave, Jack and
LEAD: Harvard freshmen typically spend an hour more in class or studying every week than adults typically spend at work.

LEAD: Q. I am having a constant problem with the sliding wooden doors on my closet. The plastic wheels are supposed to slide along in a metal track fastened to the top of the door jamb. Mine seem to have come off the track, so it is almost impossible to move the doors unless I pick them up.

LEAD: A 6-year-old girl was in critical condition with a broken skull after clashes with Israeli soldiers today, Arab doctors said. Troops raided homes in search of Arabs who had killed a soldier by dropping a cement block on his head.

LEAD: WHEN Louis Soto took his own life in the Englewood City Jail last month, a television monitoring system designed to keep detainees under constant observation had been inoperative for almost three months.

LEAD: Graduation usually means caps and gowns, a good-luck handshake from the college president and a diploma. But for some seniors at Middlebury College, graduation means caps and gowns, a good-luck handshake from the president and skis.
LEAD: THE sign in the window of Great Neck's Tarabya Restaurant reads ''Authentic Turkish Restaurant.'' Exotic, unknown and foreboding as that might seem, fear not.

LEAD: The state has suspended the license of a doctor whom some patients have accused of having sexual relations with them, then performing abortions on them without their knowledge after they became pregnant.

LEAD: To the Editor: Having vacationed in Switzerland over 30 times during the past 30 odd years and having enjoyed many delightful meals in the top restaurants of main railway stations, my wife and I greatly enjoyed Mr. Shenker's article.

LEAD: STATE environmental officials have accepted a county study that measures the ability of the Yonkers sewage-treatment plant to handle additional capacity and analyzes potential environmental impacts, the Department of Environmental Conservation announced last week.

LEAD: An article on Jan. 1 about Hispanic residents seeking a larger role in government in Perth Amboy described the namesake of MacWilliam Stadium incorrectly. Joseph Lockwood MacWilliam was an Army lieutenant at the time of his death in 1936, not a World War I hero.

LEAD: The announcement in Tokyo this week that Indonesia and China will normalize relations, frozen more than 20 years ago after the attempted coup here in 1965, closes one of the last great gaps in the circle of Southeast Asian diplomacy.
LEAD: Todd Schmiedl has not been able to speak above a whisper since his larynx was damaged in an automobile accident nine years ago.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THE board of trustees of the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, meeting Feb. 9, voted unanimously to take strong issue with the New Jersey Opinion page article by State Senator Ronald L. Rice on Feb. 5. The article contains serious distortions about the university's service to the minority community.

LEAD: Think about fresh new fashions, clothes in colors that are clear and appealing. Anticipate shapes that are clean, sometimes unexpected, but more often familiar. Keep an eye out for touches of exotica - they are the spice of this spring's style. Consider that, of course, the cost of fashion continues to rise.

LEAD: ''I'm a romantic,'' says John Milius. He is standing on a cliff in Sarawak, above the Borneo jungle, fitting a stone to a slingshot that the Malays call ''pana'' and his Iban extras call ''la stika.'' The black-bearded writer-director of ''Farewell to the King,'' which opens on Friday at Loews Astor Plaza and 84th Street Six, is competing with his star, Nick Nolte, in trying to hit the tallest tree jutting up through a cloak of jungle fog whose milky opacity will keep Mr.
LEAD: THE CALL OF STORIES Teaching and the Moral Imagination. By Robert Coles. 212 pp. Boston: A Peter Davison Book/ Houghton Mifflin Company. $18.95.
LEAD: For the third time in a week yesterday, Florence Griffith Joyner cried in public. In all likelihood, it will not happen again for quite a while.
LEAD: OFFICIALS of Loyola University of Chicago say they are confident that plans for a 16.8-acre landfill expansion into Lake Michigan at the school's North Shore campus will go forward this spring.
LEAD: I am responding to the article ''A Lack of Nurses Brings Changes at County Hospitals'' in the Feb. 5 Westchester Weekly.

LEAD: The pianist Eugene Istomin had distinct ideas about how he wanted to interpret the works on his Carnegie Hall program Wednesday evening. But throughout the performance, his technique got in the way of his intentions.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: New Jersey doesn't have enough real problems for legislators to address! We don't need to fix the auto insurance mess. We don't need to stop the sexual transmission of AIDS. We don't need to force an independent audit of waste in autonomous authorities. We don't need real progress in the fight against drugs.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh has decided not to support a Reagan Administration decision to deport an Irish Republican Army member convicted of murder in Britain.

LEAD: Mary Hart, a co-host of the syndicated television program ''Entertainment Tonight,'' and Burt Sugarman, a television and movie producer, have announced their engagement. Both are residents of Beverly Hills, Calif. Miss Hart is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Harum of Fresno, Calif. Mr. Sugarman, who also is chairman of Giant Group Ltd., an entertainment and industrial products company in Beverly Hills, is the son of Al Sugarman of Beverly Hills and the late Mrs.

LEAD: Senator Dorsey, in his article, ''A Hazard at Home: Air Pollution,'' points to an important problem that is only beginning to receive significant attention. When we realize that employed adults average less than 45 minutes a day outdoors, it becomes obvious that air pollution indoors presents real cause for concern.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. James P. Dunn of Pound Ridge, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Mary Dunn, to Lieut. Col. Charles R. Steiner Jr., U.S.A., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Steiner of Toledo, Ohio. An April wedding is planned.

LEAD: In Washington, President Bush may be tangled in problems with appointments and ethics. But beyond the capital, a majority of Americans say they like the way he is doing his job, according to the New York Times/CBS News Poll, and only a small minority say they disapprove.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: When ''The Pajama Game'' begins performances this Friday at the New York City Opera, the hit-filled 1954 musical about the garment trade will be a different kind of production from the sort of show that Beverly Sills, the company's general director, envisioned four years ago.
LEAD: NO postwar Greek Government has lasted more than eight years, and it seems increasingly unlikely that Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou will be an exception to the rule.

LEAD: The daughter of an American diplomat, Martita Kingsley Goshen grew up in South America, and in ''On the Way to Going Home'' she choreographically recalls her experiences in the upper Amazon. Her company, Martita Goshen's Earthworks, performed it with great concentration on Friday night at the Alwin Nikolais-Murray Louis Choreospace.

LEAD: Nancy Dickerson, a commentator for Fox Television in Washington, and John C. Whitehead, chairman of AEA Investors Inc., an investment concern in New York, were married yesterday at the bride's home in Washington. Judge Abner J. Mikva of the United States Court of Appeals in Washington officiated.

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: THE observance of Black History Month each February has succeeded in teaching Westchester residents about black contributions to history, but many public schools should do more to include a black historical perspective throughout the year, some local educators say.
LEAD: THE COUNTRY I COME FROM By Maura Stanton. 106 pp. Minneapolis: Milkweed Editions. Paper, $9.95.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: For This Week: Keep up with seed planting, especially flowers such as impatiens, begonias, petunias and blue salvia, which need a head start indoors; wait a few weeks to plant indoors seed of vegetables such as peppers, eggplants and tomatoes. Tubers of begonias and caladiums can be started indoors, too, to form roots; use a mixture rich with peat moss so it retains moisture.

Piper was the public-address announcer at Wrigley and had performed those duties at that ball park for more than 50 years. I posed the same question to the now-deceased Pat Piper: ''Did Babe Ruth call that famous shot?

LEAD: Of course Babe Ruth called his shot. And the bat he used was carved from a log which was part of the log cabin Abe Lincoln was born in. And that log came from a tree chopped down many years before by George Washington. RICHARD T. POTTER, Jr. Ridgewood, N.J.
LEAD: A man whose conviction for the slaying of a police officer was questioned in the documentary film ''The Thin Blue Line'' has been refused parole despite a state judge's strong backing.
LEAD: Because of an editing error, a review of ''The Village by the Sea'' on Feb. 5 described the book, a children's novel, incorrectly. It was not a 1989 Newbery Honor Book.
LEAD: ''NO cans, no bottles, no weapons.'' The security guards repeatedly shouted the list of taboo items to the 17,000 teen-agers lined up outside the Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum.

LEAD: Down the hall, the Go-Go's were blasting on a stereo. The University of Massachusetts, like most colleges these days, is largely a secular place. But in one dormitory room, four undergraduates were reading from the New Testament.

LEAD: ANY OLD IRON By Anthony Burgess. 360 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95.
LEAD: EDWARD LANSDALE The Unquiet American. By Cecil B. Currey. Illustrated. 430 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $24.95.

LEAD: Passers-by, intrigued by the distressed steel facade with ''One Off'' etched in a strange scribble, can look through a peephole for a fisheye glimpse of the architect Ron Arad's gallery and office. What they see will make them even more curious. The former storage space is now totally clad in an envelope of metal, with tiny pinpoints of light directed at an array of whimsical metal furniture.
LEAD: THE internationally respected letterer Smith-Corona Electric died at his home in Great Neck, L.I., yesterday at the age of 28. The cause of death was advanced technology.

LEAD: February always seems to be the cruelest month, a cold, slushy torment of flu and midterms between the winter holidays and spring break. For undergraduates at Yale College, however, February is not a total loss.

LEAD: City Council is violating the principle of separation of church and state by scheduling a public hearing on the Archdiocese of Detroit's plans to close 30 churches in the city, Edmund Cardinal Szoka said.

LEAD: Special elections to fill vacancies in state legislatures seldom turn heads, but the one last weekend in an affluent, nearly all-white suburb of New Orleans had heads shaking across the country. With a huge turnout of 78 percent of the electorate, David Duke, a former grand wizard of the Ku Klux Klan running under the Republican banner, won the legislative seat in Metairie by 234 votes out of the 16,688 cast.

LEAD: Karen Martha Fitz-Patrick plans to wed Peter Bruce Sundlun, a son of Bruce G. Sundlun of Providence, R.I., and Madeleine Schiffer Gimbel of Washington. The announcement has been made by the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Jeremy James Fitz-Patrick of Newport News, Va. An April wedding is planned.
LEAD: My parents divorced 27 years ago, when I was 2. I consider myself lucky to have been too young to remember the actual event. I have always seen the world through the eyes of a child of divorce.

LEAD: A bank clerk and two other women were each found handcuffed and shot in the head in the clerk's Bronx apartment Friday in what the police said yesterday may have been a retaliation killing over drug trafficking.

LEAD: Yma Sumac, the Peruvian vocal phenomenon, has always fearlessly straddled the line between the sublime and the ridiculous. In 1950, when ''Voice of the Xtabay,'' her first album of multi-octave mystical warblings, created a sensation, Miss Sumac was already regarded as something of a camp oddity, albeit one who possessed singular gifts.

LEAD: When prices were rising at double-digit rates back in 1979 and 1980, inflation was enough of a public concern for the Federal Reserve Board to raise interest rates dramatically and push the economy into a recession.

LEAD: OFF ON A WILD CABOOSE CHASE: True Adventures, Folklore, and a Farewell Tribute to the Old Train Caboose by a Writer Who Lives Aboard One. By Adolf Hungry Wolf. (Morrow, $17.95.) The enthusiasms of the rail fan, like a taste for olives, are not readily communicated to the uninitiated. To most people, the romance of the rails means the lure of travel and faraway places.
LEAD: Every year, at least one American city finds itself overwhelmed by the measles, a disease many people thought had gone away.
LEAD: Groups that have traditionally regarded each other with suspicion have joined in denouncing Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's proposed $350 million cut in Medicaid spending.

LEAD: Forget about justice. Forget about helping oppressed people. Mark Yudof, the dean of the University of Texas Law School, describes what he calls the ''glamour theory'' of why more students are applying to law school these days.

LEAD: The only officer charged as a result of the death of a Marine corporal abandoned in the Mojave Desert last August has been found guilty of dereliction of duty and sentenced to discharge and four months in jail.

LEAD: The long arm of Norm Stewart reached out to the seventh-ranked Missouri Tigers today. With Missouri a point behind top-ranked Oklahoma at halftime, the Missouri coach, who is recovering from cancer surgery at a hospital here, telephoned his team's acting coach, Rich Daly.

LEAD: Merce Cunningham hopes his dances speak for themselves, and he hesitates to explain them. Thus, when asked recently why he used the word ''cargo'' in the title of ''Cargo X,'' the choreographer said, ''It's just a word. I picked it.'' But why? ''It provokes something,'' he finally acknowledged. ''It's a poetic, ambiguous word.

LEAD: Shari Paula Batt, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Batt of New York, was married yesterday to Henry Brewster Minton, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Dwight Church Minton of Princeton, N.J. Marvin R. Reed, the acting Mayor of Princeton Borough, officiated at the Omni Nassau Inn in Princeton.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: FROM the time he was 14 years old, Dennis Foy knew he wanted to be a chef. A native of Philadelphia, he went from busing tables in a small northern Italian restaurant there to an apprenticeship in a restaurant that was owned by his brother, John. Dennis Foy moved to Summit in 1974, where he still lives.

LEAD: The article ''Higher Taxes, Dire Prospects'' (Feb. 5), ends with the statement, ''School budgets can only increase,'' attributed to the executive director of the Nassau and Suffolk School Boards Association. Since the next opportunity for the taxpayers on Long Island to express their opposition to the steadily rising tax bills will be school budget votes, it is likely that many of these budgets will be rejected.

LEAD: Beginning with their first major project - being born - the Kitchen twins have been collaborating in one way or another. And like so many identical twins, Richard and Robert are almost mystically in tune with each other.

LEAD: The Public Schools Athletic League has been having its basketball playoffs for the last two weeks, but the defending champion, Adlai Stevenson of the Bronx, did not play its first game until yesterday at the Fashion Institute of Technology in Manhattan.
LEAD: MORE than three years after Hurricane Gloria struck Long Island, hundreds of homeowners with beach-area property are still feeling its blows.

LEAD: The notion of changing cameras must be in the air. Last week two friends asked me to recommend new models that would suit their needs better than their current gear. Both want to upgrade from 10-year-old cameras to something more contemporary.
LEAD: If the growth of consulting firms that design family benefits programs for corporations is a reliable bellwether, employer-provided day-care assistance is finally taking off.

LEAD: INCLINE OUR HEARTS. By A. N. Wilson. (Viking, $17.95.) A. N. Wilson is prodigious. Praised most recently for his biography of Tolstoy, he now deserves applause for this witty and tender, delightfully written and perceptive novel. Its hero is the orphaned Julian Ramsay, brought up, cared for if not absolutely loved, by his aunt and uncle in an English vicarage.

LEAD: Remember the schoolyard canard about no more pencils and no more books? At Adelphi University this semester, students are learning to make do with no class rosters, no reading lists and no one to credit their tuition payments. Secretaries at the 93-year-old college are on strike.

LEAD: Every college student who ever struggled through Philosophy 101 knows that you cannot step twice into the same river. What Heraclitus emphasized in his famous metaphor - the singularity of all events - certainly used to be true of music.
LEAD: An article on the Century Apartments on Feb. 19 misstated its landmark status. The building was designated a New York City landmark in 1985.

LEAD: Suffolk Tea Party EVEN in protest, Long Islanders can be creative. Suffolk County Legislator Sondra Bachety received an herbal tea bag in the mail recently. ''My constituents send nothing but the best,'' Ms. Bachety said. ''I'm planning to enjoy it.''
LEAD: A panel of Governors warned today that the economic well-being of the United States was in jeopardy because so many Americans are ignorant of the languages and cultures of other nations.

LEAD: More people than ever - Bostonians and tourists alike - are flocking to Newbury Street, a fashionable eight-block stretch in the Back Bay where one can find shops and boutiques offering everything from Swiss lingerie to Japanese food to a Swedish massage. The new magnet is ''upper'' Newbury Street, the blocks between Exeter and Hereford Streets, at the far end of Newbury's gateway at the Public Garden and the Ritz Carlton Hotel (Newbury's cross streets run alphabetically, from Arlington to Hereford).

LEAD: So few people are applying for political asylum since the Government toughened procedures here in south Texas early this week that the Immigration and Naturalization Service is reducing the extra staff it brought in to start its new program.

LEAD: To the Editor: Israel Shenker's article ''In Switzerland Train Stations Are for Eating'' (Travel, Jan. 8) brought back memories. On our annual trip to our summer house at Les Avants, we left Berlin on the 4 P.M. train and arrived in Basel at 7 A.M. A change of trains left us one hour, and our first stop was the station restaurant, for breakfast.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Robert G. Loewy of Loudonville, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Esther Elizabeth Loewy to Paul Michael Giddins, a son of Ellen Giddins of New York and the late Robert Giddins. An April wedding is planned.

LEAD: IN an effort to change the honky-tonk image of this once-vibrant southern Maine seaside community, town leaders, developers and private citizens are planning an ambitious revitalization to attract businesses and residents to the downtown area.

LEAD: Computer-aided software engineering, or CASE, is a process that is supposed to simplify the creation and maintenance of computer software. It is just the type of help that is desperately needed by the many large businesses where the problem of maintaining, updating and fixing aging software has reached crisis proportions.

LEAD: As soon as the Sports Illustrated swimsuit issue hits the newsstands, the bathing suit designer Keiko Fukuzaki gets a flood of phone calls from men all over the nation, who want to order her sexy styles for girlfriends and wives.

LEAD: The thrust of Judith Wallerstein's article is that divorce per se is harmful to children. I am concerned that this focus will distract attention from the more significant issues, which are that dysfunctional families and parents are harmful to children, regardless of marital status. Ms. Wallerstein briefly acknowledges that divorce may be a more satisfactory solution to problems than continuing a harmful marriage.
LEAD: Tufts University will divest itself of all its holdings in businesses operating in South Africa, university officials announced late today.

LEAD: THE East Haven landfill was filled to capacity more than two years ago, but the town continues to use it. ''We're in the same boat as a lot of other towns at this point,'' Mayor Robert M. Norman said.

We know it mainly as an operatic instrument, but here Mr. Hadley - an American singer with a substantial international stage career - divided a recital of songs among Brahms, Vaughan Williams, Britten and Rachmaninoff.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edward Schmeltzer of Potomac, Md., of the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Sabine Schmeltzer, to Rick Franklin Hinson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Eldon F. Hinson of Redding, Calif. The couple plan to marry in June.
LEAD: A review on page 15 of The Times Book Review today discusses ''Father and Son,'' a novel by Peter Maas about Northern Ireland and the Irish Republican Army.

LEAD: I'VE LIVED IN ST. THOMAS for a number of years, but my real introduction to Caribbean cooking began when I met Tijoe Ledee, a French West Indian fisherman. Sailors here never take an impending storm seriously until Tijoe moves his boat to safety in the nearby mangroves. When this occurs, all boats in the harbor are instantly moved to safety, hatches are battened down, candles and flashlights readied.

LEAD: The tune ''Black Lightning'' opens ''Voice of Africa, The African Recordings'' (Kaz 101: record and CD, available from NMDS, 500 Broadway, New York, N.Y. 10012), the first of a four-album, eight-record set of South African jazz by the pianist and composer Abdullah Ibrahim (Dollar Brand). All the elements of South African Township jazz are there: the rolling ostinatos; the traditional African melodies; the gospel-inflected, sweet and sour tinged harmonies; the cotton-soft horn riffs and the relaxed dance beat implying that the world is, for the moment, without problems.

LEAD: FOR many single adults, the notion of meeting a mate at a bar or on a blind date is distasteful. But without a partner, they often feel they cannot do some of the things they would like to, like go to concerts and plays.

LEAD: Five years ago, the New York Housing Partnership identified six sites in the South Bronx for housing affordable by families earning up to $30,000 a year. It took that long for the Partnership to line up the financing and the many government approvals needed for the 50 two-family homes it planned, and then, late last year, the project hit a snag: The State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation asked that the design be modified to make it compatible with structures in the adjacent Longwood Historic District.

LEAD: To the Editor: It was a pleasure to learn in ''A Barbados Synagogue Is Reborn'' by Nancy Sharkey (Travel, Dec. 11) that the synagogue in Barbados is being restored to its original function and condition.

LEAD: An article on Feb. 12 about efforts to negotiate a chemical weapons treaty referred incorrectly to a guilty plea by Alcolac International, a Baltimore chemical company. In a case resulting from its sale of thiodiglycol to a German company, Alcolac acknowledged that it had ''knowledge or reason to know'' that Singapore, the destination listed on the shipper's export declaration, was not the ultimate one.
LEAD: Ted Warmbold, editor of The San Antonio Light, died of meningitis today at Humana Metropolitan Hospital. He was 45 years old.
LEAD: THE casino industry here is moving into its second decade with a torrent of revenues and slowly improving profitability.

LEAD: The Canadian Government has sent out notices to every doctor in Canada that it will allow patients with life-threatening diseases to obtain any drugs companies are willing to sell, even if no country has approved the drugs for marketing.

LEAD: Stanford University's 10 ''focus'' houses - dormitories set aside mainly for students of the same ethnic group or academic interest - have become the focus of a debate this semester. At issue is whether the separate living quarters are fostering diversity or segregation.

Cheney performed the ceremony.

Then, on Friday, the Federal Reserve Board raised the discount rate to 7 percent, the highest level since May 1986. Four experts discuss how higher interest rates affect the economy.

LEAD: ''The box the Fed is in is not of its own making: Federal budget deficits will be worse if monetary policy gets much, much tighter, and short-term interest rates will move sharply higher.'' - Allen Sinai, chief economist, the Boston Company.

LEAD: He is their phenom this spring, their kid with unlimited talent and untapped potential. He is only 20 years old, but the coaches who work with him daily say he has the skills of a big leaguer. The people in the front office speak of his intellectual and his physical growth. They all say he simply can't miss.

LEAD: Growth of jobs in the private sector in New York City virtually stagnated in 1988 after years of steady growth, Federal labor statisticians have concluded. At the same time, government employment rose by 15,000, to a record high.

LEAD: Heads thrown back, mouths wide open, the Proclaimers shout their songs with gawky exuberance and thick Scottish accents. Originally the duo of Craig and Charlie Reid, identical twins from Edinburgh, the Proclaimers came to the Bottom Line on Thursday night with a band that connects Scottish traditionalism to rockabilly.

LEAD: A 3-year-old girl left in a Brooklyn apartment with a younger child was mauled yesterday afternoon by four dogs belonging to her family while her grandmother was out buying milk, the police said.

LEAD: Yes, he called his shot, though the Babe himself reportedly denied it. But this legend has a twist. Rather than guaranteeing the monstrous trajectory over the right-center-field wall of his next four-bagger off Charlie Root in the third inning of Game 3 of the 1932 World Series at Wrigley Field, Ruth might just as plausibly have been pointing to the downtown saloon where he would be celebrating the day's 7-5 victory.

LEAD: EVERYONE here remembers September 1984. They call it ''Black September'' because that was the month that two factories closed, another laid off half its employees and unemployment in this town of 2,100 soared to 18 percent.

LEAD: If hercules were still around and looking for a 13th labor to perform, an opera company might profitably engage him to put together a repertory that would please everyone. He would probably decide that he had it easier in the days when all a hero was required to do was cleanse a few stables or steal an Amazon queen's girdle.
LEAD: THE roadside shelter at Inspiration Point, on the Henry Hudson Parkway and 190th Street, was built in 1925 as a destination point for promenaders and pleasure drivers.

LEAD: The Sarasota Opera is celebrating its 30th season this year, but that's a little misleading. From 1960 to 1974, Sarasota opera lovers sponsored a visiting troupe from Woodstock, N.Y., at the tiny Asolo Theater on the Ringling Museum grounds, then began producing their own vest-pocket productions there.

LEAD: In an age of grand museum exhibitions, the curators who mount them are exerting an important influence on design and popular culture. Their impact can be felt in fashion, architecture, drama and, even, wallpaper, as David McFadden knows all too well.

LEAD: I am from a small town in central Vermont. My parents divorced when I was 10 or 11. One sunny spring afternoon, my brother and I were sitting atop a hill near our home. We were waiting for my best friend to walk from his house to ours. He was to stay in our house for an entire week, while his parents were on vacation.

LEAD: It is getting so that academia is to the New York Public Library what the arms industry is to the Pentagon. The library, which lost its last president, Dr. Vartan Gregorian, to Brown University, announced last week that its next chief executive will be the Rev. Timothy S. Healy, the president of Georgetown University.

LEAD: Mrs. Jackson T. Witherspoon 3d of Inverness, Calif., and Washington, has made known the engagement of her daughter, Virginia Rodgers Witherspoon, to John Elmer Marlette, the son of Mrs. John E. Marlette of Buffalo and the late Mr. Marlette. The couple plan to marry in April.

LEAD: Did George Washington really chop down a cherry tree? Did Colin Kelly really dive his plane into a Japanese warship? What's the difference? Ruth's called shot, too, is part of American lore. JIM KENSIL Massapequa, L.I.

LEAD: William Bennett and Allan Bloom, the dynamic duo of the new cultural right, have become the easy targets of the cultural left, which I am defining here loosely and generously as that uneasy, shifting set of alliances formed by feminist critics, critics of so-called minority culture and Marxist and post-structuralist critics generally - in short, the rainbow coalition of contemporary critical theory.

LEAD: Few American religious leaders have made their voices heard in the controversy over Salman Rushdie's book ''The Satanic Verses,'' although the debate has raised important issues of religious sensitivity, freedom of conscience and the power of religious authority.

LEAD: IT may be the most basic purpose of government, but a state's protection of citizens from one another is required by the Constitution in only a few circumstances. Last week, the Supreme Court decided that shielding a child from abusive parents is not one of them.

LEAD: When David Levinthal was a student at the Yale School of Art in 1972, he bought a package of toy Nazi soldiers over his Christmas vacation and began to photograph them on the floor of his parents' house. He doesn't remember why, except that he had liked playing with soldiers as a boy, and he wanted now to try shooting indoors in a studio.
LEAD: In 1983, only one cable television programming service was profitable: TBS, the Atlanta-based ''superstation'' that doubles as a local broadcaster.

LEAD: Because of the changes brought by tax revision, the home equity loan has been one of the hottest banking products for the last couple of years. Now, new changes in Federal law are likely to reshape the market for these loans. While many of the changes are designed to bolster legal protections for borrowers, they are also likely to make the loans less readily available and more costly, banking experts say.
LEAD: Napoleon and Josephine were unable to attend, but that didn't stop the France Danse benefit at Lincoln Center from being a sparkling tribute to the French Revolution in its bicentennial year.

LEAD: MENTION the industrial area of West Germany around Dusseldorf, and most travelers will assume you're going to get your work done as quickly as possible and then head out. The local landscape consists mostly of smokestacks and factories linked by a maze of autobahns.
LEAD: In the first such measures since the Lebanese civil war broke out nearly 14 years ago, the authorities in Christian and Muslim areas are moving to close ports operated by private militias.
LEAD: The Gold Cup Automobile Company is China's pride: a behemoth corporation that embodies China's hopes of transforming its state-owned factories into efficient, market-oriented enterprises.

LEAD: AS hungry bison leave the sanctuary of Yellowstone National Park to be slaughtered by hunters in the largest buffalo kill of the century, conservationists are left once again to contemplate the difficulties of maintaining wildlife in a landscape that is, for the most part, no longer wild.
LEAD: HANGING like smoke above the debacle of John G. Tower's nomination to be Secretary of Defense is one central question: Who's really in charge here?

LEAD: In a case that promises to provide a window into the abuses of big-time sports in higher education, two sports agents go on trial Wednesday in United States District Court in Chicago. They are accused of inducing college athletes to sign professional contracts in violation of National Collegiate Athletic Association rules, and of threatening harm to some athletes who wanted out of the deals.

LEAD: WHILE Salvadoran political leaders and guerrilla commanders were discussing a rebel peace proposal in Mexico last week, there was a sharp surge in the violence that has once again come to characterize the civil war here. It demonstrated anew that El Salvador has turned on its head Clausewitz's dictum that war is a continuation of politics by other means.

LEAD: The cost of money rose last week when the Federal Reserve increased its discount rate to 7 percent, from 6.5 percent, and banks lifted prime lending rates by a half point, to 11.5 percent. The Fed, which has been nudging short-term rates upward for some time, said it took the action ''in light of inflationary pressures.

LEAD: WITH the economy, when things are too good for too long they can turn bad quickly. Inflation creeps up, then starts to gallop. Fears of recession loom.

LEAD: Before the first crocus or daffodil even blooms, city dwellers show their colors in casual clothes based on down-to-earth comfort. LEAD: ''Italian art in the 20th Century'' is the subject (through April 9) of a monumental exhibition at the Royal Academy of Arts in London. Every inch of the Academy's stately spaces is filled. Even the doorways have been redesigned in a handsome, if slightly authoritarian, manner. The Academy's exemplary retail outlet for art books and artists' materials has been mated with an Italianate cornucopia in which Italian herbs, Italian cookies and Italian olive oil all have their place.

LEAD: IN 1981, ON THE LAST day of my freshman year in college, I was raped in a park near my dorm. In this country, nearly three out of every four women could be the victim of a violent crime during their lifetime. What is unusual in my case is that the rapist is now serving a maximum sentence of 25 years in prison.

LEAD: IT is a cruel and sardonic god, the Mayan rain diety Chaac, who rules over the Yucatan Peninsula of Mexico. Five months ago he unleashed his fury in the form of Hurricane Gilbert, wreaking devastation on the glorious white beaches, coral reefs and hotels and restaurants that have long lured visitors to the resorts of Cancun and the nearby island of Cozumel.

LEAD: After finishing second for four successive seasons, Pete Rose would like to finish first this year. But after his team finishes first, he has another desire. If he fulfills that one, it would result in a meeting of the managers of the two largest contingents of Reds in the Westen Hemisphere.

LEAD: A quarter of a century has passed since the 15-year-old Pinchas Zukerman made his debut at Town Hall. Since then, he has worn many hats, as viola soloist, chamber player and conductor. At 29, when he joined the St. Paul Chamber Orchestra as music director and brought the ensemble to national attention, his career as a conductor seemed to have unstoppable momentum.

The article focuses on a shopping center-based, walk-in medical testing unit which produces cholesterol test results in 10 minutes. This is based on newer medical technology advances well known to those of us in the clinical laboratory profession.

LEAD: TRAVEL newsletters are a growth business, not surprising considering that the tourism industry, now the No. 3 industry in the country (after food and autos), is predicted by the Commerce Department to be in first place by the turn of the century. Add to that the reality that a home computer enables almost anyone who can type a letter to be a publisher, and you have a decade in which newsletters have popped up with regularity, although they have often dropped off within months.

LEAD: WHEN a doorbell malfunctions, the problem is usually easy to diagnose and correct. Most systems consist of only three main parts and the wiring that links them. Here is how an ordinary doorbell works: At one or more doors, pushbuttons are attached. Each of these has a pair of thin wires connected to them.

LEAD: FOR the 60 women who comprise the Green Fingers Garden Club in Greenwich, gardening means more than growing the perfect tulip or putting together the loveliest flower arrangement. It also means taking responsibility for the environment and trying to get others to do the same.

LEAD: In the aftermath of the 1973 oil embargo, the Federal Energy Administration published its Project Independence report. Energy self-sufficiency for the United States was ruled out as an impractical goal. Instead, the report adopted the more modest objective of reducing our vulnerability to oil import disruptions.

LEAD: Salman Rushdie can see no end to the terror called up by the Ayatollah Khomeini. For the rest of us in the Western world, there is an answer to intolerance and fanaticism. That is to understand our own values, and accept the responsibility of defending them.

LEAD: When Deion Sanders, the Yankees' rookie outfielder and an all-America defensive back from Florida State, took part in his second day of workouts at Fort Lauderdale Stadium yesterday, he did not get through the morning without a change of uniforms and uniform numbers.

LEAD: What kind of bounty hunter travels by train, pickup truck and Jeep? One who finds himself, on the flimsiest pretext, in a road movie. In MIDNIGHT RUN, just out on video (MCA Home Video, $89.95), Robert De Niro is the wisecracking, softhearted bounty hunter, and Charles Grodin the meek but wily white-collar criminal he captures.

LEAD: ''For more than a century, Americans enjoyed unchallenged superiority in virtually everything we turned our hands to. We could afford the luxury of ignoring the seers and experts who urged us to learn the tongues and ways of other lands. But those days have gone the way of leaded gas and the nickel phone call.

LEAD: Long Island residents, angry over property tax increases of almost 20 percent in most communities this year, are organizing grass-roots campaigns to roll back assessments and cut government spending.

LEAD: THE REAL ISSUE FOR THE FUTURE OF THE Soviet Union is not whether Gorbachev will last or even whether he will succeed or fail in his attempts to revitalize the Soviet economy and state. The real issue is whether Soviet Communism is evolving into a significantly more permissive and innovative system or whether it is decaying or even fragmenting.

LEAD: Surely no building type is as disdainful of urban values as the convention center. Everything about a convention center flies in the face of what cities ought to be. To make a good one, you need vast amounts of horizontal space, far more than can fit on a single city block. So most convention centers end up stretching on for block after block, riding roughshod over any streets that are unlucky enough to fall in their path.

LEAD: The long lines of undocumented aliens applying for political asylum at an immigration office on the border in south Texas attest to the reverberating effect of United States policies in Central America. So many Central American aliens have applied for asylum in recent months that immigration officials have finally felt compelled to devise a get-tough policy to deter other migrants, trying to escape poverty, not persecution.

LEAD: An article last Sunday about funds to study and clean Long Island Sound misstated Gov. William A. O'Neill's proposal for the state's Clean Water Fund for the next fiscal year. Mr. O'Neill recommended an appropriation of $75 million, not an elimination of $40 million.

LEAD: The first thing you notice in Lee Currlin's office at NBC's New York headquarters is the huge magnetic board that overwhelms one corner of the room. Thin colored strips with the titles of television shows are stuck to it alongside numbers signifying different time slots. At the far left side of the big board are clusters of strips in jagged disarray, as if they are captured pieces in a chess game.

LEAD: Picking up its review of obscenity regulations where it left off last week, the Supreme Court agreed today to decide the constitutionality of a Dallas law barring those convicted of certain offenses from operating sexually oriented bookstores and movie theaters.

LEAD: Morton Thiokol Inc., the maker of the booster rocket whose failure set off the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger three years ago, said today that it would spin off its commercial operations from its troubled aerospace unit.

LEAD: Joe Silver, an actor who appeared on and Off Broadway, in films and in more than 1,000 television programs, died of a heart attack yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital in Manhattan. Mr. Silver, who had been suffering from liver cancer, was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: Q. There seem to be no pigeons in the countryside, only in cities. Why? A. Pigeons, or rock doves, are actually fairly common in agricultural areas. LEAD: An Israeli policeman was stabbed by a Palestinian teen-ager today during a patrol in the West Bank, the army said. It was the third attack on an Israeli in 10 days. Also today, a group called the Palestinian Arab Army said it had seized a soldier who has been missing for 12 days.

LEAD: A RESIDENT of a Chicago suburb died two weeks ago from a rare African viral disease that he caught after flying to the funerals of his parents in Nigeria. It was the first case of Lassa fever in the United States in more than a decade and only the third since the dramatic discovery of the deadly virus that causes it in 1969.

LEAD: ''The AIDS Quarterly'' is public television's effort to keep the attention of a fickle public on the personal costs and social consquences of Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome. The first of this year's four programs, on Channel 13 at 10 o'clock tonight, sets about the job by looking at the pandemic through the eyes of Adm.

LEAD: Former Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro of Queens, the Democratic Vice-Presidential candidate in 1984, is in Washington today as president of the recently established International Institute for Women's Political Leadership.

LEAD: THE Federal Government has a large supply of the perishable gas tritium that it cannot use because it decided years ago not to build a separation plant to extract it. The amount, worth $56 million, is enough to replenish thousands of nuclear weapons now that traditional supplies of the vital weapons fuel are growing scarce.

LEAD: New York State's trade and business schools are taking in more than half a billion dollars a year in Federal and state aid and loans, but are doing such a poor job that only 22 percent of the students find work in the fields in which they are trained, a study that is being released today asserts.

LEAD: In what otherwise has been a season of uncertainties, at least two preseason expectations have held up in the Big East. Dana Barros of Boston College has scored a lot of points, and St. John's has suffered through the maturing process of its young but talented players.

LEAD: Spring football practice at Notre Dame will begin March 15, and the 17th is the date of the annual dinner for the squad that won the national championship.
